text: This post is also available in:      日本語 (Japanese)  CTB-Locker is a well-known ransomware Trojan used by crimeware groups to encrypt files on the victim's endpoints and demand ransom payment to decrypt the files back to their original state, but most antiviruses detect it by mistake as CryptoLocker (only one vendor correctly detects it as CTB-Locker).
label: malware

text: The attack vector is very basic and repeats itself: It begins with a spear phishing email sent with SCR attachments (double zipped).
label: attack-pattern

text: Once executed by the user the first stage malware downloads and executes the ransomware from a fixed hardcoded server list.
label: safe

text: The first known campaign was launched by Crimeware on November 2014.
label: TIME

text: The first stage downloaded the ransomware from these sites:
label: safe

text: A very serious campaign was launched between January 19, 2015 and January 20, 2015, and  Palo Alto Networks Enterprise Security Platform has discovered more than 1000 unique attacks since.
label: identity

text: The attacker used a polymorphic malware builder to generate malware with a unique hash for each victim, preventing signature-based solutions from detecting the new attacks before it was too late for the victim.
label: safe

text: This tactic is a nightmare for legacy security products that are based on legacy techniques such as bytes signatures, since they can only detect attacks after the damage is done instead of preventing it as a true solution should.
label: safe

text: Palo Alto Networks Enterprise Security Platform offers multilayer protection to prevent this attack along with other attacks without the need for prior knowledge of the specific attack.
label: identity

text: We can see here that server hostnames were changed but they didn’t change the server IP address – see the attached file with results for files from last week’s campaign from VirusTotal.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Most legacy security programs could not detect this malware at the time it was posted.
label: safe

text: If you re-test these hashes again from last week you can see an average of 49/57 engines that detect last week’s threat – but that’s too little, too late for anyone who already lost data.
label: safe

text: This campaign started earlier today, and the malware uses the same techniques and even the same IOCs:  And only added two new hostnames:
label: TIME

text: By now you shouldn’t be surprised that one of them is on the same known malicious IP address.
label: safe

text: We found 147 new unique pieces of malware today alone, two of them fully undetectable by the legacy security solutions in VirusTotal and most of them barely detected by one vendor (few have 4/57 detection rate).
label: SOFTWARE

text: See below:
label: safe

text: So basically you have two choices:
label: safe

text: The most surprising fact about this campaign is that almost all the IOCs haven’t been changed:  For those still using legacy solutions we’ve attached two lists of SHA256 hashes in a text file format for reference.
label: safe

text: One list shows the new campaign, which continues to progress.
label: safe

text: The other list is of last week’s campaign by the same attackers (exhaustive or close to it).  Palo Alto Networks Enterprise Security Platform would have stopped this ransomware attack campaign thanks to the platform’s unique integration between the network, endpoint and the cloud to maximize security.
label: identity

text: Attacks aren't getting any less sophisticated, so it is time to leave legacy security solutions behind and upgrade to real, prevention-based security.
label: safe

text: This post is also available in:      日本語 (Japanese)  Over the past six months, we’ve seen a major increase in the number of attack campaigns with the ultimate goal of mining cryptocurrency.
label: safe

text: It’s a subject Unit 42 has been tracking in the past year:
label: identity

text: So, what is driving a widespread shift from attackers and creating a significant trend in the industry?
label: safe

text: There are three factors at work:
label: safe

text: To answer the question in more detail, it’s important to put yourself into the criminal’s shoes and consider what alternative routes they have to monetize infections.
label: safe

text: In this brief, we’ll share how this trend came to fruition, why it’s so prevalent, and how security professionals and defenders can keep an eye out for this rising type of threat.
label: safe

text: How Attacks Monetize Infections
label: safe

text: While targeted attacks gain the most attention from researchers and media, the majority of malware infections are untargeted and even indiscriminate.
label: safe

text: Instead of seeking out specific targets, many criminals aim to infect as many systems as possible and then turn those infections into cash.
label: safe

text: This has been true for over a decade, although the mechanisms available to criminals have shifted in that time.
label: safe

text: To understand where we are now, it helps to look at how we got here, and to look at the evolution of common cybercriminal activities.
label: safe

text: Back in the early 2000s, some of the earliest “botnet herders” made their income by relaying spam emails through infected computers.
label: attack-pattern

text: Over time, that business became less profitable due to anti-spam controls and ISPs preventing infected systems from directly relaying emails.
label: safe

text: In the mid-2000s, criminals made great profits from using Banking Trojans to steal credentials for online banking websites, and subsequently draining the accounts’ associated funds.
label: TIME

text: This account takeover activity continues today, but various anti-fraud measures and law enforcement actions have made it less profitable and riskier for criminals.
label: safe

text: Another aspect of Banking Trojan infections is that, while the criminal may be infecting hosts indiscriminately, the value of the host greatly depends on the individual who owns it, and the criminals’ ability to “cash out” their bank account.
label: safe

text: Figure 1 is a capture from a book I wrote with some colleagues in 2008, “Cyber Fraud: Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures.”
label: TIME

text: It shows the price that a criminal enterprise called IFRAME DOLLARS was charging to infect computers in various countries at that time.
label: threat-actor

text: Figure 1: Capture from Cyber Fraud: Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures showing prices of host infections by country.
label: safe

text: In 2007, the infection of a system in Australia went for US$0.60, while an infection in Poland was only a fraction of the cost, at US$0.096.
label: location

text: The difference in price represented the difference in value: criminals were able to make more money through a Banking Trojan account takeover from an Australian infection than they could in Poland.
label: malware

text: As anti-fraud protections evolved, so did the criminals.
label: safe

text: Fast forward five years to 2013 and the rise of the Ransomware business model
label: TIME

text: This new way to generate profit had two major advantages over account takeovers:
label: safe

text: Put another way, the ransomware model represented both increased efficiency and decreased risk in monetizing the infection.
label: safe

text: Anyone who’s been paying attention to cybercrime since 2013 is aware of the ransomware surge, infecting systems throughout the world and plaguing networks’ administrators.
label: TIME

text: While only a tiny fraction (possibly 1 in 1000) of systems infected with a banking Trojan pay out for attackers, a much higher portion of ransomware victims pay to get their files back.
label: safe

text: While US$300 payments are less than a single account takeover could return, ransomware makes greater returns due to the volume and decreased risk in this new business model.
label: safe

text: Cybercriminals have become good business people: they saw the benefits and embraced the change.
label: safe

text: Enter “The Bubble” – Where We Are Now
label: safe

text: In the last two years, but particularly in the last six months, the price of bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies experienced a massive price surge with respect to the U.S. dollar and other fiat currencies.
label: safe

text: Here’s the chart for bitcoin over the last two years, showing a rise of 2,000% to 4,000% in the versus the U.S. dollar.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Figure 2: Price of bitcoin in U.S. dollars from CoinMarketCap  While botnets mining cryptocurrency is nothing new, the technique was much less profitable than using ransomware.
label: SOFTWARE

text: In fact, with the rise of specialized bitcoin mining hardware, no regular PC can make any significant amount of money for an attacker.
label: safe

text: However, there are many other “crypto coins” in the market today.
label: safe

text: The one we see mined most by attackers is called Monero.
label: SOFTWARE

text: In contrast to bitcoin, Monero was designed to enable private transactions using a closed ledger, and its mining algorithm is still mined effectively by both PC CPUs and GPUs.
label: SOFTWARE

text: As the chart below shows, Monero has risen even faster than bitcoin in price in the last two years, with more than a 30,000% gain in U.S. dollars.
label: TIME

text: Figure 3: Price of Monero in U.S. dollars from CoinMarketCap
label: SOFTWARE

text: A normal PC used to mine Monero can earn around US$0.25 per day at the current prices.
label: SOFTWARE

text: That number is small, but it’s important to note that it doesn’t matter what country or network a Monero miner is part of: computers in Australia and Poland mine at the same speed.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Every infected system is a profit-generating resource when mining Monero, and users are much less likely to identify their infection and remove the mining program than they would be with ransomware.
label: SOFTWARE

text: For context, in January, we found a Monero mining campaign that infected around 15 million systems, largely in the developing world.
label: SOFTWARE

text: If these systems remained infected for at least 24 hours each, the attackers could have earned well over 3 million U.S. dollars in Monero.
label: TIME

text: Additionally, the risk of arrest and conviction is significantly lower than with ransomware, as mining cryptocurrency is less likely to generate reports to law enforcement than a data-destroying ransomware infection.
label: safe

text: What’s Next?
label: safe

text: This wave of attacks will continue as long as it maintains a high level of profitability with a low level of risk for cybercriminals.
label: safe

text: For defenders, it’s important to note that the techniques used to infect systems with coin mining malware are the same as they were for ransomware.
label: safe

text: Infections typically begin with emails carrying malicious macro documents, drive-by exploit kits targeting browsers, or direct attacks on servers running vulnerable software.
label: safe

text: There is no single solution to stopping these attacks, but the same technologies and policies you use to prevent other malware infections will be effective.
label: attack-pattern

text: Across the changing landscape of botnet herders, Banking Trojans, ransomware and coin mining is one constant: the business-savvy drive to maximize profit and reduce risk.
label: safe

text: Using these as our guide, we can make sense of where we are today, how we got here, and be prepared for what has yet to develop in the future.
label: safe

text: Here are three things to watch for:
label: safe

text: 1. A marked increase in the price of Monero or other cryptocurrencies will draw even more attackers into this business.
label: SOFTWARE

text: For many users, this could actually be a positive development, as the negative impact of having resources sapped from one’s computer is much less than paying a ransom or restoring your system from a backup due to ransomware.
label: safe

text: Conversely, a crash in the price of cryptocurrencies will decrease the profitability and drive criminals back to ransomware.
label: safe

text: 2. Listen to your fans or keep an eye on your CPU usage.
label: safe

text: Many users realize their system is infected with coin mining malware when their laptop fans kick into high-speed mode to keep the overtaxed CPU cool.
label: safe

text: Listening to fans won’t work at the enterprise scale, but implementing widespread CPU performance monitoring could be a good way to find compromised devices.
label: safe

text: This will also help you identify the coin mining “insider threat,” as misguided administrators may see their organizations’ unused CPU time as a way to generate personal income.
label: safe

text: 3. Criminals will find ways to target these attacks.
label: safe

text: Compromising a user’s browser or a regular home PC will net the criminal an average system for mining coins, but higher-end systems will generate more income.
label: attack-pattern

text: Attackers will soon begin targeting devices with higher specifications to get more bang for their buck.
label: safe

text: Gaming PCs with high-end GPUs and servers with large numbers of processing cores will be prime targets.
label: safe

text: Please mark, I'm not a robot!  By submitting this form, you agree to our Terms of Use and acknowledge our Privacy Statement.
label: safe

text: It’s that time of year again – our researchers have analyzed and reviewed the threats and attacks that occurred during the first half of 2021.
label: TIME

text: Our report, Attacks From All Angles: 2021 Midyear Security Roundup, highlights many of the active attacks we saw, from APTs to ransomware to zero-day exploits.
label: TIME

text: I’d like to highlight an area where we are seeing increased activity: attacks against cloud infrastructures.
label: safe

text: I’ve spoken on this at a few events and asked my audiences how many have active cloud infrastructure projects going on, the answer is always most of them.
label: safe

text: In our 1H’ 2021 Cyber Risk Index, we asked organizations what their top infrastructure risks are.
label: identity

text: Cloud security has been in the top two for the last few years.
label: safe

text: Obviously, many organizations are moving quickly to the cloud and, as such, need to be thinking about how to secure it.
label: safe

text: Below is an overview of what we’re seeing in cloud attacks.
label: safe

text: Threats Impacting Cloud Environments
label: safe

text: In our first half report, we highlight an APT group named TeamTNT that has been targeting clouds for quite a while now.
label: threat-actor

text: They have focused most of their efforts on planting crypto-mining malware on cloud servers in an effort to mine Monero coins, but we have also seen them utilize DDoS IRC bots, steal cloud account credentials, and exfil data.
label: SOFTWARE

text: As you can see from the above diagram, all of these are end goals for most attacks.
label: safe

text: Speaking of data exfil, in the first half we saw APT actors utilize cloud-based file storage to exfiltrate their stolen data.
label: safe

text: For example, we found that Conti operators use the cloud storage synchronization tool Rclone to upload files to the Mega cloud storage service.
label: malware

text: Similarly, DarkSide operators used Mega client for exfiltrating files to cloud storage, 7-Zip for archiving, and PuTTY application for network file transfers.
label: threat-actor

text: This use of known, legitimate tools is not new; we call that “living off the land” and have seen this tactic pick up recently, including usage by ransomware actors.
label: tools

text: Many organizations now need to look at ways of monitoring legitimate tools usage within their networks to identify any malicious uses.
label: safe

text: Cloud Security Architecture
label: safe

text: When developing your cloud security architecture and strategy, it is important to always keep the ends in mind.
label: safe

text: In this case, what are the motivation and end goals of an attacker?
label: safe

text: As you see in the image above, most cloud attacks are going to fall into one of these areas.
label: safe

text: Depending on what you are doing as part of your cloud infrastructure, you should be able to identify if any or all of these end goals could be targeted in your environment.
label: safe

text: From there, you can work backwards to develop your strategy for protecting those initial access areas tied to the different attacks.
label: safe

text: A challenge many organizations face is that the cloud isn’t simple, and many of the technologies that make up the cloud are new, with new features being deployed all the time.
label: safe

text: Understanding how these work and – more importantly – how to secure them can be very difficult.
label: safe

text: Utilizing a security platform approach can help build your cloud to be more secure, but educating your architects and administrators will also help.
label: safe

text: One key area is hardening your cloud account credentials, as these will be regularly targeted by malicious actors.
label: safe

text: Using multi-factor authentication to access all accounts can minimize this risk tremendously.
label: safe

text: Take a look at Trend Micro Cloud One, part of our complete cybersecurity platform, to learn more.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The cloud is only one aspect of our full 1H 2021 report.
label: TIME

text: To get more details on all the different threats and attacks we observed, download and read the full report here.
label: safe

text: Tags  Cloud | Cyber Crime | Expert Perspective | Cyber Threats | APT & Targeted Attacks | Network | Articles, News, Reports
label: safe

text: Cybercriminals have embraced the anonymous nature of cryptocurrency as a new preferred method of profit.
label: safe

text: Unit 42 released details about attackers hijacking web browsers to mine for compute resources and exchange for cryptocurrency.
label: identity

text: With the increasing value of cryptocurrency, such as bitcoin and Ethereum, and a better business model with higher returns than malware- and exploit-type attacks, it’s no surprise these types of attacks are becoming more commonplace.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Cybercriminals will compromise a website and abuse a legitimate tool on that site to gain access to the compute resources of site visitors’ systems.
label: attack-pattern

text: Using this access, attackers will essentially steal compute resources and exchange them for cryptocurrency credit.
label: attack-pattern

text: This all occurs without the users’ consent or knowledge throughout the duration of their site visits.
label: safe

text: The malicious activity itself doesn’t cause long-term damage to systems, and ends as soon as users leave the malicious or compromised site.
label: safe

text: Additionally, the site will still provide users with its normal, intended functionality.
label: safe

text: However, users likely experience a noticeable slowdown in system performance.
label: safe

text: If you believe your system is being affected by this type of attack, leaving the site or closing your browser will, in most cases, end the attack.
label: safe

text: Additionally, you should practice good cybersecurity hygiene.
label: safe

text: This means avoiding unfamiliar websites, clicking on links or downloading attachments from unknown email senders, keeping products updated with the latest security patches, enabling multi-factor authentication, and using reputable security products.
label: safe

text: Sign up to receive the latest news, cyber threat intelligence and research from us  Please enter your email address!  Please mark, I'm not a robot!
label: safe

label: safe

text: In our updated report on ransomware from Unit 42, “Ransomware: Unlocking the Lucrative Criminal Business Model,” Unit 42 researcher Bryan Lee notes: “In 2016, it was thought that there were less than one hundred active ransomware variants out in the wild.
label: identity

text: Today, the number of total ransomware variants at least over 150, if not hundreds more.”  It’s reasonable to ask why ransomware continues not only to exist but to thrive.
label: safe

text: The first answer to this, as we’ve outlined in our report, is that ransomware is a lucrative cybercriminal business model.
label: safe

text: However, in addition to the human factor, there are technical reasons.
label: safe

text: Specifically, there are three things that combine to make ransomware a particularly potent threat on the technical level:
label: safe

text: In some ways, these three points state the obvious.
label: safe

text: But the full ramifications and why these make ransomware hard to stop aren’t always discussed.
label: safe

text: The way ransomware works is well documented, but let’s recap here.
label: safe

text: Ransomware is downloaded to a user’s system and executed on it.
label: safe

text: The way the attackers get the ransomware on the system varies: it can be through unpatched vulnerabilities, social engineering or both.
label: safe

text: The most common way ransomware operators levy attacks is through email or by web browsing to malicious or compromised sites.
label: attack-pattern

text: The overwhelming majority of ransomware attacks are against Microsoft Windows systems.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Once malware is running on the user’s system, it seeks out and encrypts files and folders that hold information critical for the user, such as documents, business applications or even database files.
label: safe

text: In some cases, the ransomware is sophisticated enough to target specific application files.
label: safe

text: Most importantly, because the ransomware is executing with the compromised user’s privileges, any file the legitimate, now-compromised user has access to, including network shares and backups, is fair game for the ransomware.
label: attack-pattern

text: It’s this last point that gets to the heart of why ransomware is so potent.
label: safe

text: From an operating system point of view, the ransomware IS the user.
label: safe

text: Even though Microsoft Windows today features a robust user access control system, that system has inherent limitations.
label: SOFTWARE

text: In the early days of Window Vista, Microsoft enabled aggressive security checking to ensure user-initiated actions were legitimate.
label: SOFTWARE

text: This was well-intentioned but ultimately backfired: users got fed up clicking “Are you sure?” dialog boxes and quickly disabled the feature, or just mindlessly clicked “OK” every time they saw it.
label: safe

text: Microsoft made reasonable adjustments so that these alerts are now raised sparingly.
label: identity

text: Although that feature was never enabled to protect user data files like ransomware targets, there is a clear lesson from the experience: too many security checks on user activity fails in the end.
label: safe

text: Bringing that lesson to bear here, the only way the operating system could protect against ransomware would be to raise “Are you sure?” dialog boxes on everyday operations against the kinds of files that ransomware targets.
label: safe

text: And this is where the second point comes to bear.
label: safe

text: Unlike other forms of malware, ransomware is very specific in its targeting.
label: safe

text: It goes after the files users are most likely to care about.
label: safe

text: These also happen to be files users are most likely to use on a day-to-day basis or that are critical to an organization’s operations.
label: safe

text: Extra layers of protection for those files would be incredibly onerous.
label: safe

text: Imagine having to click through “Are you sure?” dialog boxes for every document or picture you opened in a day.
label: safe

text: From an engineering point of view, this sole, specific targeting of files that matter significantly increases the chances of ransomware’s success.
label: safe

text: This brings us to the third point: there is little attack time wasted on files that don’t matter to the victim.
label: safe

text: Even a successful ransomware attack that is halted early by security software will achieve some level of damage – enough to make the victim consider paying the ransom to get the files back.
label: safe

text: If user32.dll were encrypted and unusable, it would be a problem.
label: FILEPATH

text: But when your organization’s overall accounting and audit report is inaccessible right before the big deadline, that’s catastrophic.
label: safe

text: The net of these three points is that ransomware is a threat such that focus needs to be placed solely around prevention.
label: safe

text: There is no effective solution for ransomware at the operating system level, as outlined above.
label: safe

text: And unlike other attacks, ransomware attacks can’t succeed “just a little.”
label: safe

text: In some cases, a single file lost is more than enough to count as a fully successful attack.
label: safe

text: In some ways, ransomware is a threat unlike any other.
label: safe

text: Its impact and scope are both broad and deep in ways that are unique.
label: safe

text: Because of that, from a risk assessment point of view, ransomware needs to be put in a class by itself – a class that acknowledges that the risks from a successful attack of any kind are very high.
label: safe

text: Over the past several weeks, Russia-Ukraine cyber activity has escalated substantially.
label: safe

text: Beginning on Feb. 15, a series of distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks commenced.
label: TIME

text: These attacks have continued over the past week, impacting both the Ukrainian government and banking institutions.
label: identity

text: On Feb. 23, a new variant of wiper malware named HermeticWiper was discovered in Ukraine.
label: malware

text: Shortly after, a new round of website defacement attacks were also observed impacting Ukrainian government organizations.
label: identity

text: Consistent with our previous reporting on the topic, several western governments have issued recommendations for their populations to prepare for cyberattacks that could disrupt, disable or destroy critical infrastructure.
label: identity

text: We have already observed an increase in Russian cyber activity, which we reported on in our initial Threat Brief published last month and our recent report on the Gamaredon group.
label: threat-actor

text: Future attacks may target U.S. and Western European organizations in retaliation for increased sanctions or other political measures against the Russian government.
label: location

text: We recommend that all organizations proactively prepare to defend against this potential threat.
label: safe

text: This post was substantially updated on Feb. 24 to add information on the recent DDoS attacks, HermeticWiper malware and website defacement; update our recommendations for how organizations should prepare for potential cyber impact; and provide additional details for our customers and clients on how we can help.
label: TIME

text: This post was substantially updated March 31 to add information on phishing and scam attacks, cybersquatting trends, fake donation websites, DoS attacks on Ukrainian news sites and distribution of malicious binaries.
label: attack-pattern

text: Full visualization of the techniques observed, relevant courses of action and indicators of compromise (IoCs) related to this report can be found in the Unit 42 ATOM viewer.  We will continue to provide updates with new information and recommendations as they become available.
label: SOFTWARE

text: DDoS Attacks Impacting Ukrainian Government and Banking Institutions HermeticWiper Malware Website Defacement Rise in Phishing and Scam Attacks Increase in Cybersquatting Trends Fake Donation Websites DoS Attacks on Ukrainian News Sites Distribution of Apps How Palo Alto Networks Is Working to Keep You Safe How You Should Prepare for an Increase in Cyberthreats Such as Wipers, DDoS, Website Defacement and Other Related Attacks How Unit 42 Threat Intelligence and Security Consulting Can Help Additional Cybersecurity Resources Indicators of Compromise
label: attack-pattern

text: Appendix A: Cortex Xpanse: Identifying Assets That May Be Impacted by CISA’s Known Exploited Vulnerabilities
label: SOFTWARE

text: On Feb. 15, the Cyberpolice of Ukraine reported that residents were actively receiving fake SMS text messages.
label: TIME

text: These messages were likely intended to cause alarm among the population, as they claimed that ATMs were malfunctioning.
label: safe

text: Shortly after the text messages were observed, several DDoS attacks occurred.
label: attack-pattern

text: These attacks impacted Ukrainian government organizations including the Ministry of Defense, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Armed Forces of Ukraine and the publicly funded broadcaster Ukrainian Radio.
label: identity

text: Additionally, the attacks targeted two banking institutions, PrivatBank and Oschadbank.
label: identity

text: An initial investigation into the DDoS attacks suggested that Mirai and Meris bot networks may have been leveraged in the attacks.
label: malware

text: On Feb. 18, both the United States and the United Kingdom attributed these DDoS attacks to Russia’s Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU).  Over the past week, Ukraine has continued to observe a relatively constant flow of DDoS attacks targeting its government and financial institutions.
label: identity

text: However, at this time, attribution for the ongoing attacks has not been established.
label: safe

text: The Ukrainian CERT did identify a post on RaidForums from a user named “Carzita” that suggested that additional actors may also be launching DDoS and defacement attacks for undisclosed reasons.
label: identity

text: On Feb. 23, a malicious file named conhosts._exe (SHA256: 1bc44eef75779e3ca1eefb8ff5a64807dbc942b1e4a2672d77b9f6928d292591) was uploaded to a public malware repository from an organization in Kyiv, Ukraine.
label: SHA2

text: This executable is a signed file with a valid signature from an organization named Hermetica Digital Ltd. This signing certificate has since been explicitly revoked by its issuer.
label: identity

text: Upon execution, this file enumerates all files on a hard drive, wipes the partition info and then forces a system reboot, which predictably results in the following screen:
label: safe

text: Further analysis has confirmed that the malware accepts command-line arguments allowing an attacker to instruct the malware to sleep for a period of time or to shut down the system.
label: safe

text: Additionally the kernel module responsible for the actual wiping activity is from a legitimate application called EaseUS Partition Master.
label: tools

text: This software is designed as free partition software that can reorganize disk space for better performance.
label: safe

text: In tracking this threat, early reports show that the malware has been deployed against a financial institution in Ukraine as well as two contractors in Latvia and Lithuania that provide services to the Ukrainian Government.
label: location

text: Additionally, ESET researchers have warned that they found this malware installed across “hundreds of machines” in Ukraine.
label: identity

text: Concurrent with the discovery of wiper malware, we also witnessed a second round of website defacements on Feb. 23.
label: TIME

text: These attacks appear to have copied the messaging template observed in attacks exploiting the OctoberCMS vulnerability a month earlier on Jan.14, while adding a .onion web address and a message in red font that translates to, “Do you need proof, see the link at the end.”
label: vulnerability

text: The .onion site links to an entity calling themselves “Free Civilian” and offering to sell databases containing the personal data of Ukrainian citizens.
label: safe

text: Over the past 24 hours, the list of entities on the leaks section has expanded to 48 gov.ua domains and one Ukranian company (motorsich[.]com) that builds engines for airplanes and helicopters.
label: TIME

text: Our team analyzed the larger trends regarding Ukraine-related phishing and scam URLs detected by Advanced URL Filtering.
label: attack-pattern

text: We noticed an overall increase in the detection of websites that host phishing and scam URLs on domains using Ukraine-related TLDs such as gov.ua and com.ua, or containing popular Ukraine-related keywords such as "ukraine" and "ukrainian".
label: attack-pattern

text: This trend correlates with an increase in Google searches for terms like "Ukraine aid."
label: SOFTWARE

text: From January to late February, it appears that the number of Ukraine-related phishing and scam sites largely followed a similar trend as Ukraine-related internet searches; however, the number of phishing and scam sites has continued to rise through mid-late March as the situation remains ongoing.
label: attack-pattern

text: Figure 8 shows that the number of Ukraine-related phishing/scam sites is currently continuing to rise about a month after the “Ukraine aid” search term started trending in Google search.
label: attack-pattern

text: Among these phishing and scam URLs, we found a targeted phishing attack.
label: attack-pattern

text: On March 16 while ingesting a third-party data feed, our in-house machine learning models detected a phishing webpage targeting a Ukrainian state administration employee.
label: attack-pattern

text: The webpage is imitating a popular cloud file storage site.
label: safe

text: Upon visiting the webpage, the “Username” field is pre-
label: safe

text: populated with the targeted employee’s email address, and the user is then prompted to enter in their password in order to view a sensitive document as shown in Figure 9.
label: safe

text: Figure 9. hxxps://startrackzm[.]com/wap-admin/ONE-DRIVE/one%20d%20%20no%20auto.php?Email=REDACTED@REDACTED.gov.ua.
label: URL

text: A phishing webpage targeting a Ukrainian state administration employee, detected by our in-house machine learning models on March 16.Our teams at Palo Alto Networks are actively monitoring the phishing landscape surrounding Ukraine-related URLs and are sharing this threat intelligence with relevant authorities in Ukraine and internationally.
label: attack-pattern

text: We are also sharing a list of IoCs that were detected as phishing and scam URLs.
label: attack-pattern

text: Palo Alto Networks customers who subscribe to Advanced URL Filtering are already protected from these IoCs.
label: identity

text: We monitored a list of 50 legitimate Ukraine-related domains (e.g., popular news and donation websites) and keywords (e.g., Ukraine, refugee) as targets for cybersquatting.
label: location

text: We detected 11,637 cybersquatting newly registered domains (NRDs) during February and March.
label: TIME

text: In particular, we noticed a sharp increase in the number of cybersquatting domains that were registered close to Feb. 24, as shown in Figure 10 below.
label: attack-pattern

text: We manually analyzed a sample set of these cybersquatting domains.
label: attack-pattern

text: Below we share some interesting case studies.
label: safe

text: A detailed analysis of these domains revealed that many of them are fake.
label: safe

text: These donation websites provide little to no information about the associated organization and distribution of funds.
label: safe

text: Many of these websites use cryptocurrency wallets (e.g., BTC, ETH) to accept payment (likely because these wallets are easy to set up and require no verification).  We also find that some websites are mimicking popular donation websites or organizations to trick users into paying them money.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We show some examples in Figure 11.
label: safe

text: For instance, donatetoukraine[.]com is pretending to be associated with the popular Come Back Alive campaign.
label: DOMAIN

text: While the banking information shared on the donation website matches the original campaign website, we confirmed that the BTC wallet address is different from the actual.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We found a cybersquatting domain – save-russia[.]today – that is launching DoS attacks on Ukrainian news sites.
label: attack-pattern

text: Once a user opens the website in the browser, it starts making requests to various Ukrainian news sites and lists the number of requests made to each new site on the home page, as shown in Figure 12 below.
label: identity

text: Figure 12.
label: safe

text: A cybersquatting domain save-russia[.]today is launching DoS attacks on Ukrainian news sites.
label: attack-pattern

text: We strongly recommend that users be alert to the possibility of cybersquatting domains.
label: attack-pattern

text: In particular, fake donation websites mimicking popular websites can be misleading, as described earlier.
label: attack-pattern

text: Before donating money, we recommend checking whether the website is referenced and shared by the official charity or government organization.
label: safe

text: Our teams at Palo Alto Networks will continue monitoring domain squatting attacks and work to protect customers against them.
label: identity

text: We detected campaigns of fake downloads where threat actors have set up web pages to host malicious binaries.
label: attack-pattern

text: Most of these web pages show malicious binaries as popular browsers or communication apps in order to deceive users.
label: safe

text: For example, we detected a website that was distributing a malicious binary by masquerading as a popular global communication app targeting users in Ukraine.
label: attack-pattern

text: Note that Palo Alto Networks customers receive protections against such domains from the Next-Generation Firewall via Advanced URL Filtering, DNS Security and WildFire URL Analysis subscriptions.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We also found that these fake download campaigns rotate domains to distribute the same malicious binaries.
label: attack-pattern

text: For example, we detected two domains distributing the same malicious binary where one domain was impersonating a popular, widely used video conferencing application and the other a widely used internet browser.
label: safe

text: Our teams at Palo Alto Networks will continue to monitor and work to protect our customers against such attacks.
label: identity

text: Consistent with our previous reporting on the situation, Unit 42 continues to lead a company-wide effort to collect, evaluate and disseminate the latest intelligence on cyber activity related to Russia and Ukraine.
label: identity

label: safe

text: These efforts have enabled us to make near-daily updates to our platform to ensure our customers have the best protection possible.
label: safe

text: This includes blocking hundreds of domain names, IP addresses and URLs for our customers related to newly discovered attacks.
label: safe

text: We’ve updated and added signatures to the WildFire analysis and Cortex XDR Prevent and Pro products to block newly discovered vulnerabilities and malware including HermeticWiper.

text: Read more about Cortex XDR protections.

text: As the situation continues to develop, we’ll continue to update our blog with the latest information.

text: There is no single action you can take to protect your organization against this threat.
label: safe

text: Unlike a new malware family or vulnerability in the wild, the attacks we expect could come in many forms.

text: Several western governments have proposed broad recommendations focused on technical hygiene.
label: identity

text: We consider these appropriate given the variety of tactics that Russian actors have used in the past.

text: We recommend organizations prioritize actions in the following four areas:  There is no way to know for certain what shape an attack may take, but taking these steps will help provide broad protection against what we expect to come.

text: In Alert AA22-011A (updated March 1, 2022), the U.S. Department of Homeland Security’s Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (DHS/CISA) identifies a selection of vulnerabilities that Russian advanced persistent threat (APT) groups are assessed to have exploited in the past, but recommends that users take action against a much broader list of known exploited vulnerabilities (KEVs).
label: identity

text: The cited KEVs and their impacted devices – all of which can be identified using Cortex Xpanse – are:   Cortex Xpanse’s ability to index the entire internet helps organizations discover, prioritize, and remediate significant exposures on their attack surfaces – including all of the impacted services listed above.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We routinely observe vulnerable devices across the global internet, despite the fact that most of these CVEs are more than two years old.
label: safe

text: Beyond Alert AA22-011A, CISA’s overarching guidance for attack surface reduction includes hardening of forward-facing network services, with prioritized patching of KEVs, as documented in Binding Operational Directive (BOD) 22-01: Reducing the Significant Risk of Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV).
label: identity

text: This directive requires agencies to remediate all vulnerabilities that CISA includes in their KEV catalog based on an assessment that the vulnerabilities “carry significant risk to the federal enterprise.”
label: identity

text: Updated April 1, 2022, at 11 a.m. PT.
label: TIME

text: Sign up to receive the latest news, cyber threat intelligence and research from us  Please enter your email address!

text: Recent events continue to highlight the abuse of remote access applications in the enterprise.
label: safe

text: Last Tuesday, Trusteer reported that a new variant of Citadel, which has long relied on VNC to give attackers remote control over systems, began adding new credentials to systems it infects and enabling the standard Windows remote desktop application (RDP).
label: malware

text: This allows the attacker to maintain control over the system even after the Citadel infection is removed.
label: malware

text: As the report indicates, using RDP this way also allows the attackers to “fly under the radar” as RDP is commonly used by administrators and often not treated as a threat.
label: tools

text: Later that same week, US-CERT released alert TA14-212A on the Backoff Point of Sale (PoS) malware, which describes how malicious actors used publicly available tools to identify organizations that use remote access applications in an unsafe way.
label: identity

text: This reconnaissance was then leveraged in brute force attacks against credentials, toward unauthorized access, implant installation, and subsequent exfiltration of consumer payment data.
label: attack-pattern

text: As with any tool, remote access applications can be used for good or malicious intent.
label: safe

text: It would be inefficient for an administrator to travel to a physical office to make a change on a system, but its critical that organizations take control over these applications.
label: safe

text: The first step is identifying them in your network.
label: safe

text: Palo Alto Networks currently tracks 90 different remote-access applications in Applipedia.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Examples include Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP), Virtual Network Connection (VNC), TeamViewer, and even Secure Shell (SSH), to name a few.
label: attack-pattern

text: Once you can identify the traffic, you need to separate the good from the bad.
label: safe

text: If your company runs Windows and relies on RDP, you can close off VNC, TeamViewer and the other 87 applications because you don’t need them.
label: SOFTWARE

text: If your administrators and help desk are the only ones who need RDP access to your systems, disable RDP for the rest of your users.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The key is putting a policy in place and making sure your technology is enforcing that policy at the network layer.
label: safe

text: The Backoff and Citadel reports from last week highlight how uncontrolled remote access broadens your attack surface and acts as a backdoor for attackers already in your network.
label: malware

text: Remote-access abuse is not a new problem.
label: attack-pattern

text: We’ve been highlighting the importance of controlling this threat since 2009, but five years later it remains an issue for many organizations.
label: TIME

text: By submitting this form, you agree to our Terms of Use and acknowledge our Privacy Statement.
label: safe

text: The latest development in the ransomware world is CryptoWall 2.0, a new version of this malware family that uses the Tor network for command and control.
label: malware

text: F-Secure was the first to spot this new version on October 1, but since then the attacks have ramped up and new variants of the malware are emerging daily.
label: TIME

text: Our WildFire analysis platform has picked up 84 CryptoWall 2.0 variants since September 30, delivered primarily through e-mail attachments but also through malicious PDFs and web exploit kits.
label: tools

text: CryptoWall 2.0 is similar to other ransomware attacks that have plagued users and businesses for nearly a decade.
label: malware

text: Once it is running on a system, CryptoWall 2.0 seeks out document files and encrypts them using the RSA encryption algorithm.
label: malware

text: The attacker holds the key necessary to decrypt the files unless the victim agrees to pay a $500 ransom.  Unlike previous versions of CryptoWall, 2.0 communicates with its command and control (C2) server through the Tor anonymization network.
label: malware

text: This allows attackers to hide their communications and avoid having their C2 servers shut down, but also makes it easy for organizations to block the threat.
label: safe

text: CryptoWall isn’t the only threat that communicates over Tor and if your network doesn’t have an explicit reason to allow anonymization networks, you should consider blocking the application altogether with your firewall.
label: malware

text: If your system has already been infected with CryptoWall 2.0, you’ll see a pop-up just like this one shortly after the malware has encrypted your documents.
label: malware

text: Note that the attacker has given you a few options for how to pay them the ransom.
label: safe

text: The green box contains four links that will work only for your system.
label: safe

text: These use four domains registered just today:
label: safe

text: All of the domains currently resolve to 151.248.115.146, a Russian IP address and have WhoIs records associated with the e-mail address “ladomfichisi1987@mail.ru”.
label: IPV4

text: This is the same address used to register two other payment domains registered earlier this month:
label: safe

text: If these domains are confiscated or otherwise shut down, CryptoWall instructs the user to download the Tor Browser and access a website (paytordmbdekmizq.onion) that is only accessible over the Tor network.  Unlikely some of it’s more flexible competition, CryptoWall only accepts ransom in the form of BitCoin.
label: malware

text: To pay the ransom the user will need to acquire 1.33 BitCoins and transfer them to a specific BitCoin wallet that is associated with their specific infection.
label: SOFTWARE

text: History has shown that paying the ransom will likely allow you to retrieve your files, but the best defense against ransomware is having up-to-date back-ups or by preventing the infection all-together.
label: safe

text: Since we detected the first CryptoWall 2.0 variant with our WildFire engine on September 29, we’ve seen over 85,000 separate attacks attempting to deliver the malware.
label: malware

text: The majority of these have come through e-mails with executable attachments, sometimes contained in .zip files.
label: safe

text: Most of the e-mail attacks used fake invoice, fax and voicemail themes with attachments named like the following:
label: safe

text: In the last week we’ve seen the attack vectors evolve to contain exploit kits as well.
label: safe

text: On October 19, the Kafeine posted a blog discussing the inclusion of CVE-2014-0556 in the Nuclear Pack exploit kit, which was installing CryptoWall 2.0.
label: TIME

text: Yesterday we picked up an e-mail campaign pretending to be a fax report that carried a .zip attachment with a PDF inside.
label: campaign

text: The PDF  exploits CVE-2013-2729 to download a binary which also installed CryptoWall 2.0.
label: malware

text: The best way to protect yourself against ransomware is to keep up-to-date backups of your important files.
label: safe

text: A ransomware infection, which encrypts all of your files, is similar to a drive failure, except that for a small fee you have the chance to get your files back.
label: safe

text: To protect against CryptoWall 2.0 we recommend taking the following actions:  Adobe Reader Embedded BMP Parsing Integer Overflow Vulnerability  CVE-2014-0556  Sign up to receive the latest news, cyber threat intelligence and research from us  Please enter your email address!
label: SOFTWARE

text: Yesterday, TrustedSec, a security consultancy based on Ohio, wrote that the recent breach at Community Health Systems (CHS) was the result of exploitation of the Heartbleed OpenSSL vulnerability (CVE-2014-0160).
label: TIME

text: CHS’s 8-K filing on Monday did not reveal how the attackers got into their network, only that the records of approximately 4.5 million patients were stolen in attacks in between April and June of 2014.
label: identity

text: TrustedSec reports on how attackers were apparently able to glean user credentials from a certain device via the Heartbleed vulnerability and use them to log in via a VPN.
label: identity

text: We need more facts to be sure, but this instance may be the first public breach related to the Heartbleed vulnerability since it was announced in April.
label: TIME

text: Now, over four months since the Heartbleed disclosure, this attack reminds us of how serious this vulnerability is and how critical protection against it remains.
label: vulnerability

text: As Heartbleed allows the attacker to scrape memory from the vulnerable device, they can retrieve significant amounts of secret information.
label: attack-pattern

text: In this case, that apparently included VPN credentials, which they then used to log into the network and more laterally from system to system until discovering the data they were after.
label: SOFTWARE

text: While most vendors released patches for their products months ago it remains up to the users and administrators to ensure those patches are deployed.
label: safe

text: As the OpenSSL library is so widely used, some administrators may be finding unpatched systems for years to come.
label: SOFTWARE

text: While network-based defenses are not a substitute for patching software, Heartbleed is detectable using IPS signatures.
label: vulnerability

text: Palo Alto Networks deployed five signatures in April to defend against this threat, 40039, 36420, 36419, 36418 and 36416.
label: identity

text: No matter how well patched your systems are, there’s no reason not to deploy IPS signatures like these to detect and block attempted Heartbleed exploits.
label: vulnerability

text: If you’ve already deployed signatures and your logs are showing attempted exploits, consider blocking or monitoring the IP addresses sending the requests.
label: safe

text: A Heartbleed probe could be evidence of the early stages of an attack on your network, and persistent attackers are unlikely to give up after jiggling the handle on the front door.
label: vulnerability

text: This post is also available in:      日本語 (Japanese)  On June 2, Volexity reported that over Memorial Day weekend, they identified suspicious activity on two internet-facing servers running Atlassian’s Confluence Server application.
label: TIME

text: After analysis of the compromise, Volexity determined the initial foothold was the result of a remote code execution vulnerability in Confluence Server and Data Center.
label: vulnerability

text: The details were reported to Atlassian on May 31, and Atlassian has since assigned the issue to CVE-2022-26134.
label: TIME

text: Based on the security advisory issued by Atlassian, it appears that the exploit is indeed an unauthenticated, remote code execution vulnerability.
label: identity

text: If the vulnerability is exploited, threat actors could bypass authentication and run arbitrary code on unpatched systems.
label: attack-pattern

text: At the time of publication, the Palo Alto Networks attack surface management solution Cortex Xpanse identified 19,707 instances of Confluence Servers that are potentially affected by this CVE.
label: identity

text: A patch resolving the issue has been posted by Atlassian.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Palo Alto Networks strongly advises organizations to patch immediately.
label: identity

text: Updated June 7 to add additional in-the-wild observations.
label: TIME

text: Vulnerable Systems CVE-2022-26134 in the Wild Cortex Managed Threat Hunting Detections of CVE-2022-26134
label: vulnerability

text: Conclusion Indicators of Compromise
label: safe

text: The Palo Alto Networks attack surface management solution Cortex Xpanse found 19,707 instances of Confluence Servers that are potentially affected by this CVE.
label: identity

text: Additionally, the Xpanse research team also found 1,251 end-of-life versions of the Confluence Server exposed on the public internet.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Assets running end-of-life software should never be internet-facing.
label: safe

text: If an asset cannot be updated to secure versions of software, it should be isolated or decommissioned altogether.
label: safe

text: To learn more about the ubiquitous problem of end-of-life software, please refer to the 2022 Cortex Xpanse Attack Surface Threat Report.
label: TIME

text: Thus far, Unit 42 has noted historical scans being performed by the IP addresses publicly shared by Volexity.
label: identity

text: These scans date back as early as May 26, 2022, and target organizations in various industries.
label: TIME

text: Additionally, a purported proof of concept (PoC) has reached the public domain, increasing the threat this particular vulnerability poses.
label: safe

text: The Cortex Managed Threat Hunting team has detected several exploitation attempts.
label: identity

text: Among the attempts, we found successful exploitation, which resulted in the Cerber Ransomware attack.
label: campaign

text: The ransomware was blocked by the Cortex XDR agent.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The Managed Threat Hunting team immediately reported this incident to the customer and continues to monitor our customers using the XQL queries in the following section.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Cortex XDR also includes multiple detections for post-exploitation activities.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Below are details of what was seen in the attempt.
label: safe

text: In this case, the process tomcat.exe spawned multiple reconnaissance commands such as: whoami, systeminfo, arp, ipconfig, etc.  On top of that, a Base64-encoded PowerShell command was executed and retrieved a ransomware binary.
label: tools

text: In order to confirm the assumption that the above activity is related to CVE-2022-26134, we looked into the Confluence Apache access logs (atlassian-confluence.log) and found the PowerShell execution.  The Cortex Managed Threat Hunting team continues to track any attempts to exploit CVE-2022-26134 across our customers, using Cortex XDR and the XQL queries below.
label: vulnerability

text: Palo Alto Networks provides protection against the exploitation of this vulnerability in the following ways:  Additionally, Xpanse has the ability to identify and detect Atlassian Confluence Servers that may be a part of your attack surface or the attack surface of third-party partners connected to your organization.
label: identity

text: Xpanse is even able to classify those servers which have not been upgraded to the most recent version.
label: SOFTWARE

text: These abilities will be updated to detect additional instances or versions that are insecure against this CVE.
label: safe

text: Existing Xpanse customers can log into Expander and identify their enumerated Atlassian Confluence devices by filtering by “Atlassian Confluence Server” in the Services tab.
label: SOFTWARE

text: As further information emerges or additional detections and protections are put into place, Palo Alto Networks will update this publication accordingly.
label: identity

text: During the hunting process, we encountered exploitation attempts that originated from the following IP addresses: Updated June 13, 2022, at 5:30 a.m. PT.
label: TIME

text: Overview
label: safe

text: As shoppers and retailers gear up for the 2017 holiday season, they need to be aware of a new kind of cybersecurity threat they may face this year: unauthorized coin mining.
label: attack-pattern

text: Unauthorized coin mining is a new threat that can affect retailers and shoppers in a way that could impact or even halt their online shopping experience.
label: attack-pattern

text: A recent Unit 42 threat intelligence posting on the topic showed how 63 percent of the unauthorized coin mining sites we found came online in October 2017.
label: identity

text: This surge in unauthorized coin mining is driven, in large part, by the recent skyrocketing in the value of digital currencies like bitcoin.
label: SOFTWARE

text: As that trend shows no sign of slowing down anytime soon, we can expect this to remain a very lucrative avenue for attackers.
label: safe

text: Unlike other cybersecurity threats we’re used to bracing for around the holiday season, unauthorized coin mining attacks can affect shoppers who are up-to-date with security patches and even some running some security protections.
label: attack-pattern

text: And unlike spam or phishing, these attacks also don’t require any lapse in vigilance by the user: they can happen simply by going to websites users know and trust.
label: attack-pattern

text: The good news for retailers is that these attacks are wholly preventable.
label: safe

text: And for shoppers, the impact of a successful attack is minimal: there are no lasting effects or impact, making it an annoyance at worst.  But because of the potential impact on holiday shopping and the ease of attacks, unauthorized coin mining is an attack that retailers need to be aware of and take active steps for prevention this holiday season.
label: attack-pattern

text: What Is Unauthorized Coin Mining?
label: attack-pattern

text: The best way to understand the threat of unauthorized coin mining is to first understand its impact.
label: attack-pattern

text: Unauthorized coin mining is an attack that can cause a user’s system to suddenly and unexpectedly slow down, sometimes significantly, when visiting a website.
label: attack-pattern

text: In a worst case, the slow-down can be so severe that it can make a website basically unusable.
label: safe

text: Obviously, this impact is potentially dire for shoppers and retailers as it directly impacts and harms the online shopping experience.
label: safe

text: What causes this impact is when the website the user visits is running “coin miner” code.
label: malware

text: “Coin miner” code is code used to “mine” for digital currency like bitcoin.
label: malware

text: Mining provides the computing necessary to power the digital currency’s infrastructure.
label: safe

text: Mining is also a computationally intensive process, meaning it takes a lot of system resources.
label: safe

text: Because of this, people can earn digital currency credit in exchange for the use of their computing resources to power that digital currency’s infrastructure.
label: safe

text: There are many kinds of coin mining software.
label: safe

text: In this case, we are concerned about coin mining code that’s used on websites.
label: safe

text: When the user visits the website, the code runs on their system and “mines” on behalf of others – either the website or someone else.
label: safe

text: When this is done with the visitor’s full knowledge and consent, it’s a fair and reasonable exchange.
label: safe

text: For instance, there are some websites that now use coin mining as an alternative to digital advertising to generate revenue.
label: safe

text: In these cases, the coin mining is authorized; the website informs the user that, while on the site, his or her computing resources will be used to “mine” digital currency, and the site will receive the credits.
label: safe

text: While the user will experience a slow-down as the coin mining software is run, it is (or should be) expected, because of the notification, and so done with the site visitor’s consent.
label: safe

text: Where this becomes a problem is when coin mining is done without the user’s knowledge and consent.
label: safe

text: In this case the coin mining is unauthorized: in essence, it’s an attack against the user’s resources.
label: safe

text: How Do Unauthorized Coin Mining Attacks Happen?
label: attack-pattern

text: Unauthorized coin mining attacks happen very simply: the website the user is visiting has special code on it that performs coin mining operations on the visitor’s computer while they’re on the website.
label: attack-pattern

text: And, as noted before, this happens without the user’s knowledge or consent.
label: safe

text: Because these attacks happen due to code on the website, that code is either there with the site owner’s knowledge and permission or not.
label: safe

text: When unauthorized coin mining happens with the site owner’s knowledge and permission, it’s basically a malicious site.
label: attack-pattern

text: That site’s owner is the attacker.
label: safe

text: When we’re talking about online shopping, clearly there’s no threat here to the retailer: they’re the ones doing the attacking.
label: safe

text: And for the shopper, it means you’re on an untrustworthy site and so open to all manner of risks beyond just unauthorized coin mining.
label: attack-pattern

text: The real, significant situation shoppers and retailers need to think about this season is when unauthorized coin mining code is on a site without that site owner’s knowledge and permission.
label: attack-pattern

text: Here the site itself has been attacked, and the site owners are also victims.
label: safe

text: This is an attack against not just shoppers but the retailers operating online shopping sites.
label: safe

text: How You Can Prevent Unauthorized Coin Mining Attacks  If you’re a shopper, there are three things you can do to protect yourself against unauthorized coin mining attacks this holiday season:  If you’re a retailer, preventing unauthorized coin mining attacks comes down to focusing on two tasks, both of which you should be doing anyway:  Finally, if you’re a legitimate website that has chosen to implement coin mining to raise funds from your visitors, you can ensure that your visitors don’t think you’re engaged in unauthorized coin mining by doing three things:  Conclusion  Working to prevent cybercrime threats during the holiday season has become a standard part of what shoppers and retailers do every year.
label: safe

text: This year, for the first time in many years, shoppers and retailers are facing a new threat, unauthorized coin mining, driven by the surge in digital currency prices.
label: safe

text: While this threat can have a clear, negative impact on retailers and shoppers, the good news is that this threat is easily preventable and poses no lasting harm to consumers.
label: safe

text: This is a case where forewarned is forearmed, and that forearming can result in effective prevention.  Sign up to receive the latest news, cyber threat intelligence and research from us  Please enter your email address!
label: safe

text: This post is also available in:      日本語 (Japanese)  Intro
label: safe

text: One of the most important “innovations” in malware in the past decade is what’s called a Domain Generation Algorithm (“DGA”)”.
label: safe

text: DGA is an automation technique that attackers use to make it harder for defenders to protect against attacks.
label: safe

text: While DGA has been in use for over 10 years now, it’s still a potent technique that has been a particular challenge for defenders to counter.
label: safe

text: Fortunately, there are emerging technologies now that can better counter DGAs.
label: safe

text: What is it?
label: safe

text: A Domain Generation Algorithm is a program that is designed to generate domain names in a particular fashion.
label: safe

text: Attackers developed DGAs so that malware can quickly generate a list of domains that it can use for the sites that give it instructions and receive information from the malware (usually referred to as “command and control” or C2).
label: safe

text: Attackers use DGA so that they can quickly switch the domains that they’re using for the malware attacks.
label: safe

text: Attackers do this because security software and vendors act quickly to block and take down malicious domains that malware uses.
label: safe

text: Attackers developed DGA specifically to counter these actions.
label: safe

text: In the past, attackers would maintain a static list of malicious domains; defenders could easily take that list and start blocking and taking down those sites.
label: safe

text: By using an algorithm to build the list of domains, the attackers also make it harder for defenders to know or predict what domains will be used than if they had a simple list of domains.
label: safe

text: To get that list of domains that the malware will use, defenders have to decode the algorithm which can be difficult.
label: safe

text: Even then, taking down sites that malware using a DGA can be a challenge as defenders have to go through the process of working with ISPs to take down these malicious domains one by one.
label: identity

text: Many DGAs are built to use hundreds or even thousands of domains.
label: safe

text: And these domains are often up for only limited periods of time.
label: safe

text: In this environment blocking and taking down DGA-related domains quickly becomes a game of “whack a mole” that is sometimes futile.
label: safe

text: Why should I care, what can it do to me?
label: safe

text: DGA by itself can’t harm you.
label: safe

text: But it is an important piece that enables modern malware to try and evade security products and countermeasures.
label: safe

text: The importance and usefulness of DGA is best shown by the fact that it’s been in regular and constant use since at least 2008.
label: TIME

text: DGA was a key component in the Conficker attacks in 2008 and 2009 and part of its success.
label: malware

text: What can I do about it?
label: safe

text: Because DGA is a technique the fuels malware attacks, the things you can do to help prevent malware can also help prevent DGA-fueled malware attacks:  In addition, new technologies are being developed that can more directly counter DGA-fueled attacks, particularly for organizations.
label: safe

text: In particular, security vendors are bringing automation to bear to counter the attackers’ automation.
label: safe

text: New anti-DGA technologies that leverage machine learning and big data are capable of countering DGA’s automation with automated prediction of their own that can anticipate, block, assist with malicious site takedowns or even, in some cases, prevent those malicious sites from being used in the first place.
label: safe

text: You can also learn more about these new technologies and look at deploying them as an additional layer of protection.
label: safe

text: About: Threat Briefs are meant to help busy people understand real-world threats and how they can prevent them in their lives.
label: safe

text: They’re put together by Palo Alto Networks Unit 42 threat research team and are meant for you to read and share with your family, friends, and coworkers so you can all be safer and get on with the business of your digital life.  Got a topic you want us to write about for you, your friends, or your family?
label: identity

text: Email us at u42comms@paloaltonetworks.com.
label: EMAIL

text: Unit 42 released details about a vulnerability that affects Android devices running operating systems older than 8.0 Oreo.
label: identity

text: The vulnerability leaves Android users at risk of falling victim to an Android Toast Overlay attack.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Patches are available that fix this vulnerability, so Android users should get the latest updates as soon as possible.
label: SOFTWARE

text: How it Works
label: safe

text: The vulnerability affects the Toast feature on Android devices, an Android feature that allows display messages and notifications of other applications to “pop up,” and allows an attacker to employ an overlay attack.
label: SOFTWARE

text: An overlay attack happens when an attacker places a window over a legitimate application on the device.
label: safe

text: Users will interact with the window, thinking they are performing their intended function, but they are actually engaging with the attackers overlay window and executing the attacker’s desired function.
label: safe

text: You can see an example of how this would work in Figure 1.
label: safe

text: Figure 1: Bogus patch installer overlying malware requesting administrative permissions  This interaction can install malware or malicious software on the device, grant malware full administrative privileges or lock the user out and render the device unusable.  In the past successful overlay attacks were typically dependent on two conditions:  However, with this particular vulnerability, these conditions are no longer required for a successful attack.
label: safe

text: This means that attackers can use this vulnerability in apps users get from places other than Google Play.
label: SOFTWARE

text: And when they install these malicious apps, they don’t have to ask for the “draw on top” permission.
label: safe

text: How to Defend Against It  Keeping devices updated is a general security best practice.
label: safe

text: The Android Toast Overlay attack specifically targets outdated devices using versions prior to 8.0.
label: attack-pattern

text: In order to defend against the Android Toast Overlay attack, update all Android devices to the latest version.
label: attack-pattern

text: Additionally, avoid downloading malicious applications by only downloading from the Google Play store is another best practice you should always follow.
label: SOFTWARE
