text: This post is also available in:      日本語 (Japanese)  Ransomware is one of the top threats in cybersecurity and a focus area for Palo Alto Networks.
label: identity

text: In the current threat landscape, ransom payments are rising and organizations are seeking to protect themselves from threat actors.
label: safe

text: In the 2021 Unit 42 Ransomware Threat Report, we detailed the observations and the trend of top ransomware families from January 2020-January 2021.
label: identity

text: This post supplements that information based on observations from the first three months of 2021, and will discuss the propagation of different ransomware families we observed in the wild and the different types of extortion used.
label: TIME

text: We hope the information will help readers get a clear picture of current directions in ransomware trends.
label: safe

text: In the first quarter (Q1) of 2021, Unit 42 detected 113 different ransomware families in the wild.
label: TIME

text: Based on the statistical data, the top 15 ransomware families only cover 52.3% of total ransomware cases.
label: safe

text: This demonstrates the diversity of ransomware and emphasizes how difficult it is to expand ransomware detection coverage with static profiling.
label: safe

text: Figure 1 shows the proportion of ransomware sample numbers for different families that Unit 42 detected in the wild.
label: identity

text: Among all, 6.7% of the ransomware samples are Virlock, which has been active since 2014.
label: malware

text: Virlock has the largest number of variants due to its file-infector-like behavior.
label: attack-pattern

text: Higher malware variant numbers don't necessarily imply a higher prevalence.
label: safe

text: Some ransomware families don’t deliver different variants every time, but the infection ratio per sample is high, meaning attackers delivered the same malware to huge numbers of victims.
label: safe

text: Figure 2 shows a completely different result from Figure 1 and stems from only counting ransomware samples from cases in which more than five hosts were infected with the same malware.
label: safe

text: From this lens, the top three families observed are Ryuk (31.7%), Sodinokibi (20%) and Maze (15%).  Emails are still the most efficient method to deliver and propagate ransomware.
label: malware

text: Figure 3 shows ransomware arrives via different application protocols.
label: safe

text: The majority of ransomware is delivered by email.
label: attack-pattern

text: Web browsing is the second most common entry vector for ransomware infections.
label: safe

text: The process of delivering malware by a URL can include various techniques.
label: safe

text: For example, the URL links can be posted on forums or chat group software, sent by IM applications, offered via fake freeware for download or attached in emails.
label: attack-pattern

text: Web hosting ransomware can also be downloaded and successfully installed through a multi-layered infection chain among different file types.
label: attack-pattern

text: For example, AlumniLocker is first delivered as a phishing PDF.
label: malware

text: It leads to downloading a ZIP archive that contains an LNK downloader.
label: SOFTWARE

text: This downloads and executes an obfuscated PowerShell script to finally install the ransomware.
label: attack-pattern

text: Figure 4 breaks down which file types we saw in the course of ransomware detection and their prevalence.
label: safe

text: 32-bit EXE is the most common ransomware file type we observed.
label: safe

text: Other file types are often used as the first stage of infection or downloaders, such as archives, documents and scripts.
label: safe

text: Most ransomware is delivered via email with an attached archive; the ransomware is compressed in the archived files with or without password protection.
label: safe

text: “Resume” or “portfolio document” are examples of archive file names, and the archive contains one or more pieces of malware with fake document file icons.
label: safe

text: One example here is Makop, contained in a 7z archive along with an infostealer malware (SHA256: DE6DFA018773E07C218EF1DF62CE0D99A708841BF1DDFB4C6AD7E323D5D666A4).
label: malware

text: A script file is also used to download or install ransomware.
label: safe

text: For example, GandCrab uses JScript as a downloader, leveraging Windows Background Intelligent Transfer Service (BITS) to download the payload in the background (Figure 5).
label: malware

text: We also observed that Mailto (AKA NetWalker) tends to deliver ransomware in a highly obfuscated PowerShell script.
label: malware

text: Exploit documents are seldom seen for delivering ransomware.
label: safe

text: One example is an exploit RTF that led to downloading and installing Makop ransomware remotely.
label: attack-pattern

text: Besides encrypting files on infected hosts, the main feature of ransomware is, of course, the demand for ransom.
label: safe

text: Since ransomware threat actors have had years to evolve their techniques, there are now several different ways for attackers to receive payments and provide the "service" they claim to offer.
label: safe

text: Usually, after the ransomware successfully installs, it pops up a message box or leaves text files to explain how to pay the ransom – the ransom note.
label: safe

text: Some ransomware locks the victim's screen and only displays the ransom note.
label: safe

text: Unit 42 has reviewed ransom notes from different ransomware families.
label: identity

text: Most ransom notes request payment in cryptocurrency or mention reaching out via the darknet, though some other contact methods also appear.  In these cases, the ransom note asks victims to pay a specific amount in cryptocurrency – Bitcoin (BTC), Monero (XMR), etc. — to a specific wallet address.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Two ransomware families that utilize these types of ransom notes are Virlock and WanaCrypt0r.
label: malware

text: Some ransomware families, including Babuk, Sodinokibi, Cerber, Mailto, Ryuk and others, seldom show the ransom amount or cryptocurrency wallet address.
label: malware

text: Instead, they instruct victims to install TOR and reach out to them on the darknet.
label: tools

text: Usually, they host a website for victims to input the identification key found in the ransom note, upload encrypted files for decryption – and pay the ransom.
label: safe

text: Ransom notes from Makop, Dharma, Ryuk, DearCry and others, sometimes ask victims to reach out to them via email.
label: malware

text: The email addresses given are usually from untraceable email accounts.
label: safe

text: At other times, a threat actor lets the victim chat with them directly on group chat software.
label: safe

text: The victims can find the threat actor’s user name through specific group chat software or follow a chat group link in the ransom note.  Ransom payment operations are complicated and highly automated processes.
label: safe

text: Attackers can create a lot of cryptocurrency wallets automatically; they can even make a unique wallet address for each victim.
label: safe

text: Once a ransom is received, the ransom will be involved in the multiple transactions that are managed to distribute and aggregate the ransom across thousands of virtual wallets.
label: safe

text: For example, the Xorist ransomware (SHA256: 4979A10B81C41ECC0FC3A0F376ADE766CE616D2301639F74E0277047CC40E3D6) demanded £1,000 for a ransom; the bitcoin wallet address was 1BFqrLCDwwrxueY7FFDn8DqeoasPJignxt.
label: SHA2

text: However, this wallet had not really received any ransom payments when the malware was delivered.
label: safe

text: The wallet got involved in the operation of mixing and tumbling among several other virtual wallets.
label: safe

text: This is a pretty common operation when attackers want to withdraw or disperse currency from ransom payments into other wallets.
label: safe

text: During the operation, 25.1 BTC from 538 wallets was sent to 1NDyJtNTjmwk5xPNhjgAMu4HDHigtobu1s (SHA256: CE11703DEF517306326C48A67A7C859A3DE0F18E2451DF226CE171389A5B7953), which is a wallet owned by Binance cryptocurrency exchange.
label: SHA2

text: (ref: Binance on Twitter ).
label: SOFTWARE

text: The 25.1 BTC amount was worth $1.18 million at that time, and now is about $876,000.
label: safe

text: Since Virlock only requests a $250 ransom, it does not draw too much public attention.
label: malware

text: Other ransomware families, however, target enterprises and ask for multimillion dollar ransoms, which garners much more media attention.
label: safe

text: Based on the way Virlock spreads the ransom amount it demands, it is likely designed to target consumers or home users.
label: malware

text: After infection, Virlock hides the file extension through modification of the registry (HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\Advanced\HideFileExt = 1, HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\Advanced\Hidden = 2).
label: REGISTRYKEY

text: The encrypted file icon will look the same as usual, but after opening the infected file, the ransom note will pop up.
label: safe

text: Virlock uses, but isn’t limited to, PDF, DOC, PPT, JPG, BMP,GIF, RAR, 7Zip, Zip and EXE files.
label: malware

text: Figure 6 is a screenshot of a recently captured Virlock ransom note.
label: malware

text: The attacker asked for $250 and required payment as 0.004 BTC (suggesting that at the time the ransom note was written, 1 BTC equaled approximately $62,500).
label: safe

text: At the time of infection experiments, 1 BTC equaled approximately $54,649, suggesting that the exchange rate in the ransom note is not updated on the fly.
label: safe

text: Some Virlock variants ask for more ransom, such as 0.771 BTC, 1.008 BTC or more.
label: malware

text: The top three samples we observed spreading in early 2021 were Ryuk, Maze, and Sodinokibi.
label: malware

text: These three contribute 7.2% out of the total infected numbers we collected.
label: safe

text: Ryuk will change the infected file extension to .RYK, and leave a ransom note called RyukReadMe.html.
label: malware

text: One of the reasons Ryuk causes so much damage is because it will scan the local network and try to infect other machines through Server Message Block (SMB) protocols.
label: malware

text: Ryuk will even send out Wake-on-LAN packets to wake up systems that have been configured with this feature.
label: malware

text: In this research, we discussed ransomware family trends we observed in the first three months of 2021.
label: TIME

text: First, we reviewed the trends from prevalent ransomware families, then we discussed the most common file types used as attack vectors leveraged by ransomware.
label: safe

text: Lastly, we gave an example of ransom operations and updates about top ransomware families.
label: safe

text: Ransomware threats are a serious challenge.
label: safe

text: Employing effective backup strategies and disaster recovery procedures is important.
label: safe

text: Palo Alto Networks customers are further protected from ransomware.
label: identity

text: Cortex XSOAR can automatically and instantly coordinate with network security, malware analysis and threat management solutions to ensure customers remain protected.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Cortex XDR endpoint protection stops malware, exploits and ransomware before they can compromise endpoints.
label: SOFTWARE

text: With AI-powered Inline analysis, the Next-Generation Firewall stops exploits that lead to infection, and WildFire’s always up-to-date machine learning models monitor behavior to preemptively detect unknown ransomware.
label: identity

text: If you think you may have been impacted by ransomware, please email unit42-investigations@paloaltonetworks.com or call (866) 4-UNIT42 to get in touch with the Unit 42 Incident Response team.
label: EMAIL

text: Highlights from the 2021 Unit 42 Ransomware Threat Report  Ransomware Threat Assessments: A Companion to the 2021 Unit 42 Ransomware Threat Report  Sign up to receive the latest news, cyber threat intelligence and research from us  Please enter your email address!
label: identity

text: Please mark, I'm not a robot!
label: safe

text: If you need to understand one thing about cybercrime, it’s that it is all about business.
label: safe

text: In our latest Unit 42 research on cybercriminals using the Hancitor malware, we show that not only are their attacks about business, we can see these cybercriminals deftly applying some fundamental business principles around timing, specialization, and globalization.
label: identity

text: Hancitor is a malware that focuses getting other malware onto the victim’s system.
label: malware

text: In the case of Hancitor, it’s typically banking Trojans that steal the victim’s banking information.
label: malware

text: In our latest research, we can see the attackers behind Hancitor have been timing their attacks to happen during the busiest time of the global working week, the middle of the week.
label: malware

text: And we’ve seen that in adapting their attacks to better evade detection, they’ve specialized their operations around the globe.
label: safe

text: Hancitor isn’t particularly advanced in its tactics: it’s ideal target is an old or outdated version of Microsoft Windows like Windows 7 or even Windows XP.
label: malware

text: But it’s effective enough that when used in several hundred different spam campaigns every month it pays for the criminals to keep up these attacks against targets around the world.
label: safe

text: Timing   In our most recent research, one of the things that jumped out for our researchers is the clear pattern around the timing of the attacks.
label: safe

text: As you can see in Figure 1 below, throughout 2017, the Hancitor attacks show clear spikes in their occurrence and these spikes happen during the middle of the week.
label: TIME

text: Figure 1: Timeline of Hancitor campaign activity since January 2017.
label: malware

text: The attackers behind Hancitor aren’t the first to time their spam attacks like this, but it is an effective tactic to try and increase their chances of success, especially when combined with the other innovation that we’ve seen.
label: malware

text: Adapting the Attacks
label: safe

text: In the past, Hancitor was sent as a malicious attachment in a spam email which would then download and install the attackers’ final malware like a banking Trojan.
label: malware

text: When they would do this, the Hancitor attachment would download and install the final malware from a malicious or compromised site.
label: malware

text: But as organizations have gotten more effective at blocking malicious attachments like Hancitor, we’ve seen the attackers behind Hancitor adapt to evade detection and prevention.
label: malware

text: They’ve done this by moving the Hancitor malware from being a malicious attachment in spam to itself being a malicious download.
label: malware

text: The spam the attackers use no long has a malicious attachment but instead a malicious link that downloads the malicious Hancitor attachment.
label: malware

text: To do this, they make the spam look like something that requires you to click and download something like and invoice, a message, or a delivery notification.
label: safe

text: Figure 2 shows one of these that was made to look like an Amazon shipping notice.
label: identity

text: Figure 2: Hancitor malspam example from February 2017.
label: malware

text: This means that a Hancitor attack now has two downloads rather than one and what these attackers did around the malicious downloads shows another modern business tactic: globalization.
label: malware

text: Globalizing the Attacks  Figure 3 below is a map showing where our Unit 42 researchers have found webistes involved in Hancitor attacks.
label: malware

text: Figure 3: Hancitor distribution servers globally thus far in 2017  Table 1 – Number of Distribution Servers by Country
label: malware

text: The hot spots in the United States represents distribution servers which are created using fraud based accounts at various hosting providers that are hosting the Hancitor documents while the hotspots in Asia represent legitimate sites for small and medium businesses that have been compromised by the actors behind Hancitor campaign to host the malicious Hancitor documents.
label: malware

text: Conclusion  Attackers are always making business decisions to optimize their attacks in ways that are most successful and profitable.
label: safe

text: What is most interesting about Hancitor is the way these decisions so clearly reflect an awareness of business realities (by targeting peak working times) and dividing up the “work” of their attacks in a way that so clearly mirrors mainstream business decisions around globalizing operations.
label: malware

text: In the end, while Hancitor may not be sophisticated, these steps to adapt and stay effective seem to be succeeding.
label: malware

text: And we expect to continue to see Hancitor be a global threat for the foreseeable future.
label: malware

text: This post is also available in:      日本語 (Japanese)  This Unit 42 blog provides an update on the threat situation surrounding attacks using the Petya Ransomware which are impacting organizations in Ukraine, Russia and to a lesser extent around the world.
label: identity

text: On June 27th, 2017 we became aware of a new variant of the Petya malware which is spreading through multiple lateral movement techniques.
label: malware

text: One technique includes  the ETERNALBLUE exploit tool.
label: malware

text: This is the same exploit the WanaCrypt0r/WannaCry malware exploited to spread globally in May, 2017.
label: malware

text: At least 50 organizations have reported impacts from the malware, including government and critical infrastructure operators.
label: safe

text: Palo Alto Networks is documenting our prevention capabilities with regard to this threat in the Palo Alto Networks Protections for Petya Ransomware blog post.
label: identity

text: Windows users should take the following general steps to protect themselves:
label: SOFTWARE

text: This is a developing situation, we will update this blog as new information becomes available.
label: safe

text: AutoFocus users view samples using the Petya tag.
label: malware

text: Petya is a ransomware family that works by modifying the Window’s system’s Master Boot Record (MBR), causing the system to crash.
label: malware

text: When the user reboots their PC, the modified MBR prevents Windows from loading and displays a fake “chkdisk” screen which indicates the computer's hard drive is being repaired, but the malware is actually encrypting the user's files.
label: SOFTWARE

text: When this process completes, the malware displays an ASCII Ransom note demanding payment from the victim (Figure 1).  Figure 1: Latest Petya Ransom note displayed on a compromised system.
label: malware

text: The latest version of the Petya ransomware is spreading over Windows SMB and is reportedly using the ETERNALBLUE exploit tool, which exploits CVE-2017-0144 and was originally released by the Shadow Brokers group in April 2017.
label: malware

text: After the system is compromised the victim is asked to send US $300 in Bitcoin to a specific Bitcoin address and then send an e-mail with the victim’s bitcoin wallet ID to wowsmith123456@posteo[.]net to retrieve their individual decryption key.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Posteo (a free e-mail provider) has already shut down this e-mail address, and as such victims should not even attempt to pay the ransom.
label: SOFTWARE

text: As of 13:00 UTC on June 28thth, approximately 4 Bitcoin have been transferred to the attacker's wallet.
label: TIME

text: Unit 42 is unaware of ANY successful recovery after paying the ransom.
label: identity

text: Additionally, ongoing research by the industry is showing that specific actions this malware takes makes it technically infeasible, if not impossible, for recovery to occur.
label: safe

text: This means that even though this malware is functionally ransomware, for threat assessment purposes, it should be functionally considered a “wiper”.
label: safe

text: We are aware of the following information about how the Petya attack lifecycle works.
label: malware

text: Delivery/Exploitation
label: safe

text: We have not yet confirmed the initial infection vector for this new Petya variant.
label: malware

text: Previous variants were spread through e-mail, but we have not identified this latest sample carried in any e-mail related attacks.
label: safe

text: While we have not been able to directly confirm the source, we have seen evidence that a Ukrainian software application called MEDoc was used by attackers to deliver the Petya DLL.
label: location

text: The software is heavily used in Ukraine it appears the company’s systems may have been compromised and used to issue a malicious update to systems running the program on the morning of Jun 27th.
label: TIME

text: Installation
label: safe

text: This variant of Petya is spread as a DLL file, which must be executed by another process before it takes action on the system.
label: malware

text: Once executed, it overwrites the Master Boot Record and creates a scheduled task to reboot the system.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Once the system reboots, the malware displays a fake “chkdisk” scan which tricks the victim into believing the program is repairing their hard drive.
label: safe

text: In reality, the malware is encrypting the NTFS Master File Table in the background.
label: safe

text: Once the fake chkdisk completes, the malware displays a ransom note which demands a payment of $300 in bitcoin.
label: safe

text: Command and Control  Petya contains no Command and Control mechanisms that we know of.
label: malware

text: After a host is infected, there is no communication from the malware back to the attacker.
label: safe

text: Lateral Movement  Petya uses three mechanisms to spread to additional hosts.
label: malware

text: Ransomware attacks are very common, but they are rarely coupled with an exploit that allows the malware to spread as a network worm.
label: safe

text: The WannaCry attacks in May, 2017 demonstrated that many Windows systems had not been patched for this vulnerability.
label: malware

text: The spread of Petya using this vulnerability indicates that many organizations may still be vulnerable, despite the attention WannaCry received.
label: malware

text: As always if you have any questions, please come to the Threat & Vulnerability Discussions on our Live Community.  Version Summary  June 27, 2017:  June 27, 2017 – 1:08 PM PT  June 28, 2017 – 8:40 AM PT  June 29, 2017 - 5:00 PM PT  Sign up to receive the latest news, cyber threat intelligence and research from us  Please enter your email address!
label: TIME

text: Nearly all of us have a use for Microsoft Office documents.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Whether they are work documents, e-receipts, or a lease on a new apartment – Office documents are useful to all of us, and this is part of the reason we’re very likely to open an office document we receive as an attachment in e-mail.
label: safe

text: Armed with the knowledge that many people will open nearly any document, even those from an untrusted source, adversaries commonly choose these files in attacks to compromise a system.
label: safe

text: In this threat brief we show you five different ways that Office documents can be subverted and abused to attack and compromise a Windows endpoint, some we’ve already posted about before, and some are new.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Macros Macros are the most straight-forward way for an attacker to weaponize Office documents.
label: safe

text: Office applications have a built-in script engine that can run VBA (Visual Basic for Applications) scripts.
label: SOFTWARE

text: These scripts can execute immediately as the document opens, without any user interaction (assuming the user has previously enabled macros) and run malicious code on the system.
label: safe

text: If the user has not enabled macros, a popup window will appear asking the user to click to do so.
label: safe

text: The pop-up is one of several security mechanisms added by Microsoft to mitigate the security risk that macros pose.
label: identity

text: Microsoft will also force a different file extension (.docm instead of .docx for new documents containing macros).
label: identity

text: Despite these measures, users still choose to open these files and enable their content, thus allowing macros to continue be a common attack vector – both in wide and simple attacks to deliver ransomware such as Emotet, as well as for sophisticated attacks like this Sofacy campaign.
label: malware

text: Figure 1.
label: safe

text: The Sofacy document before & after the content is enabled
label: malware

text: As you can see in this example, attackers try to convince users to disable the security mechanisms added by Microsoft using social engineering, convincing the user to enable content for them to be able to see the full document.
label: attack-pattern

text: In the Sofacy example, the attackers had simply made the font color white, so the text was present prior to the user enabling macros, just not clearly visible.
label: malware

text: Embedded Flash files  In addition to built-in capabilities, like macros, Office documents can also be embedded with external objects, such as Adobe Flash files.
label: location

text: These objects are passed to the appropriate software for handling, thus any vulnerability that the software has can also be exploited by embedding it within the Adobe Flash content in the Office document.
label: SOFTWARE

text: An example for such attack vector being leveraged by attackers is CVE-2018-4878, an Adobe Flash Player Zero-Day exploited by embedding malicious SWF files in Excel documents.
label: vulnerability

text: In these types of attacks, the malicious Excel contains embedded Adobe Flash content which can trigger the Flash vulnerability and execute embedded shellcode.
label: vulnerability

text: Microsoft Equation Editor
label: SOFTWARE

text: In a similar way to embedding Adobe Flash files into an Office document, you can also embed equations in documents that will be parsed by Microsoft Equation Editor - a program that lets you easily write mathematical equations: Figure 2.  Microsoft Equation Editor  As in our previous example, vulnerabilities in the equation editor can be exploited by leveraging malicious Office documents.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We’ve seen examples of this just recently, when CVE-2017-11882 was exploited in the wild, paving the way to other exploits like CVE-2018-0802, both of which exploit flaws in the equation editor, enabling attackers to get from the user opening an Office document to remote code execution.
label: vulnerability

text: While still not seen in the wild, similar exploits in Microsoft Equation Editor, such as such as CVE-2018-0807 and CVE-2018-0798, were identified by Unit 42 researchers.
label: identity

text: Note that since the Microsoft Equation Editor runs as its own process (eqnedt32.exe), protections specific to Microsoft Office such as EMET and Windows Defender Exploit Guard are not effective by default, as they only protect Microsoft Office processes (such as winword.exe).  OLE Objects & HTA Handlers
label: SOFTWARE

text: OLE Objects & HTA Handlers are mechanisms Office documents use to make references to include other documents in their content.
label: safe

text: They can be used to compromise an endpoint in the following way:  This functionality was leveraged in exploitation of CVE-2017-0199 - a Microsoft Office/WordPad remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability patched by Microsoft in September 2017, and was used in multiple campaigns, like this OilRig campaign.
label: identity

text: Figure 3.
label: safe

text: RTF files will look exactly like regular Word documents
label: SOFTWARE

text: In addition to the previous OLE & HTA exploit, attackers discovered RTF files can also execute ‘text/html’ mime-type OLE objects using the MSHTML.
label: vulnerability

text: This means that RTF documents expose the same attack surface as Internet Explorer!
label: SOFTWARE

text: Leveraging this logical vulnerability, known as CVE-2018-8174, allows attackers to execute arbitrary HTML/JavaScript/VBScript.
label: vulnerability

text: While code executed in this way is ‘sandboxed’ (where it cannot run new processes or write to the filesystem etc.), like other code running from Internet Explorer
label: SOFTWARE

text: , this flaw can be used to leverage other vulnerabilities, such as a memory corruption UAF vulnerability in the VBScript engine, to gain arbitrary code execution in the context of the Word application (winword.exe), allowing them to gain control on the system.
label: FILEPATH

text: Conclusion
label: safe

text: While document-based attacks have been a common attack vector for over a decade, we’re seeing a recent rise in their popularity and complexity.
label: safe

text: This rise may be a result of browser exploits becoming more difficult to use, due to the hardening done by browser developers.
label: safe

text: No matter the reason
label: safe

text: , it is important that organizations know how to defend against these common techniques.
label: safe

text: Prevention Palo Alto Networks Traps advanced endpoint protection offers multiple methods of malware and exploit prevention to protect against these threats:
label: identity

text: On Sept. 14, 2021, security researchers from Wiz released a report detailing the findings of four critical vulnerabilities affecting the Microsoft Azure package OMI.
label: identity

text: Dubbed OMIGOD, the four vulnerabilities were found to directly affect Azure Cloud Instances.
label: vulnerability

text: Use-after-free bugs have affected Internet Explorer for years.
label: SOFTWARE

text: In the past year alone, Microsoft patched 122 IE vulnerabilities, the majority of which were use-after-free bugs.
label: identity

text: This year Microsoft has already patched 126 IE vulnerabilities to date.
label: identity

text: Of those vulnerabilities, 4 were actively being exploited in the wild.
label: safe

text: These 4 exploits (CVE-2014-1815, CVE-2014-1776, CVE-2014-0322, CVE-2014-0324) were all based on use-after-free bugs.
label: vulnerability

text: To deal with the increasing number of use-after-free bugs and associated exploits, Microsoft introduced a series of new control mechanisms in the most recent Internet Explorer patches.
label: identity

text: In June, Microsoft introduced a new isolated heap mechanism to solve the usage issue of use-after-free exploitation.
label: identity

text: They followed that up In July by implementing a deferred free method to solve the freeing issue of use-after-free bugs.
label: TIME

text: The main concept of an isolated heap is simple.
label: safe

text: It allocates a dedicated heap for select critical objects to use that is separate from other heaps that a user can directly access.
label: safe

text: The heap block will not be occupied by user-controlled data after the critical objects are freed.
label: safe

text: This mechanism prevents precise control of the data of a freed object from further exploitation.
label: safe

text: Figure 1. _g_hIsolatedHeap handle used for isolated heap
label: safe

text: The isolated heap was applied to many but not all internal objects, leaving some still vulnerable.
label: safe

text: To address this, Microsoft introduced another protection method of deferred free named ProtectedFree.
label: identity

text: They encapsulate this method and apply it to almost every object in mshtml.dll.
label: FILEPATH

text: In IE9, for example, it has been applied to every object through MemoryProtection::HeapFree as shown in figure 2.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Figure 2.
label: safe

text: References of MemoryProtection::HeapFree
label: safe

text: The main idea of this protection mechanism is to delay the freeing action so that the intruder is unable to determine when they can occupy the freed object using controlled data.
label: safe

text: In this new patch, every time Internet Explorer tries to free an object, it is not freed immediately.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Instead, the block to be freed is marked and filled with 0x00 data and added to a pool.
label: safe

text: When the size of the pool hits a predefined threshold, which is currently 100k (0x186A0 as highlighted in figure 3), it performs the real freeing operation (ReclaimUnmarkedBlocks).    Figure 3.
label: safe

text: C++ style pseudo code of ProtectedFree function
label: safe

text: Microsoft stores the to-be-freed blocks in a structure called st_ProtecFreeManageHeap.
label: identity

text: This structure is created in the function MemoryProtection::CMemoryProtector::ProtectCurrentThread and is used to manage deferred free heap blocks.
label: safe

text: Figure 4 shows an example of the structure in memory.
label: safe

text: Figure 4. st_ProtecFreeManageHeap  Figure 5 provides an alternate view of the structure in a C style code block.
label: safe

text: Figure 5. C style code of st_ProtecFreeManageHeap
label: safe

text: If we were able to make the size of the current heap block in this structure larger than the threshold of 0x186A0 bytes and trigger CMemoryProtector::ProtectedFree, it is still possible to force a true freeing action and occupy the freed object with other data as we show in the following piece of javascript code in figure 6.    Figure 6. Javascript proof of concept to force freeing  When creating the anchor element, the debug logs are shown in figure 7.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The address of the anchor element is 0x0c3b3f98.
label: safe

text: Figure 7:
label: safe

text: Before free  We then manually decrease the reference number, so the CMemoryProtector::ProtectedFree function will fill the block with 0’s, but the object is still not freed.
label: safe

text: Figure 8: decrease the reference number, not yet freed
label: safe

text: Finally we make the size of the CMemoryProtector::ProtectedFree management structure larger than 0x186a0 forcing the freeing operation.
label: safe

text: Figure 9: field “TotalMemorySize” of st_ProtecFreeManageHeap is greater than threshold
label: safe

text: The anchor element is now actually freed as shown in figure 10.
label: safe

text: Figure 10: object is in the free list now
label: safe

text: From a researchers' point of view, deferred free created a few problems, one of the major ones being that the page heap feature may not work correctly.
label: safe

text: Page heap is a useful feature for debugging.
label: safe

text: When page heap is turned on, the system allows only one object in one memory page.
label: safe

text: Once this object is freed the whole page is marked as invalid.
label: safe

text: So the next time IE tries to access a freed object an invalid address exception would be raised.
label: SOFTWARE

text: This mechanism is extremely helpful when researchers are trying to find use-after-free bugs.
label: safe

text: With the introduction of the deferred free patch the object is no longer truly freed, so the page still exists.
label: safe

text: In this situation the researcher is no longer able to determine whether a use-after-free behavior has occurred because no exception would be thrown out.
label: safe

text: To reduce the impact of the deferred free patch, a research may consider patching the mshtml.dll in memory.
label: FILEPATH

text: For example, you can call MemoryProtection::CMemoryProtector::UnprotectProcess before you perform any fuzzing tasks.
label: attack-pattern

text: The recent patches and introduction of isolated heap and deferred free are strong signs that Microsoft plans to address the fundamentals of use-after-free exploitation in a preventative manner rather than to passively patch the vulnerabilities as they are discovered.
label: identity

text: From the results of our research, applications of such methods can effectively stop unpatched use-after-free attacks.
label: attack-pattern

text: It can also make the exploitations of heap overflows or type confusion bugs significantly more difficult.
label: attack-pattern

text: But this is not the end.
label: safe

text: For the foreseeable future, Microsoft may introduce more defensive mechanisms against use-after-free bugs or even heap fengshui to reduce the risk of being exploited.
label: identity

text: Could it be game over for use-after-free exploitation, or it is just the beginning of another cat and mouse game?
label: safe

text: Time will tell.
label: safe

text: Today we’re releasing a new Unit 42 white paper titled “Credential-Based Attacks: Exposing the Ecosystem and Motives Behind Credential Phishing, Theft and Abuse.”
label: identity

text: In this paper, we look at the problem of credential theft by exploring how it happens, what attackers do with credentials once they’ve stolen them, and what you can do to help prevent credential-based attacks.
label: attack-pattern

text: Credentials and authentication have become synonymous, with valid credentials allowing access to sensitive resources.
label: safe

text: Adversaries are increasingly stealing and using credentials as part of their playbooks; impersonating legitimate users to access a company’s most sensitive information, erase data on servers, and reconfigure them so that they can’t boot; and undertake other malicious activities.
label: safe

text: Stolen credentials underpin some of the most critical and damaging attacks out there; both Shamoon 2 and the Sofacy threat actor group, for example, have made detailed use of credential theft.
label: attack-pattern

text: Credential theft today can happen in many ways, but the most notable are through credential phishing and the use of malware like keyloggers (both staples of the Sofacy group), as well as password reuse.
label: attack-pattern

text: The impact of a successful credential theft is, ultimately, access and authorization.
label: attack-pattern

text: Attackers will use credential theft for remote access to an organization, to access cloud-based resources (which may have weaker credential protections than network-based resources), or to move laterally within an organization once they’ve gained entry.
label: attack-pattern

text: The most sophisticated attacks can – and do – blend these actions together, sometimes using multiple stolen credentials to penetrate networks, move laterally within them, elevate privileges, and then access and steal data.  Prevention of credential theft is too often overlooked.
label: attack-pattern

text: Organizations should continue with user education to help users better spot and not fall for phishing and spam attacks.
label: attack-pattern

text: You and your employees can also use password managers to make unique, complex passwords for each site not just a goal but a reality.
label: safe

text: Technology is also catching up; recent advances in two-factor/multi-factor authentication (2FA/MFA) and one-time passwords (OTP) represent the best long-term approaches to preventing credential theft.
label: attack-pattern

text: (Our newest release, PAN-OS 8.0, also includes protections to significantly limit or eliminate password reuse.)
label: safe

text: Get your copy of our white paper here.
label: safe

text: This post is also available in:      日本語 (Japanese)  In January 2020, during the first Patch Tuesday of the new year, Microsoft released patches for 17 new vulnerabilities including one for CVE-2020-0601 known as Curveball.

label: FILEPATH

text: At the time of release, Microsoft affirmed that they had not yet seen the vulnerability exploited in the wild (ITW).
label: identity

label: location

text: The patch provided by Microsoft included the typical release of operating system patches, but this time a new Application Programming Interface (API) function was added.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The new CveEventWrite function can be used to publish events when an attempt to exploit security vulnerabilities in user-mode applications occurs.
label: safe

label: vulnerability

text: We also recommend users of the Chrome browser to update to version 79.0.3945.130 as they recently released an update to fix the TLS issue.
