text: In the months since the WanaCrypt0r/WannaCry and the Petya/NotPetya attacks, security researchers have delved into the nuts and bolts these incidents and the malware involved.
label: malware

text: One key thing that research into these security incidents shows is that these attacks used a relatively new and unknown technique called kernel APC attacks as part of their toolkit.
label: attack-pattern

text: Kernel APC attacks occur in a way that increases the “stealth” factor and makes standard detection and prevention very difficult.
label: attack-pattern

text: And kernel APC attacks do this while still maximizing the power and control that the code has on the target system.
label: attack-pattern

text: While kernel APC attacks aren’t well known and can be hard to understand, their proven success in WanaCrypt0r/WannaCry and the Petya/NotPetya make them an important threat to understand because proven attack techniques are quickly adopted widely.
label: malware

text: And understanding is a first step to prevention.
label: safe

text: To understand what makes kernel APC attacks so dangerous, it’s important to understand what they are.  The kernel is the heart of the operating system.
label: attack-pattern

text: When talking about operating systems with security permissions and controls like Windows or UNIX/Linux, the kernel operates with the highest level of control.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Because of this, attacks against the kernel are used to gain complete control over a system, generally as part of an “elevation or privilege” (EoP) or “privilege escalation” attack.
label: attack-pattern

text: Typically, attacks against the kernel are used in conjunction with code execution attacks so that an attacker can target a limited privilege user but ultimately gain full control over the system.
label: safe

text: Privilege escalation attacks against the kernel have been around for some time and are well-known and can be well protected against.  Kernel APC attacks however are a different class of attack.
label: attack-pattern

text: These don’t attack the kernel to gain privileges.
label: safe

text: Instead kernel APC attacks already have kernel privileges and use them to further carry out their attack.
label: attack-pattern

text: In this case by making legitimate programs execute malicious code rather than their own legitimate code.
label: attack-pattern

text: Kernel APC attacks do this using their control over the kernel to redirect APCs: “Asynchronous Procedure Calls”.
label: attack-pattern

text: APCs can basically be thought of as places in line for the CPU that the kernel gives access to.
label: safe

text: In a kernel APC attack, the attacker gives a legitimate program’s place in line to the attacker’s code.
label: attack-pattern

text: The crux of what makes this attack technique so important is how the technique uses this level of control to have legitimate programs run illegitimate commands.
label: safe

text: It’s easier to detect and prevent illegitimate programs (malware) from executing commands.
label: safe

text: But when legitimate programs execute illegitimate commands, it’s harder to detect and prevent: it’s not always clear whether a command is legitimate or not, and interfering with commands from legitimate programs can have significant (sometimes catastrophic) unintended consequences.
label: safe

text: And finally because of ways that kernel APC attacks are carried out, it doesn’t leave the usual fingerprints you find after an attack making detection harder still.
label: safe

text: Taken altogether, these make kernel APC attacks an effective and sophisticated technique.
label: attack-pattern

text: And while this technique alone isn’t solely responsible for the damaging power of WanaCrypt0r/WannaCry and Petya/NotPetya it is certainly an important contributing factor.
label: malware

text: Perhaps more importantly, it’s a piece of those attacks that has escaped relative notice outside of some specialized parts of the research community.
label: safe

text: New effective attack techniques that escape notice are always inviting for other copycat attackers.
label: safe

text: A good way to defend against this is to understand and be aware of the thread: forewarned is forearmed.
label: safe

text: If you want a more detailed understanding of kernel APC attacks as they occurred in WanaCrypt0r/WannaCry, two good resources are Microsoft’s MMPC blog “WannaCrypt ransomware worm targets out-of-date systems” and Countercept’s “DOUBLEPULSAR Usermode Analysis: Generic Reflective DLL Loader”.
label: identity

text: In recent years, ransomware families are often glamorized as being some of the most dangerous types of malware.
label: safe

text: They’ve certainly caused a wealth of damage to end users with some of the more prominent malware families, such as CryptoLocker, CryptoWall, TorrentLocker, and TeslaCrypt infecting millions of users overall.
label: malware

text: For readers that might be unfamiliar with ransomware, it’s a type of malware that is responsible for encrypting a user’s files with a key known only to the attackers.
label: safe

text: Examples of files that might be encrypted include financial documents, home movies, photos, or business-related files.
label: safe

text: In order to decrypt these files, the victim must provide a ransom, or payment, to the attacker, often in the form of a digital currency.
label: safe

text: While ransomware is often thought to be bullet-proof, it is certainly not always the case.
label: safe

text: In early 2015, Emnisoft identified a new family of malware named PClock.
label: identity

text: At the time, the malware was riddled with issues, specifically in the way it encrypted files.
label: safe

text: It used a simple XOR encryption routine with a static key, allowing victims to easily recover their files without paying a ransom.
label: safe

text: In August, we started detecting updated copies of PClock, which has been improved upon by the malware author.
label: TIME

text: We set out to determine if this updated version of PClock holds up to some of the more prominent families.
label: malware

text: For the sake of clarity, I will refer to this newer version of PClock as PClock2 going forward.
label: malware

text: The following sample is used for analysis:  Figure 1.
label: safe

text: PClock2
label: malware

text: analysis sample  PClock2 is written in Visual Basic.
label: SOFTWARE

text: For a copy of this file’s IDA Pro database (idb), please refer here.
label: SOFTWARE

text: When initially executed, PClock2 performs a very simple anti-analysis check where it will sleep for a random amount of time and compare the time spent sleeping against a set value.
label: malware

text: This check is essentially looking for sandbox systems where the sleep function accelerates analysis.
label: safe

text: Figure 2. Check by PClock2 for hooking of sleep function  A simple check is performed to determine if the malware is running with administrative privileges.
label: malware

text: Once completed, the malware sends the result via an HTTP POST request to a remote server.
label: safe

text: All data sent via HTTP POST requests is sent in the clear.
label: safe

text: Figure 3. HTTP POST request containing administrative privileges
label: safe

text: The ‘P0’ is statically set by the malware in the above request.
label: safe

text: The ‘1828’ represents the thread ID (TID) of the malware, while the ‘rnd’ GET variable is randomly generated.
label: safe

text: Throughout the runtime of PClock2, it makes multiple HTTP POST requests to a remote server using the same characteristics, including the ‘PO[TID]’ and the current time.
label: malware

text: Additionally, the user-agent used by the entire PClock family, including PClock2, is consistent across samples.
label: malware

text: PClock2 proceeds to copy itself with the name “winjab.exe” in the following path.
label: FILEPATH

text: While this particular sample is seen installing itself to the %ALLUSERSPROFILE% path, other samples have been witnessed using %APPDATA% instead.
label: FILEPATH

text: PClock2 also enables persistence by setting the following registry key.
label: malware

text: All instances of the entire PClock family have been found to use this particular registry key.
label: malware

text: After installation is complete, the malware makes another HTTP POST containing the various file paths it used.
label: safe

text: Figure 4. HTTP POST request containing file paths of malware  After installation, PClock2 will also set the following registry key with a value of ‘INSTALL_OK’.
label: malware

text: This particular registry key is used to hold the latest state of the malware.
label: safe

text: Other messages that might be present in this key include the following.
label: safe

text: The following registry keys are also used within the CLOCK sub-path by PClock2:  PClock2 proceeds to use the API from blockchain.info to generate a unique Bitcoin (BTC) wallet identifier, which is configured to automatically forward payments to a hardcoded wallet identifier of ‘1MRfkK134ErfbcadUSoSUCBahngCqoBKju’.
label: malware

text: The following HTTPS request accomplishes this.
label: safe

text: PClock2 will also make a request to the following blockchain.info address to determine the current value of BTC.
label: DOMAIN

text: This information is stored in the ‘\BData\B’ registry key as previously stated.
label: REGISTRYKEY

text: The malware proceeds to generate a unique key that will be used in subsequent file encryption using the following data:  This data is concatenated to form a string similar to the following:  Figure 5.
label: safe

text: Data collected to be used in formation of unique key  This data is then hashed using the SHA256 algorithm to generate a unique key.
label: safe

text: This key is stored in the ‘\CData\C’ registry key as previously stated.
label: REGISTRYKEY

text: This key is also sent via a HTTP POST request.
label: safe

text: Figure 6.
label: safe

text: HTTP POST request containing unique SHA256 key  PClock2 scans the file system of the victim in order to identify files that are to be encrypted.
label: safe

text: The following paths are ignored:  Additionally, for a list of targeted file types, please see the following link.
label: safe

text: Once files are identified, PClock will begin encrypting them, one-by-one.
label: malware

text: Unlike the original version of PClock, this variant has forgone the simple XOR encryption routine in place of using RC4.
label: malware

text: The RC4 key is generated by concatenating the SHA256 value previously generated with the path to the file being encrypted.
label: safe

text: 250dd811187959220220574a185ccf669e06c0ee3926773a7cb94750c401812cC:\Documents and Settings\Administrator\Desktop\Form1.cs
label: SHA1

text: It should be noted that PClock takes a very long time to encrypt these files.
label: malware

text: On a test sandbox, the malware took upwards of 20 minutes to complete encryption, which is less than ideal for an attacker as it gives the victim time to notice the infection and stop it.
label: TIME

text: By comparison, the latest version of the CryptoWall malware family takes roughly 1-3 minutes to complete its encryption routine.
label: malware

text: It’s also interesting to note that each time PClock2 scans a directory or encrypts a file, it makes an HTTP POST request to the C2 server.
label: Infrastucture

text: Figure 7. HTTP POST request indicating a folder is being scanned  This resulted in over 1,000 requests being made on a sandbox machine, which contained little data of interest.
label: safe

text: After it finished the encryption routine, PClock2 generates a VBScript file in the following directory:
label: malware

text: This script file contains the following commands, which will delete shadow copies on the Windows operating system.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Set UAC = CreateObject("Shell.Application") UAC.ShellExecute "vssadmin", "Delete Shadows /All /Quiet", "", "runas", 1  On Windows XP, the following dialog box appears to the victim when this script runs, making it fairly apparent that something suspicious is occurring:  Figure 8.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Dialog box that appears to victim when VBS attempts to run
label: safe

text: After running the clean up script the malware overwrites the ‘\CData\C’ registry key with a value of zero, which removes the unique SHA256 key.
label: REGISTRYKEY

text: Finally, the malware changes the victim’s wallpaper and generates a GUI instructing the victim how they can provide payment and retrieve their files.
label: safe

text: This dialogue mimics the more-capable “CryptoLocker” malware family and provides instructions in both English and Spanish.
label: malware

text: Figure 9.
label: safe

text: Ransom demand
label: safe

text: I originally wished to determine if the new version of PClock, PClock 2, included enough improvements to compete with some of the larger ransomware malware families, such as CryptoWall, TeslaCrypt, or TorrentLocker.
label: malware

text: In truth, this version has made a number of improvements, such as adding more file types to target, ignoring certain directories, and using a better encryption routine.
label: safe

text: However, a number of strong issues still plague this malware family, such as the following:  While this version is an improvement, it still lacks many of the features and stealth that are currently present in the larger ransomware families.
label: safe

text: While ransomware is a large problem for users, it’s important to realize that not all malware families are created equal.
label: safe

text: Like most things in life, malware comes in many shapes and forms, from the more elegant and robust solutions, to those that come up lacking.
label: safe

text: All PClock malware family samples are properly classified as malicious by WildFire.
label: malware

text: AutoFocus users can find more information on samples and indicators related to this attack by viewing the PClock tag.
label: malware

text: Mobile app creators are often looking for ways to monetize their software.
label: safe

text: One of the most common ways to do this is by displaying advertisements to users or by offering in-app purchases (IAPs).
label: safe

text: Mobile monetization platforms create software libraries that authors can embed into their apps to start earning money quickly.
label: safe

text: We previously highlighted the dangers of installing apps that enable IAPs using SMS messages, as these apps typically have access to all SMS messages sent to the phone.
label: safe

text: While not all SMS-based IAP applications steal user data, we recently identified that the Chinese Taomike SDK has begun capturing copies of all messages received by the phone and sending them to a Taomike controlled server.
label: location

text: Since August 1, Palo Alto Networks WildFire has captured over 18,000 Android apps that contain this library.
label: TIME

text: These apps are not hosted inside the Google Play store, but are distributed via third party distribution mechanisms in China.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Background  WildFire captures many samples of mobile malware that intercept and upload SMS messages.
label: identity

text: Most of these are created by malware authors who set up command and control (C2) servers with third party hosting providers and frequently update their locations to avoid detection.
label: safe

text: Among these malware we have found many that are created by “mobile monetization” companies who distribute apps that provide little value but have a high cost to the user.
label: safe

text: These apps are often installed by tricking users into clicking a pop-up, only to find later that a charge has appeared on their phone bill.
label: attack-pattern

text: Antivirus programs typically identify these apps as malware, the topic of this blog is something different and harder to detect.
label: safe

text: Taomike is a Chinese company that aims to become the biggest mobile advertisement solution platform in China.
label: identity

text: They provide an SDK and services to help developers display rich advertisements with a high pay rate.
label: safe

text: Taomike has not previously been associated with malicious activity, but a recent update to their software added SMS theft functionality.
label: identity

text: The apps this library is embedded in may be legitimate and have significant functionality, but their developer’s choice to use this library has put them at risk.  Technical Details:
label: safe

text: SMS Theft
label: attack-pattern

text: Not all apps that use the Taomike library steal SMS messages.
label: identity

text: Our analysis indicates that only samples that contain the embedded URL, hxxp://112.126.69.51/2c.php have this functionality.
label: URL

text: This is the URL to which the software uploads SMS messages, and the IP address belongs to the Taomike API server used by other Taomike services.
label: identity

text: We have captured around 63,000 Android apps in WildFire that include the Taomike library but only around 18,000 include the SMS theft functionality.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We believe there are different versions of the Taomike SDK and only some of them include SMS uploading behavior.
label: identity

text: Based on our data, the version that contains the SMS stealing functions is newer and was released around August 2015.
label: TIME

text: Apps that use earlier versions of the library appear to be safe.
label: safe

text: The Taomike library is called “zdtpay” and is a component of Taomike’s IAP system.  Because Android apps are required to list the permissions they need in their manifest file, we can see that this library requires both SMS and network related permissions.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The library also registers a receiver named com.zdtpay.Rf2b for both the SMS_RECEIVED and BOOT_COMPLETED actions with highest priority of 2147483647.
label: safe

text: Registered receiver for SMS_RECEIVED  The registered receiver Rf2b reads SMS messages whenever they arrive.
label: safe

text: The message body and sender phone number are collected as shown in Figure 2.  Figure 2.
label: safe

text: SMS body and sender number read
label: safe

text: If the device has just booted, it will start the service MySd2e, which then registers a receiver for Rf2b as shown in Figure 3.
label: safe

text: MySd2e Service registers receiver for Rf2b
label: safe

text: SMS information collected by the receiver is saved in a hashmap with “other” as the key and sent to a method that uploads the message to 112.126.69.51 as shown in Figure 4.
label: IPV4

text: Figure 4. Information uploaded to IP Address used by api.taomike.com
label: DOMAIN

text: All SMS messages sent to the phone are uploaded, not just those that are relevant to Taomike’s platform.
label: identity

text: Figure 5 shows a packet capture of a test message upload.
label: safe

text: The message content is “hey test msg” as circled with dashed red box.
label: safe

text: Figure 5.
label: safe

text: SMS uploaded via HTTP in pcap  The Taomike library makes contact with the following URLs, but only the “2c.php” path is used to capture SMS messages.
label: attack-pattern

text: The rest appear to be used for other parts of the IAP functionality in the library.
label: safe

text: Risks and Mitigation
label: safe

text: We have captured over 18,000 samples that contain the SMS stealing library since August 2015, meaning the number of affected users is considerable.
label: TIME

text: We expect the number of affected apps and users to increase as more developers incorporate the newer version of Taomike library.
label: identity

text: The infected apps are not limited to a single developer or third party store as many developers appear use the Taomike library.
label: identity

text: Some of the infected apps purport to contain or display adult content.
label: safe

text: We do not know how Taomike is using the stolen SMS messages, but no library should capture all messages and send them to a system outside the phone.
label: identity

text: In version 4.4 of Android (KitKat) Google began preventing apps from capturing SMS messages unless they were defined as the “default” SMS app.
label: identity

text: Users outside of China and those that only download apps from the official Google Play store are not at risk from this threat.
label: SOFTWARE

text: To protect Palo Alto Networks customers from the Taomike SMS stealer, we’ve made the following protections available:
label: identity

text: Conclusion  Even popular third party monetization platforms are not always trustworthy.
label: safe

text: When developers incorporate the libraries into their apps they need to carefully test them and monitor for any abnormal activities.
label: safe

text: Identifying monetization and advertising platforms that behave poorly and abuse their users is something that our industry must to do ensure the safety of all mobile devices and their users.
label: safe

text: Acknowledgement  We greatly appreciate the help from Rongbo Shao from Palo Alto Networks in working on the Threat Prevention signature.
label: identity

text: We would also like to thank Ryan Olson, Benjamin Small, Richar Wartell, and Chris Clark from Palo Alto networks in publishing the discovery.
label: identity

text: Related Sample Hash Values  Sign up to receive the latest news, cyber threat intelligence and research from us  Please enter your email address!  Please mark, I'm not a robot!
label: safe

text: Recently, we found email accounts from top universities across the world being sold on Taobao, the largest consumer-to-consumer (C2C) e-commerce platform in China.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Advertised uses for these accounts included registering for special accounts under software developer programs, receiving student discounts or coupons from retailers, and obtaining access to academic databases.
label: safe

text: This post describes the scope, associated risks, and implications of this activity.
label: safe

text: Our investigation began with a Chinese language search for "edu mailbox" in Taobao, which returned 99 results related to stolen university email accounts.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The most expensive account was listed at ¥2400 RMB ($390.80 USD), while the cheapest was only ¥0.98 RMB ($0.16 USD).  Figure 1: Results for Chinese language "edu mailbox" search on Taobao.
label: SOFTWARE

text: These accounts, which include an education (EDU) top-level domain email address with valid password, represent 42 of the world’s top universities, across 10 countries:
label: safe

text: The descriptions for these items proposed three main uses for buyers:
label: safe

text: 1. Registering for special accounts under software developer programs:
label: safe

text: For example, the most popular account type, which has been bought at least 569 times, was advertised as a Microsoft’s student Windows Phone 7 and 8 developer account.
label: identity

text: By using this kind of account, a user can perform a developer unlock on their Windows Phone devices without incurring a fee.
label: safe

text: Most reviews of this package were favorable, with comments like "very good to use" or "with seller’s help I can unlock my phone now."
label: safe

text: Figure 2: The most popular account type has sold at least 569 times.
label: safe

text: 2. Receiving student discounts or coupons from retailers:
label: safe

text: Some accounts advertised candidacy towards registration for student discount at retailers such as Amazon, BestBuy, Apple, and Dell.
label: identity

text: For example, the standard annual fee for Amazon Prime is $99 USD; however, with the student discount, a buyer could enjoy it for free the first six months and then renew at half price for subsequent years.
label: identity

text: Figure 3: The seller showed how to register for student discount accounts.
label: safe

text: 3. Obtaining access to academic databases:
label: safe

text: Accounts for big universities (e.g., MIT, Stanford, etc.) are mainly used to access respective library services and resources, "including research help, study spaces, print and electronic books/journals and more."
label: identity

text: Figure 4:
label: safe

text: A seller advertises how an MIT account can be used to access online library resources.
label: identity

text: We talked with some sellers through AliWangWang, an instant message (IM) system developed by Taobao for online trading.
label: SOFTWARE

text: A well-stocked seller told us that every account he sold belonged to an active student at the respective university.
label: safe

text: He claimed that once the account was sold, only the one buyer and the legitimate user would have access.
label: safe

text: He recommended not changing the account password to avoid detection by the legitimate user.
label: safe

text: Another seller offered to provide real identity information for a stolen account so the buyer could change the corresponding password and security questions.
label: safe

text: This type of account access was the most expensive and least flexible in terms of customization (i.e., username, institution, etc.).
label: safe

text: Additionally, it should be noted that there is value beyond the EDU account itself for password and security question information, in the event they are shared across other online accounts for the legitimate user.
label: safe

text: Other sellers were also able to offer customizable email accounts from a specific domain/institution.
label: safe

text: Figure 5: A seller advertising a customizable “xxx.edu” email account.
label: safe

text: In the above advertisement, the seller describes the ability to choose an account under a subdomain (academia, student, me, email, or contact) of the requested domain.
label: safe

text: The price for this custom account was only ¥27 RMB ($4.40 USD); for an extra ¥13 RMB ($2.12 USD), the buyer can request a custom username at any subdomain for the given institution.
label: safe

text: To further assess this threat, we purchased a customized, new account from a seller on Taobao.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Four hours later, we received confirmation that the custom email address "claud@student.cnri.edu" was active.
label: TIME

text: Navigating to CNRI’s webmail page, we were then able to successfully access and send an email from that account.
label: identity

text: Figure 6: Sending an email through a newly bought customized EDU account.
label: safe

text: Another noteworthy trend we observed was that some sellers provided email addresses with customizable usernames at "californiacolleges.edu".
label: DOMAIN

text: In fact, anyone can do the same by visiting the California Colleges Create an Account page.
label: identity

text: Accounts made through this site "can be used to apply [for] related memberships of Amazon Prime, Microsoft Developer, Adobe and Apple by some secret ways," one seller said.
label: identity

text: Figure 7: Using a newly created California Colleges account.
label: identity

text: As with most criminal enterprises, not all sellers on Taobao use their real identity, presenting a challenge in tracking down the individuals behind this activity.
label: SOFTWARE

text: In order to sell anything on Taobao, a seller must at least create a valid Alipay account (similar to PayPal) linked to a valid Chinese citizen ID number (similar to a U.S. Social Security number), and then associate it with a valid Chinese bank account under the same citizen ID.
label: SOFTWARE

text: However, identity theft is a global concern and the Chinese citizen ID is no exception, allowing for potential sellers to simply purchase a usable identity online.
label: attack-pattern

text: Based on our investigation, we believe that stolen accounts for these universities are actively selling on Taobao.
label: SOFTWARE

text: On August 27, we reported our findings to Taobao.
label: TIME

text: Their response was that they were addressing this issue and have already removed a number of these items, with the remainder requiring further investigation.
label: safe

text: However, this malicious seller activity may also reveal a larger scale problem within university systems.
label: safe

text: Through the types of accounts advertised on Taobao, an attacker can steal a student or staff account, assume their identity, and gain unauthorized access to standard university resources.
label: SOFTWARE

text: More sophisticated and nefarious uses include leveraging accounts in social engineering/phishing attacks or exploiting access to high-value university systems (e.g., personnel, financial, research) to steal information.
label: attack-pattern

text: Fortunately, a number of the institutions impacted by this activity have already implemented two-factor authentication for high-value resources, reducing the risk of the latter.
label: safe

text: Yet, we believe the residual risk and exposure call for further action.
label: safe

text: The following are our suggestions for discovering and mitigating risks associated with this activity:  Sign up to receive the latest news, cyber threat intelligence and research from us  Please enter your email address!
label: safe

text: This post is also available in:      日本語 (Japanese)  Today, Palo Alto Networks Unit 42 researchers are announcing details on a new high- severity vulnerability affecting the Google Android platform.
label: identity

text: Patches for this vulnerability are available as part of the September 2017 Android Security Bulletin.
label: TIME

text: This new vulnerability does NOT affect Android 8.0 Oreo, the latest version; but it does affect all prior versions of Android.
label: SOFTWARE

text: There is some malware that exploits some vectors outlined in this article, but Palo Alto Networks Unit 42 is not aware of any active attacks against this particular vulnerability at this time.
label: identity

text: Since Android 8.0 is a relatively recent release, this means that nearly all Android users should take action today and apply updates that are available to address this vulnerability.
label: SOFTWARE

text: What our researchers have found is a vulnerability that can be used to more easily enable an “overlay attack,” a type of attack that is already known on the Android platform.
label: SOFTWARE

text: This type of attack is most likely to be used to get malicious software on the user’s Android device.
label: SOFTWARE

text: This type of attack can also be used to give malicious software total control over the device.
label: safe

text: In a worst-case attack scenario, this vulnerability could be used to render the phone unusable (i.e., a “brick”) or to install any kind of malware including (but not limited to) ransomware or information stealers.
label: safe

text: In simplest terms, this vulnerability could be used to take control of devices, lock devices and steal information after it is attacked.
label: attack-pattern

text: An “overlay attack” is an attack where an attacker’s app draws a window over (or “overlays”) other windows and apps running on the device.
label: attack-pattern

text: When done successfully, this can enable an attacker to convince the user he or she is clicking one window when, in fact, he or she is actually clicking another window.
label: safe

text: In Figure 1, you can see an example where an attacker is making it appear that the user is clicking to install a patch when in fact the user is clicking to grant the Porn Droid malware full administrator permissions on the device.
label: malware

text: Figure 1: Bogus patch installer overlying malware requesting administrative permissions
label: safe

text: You can see how this attack can be used convince users to unwittingly install malware on the device.
label: safe

text: This can also be used to grant the malware full administrative privileges on the device.
label: safe

text: An overlay attack can also be used to create a denial-of-service condition on the device by raising windows on the device that don’t go away.
label: attack-pattern

text: This is precisely the type of approach attackers use with ransomware attacks on mobile devices.
label: safe

text: Of course, an overlay attack can be used to accomplish all three of these in a single attack:  Overlay attacks aren’t new; they’ve been discussed before.
label: safe

text: But until now, based on the latest research in the IEEE Security & Privacy paper, everyone has believed that malicious apps attempting to carry out overlay attacks must overcome two significant hurdles to be successful:  These are significant mitigating factors and so overlay attacks haven’t been reckoned a serious threat.
label: identity

text: However, our new Unit 42 research shows that there is a way to carry out overlay attacks where these mitigating factors don’t apply.
label: identity

text: If a malicious app were to utilize this new vulnerability, our researchers have found it could carry out an overlay attack simply by being installed on the device.
label: attack-pattern

text: In particular, this means that malicious apps from websites and app stores other than Google Play can carry out overlay attacks.
label: SOFTWARE

text: It’s important to note that apps from websites and app stores other than Google Play form a significant source of Android malware worldwide.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The particular vulnerability in question affects an Android feature known as “Toast.” “Toast” is a type of notification window that “pops” (like toast) on the screen.
label: SOFTWARE

text: “Toast” is typically used to display messages and notifications over other apps.
label: safe

text: Unlike other window types in Android, Toast doesn’t require the same permissions, and so the mitigating factors that applied to previous overlay attacks don’t apply here.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Additionally, our researchers have outlined how it’s possible to create a Toast window that overlays the entire screen, so it’s possible to use Toast to create the functional equivalent of regular app windows.
label: safe

text: In light of this latest research, the risk of overlay attacks takes on a greater significance.
label: safe

text: Fortunately, the latest version of Android is immune from these attacks “out of the box.”
label: SOFTWARE

text: However, most people who run Android run versions that are vulnerable.
label: SOFTWARE

text: This means that it’s critical for all Android users on versions before 8.0 to get updates for their devices.
label: SOFTWARE

text: You can get information on patch and update availability from your mobile carrier or handset maker.
label: safe

text: Of course, one of the best protections against malicious apps is to get your Android apps only from Google Play, as the Android Security Team aggressively screens against malicious apps and keeps them out of the store in the first place.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Mutex analysis is an often overlooked and useful tool for malware author fingerprinting, family classification, and even discovery.
label: safe

text: Far from the hypothesized "huge amount of variability" in mutex names, likely hypothesized due to the seemingly random appearance of them, practical mutex usage is embarrassingly consistent.
label: safe

text: In fact, over 15% of all collected worms share a single mutex [2gvwnqjz].
label: safe

text: This blog was sourced from the data generated by the WildFire Analytics cloud, which processes thousands of samples a day and provides insights into various characteristics and behaviors of malware worldwide.
label: SOFTWARE

text: But before we get into the details, here is a quick overview of mutexes and why they exist in the first place.
label: safe

text: The mutex is the fundamental tool for managing shared resources between multiple threads (or processes).
label: safe

text: If you think of the threads as a whole bunch of people in a meeting, all trying to talk at once, a mutex is the baton that gets passed from one person to the next so that there’s only one person talking at a time.
label: safe

text: The important thing to understand is what the mutex is really protecting.
label: safe

text: In the above example, the resource being protected isn’t the right to speak, as many might think, but rather the ability to listen.
label: safe

text: Here’s a more technical example.
label: safe

text: Lets say you want to update an Internet Explorer (IE) cookie file, adding a unique identifier for use later.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Naively, what you need to do is read the cookie file in, add your data to what you’ve read, and write the file back to disk.
label: safe

text: But what if IE is running and also updating that file?
label: SOFTWARE

text: The worst case, for you, is that both you and IE read the file at the same time but you write your edits first.
label: SOFTWARE

text: This is because IE will completely destroy your edits when it writes its new version of the file over yours.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The solution to this problem is to use a mutex to protect the integrity of the cookie file.
label: safe

text: A process that has the mutex knows that while it holds that mutex no other process will be accessing the cookie file.
label: safe

text: It can then read, tweak, and write the file without fear of any clobbering by other processes.
label: safe

text: Since each shared resource can only have a single mutex effectively protecting it, leveraging that mutex is indication that a program will be using said resource.
label: safe

text: In the cookie file example above, just referencing the mutex protecting that file indicates, with extremely high probability, that functionality to change the file exists somewhere in the program.
label: safe

text: Any given mutex, and protected functionality, can then be thought of as an independent library of sorts.
label: safe

text: Note that while the technical implementation may not expose said functionality as a normal library, such exposure is not necessary for the types of analysis performed here.
label: safe

text: That library’s usage can be analyzed in terms of who uses it.
label: safe

text: Simply put: malware writers leverage malware specific libraries and groups of like actors will reuse these core libraries when able.  The needle in a haystack problem forever plagues malware research: it’s extremely difficult to find reliable information with malware writers constantly working to undermine or eliminate that information.
label: safe

text: But, in the case of mutex analysis, the useful information pretty well slapped us in the face.
label: safe

text: As can be clearly seen, mutex 2gvwnqjz1 is strongly associated with malware.
label: safe

text: In fact, we have only seen it in malware.
label: safe

text: As is equally obvious, not all mutexes offer such dramatic insight.
label: safe

text: There are many common mutexes shared across both benign software and malware.
label: safe

text: What’s more, they don’t all share millions of uses across both sides of the fence.
label: safe

text: In cases such as these the common approach is to use sets of the data, in this case sets of mutexes, to create fingerprints of each sample and then leverage those fingerprints to extract higher confidence classification decisions.
label: safe

text: While this avenue of research is being pursued, it suffers from all the traditional challenges of big data research.
label: safe

text: In other words, it’s slow going.
label: safe

text: In parallel, and to inform better hypothesis for the fingerprint generation, research is being done to determine how far single mutex analysis can take us.
label: safe

text: The research is ongoing but the initial results are extremely promising.
label: safe

text: The number of times any single mutex is used drops rapidly from the millions of samples down to thousands and from there, even further.
label: safe

text: Tens of thousands of the mutexes have been seen in only a single sample each.
label: safe

text: This results in a few hundred thousand individual mutexes available for further analysis.
label: safe

text: What quickly becomes apparent is that a large majority of the mutexes provide no obvious means to automatically classify them as necessarily indicative of good or bad behavior.
label: safe

text: And, unfortunately, the ones, which are reasonably easy for a human to identify, are so for significantly different reasons.
label: safe

text: For example,  “autoproto_*”  -- More than 20 mutexes share that preface, offering a natural fingerprint.
label: safe

text: “global\setup_028746_mutexitem” -- Associated solely with known malware digital signers.
label: safe

text: “defined_setnocandy”  -- After reading mutex names for a few hours this just sticks out like a sore thumb.
label: TIME

text: Only the first of the examples had the mutex associated with a vast majority of malware samples.
label: safe

text: This implies that any fully automated association of a mutex to either benign or malware samples will itself require complex fingerprinting and confidence models.
label: safe

text: Full automation is always the ideal but it isn’t always necessary.
label: safe

text: With the appropriate tools it’s possible to enable a single researcher to continually review and categorize new mutexes.
label: safe

text: The initial classifications to be used are “benign”, “malware”, or “statistical”.
label: safe

text: Meaning that the mutex either itself indicates a benign or malware sample, or that the mutex alone is not enough to make a determination and the statistical ratio of benign to malware is the best it can offer.
label: safe

text: The backlog of already collected mutexes is too great for a small team of researchers to meaningfully tackle without some kind of ranking system.
label: safe

text: Luckily, the most objective piece of data collected about each mutex, how many samples were classified benign vs. malware, has all the information necessary to ensure that the researchers’ tackle the low hanging fruit first.
label: safe

text: With over hundreds of thousands of malware associations, this specific mutex is associated exclusively with the Net-worm:W32/Allaple malware family which has been around since 2006 but continues to propagate and reinvent itself through the years.
label: malware

text: Though the fact that the malware writer obviously named the mutex by rolling their face on the keyboard made it obvious before we'd done any further analysis that we’d found a unique identifier within the binaries.
label: safe

text: This malware is well documented as a powerful polymorphic worm that encrypts itself differently every time it propagates.
label: safe

text: The evasive nature of this malware family leads to a different file hash, import hash, and only a 20% average SSDeep hash overlap between the samples.
label: tools

text: But because the mutex name is set at compile time, the mutex itself offers a common thread between all of the samples we collected and analyzed.
label: safe

text: However, this particular mutex was associated with only a recent subset of the Allaple family.
label: malware

text: Unlike many other avenues of research and classification, mutex name based associations provides an almost trivial means of uniquely identifying common code blocks and thereby malware families.
label: safe

text: The first thing our researchers noticed was the similarity between this mutex name and the previous one.
label: safe

text: While programmatic analysis would have a hard time associating the two, it's obvious to a human that the same face rolling technique was used to name this mutex.
label: safe

text: The author simply rolled around a bit more.
label: safe

text: Quick follow up analysis revealed that this mutex was also associated with the Allaple malware family.
label: malware

text: More interestingly, it was another, non-overlapping, subset of the Allaple family.
label: malware

text: Several hypotheses followed directly from this observation.
label: safe

text: Absolute proof for a few of these hypotheses may never be realized.
label: safe

text: However, and lucky for us, the malware author was arrested in 2010 so several of the hypothesis can be verified.
label: TIME

text: The first is very likely due to the similarities present in the order of keys hit.
label: safe

text: Both begin with “jhd”.
label: safe

text: “jh” itself is more common than would be expected given that, with fingers on the home row, it requires the right index finger to move and press another key before any other key is struck.
label: safe

text: And “jh” is always followed by a key from the left side of the keyboard.
label: safe

text: These unique consistencies make it extremely improbable that two different people named these mutexes.
label: safe

text: The second mutex appears to be a concerted effort to make the mutex seem “more random” than the first.
label: safe

text: It's immediately obvious that the author didn't move his fingers/hands much while typing the first.
label: safe

text: It’s obvious enough that the author likely noticed it when reworking this section of code.
label: safe

text: It's highly improbable that one would see the second mutex and make a concerted effort to make it appear “less random”.
label: safe

text: And, as can be quickly verified by searching through standard virus detection logs, the mutexes did in fact appear in the hypothesized order.
label: safe

text: The third is likely due to the lack of overlap between mutex names.
label: safe

text: However, the research necessary to conclusively prove this hypothesis would be very time consuming and provide little other benefit.
label: safe

text: The fourth is likely due to the mutexes only appearing in a single malware family.
label: safe

text: If this functionality were available in some more open source setting, and was of even moderate quality, we would expect to see it used in other malware families as well.
label: safe

text: As this functionality has not migrated outside the Allaple family, either the quality of the code is bad (see: face rolling), or it's simply not available to other malware developers.  The fifth is very likely as a change to the specific functionality these mutexes protect, with every change to any functionality, is simply not a practical method of development.
label: malware

text: And indeed, as with the second hypothesis, standard virus detection logs prove that each of these mutexes do span multiple variants of the worm.
label: safe

text: Mutex names provide a window into the entire development process and timeline for malware.
label: safe

text: Idiosyncrasies of the malware author become apparent, the evolution can be traced, the availability or quality of code deduced, and reuse of functionality made clear with a simple mutex.
label: safe

text: No other currently used method of analysis offers such a personal view into malware development.
label: safe

text: Mutex name analysis as a whole offers a unique look into the results of any sample classification system and the malware therein.
label: safe

text: While the research may never result in a fully automated decision system, it has been proven that researchers employing a hybrid approach to analysis will be able to provide critical and timely information to support the continual improvement of the classification system as a whole.
label: safe

text: From edge case to systematic misclassifications, mutex usage is even more generally the canary in a coal mine than was previously realized.  While tedious and time consuming, combing through mutex names did come with more than a few good laughs.
label: safe

text: After nearly as much debate as some of the real research, we’ve whittled the list down to our favorites (For the curious, these are all malware mutexes).
label: safe

text: Enjoy.
label: safe

label: safe

text: Development environments don’t have spell check but, maybe they should.
label: safe

text: senna spy rock in rio 2001 virus - Subtlety.
label: malware

text: Overwhelming.
label: safe

text: There were many variations on this one, Senna’s obviously proud of his work.
label: identity

text: chinese-hacker-2 - We’re not sure which is worse: that this is a legitimate signature or a sad frame job.
label: safe

text: Either way, somebody needs their computer privileges revoked.
label: safe

text: mutexpolesskayaglush*.*svchost.comexefile\shell\open\command %1 %*@ - Putting shell code in a mutex name is right on the border of brilliant and insane.
label: safe

text: We’ll leave that determination to the reader.
label: safe

text: mr_coolface - Really, not so much, no.
label: safe

label: safe

label: safe

text: In-App Purchase (IAP) has become a popular way to sell services and virtual items through mobile applications.
label: safe

text: In the Android ecosystem, in addition to the official IAP service by Google, there are many third-party IAP Software Development Kits (SDKs) spread around the world.
label: identity

text: Some of these third-party SDKs provide IAP services based on existing online payment platforms.
label: safe

text: However, an increasingly popular method uses premium SMS.
label: safe

text: A primary reason for the popularity of SMS-based IAP is that it does not require Internet connectivity, just cell service.
label: safe

text: While this is more convenient for both users and developers, there are significant security concerns with using SMS-based IAP on Android.
label: SOFTWARE

text: These concerns are detailed below.
label: safe

text: Installing an Android app with SMS-based IAP is almost equivalent to installing an “SMS manager” (or even a “contacts manager”) app on the phone.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The reason is because most SMS-based IAP SDKs include comprehensive functionalities to monitor, manage, and even intercept a user’s SMS communication silently in the background, without any user interaction or knowledge.
label: safe

text: This is a critical point: these SMS-based IAPs are able to independently send, receive, or block any SMS to/from any cellphone on which they are installed, without the user having any idea this is occurring.
label: safe

text: This can include receiving instructions from a cloud server under the control of the SDK author.
label: safe

text: Palo Alto Networks Wildfire, through custom SMS blocking policies, recently discovered eight different SMS-based IAP SDKs with this abusive functionality.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Further investigation shows that these SDKs have been used in at least 25 different Android games in two third-party app markets, JoloPlay and Wanyx.
label: SOFTWARE

text: 17 of the top 50 games in JoloPlay contain at least one of these IAP SDKs.
label: SOFTWARE

text: According to JoloPlay’s website, these 17 games have been downloaded and installed more than 1.7 million times.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Most of them are pirated or repackaged from famous Android games, such as Plants vs. Zombies 2, Jewels Maze, Fishing Joy, and Where's My Water.
label: SOFTWARE

text: According to Wanyx’s website, 12 of the 50 games in Wanyx’s suggested games column contain the discussed IAP SDKs.
label: identity

text: In Wildfire, we classify apps using these IAP SDKs as Potentially Unwanted Applications (PUA).
label: SOFTWARE

text: The reason they are not marked as malware is because all SDKs require user interaction when making a purchase (e.g. user clicks on the agreement).  However, these IAP SDKs are very dangerous to users because of what they are doing with a user’s SMS without his or her knowledge.
label: safe

text: Below are the details of eight SMS-based IAP SDKs discovered by Wildfire:
label: SOFTWARE

text: All of the identified IAP SDKs use premium SMS to provide the IAP service.
label: safe

text: They implement code that will send SMS to pre-defined premium numbers (Figure 1).
label: safe

text: This code implementation is also abstracted in an interface for developers.
label: safe

text: However, in addition to sending, all of these IAP SDKs also implement a BroadcastReceiver and register it for SMS_RECEIVED actions (Figure 2).  In addition, Umpay, WiPay, and NgstreamPay will also register a ContentObserver to monitor all changes in an SMS inbox (Figure 3).
label: SOFTWARE

text: After an SMS is received, these receivers and observers will check the originating number and/or message body, and block the SMS by some policies (Figure 3 and Figure 4).
label: safe

text: For example, in Figure 4, the policy is defined as deleting SMS satisfying two conditions at the same time:  1. Message comes from the phone number “+8610658008” or “10658008”  2.
label: safe

text: The message body contains the term “You will use” (translated from Chinese shown in Figure 4).
label: safe

text: Some of these policies are hard-coded in the SDKs, e.g., in UmPay; but others are pre-fetched from cloud servers that are operated by the SDKs’ providers (Figure 5).
label: SOFTWARE

text: Again, all the functions mentioned above run silently in the background.
label: safe

text: Except for LinkSMSPayment, all the IAP SDKs listed in this post do not notify the user in any way that they are taking actions against the user’s daily SMS communication.
label: safe

text: Users have no idea if an SMS was blocked or if it was delivered.
label: safe

text: All of the IAP SDKs in this post target Chinese users.
label: safe

text: Both SMS sending and SMS blocking will only affect Android phones with a valid Chinese mobile phone number.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Some of them will even check which SIM operator a user is using (Figure 6).
label: safe

text: An interesting observation is that half of these IAP SDKs implement the send and block SMS functions in separate codes.
label: safe

text: More specifically, the code was separated into two parts.
label: safe

text: One piece is embedded into Android apps or games for developers as a part of the source code.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The other piece is included separately in the assets directory in APK files, and will be invoked by Java reflection in runtime (Figure 7).
label: safe

text: For example, JoloPay, WiPay, TPADPay and EgamePay follow this design exactly.
label: SOFTWARE

text: AstepPay implements both sending and blocking in the “assets/astep.bin” file.
label: SOFTWARE

text: This separation of functions may be intended to avoid detection by security products.
label: safe

text: SMS should not be used in payment or authentication for e-finance transactions.
label: safe

text: On the existing Android platforms it is very easy for any installed apps to send, intercept, or even forward SMS messages in background without any user knowledge or interaction.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Previous attack cases, such as Zitmo and Cardbuyer, showed the risk of using SMS for payment authentication.
label: malware

text: For instance:  To improve the security of IAP, some payment platforms try to add a verification step in order to confirm an SMS was really sent by the user, for example, it will ask the user to reply with certain text that was sent to a phone number specified by the user.
label: safe

text: However, two months ago, WildFire discovered a new Android malware, Cardbuyer, that circumvents this verification technique.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Cardbuyer targets 11 different online payment platforms, as well as stolen prepaid cards, by parsing their verification SMS and automatically replying.
label: malware

text: The good news is this technique might be partially mitigated in Android KitKat (version 4.4), where Google introduced a security enhancement around SMS security.
label: identity

text: A user can set a system-wide default SMS app as the only app with permission to send and receive SMS.
label: safe

text: However, other installed apps are still allowed to receive SMS and upload the content via Internet.
label: safe

text: But as of June 4, 2014, only 13.6% of worldwide users had installed Android 4.4 or above.
label: TIME

text: This means more than 86% of Android users do not benefit from this enhancement and are vulnerable.
label: SOFTWARE

text: However, Palo Alto Networks users are protected from these PUAs by subscribing to WildFire and GlobalProtect services.
label: SOFTWARE

text: SMS-based IAP SDKs have become a gray zone that needs close attention.
label: safe

text: Because of convenience and popularity, SMS-based IAP will likely continue to spread and increase in worldwide use.
label: safe

text: However, users need to be protected from PUAs and malware that abuses the SMS-based IAP.
label: safe

text: Also, developers need to be aware that SMS cannot meet security requirements (e.g. authentication) during the payment transactions.
label: safe

text: We would like to thank Kyle Sanders for his contribution to this work.
label: identity

text: This post is also available in:      日本語 (Japanese)  Palo Alto Networks Unit 42
label: identity

text: used the AutoFocus threat intelligence service to identify a series of phishing attacks against Japanese organizations.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Using AutoFocus to quickly search and correlate artifacts across the collective set of WildFire and other Palo Alto Networks threat intelligence, we were able to associate the attacks with the group publicly known as “DragonOK.”
label: malware

text: [1] These attacks took place between January and March of 2015.
label: TIME

text: DragonOK has previously targeted Japanese high-tech and manufacturing firms, but we’ve identified a new backdoor malware, named “FormerFirstRAT,” deployed by these attackers.
label: threat-actor

text: See the “Malware Details” section for analysis of the three RATs and two additional backdoors deployed in this persistent attack campaign.
label: safe

text: This campaign involved five separate phishing attacks, each carrying a different variant of Sysget malware, also known as HelloBridge.
label: attack-pattern

text: The malware was included as an attachment intended to trick the user into opening the malware.
label: attack-pattern

text: This included altering the icon of the executable to appear as other file types (Figure 1) as well as decoy documents to trick users into thinking they had opened a legitimate file.
label: safe

text: Figure 1. Icons used by malicious Sysget attachments.
label: malware

text: All of the Sysget files used in this campaign communicate with a single command and control (C2) server, hosted at biosnews[.]info.
label: DOMAIN

text: Sysget communicates with this server using the HTTP protocol; see the Malware Details section for specifics of the command and control traffic.
label: malware

text: All five phishing campaigns targeted a Japanese manufacturing firm over the course of two months, but the final campaign also targeted a separate Japanese high-tech organization.
label: attack-pattern

text: (Figure 2)
label: safe

text: Five Sysget samples used to target two Japanese organizations.
label: identity

text: Four of the five Sysget variants included a form of decoy document to trick users into believing they had opened a legitimate file rather than malware.
label: malware

text: Two of the executables used decoy documents that included information about obituaries.
label: safe

text: Figure 3 shows a GIF file containing an obituary notice for a woman, while Figure 4 shows a Microsoft Word document containing the obituary of a man.

text: Figure 3. Japanese decoy document containing an obituary notice for a woman.

label: malware

text: During analysis of this threat, we identified five additional backdoor tools hosted on biosnews[.]info which may be downloaded by the Sysget variants once the attackers have established a foothold.
label: DOMAIN

text: Three of the backdoors, NFlog, PoisonIvy, and NewCT have previously been publicly associated with DragonOK.
label: malware

text: Additionally, the actors have now added the popular PlugX backdoor to their toolkit.
label: malware

text: An additional backdoor appears to be a new, custom-built tool, which we have not previously associated with DragonOK or any other attack group.
label: threat-actor

text: We’ve named this tool “FormerFirstRAT” as it appears to be the names used by the developers to refer to their creations.

text: This post is also available in:      日本語 (Japanese)  Beginning on Jan. 14, 2022, reports began emerging about a series of attacks targeting numerous Ukrainian government websites.
label: identity

text: As a result of these attacks, numerous government websites were found to be either defaced or inaccessible.
label: safe

text: A day later, public reporting outlined new malware called WhisperGate that originally was observed on Jan. 13, 2022.
label: TIME

text: This malware disables Windows Defender Threat Protection, is destructive in nature and was discovered to have targeted multiple organizations in Ukraine.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Microsoft has publicly attributed the use of this custom malware to a threat actor they refer to as DEV-0586.
label: threat-actor

text: Though both attacks have targeted Ukrainian organizations, the two threats have so far been implemented in separate situations.
label: identity

text: As a result of these events, Palo Alto Networks researchers took immediate action to ensure that customers anywhere in the world can be appropriately protected against these reported threats, however they may be exploited.
label: identity

text: These attacks ultimately resulted in the investigation of the following two threats:  Palo Alto Networks customers can use Xpanse or Threat Prevention for the Next-Generation Firewall to identify vulnerable and/or internet-facing instances of OctoberCMS.
label: identity

text: Protections against WhisperGate malware have been included in Cortex XDR, as well as in the WildFire and Advanced URL Filtering subscriptions for the Next-Generation Firewall.
label: SOFTWARE

text: There is a Cortex XSOAR pack available to assist with detecting and mitigating both threats.
label: SOFTWARE

text: CVE-2021-32648 Vulnerability WhisperGate Malware Family Mitigation Actions Hunting for WhisperGate Conclusion Additional Resources
label: malware

text: The CVE-2021-32648 vulnerability lies within the OctoberCMS platform prior to version 1.0.472 and results in an attacker gaining access to any account via a specially crafted account password reset request.
label: vulnerability

text: This vulnerability is believed to have allowed threat actors to gain access to the underlying websites leveraged by the Ukraine government.
label: identity

text: Once the vulnerability was discovered, Palo Alto Networks threat researchers quickly began reverse-engineering the patch that remediated this vulnerability and were able to produce a working proof of concept (PoC) in a very short time.
label: identity

text: Later that day, a public PoC surfaced, allowing organizations to better understand this vulnerability and how it is exploited.
label: TIME

text: Using our PoC, we created the following demonstration video of how a malicious actor would exploit the CVE-2021-32648 vulnerability, log into the compromised OctoberCMS account and to deface a web page hosted by the server:
label: vulnerability

text: To determine how this vulnerability was exploited, we analyzed the patch that developers added to OctoberCMS version 1.0.472 to mitigate the CVE-2021-32648 vulnerability.
label: vulnerability

text: We discovered that the vulnerable code existed in the Auth/Models/User.php file within the October Rain library of OctoberCMS.
label: FILEPATH

text: The code that exposes this vulnerability is within a function named checkResetPasswordCode, specifically, line 281 in User.php.
label: FILEPATH

text: The following line of code attempts to validate the inbound password reset request by comparing the reset code submitted within the HTTP request with the reset code generated by OctoberCMS during a legitimate reset process:  To exploit this vulnerability, the actor would simply supply a boolean true value as the reset code within a custom-crafted HTTP request to reset the password of an account.
label: SOFTWARE

text: By supplying the boolean true, the comparison between boolean true and the reset code string results in a boolean true, even though the two variables have different types.
label: safe

text: This effectively validates the actor’s inbound password reset request, which allows the actor to then change the password  To fix this vulnerability in version 1.0.472, the OctoberCMS developer changed the line of code above to use === instead of == when comparing the values of the reset code provided by the user via an HTTP POST request.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The difference between === and == involves the === comparing the value and type of value of the variable, not just the value, as happens when using ==.
label: safe

text: To demonstrate the difference, the following two commands run PHP code to show that a comparison of the string code with boolean true using == results in a boolean true, while the same comparison using === results in a boolean false:  As a result of the analysis of the CVE-2021-32648 vulnerability, various product protections were created or enhanced.
label: vulnerability

text: More information about these protections can be found within the Mitigation Actions section of the briefing.
label: safe

text: First observed by Microsoft on Jan. 13, 2022, WhisperGate malware is computer network attack (CNA) malware aimed at deleting Microsoft Windows Defender and corrupting files on the target.
label: identity

text: It consists of two samples: One appears as ransomware while the other is a beaconing implant used to deliver an in-memory Microsoft Intermediate Language (MSIL) payload.
label: identity

text: The in-memory code uses Living Off the Land Binaries (LOLBINs) to evade detection and also performs anti-analysis techniques, as it will fail to detonate when certain monitoring tools exist.
label: tools

text: At the time of writing, there are two known samples identified as WhisperGate: Stage1.exe and Stage2.exe.
label: malware

text: Stage1.exe purports to be ransomware, as it overwrites the target’s master boot record with 512 bytes and upon reboot displays the following ransom note:  Stage2.exe is a beaconing implant that performs an HTTPS connection to download a JPG file hosted on Discord’s content delivery network (CDN).
label: FILEPATH

text: Discord’s CDN is a user-created service that allows users to host attachments and is not malicious.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The hosted file is retrieved from the following URL:  hxxps://cdn.discordapp[.]com/attachments/928503440139771947/930108637681184768/Tbopbh.jpg
label: URL

text: File Tbopbh.jpg is the malicious payload that is in-memory loaded and kicks off the destructive capabilities.
label: FILEPATH

text: The following patterns of activities are associated with this payload:  1. File InstallUtil.exe is copied to the host’s %TEMP% directory, e.g. C:\Users\[USERNAME]\AppData\Local\Temp.
label: FILEPATH

text: This file is a legitimate Microsoft Windows binary.
label: identity

text: Two instances of PowerShell are spawned with an encoded command to sleep for 10 seconds, e.g. C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe" -enc UwB0AGEAcgB0AC0AUwBsAGUAZQBwACAALQBzACAAMQAwAA== 3.
label: FILEPATH

text: A Visual Basic Script (VBS) is created in C:\Users\[USERNAME]\AppData\Local\Temp named: Nmddfrqqrbyjeygggda.vbs  4. Process wscript.exe is used to execute the VBS script in step 3.
label: FILEPATH

text: The VBS script is used to call PowerShell to set Windows Defender exclusion path to C:\ e.g. C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe" Set-MpPreference -ExclusionPath 'C:\'  5. AdvancedRun.exe is created and written to the C:\Users\[USERNAME]\AppData\Local\Temp directory.  6.
label: FILEPATH

text: AdvancedRun.exe is used to execute PowerShell.exe to delete and stop Windows Defender.
label: FILEPATH

text: The following command parameters are passed to AdvancedRun:  "C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe" /WindowState 0 /CommandLine "rmdir 'C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows Defender' -Recurse" /StartDirectory "" /RunAs 8 /Run  "C:\Users\USERNAME]AppData\Local\Temp\AdvancedRun.exe" /EXEFilename "C:\Windows\System32\sc.exe" /WindowState 0 /CommandLine "stop WinDefend" /StartDirectory "" /RunAs 8 /Run  7.
label: FILEPATH

text: PowerShell process used to delete Windows Defender, e.g. C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe rmdir 'C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows Defender' -Recurse  8. File InstallUtil.exe running from C:\Users\[USERNAME]\AppData\Local\Temp directory.
label: tools

text: The in-memory payload (Tbopbh.jpg) is running within the context of the InstallUtil.exe process  9. Multiple instances of cmd.exe calling Ping.exe to delete file InstallUtil.exe, e.g. cmd.exe /min /C ping 111.111.111[.]111 -n 5 -w 10 > Nul & Del /f /q %TEMP%\InstallUtil.exe  10. File AdvancedRun.exe is deleted from the C:\Users\[USERNAME]\AppData\Local\Temp directory by the stage2.exe binary.  11. ICMP traffic to host: 111.111.111[.]111  12.
label: malware

text: All files and directories, including those on mounted USB drives, excluding the floppy drive (A:) are targeted.
label: FILEPATH

text: The following file extensions are overwritten with a one-byte value of 0xCC.
label: safe

text: 13. Targeted files greater than one megabyte are truncated to one megabyte when overwritten.
label: safe

text: 14. Virus & Threat protection is no longer available from Windows Security.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Organizations running OctoberCMS prior to Build 472 and v1.1.5 are encouraged to update to the latest version.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Additionally, in order for this vulnerability to be exploited, the web server must be running PHP below 7.4.
label: SOFTWARE
