label: threat-actor

text: On Saturday, Microsoft disclosed a critical vulnerability in Internet Explorer, CVE-2014-1776, affecting Internet Explorer versions 6 through 11.
label: TIME

text: The vulnerability exists in the way that Internet Explorer accesses an object in memory that has been deleted or has not been properly allocated.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The vulnerability allows an attacker to execute arbitrary code in the context of the current user within Internet Explorer.
label: attack-pattern

text: This could be exploited with drive-by downloads or watering-hole attacks, and has been observed being used in attacks in the wild.
label: attack-pattern

text: The exploit code used in these attacks only targets IE versions 9, 10 and 11, but earlier versions are still vulnerable.
label: SOFTWARE

text: As of this writing, Microsoft has not stated when a patch for the vulnerability will be available, but in its advisory the company provided multiple work-arounds.
label: identity

text: Additionally, Windows XP systems running IE 6, 7 and 8 are also vulnerable, but will not receive a patch, as Microsoft no longer supports them.
label: identity

text: It is always important to view this type of critical vulnerability in the larger context of the threat landscape.
label: safe

text: Attackers identify thousands of critical vulnerabilities in commonly used software each year, such as Internet Explorer.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Once identified, they then craft a seemingly endless supply of exploits that leverage these vulnerabilities to deliver unknown malware and compromise networks and endpoints.
label: safe

text: Palo Alto Networks enterprise security platform is focused on providing an integrated approach to detecting and preventing advanced threats across each step in the attack kill-chain.
label: identity

text: Bringing together our next-generation firewall – again a Gartner Magic Quadrant Leader – Threat Prevention, URL Filtering, WildFire, and Cyvera’s ability to prevent exploitation of unknown vulnerabilities will allow us to continue offering ground-breaking protection for our customers’ networks and endpoints, including Windows XP clients.
label: SOFTWARE

text: This post is also available in:      日本語 (Japanese)  In March 2020 Microsoft released a security advisory, ADV200005 | Microsoft Guidance for Disabling SMBv3 Compression, for a new remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability.
label: TIME

text: Shortly after this advisory was released, Microsoft issued an out-of-band patch to protect affected users from CVE-2020-0796.
label: vulnerability

text: An out-of-band patch is typically released outside of the expected update period for a vendor.
label: safe

text: In this particular case, Microsoft is known to release updates on Patch Tuesday, which was two days prior to this out-of-band update.
label: SOFTWARE

text: This vulnerability exists within the Microsoft Server Message Block 3.0 (SMBv3), specifically regarding malformed compression headers.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Compression headers are a feature that was added to SMBv3 negotiate context request packets in May 2019.
label: TIME

text: For successful unauthenticated exploitation an attacker would need to craft a SMBv3 packet that contains the malformed compression header to a vulnerable SMBv3 Server.
label: attack-pattern

text: For SMBv3 clients would require enticing a user to connect to a compromised SMBv3 server that they control.
label: SOFTWARE

text: At the time of release, Microsoft affirmed that they had not yet seen the vulnerability exploited in the wild (ITW).
label: identity

text: This vulnerability only affects SMBv3 and the following builds of the Microsoft Windows operating system (OS):  Review the workaround guidance provided by the Microsoft Security Vulnerability.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Upgrade Cortex XDR and Traps agents for protection against this vulnerability regardless of whether your systems have installed the relevant security update from Microsoft.
label: SOFTWARE

text: For client mitigation, recommend creating an outbound firewall rule to block SMB outbound on public and private interfaces.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Palo Alto Networks Cortex XDR and Traps provide protection against this vulnerability regardless of whether they are running on an unpatched instance of Microsoft Windows 10.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Additionally, Palo Alto Networks offers multiple, additional complementary protections for this exploit.
label: identity

text: As a member of the Microsoft Active Protections Program (MAPP) program, Palo Alto Networks received early details of the vulnerability, providing greater understanding of the threat, which helps us implement strong product coverage.
label: identity

text: As always, we recommend keeping your Microsoft products up to date with the latest patches to mitigate this vulnerability.
label: identity

text: Palo Alto Networks will update this Threat Brief with new information and recommendations as they become available.
label: identity

text: This post is also available in:      日本語 (Japanese)  Around 6:00 am PST on September 24, the details of a vulnerability in the widely used Bourne Again Shell (Bash) were disclosed by multiple Linux vendors.
label: TIME

text: The vulnerability, assigned CVE-2014-6271 by Mitre, was originally discovered by Stephane Chazelas, a Unix and Linux network and telecom administrator and IT manager at UK robotics company SeeByte, Ltd.
label: identity

text: While this vulnerability didn’t come with quite the fanfare or a catchy name like Heartbleed, the security community quickly dubbed it “Shellshock.”
label: vulnerability

text: Bash is present in most Linux and Unix distributions as well as Apple’s Mac OS X, and there’s a good chance anyone reading this has a system they need to patch.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Palo Alto Networks initiated an emergency IPS content release to detect this vulnerability last night with Signature ID: 36729 "Bash Remote Code Execution Vulnerability.”
label: identity

text: All versions of PAN-OS and Panorama include the vulnerable version of Bash, but we’ve determined the issue is only exploitable by authenticated users.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Normal PAN-OS maintenance release updates will provide a fix for the vulnerability.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We have posted the advisory on our product vulnerability page.
label: safe

text: Read on for more details.
label: safe

text: Vulnerability Details  CVE-2014-6271 exists in all versions of Bash and is related to how environment variables are processed when the shell starts up.
label: vulnerability

text: Environment variables are used by shell software to store pieces of information like the location of the user’s home directory.
label: safe

text: In addition to storing variables, Bash allows for storing shell functions in variables that users can call later.
label: SOFTWARE

text: It’s in parsing these functions that the new Bash vulnerability exists, as the shell mistakenly executes code that is added after a function definition.
label: tools

text: Here’s an example:  $ env x='() { :;}; echo vulnerable'
label: safe

text: bash -c "echo this is a test"
label: safe

text: vulnerable  this is a test
label: safe

text: Bash should stop processing the environment variable “x” after the closing semicolon for the function, but instead continues to process “echo vulnerable”.
label: safe

text: At first glance, this might not seem too dangerous as executing commands is Bash’s primary function, but it’s important to understand that many other programs use Bash to process commands.
label: SOFTWARE

text: While these two scenarios are currently the most-likely vectors for exploiting this vulnerability, it’s likely that other services use Bash in a network-exploitable way.
label: safe

text: The only way to fully prevent exploitation is to upgrade Bash on the system to a non-vulnerable version.  Impact
label: safe

text: The good news is that this vulnerability was disclosed responsibly and patches are available for most platforms on the day of the public disclosure.
label: safe

text: The bad news is that this vulnerability is going to have a very long tail.
label: safe

text: Bash is the default shell for the most-popular Linux variants and every version of the software stretching back over two decades is vulnerable.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Well-maintained systems will be patched today, but that dusty old system in the networking closet might never get the update.
label: safe

text: Additionally, network devices, embedded systems and Internet-connected devices (like IP Cameras) often run Linux and could be vulnerable.
label: safe

text: Fortunately, not every system is remotely exploitable simply because it’s running Bash, it also needs to be running an application which makes Bash accessible over the network.
label: tools

text: As described above, the most-common exploit scenario seems like it will be web servers running Apache and using CGI scripts.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Web servers are great resources for attackers.
label: safe

text: They can be used to:  These are all likely outcomes from mass scanning of the Internet for vulnerable hosts, which are already underway.
label: safe

text: Recommendations  Sign up to receive the latest news, cyber threat intelligence and research from us  Please enter your email address!
label: safe

text: On January 2, 2017, one Bitcoin was worth US $985.56.
label: TIME

text: By October 16, 2017, that same Bitcoin was worth US $ 5,707.40: a 579% increase in value in ten and a half months.
label: TIME

text: By comparison, Ethereum has gone from US $8.15 per ether on January 2, 2017 to US $342.83 per ether on October 16, 2017: a jump of 4,206%.  Cryptocurrencies are big money these days and seemingly getting bigger by the day.  And if we’ve learned one thing about cybercriminals, they follow the money.
label: TIME

text: So, it’s not surprising to see that cybercrime is turning its attention to cryptocurrencies.
label: safe

text: In our latest research, “Unauthorized Coin Mining in the Browser”, Unit 42 researchers show how cybercriminals have taken an old tactic, hijacking web browsers without the users consent or knowledge (commonly called a “drive -by attack”), and adapted it to make money in the increasingly lucrative cryptocurrencies markets.
label: attack-pattern

text: Before, drive-by attacks focused on abusing a browser’s legitimate download capabilities to download malware onto the victim’s system without their consent or knowledge.
label: attack-pattern

text: These new drive-by attacks focus on hijacking the computational resources of the victim’s computer to “mine” cryptocurrency on behalf of the attackers.
label: attack-pattern

text: The focus of these attacks is to use the victim’s web browser to access the computational resources of their system.
label: safe

text: The attackers accomplish this through abuse of a legitimate tool by placing it on malicious or compromised websites and running it in the victim’s browser without his or her consent or knowledge when they visit the site.
label: safe

text: The tool is designed to “mine” cryptocurrencies, that is it earns credit in the cryptocurrency in exchange for computing power that is used to power the cryptocurrencies’ digital infrastructure.
label: safe

text: This tool has a legitimate use: sites can and do notify users that they’re using the site visitors’ resources in this way to support the site, typically as a substitute for ads on the site.
label: safe

text: But in this case, the attacker actually gets the credit that the victim’s computational resources earns without the visitors’ consent or knowledge making it a malicious attack.
label: safe

text: Put simply, the net result is that the victim’s computer slows down (sometimes significantly) while on the malicious or compromised website.
label: safe

text: And while the computer is impacted like this, the attacker is earning money.
label: safe

text: The attacker steals the victims computing resources and translates it into a cryptocurrency like Bitcoin.
label: SOFTWARE

text: This new kind of attack tells us that at least some cybercriminals are starting to view theft of victim’s computing power to translate into cryptocurrencies as a better business proposition than the traditional practice of loading malware on the victim’s system through drive-by downloads.
label: safe

text: And our research shows that this isn’t an isolated event.
label: safe

text: Our researchers analyzed over 1,000 of sites and what they found was very telling.
label: safe

text: The good news is that these attacks are more like denial of service attacks: they don’t do lasting harm to your system and they end when you leave the site.  The bad news is that these are harder to defend against than typical drive-by download attacks.
label: safe

text: Where drive-by download attacks usually exploit unpatched vulnerabilities, the root of these attacks is that they abuse otherwise legitimate functionality: you can’t prevent them by being fully patched.
label: safe

text: Security products that take a comprehensive, layered approach can help prevent these attacks.
label: safe

text: And if you think your system is being affected by one of these attacks, you can, in most cases, end the attack by either leaving the site or closing the browser.
label: safe

text: Most of all, this latest development shows how a changing economic landscape in turn changes the cybercrime landscape.
label: safe

text: Loading malware through drive-by downloads is so 2012: in 2017 it’s about drive-by mining attacks to earn cryptocurrencies.
label: TIME

text: This post is also available in:      日本語 (Japanese)  This Unit 42 blog provides an update on the threat situation surrounding the WanaCrypt0r ransomware attacks and how the attack propagates.
label: identity

text: Initial reports said that the WanaCrypt0r attack began as part of a spam/phishing campaign.
label: malware

text: Unit 42 and other researchers have concluded that these reports are not substantiated.
label: identity

text: While the initial attack vector for these attacks is unknown, it is certain that the spread of the ransomware occurs through active exploitation of the ETERNALBLUE vulnerability (CVE-2017-0144) in Microsoft Windows.
label: vulnerability

text: Patches for this vulnerability for all supported versions of Windows have been available since March 2017.
label: TIME

text: On Friday May 12, 2017, Microsoft took the extraordinary step of releasing patches for out-of-support versions of Windows to help protect against these attacks.
label: TIME

text: As the attack leverages this Microsoft vulnerability, the most appropriate first step to take against the attack is to apply the patches.
label: identity

text: Unit 42 researchers have confirmed that the patch is effective against the WanaCrypt0r Ransomware attacks.
label: identity

text: In addition, Palo Alto Networks, and other vendors, including our fellow members of the Cyber Threat Alliance, have released additional protections that help prevent the spread of the WanaCrypt0r ransomware.
label: malware

text: For information on Palo Alto Networks protections, please see our posting Palo Alto Networks Protections Against WanaCrypt0r Ransomware Attacks.
label: identity

text: As with all ransomware attacks, Palo Alto Networks and Unit 42 recommends that anyone affected NOT pay the ransom.
label: identity

text: Unit 42 is not aware of any reports where paying the ransom to the WanaCrypt0r attackers has resulted in the recovery of data.
label: identity

text: In addition, Unit 42 research has shown that very few have attempted to pay the ransom.
label: identity

text: Unit 42 is following this situation very closely and will update this blog with any new information as it becomes available.
label: identity

text: WanaCrypt0r is a global ransomware attack that emerged on Friday, May 12, 2017.
label: malware

text: It immediately gained broad media attention, due to its destructive nature, how widespread it was, and multiple high profile victims.
label: safe

text: This attack uses the version 2.0 of this ransomware.
label: safe

text: WanaCrypt0r v 1.0 was first reported a few months ago but did not include the worm capability associated with this attack.
label: malware

text: Reports quickly emerged that this attack was effective due to the presence of code exploiting a vulnerability (CVE-2017-0144) in Microsoft Windows (code named: ETERNALBLUE) that was released as part of the Equation Group dump by the Shadow Brokers in their fifth leak on April 14, 2017.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Microsoft patched this vulnerability as part of the March 2017 Monthly Security Update Release by Microsoft Security Bulletin MS17-010.
label: identity

text: This is a SYSTEM-level remote code execution (RCE) in the handling of the Server Message Block (SMB) protocol in Microsoft Windows.
label: attack-pattern

text: The attack uses this vulnerability to spread the WanaCrypt0r ransomware on the network.
label: malware

text: This is a classic network worm-class vulnerability like MS-Blaster and Conficker.
label: vulnerability

text: Early reports indicated that the initial attack vector was via spam and/or phishing email.
label: attack-pattern

text: However, this has not been confirmed and is unlikely to account for the global spread of the malware.
label: safe

text: When the WanaCrypt0r ransomware executes successfully, it will encrypt key files on the system and display a ransom note as shown below (SOURCE: Microsoft).
label: identity

text: Figure 1 Ransom note for WanaCrypt0r
label: tools

text: One thing reports have indicated that make this attack unique is a “killswitch” capability built into the malware.
label: safe

text: This “killswitch” will prevent the WanaCrypt0r ransomware from executing.
label: malware

text: The “killswitch” is code which will attempt to connect to an extremely long domain that should not resolve.
label: safe

text: The initial variant of WanaCrypt0r uses hxxp://iuqerfsodp9ifjaposdfjhgosurijfaewrwergwea[.]com, however, there are reports of newer variants using different domains.
label: URL

text: If it was successful in connecting to the domain, the ransomware would not execute.
label: safe

text: However, it was easily subverted to work against the malware.
label: safe

text: A security researcher in the United Kingdom initially registered this domain in order to track this threat, and soon discovered that in doing so, he had enabled this “killswitch”, causing a number of instances of WanaCrypt0r to not execute for a large number of infected systems.
label: location

text: On Friday, May 12, 2017, Microsoft announced that they were making an emergency patch available for out-of-support versions of Windows (Windows XP, Windows 8 and Windows Server 2003).
label: SOFTWARE

text: As of this writing attacks appear to have subsided.
label: safe

text: This is likely due to increased uptake of the patch MS17-010 in light of the WanaCrypt0r attacks, as well as efforts made within the security community.
label: malware

text: Unit 42 research shows there is likely very little actual payment of ransom.
label: identity

text: We analyzed our known WanaCrypt0r samples and extract the following Bitcoin (BTC) addresses likely associated with the attackers and associated totals:  This results in a total of 36 BTC, or roughly $63k based on the current price of BTC.
label: identity

text: Given that WanaCrypt0r requests $300 per infected machine, we can infer that approximately 210 victims have made payments to the attackers.
label: malware

text: Therefore, there appears to be little recon as part of this attack.
label: safe

text: There are some reports that there may be scanning of TCP port 445, which is one of the ports associated with SMB.
label: safe

text: But these reports haven’t been conclusively verified.
label: safe

text: There is no consensus in the industry on what the delivery method/initial infection vector is.
label: safe

text: There have been several theories:  Unit 42 believes the most likely delivery method is method #2.
label: identity

text: However, this is not conclusively provenLateral Movement
label: attack-pattern

text: The WanaCrypt0r ransomware spreads itself by heavily scanning over TCP port 445 (associated with SMB) and attempting to exploit the ETERNALBLUE vulnerability on systems.
label: malware

text: A successful attack against this vulnerability will infect the target system with the WanaCrypt0r ransomware, which will encrypt data on the target system and attempt to spread itself once again.
label: malware

text: Multiple vendors report that the malware includes the ability to spread via port 445 scans and attacks against the ETERNALBLUE vulnerability not only on internal networks but also across the Internet.
label: vulnerability

text: These reports indicate that in addition to the internal lateral movement already outlined, the WanaCrypt0r ransomware will scan for port 445 on random external IP addresses and if it finds an IP address with an open port 445, it will then scan all devices on the same /24 IP range (i.e. that share the first three octets as that IP address with the open port 445).  In general, WanaCrypt0r does not have C2 capabilities but it does utilize the TOR network to communicate encryption keys for decryption upon payment of ransom.
label: malware

text: It has been reported that the DOUBLEPULSAR backdoor (also from the Equation Group leak by Shadow Brokers) is installed and used to execute the malware after successful exploitation of a host via ETERNALBLUE, but this warrants further analysis.
label: threat-actor

text: Overall, WanaCrypt0r has been a notable incident within the security community, as the threat couples a wormable vulnerability/exploit with a ransomware family.
label: malware

text: Users are urged to apply the necessary Microsoft patch to protect themselves against this threat.
label: identity

text: For protections, customers are advised to view this blog post that outlines the various ways the Palo Alto Networks platform prevents this threat.  Cyber Threat Alliance member ElevenPaths has developed a tool which can be used to attempt to recover some files deleted by WanaCrypt0r.
label: identity

text: You can find more information on this tool here.
label: safe

text: Register for Ignite ’17 Security Conference  Vancouver, BC June 12–15, 2017
label: location

text: Ignite ’17 Security Conference is a live, four-day conference designed for today’s security professionals.
label: safe

text: The latest episode of the Don’t Panic cybersecurity podcast is now live.
label: safe

text: In this latest episode, Ryan goes back to the topic he talked about in his 2018 predictions piece “The Era of Software Supply-Chain Attacks Has Begun”: Software Supply Chain attacks.
label: identity

text: As a reminder, “Don’t Panic,” is the official podcast of Unit 42, the Palo Alto Network threat intelligence team and features Palo Alto Networks CSO Rick Howard and Palo Alto Networks Senior Vice President, Threat Intelligence Ryan Olson.  You can find this episode and other Palo Alto Networks podcasts on iTunes, Google Play, or integrate the RSS feed into your favorite service.
label: identity

text: Late last month reports surfaced that a new Internet Explorer vulnerability (CVE-2014-1776) was being exploited in targeted attacks.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The vulnerability allows an attacker to take full control over the system after a user views a web page in their browser.
label: safe

text: According to Microsoft, it affects versions of Internet Explorer from version 6 to 11, meaning that almost all IE users are vulnerable to this bug.
label: SOFTWARE

text: This vulnerability is so widespread that Microsoft has released patches to protect Windows XP, for which Microsoft has ended support since April 8, 2014.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Researchers from Palo Alto Networks have investigated this exploit in depth and concluded that this is a Use-After-Free vulnerability that occurs when Internet Explorer tries to reuse a freed CMarkup object.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Attackers can manipulate memory allocations by using JavaScript to allocate an object that is freed before all references to that object are removed.
label: safe

text: Once the object is free the Flash file will overwrite a length field in the vector object and allow arbitrary memory access.
label: SOFTWARE

text: After that the exploit uses a ROP chain to overwrite the virtual function table of a sound object to gain full control.
label: safe

text: The exploit utilized several advanced exploit techniques to make it almost 100% reliable.
label: safe

text: The exploit used in the wild contains two major parts, one is HTML which sets up the page to exploit, and the other is a Flash file which builds the memory layout in IE process and triggers the bug.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Two parts must be combined to ensure a successful attack.
label: safe

text: The attack separated critical code into different pieces so that researchers could not reproduce the original exploit until they have both files.
label: safe

text: The techniques used in this exploit are similar to those used in other recent attacks.
label: safe

text: Last year, exploitation of CVE-2013-3163 targeted Internet Explorer 8 and earlier this year, we found exploitation of CVE-2014-0322 in Internet Explorer 10.
label: vulnerability

text: Similarities in each of these exploits indicate that they may have been created by the same author.
label: safe

text: All three exploits share the same exploit techniques:  All the Flash files used across the exploits have similar structures and even the same variable names.
label: SOFTWARE

text: For example, they all use the Timer object to check if a Vector object is modified.
label: safe

text: The Timers are all set to repeat every one second for 4,096 seconds.
label: TIME

text: The Vector object is named ‘s’ and the Sound object is named “ss” in the Flash files used in all three exploits.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The following code is snippet from the disassembled ActionScript code of CVE-2014-1776.
label: vulnerability

text: Neither of these variables is actually used in this exploit.
label: safe

text: If we go back and examine the exploit code for CVE-2013-3163, we see that the string ‘org’ was originally used as the trigger, and the variable ‘found’ was originally used as a flag indicating if the Vector object was modified.
label: vulnerability

text: It appears that the attacker reused the code from the earlier exploit and forgot to remove the unnecessary variables.
label: safe

text: s[_local28][(((_local41 - _local12) / 4) + 9)] = _local9;  s[_local28][(((_local41 - _local12) / 4) + 10)]
label: safe

text: #NAME?
label: safe

text: local7
label: safe

text: = (this.m_longArrBase - 8);
label: safe

text: = this.m_rawLen;
label: safe

text: The exploit uses the code above to restore the corrupted object and save the stack frame on the heap so that the process would not crash after the exploit is successful.
label: safe

text: All three exploits use the same method and similar addresses to achieve that goal, even including the same hard coded assembly and registers.
label: safe

text: _local10 = this.m_ZwProtectAddr;  _local41 = _local6;  s[_local28][((((_local6 - _local12) / 4) - 2) - 4)] = (_local41 & 0xFFFFF000);  s[_local28][((((_local6 - _local12) / 4) - 1) - 4)] = 0x3000;  s[_local28][((_local6 - _local12) / 4)] = _local10;  s[_local28][(((_local6 - _local12) / 4) + 1)] = (_local41 + 28);  The code above shows the Flash code setting up the ROP chain to bypass DEP and includes another interesting marker.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Normally programmers begin counting at 0 when referencing arrays, but in all three exploits they began at -2, which is quite unusual.
label: safe

text: Additionally, each sample uses a Sound object named ‘snd’ to gain control, and they all invoke the function toString().
label: safe

text: The many similarities between these exploits lead us to believe they were written by the same actor or group.
label: safe

text: Or at the very least, a common template has been used to craft exploits for the three Internet Explorer vulnerabilities we analyzed.
label: SOFTWARE

text: This re-use of techniques is common among exploits, even if they were not developed by the same group, and Palo Alto Networks employs a unique payload-based signature detection methodology, which is able to look at the behaviors of an exploit to prevent similar attacks in the future.
label: identity

text: Palo Alto Networks customers with a Threat Prevention subscription were automatically protected from exploitation of these vulnerabilities:  We suggest customers ensure they are running the latest content version on their devices and apply the patches Microsoft released on May 1, 2014.  Sign up to receive the latest news, cyber threat intelligence and research from us  Please enter your email address!
label: identity

text: In October 2017, Palo Alto Networks Unit 42 published research showing how attackers were adapting attack techniques to generate cryptocurrency for themselves.
label: TIME

text: In that research, we also showed how these attacks were very broad and grew very quickly.
label: safe

text: At the time, we said that the sudden, surging value of cryptocurrencies was likely behind the sudden, strong rise of these new attacks.
label: safe

text: We said that if cryptocurrency values continue to remain high, we could expect to see attackers continue to focus on finding ways to carry out attacks to gain cryptocurrency, and that those attacks would continue to adapt proven attack techniques.
label: safe

text: Unit 42 has just released new research showing that attackers are indeed continuing to adapt existing techniques to generate cryptocurrency.
label: identity

text: In our research posting “Large Scale Monero Cryptocurrency Mining Operation using XMRig” we detail a new malware campaign that is global in scale, very large in the likely number of victims and uses well established techniques to mine the Monero cryptocurrency.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Monero is a cryptocurrency similar to bitcoin but notable for its increased emphasis on providing a higher level of privacy around its transactions.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Like bitcoin, Monero is generated through “mining” a computationally intensive process that provides cryptocurrency credit in exchange for computing resources provided in service to the cryptocurrency and its transaction infrastructure.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The operation that Unit 42 has recently uncovered works to deliver XMRig, software that is used to mine the Monero cryptocurrency, to victims’ systems without their knowledge or consent.
label: identity

text: While XMRig isn’t itself specifically malware, it’s being delivered using malware-delivery techniques without the user’s knowledge and consent just like malware.
label: tools

text: The attackers are doing this by using URL shorteners to make XMRig look like other, legitimate, and expected programs.
label: tools

text: This is a method attackers have used for years to deliver malware and they are using it now to get coinmining software on to people’s systems illicitly.
label: safe

text: The attackers’ use of URL shortners enables our Unit 42 researchers to get an idea of the size, scope, and scale of this operation.
label: identity

text: And these are all notable and sobering.
label: safe

text: First, this is a young campaign.
label: safe

text: Our research shows this operation to be only about four months old.
label: safe

text: Second, this is a very large campaign.
label: safe

text: Our researchers can show that about one-half of the samples we found have affected 15 million people worldwide.
label: safe

text: While we can’t see how many people the other half of the samples affect, it’s a reasonable supposition that the other half of the total samples affect just as many people as the half we can see.
label: safe

text: This would mean that this operation may affect about 30 million people worldwide.
label: safe

text: In terms of who’s been affected by this operation, again, we can only see half of those who have been affected.
label: safe

text: But what we do see shows that this is a truly global operation.
label: safe

text: This operation affected countries around the globe, but it appears that southeast Asia, northern Africa, and countries in South America were hit the most as shown below.  Malicious downloads by country  The specific breakout of countries affected, and their download counts are as follows:  Taking all those points together, this is operation is very large and clearly very effective.
label: attack-pattern

text: It shows how attackers are aggressively focusing their operations and campaigns on generating and acquiring cryptocurrency.
label: safe

text: From a threat point of view, there are two things that are notable.
label: safe

text: First is the fact that from an attack technique point of view, there is nothing new here.
label: safe

text: The tactics and techniques are not new or sophisticated.
label: safe

text: Second is the fact that this operation is clearly very successful based on its size, scope, and age.
label: safe

text: Looking at this latest operation on the continuum of evolving cryptocurrency-focused threats, it’s clear that this is an early-stage threat given its lack of sophistication and reuse of established techniques and tactics.
label: safe

text: But given how quickly and broadly successful it is, combined with the continued high value of cryptocurrencies, we can also conclude that attackers will continue to focus on cryptocurrency and likely will evolve their techniques and tactics quickly.
label: safe

text: Cryptocurrency-focused threats is a key area that all defenders should focus their intelligence and prevention efforts around in 2018.
label: safe

text: Meanwhile, see our full research blog for full details on how attackers are distributing and using XMRig to generate Monero.  Sign up to receive the latest news, cyber threat intelligence and research from us  Please enter your email address!
label: tools

text: Today, Microsoft patched 59 Internet Explorer vulnerabilities, 21 of them discovered by Palo Alto Networks researchers.
label: identity

text: Palo Alto Networks is committed not only to detecting attacks, but preventing them as well.
label: identity

text: Our internal research team discovered each of these 21 vulnerabilities and reported them to Microsoft so they could begin building and testing patches.
label: identity

text: Microsoft has already credited our team with 14 previous IE vulnerabilities in 2014, bringing our total for the year up to 35.
label: identity

text: We want to acknowledge Palo Alto Networks researchers Bo Qu, Hui Gao, Royce Lu, Xin Ouyang and the entire IPS team for all of the hard work they’ve put into discovering and validating these vulnerabilities.
label: identity

text: The table below provides a summary of the vulnerabilities and which versions of Internet Explorer they impact.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Internet Explorer is used in many of the networks Palo Alto Networks protects around the world and we’re doing our part to make it as secure as possible.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Last week we released a series of IPS signatures to detect an advanced exploitation technique that takes advantage of ActiveX. In May, we linked a recent IE 0-day (CVE-2014-1776) to exploit code used against two other IE vulnerabilities exploited in the last 12 months.
label: vulnerability

text: Microsoft patched 129 IE vulnerabilities in all of 2013 and today’s release brings the 2014 total to 116.
label: identity

text: The faster the good guys track these down and get them patched, the harder we make the lives of the criminals looking to exploit them.
label: safe

text: This time every year, people all over the world get new devices.
label: safe

text: Regardless of what holiday(s) you may (or may not) celebrate, the end of the year is a time for people to give and receive some of the latest devices to come on to the market.
label: safe

text: Nothing spoils a new gadget more than having some kind of security or privacy problem related to it.
label: safe

text: After that, nothing spoils the fun and excitement of unboxing and playing with an exciting new device than trying to figure out what you need to do to use it with reasonable safety and privacy.
label: safe

text: To that end, we’re providing some very basic, but critical steps that you, your family, your loved ones, and friends can take to ensure some basic security and privacy for new devices quickly and easily that can help you be safer and not spoil your unboxing fun.  In the vein of the holiday spirit, we’re providing a list of twelve short, simple recommendations that can help you have a happy, safe, and private holiday season.
label: safe

text: 1. Use a Password Manager:
label: safe

text: Even though not all devices can use password managers directly, it’s still one of the best things you can set up.
label: safe

text: PCs and Macs as well as smartphones and tablets increasingly support the use of password managers directly.
label: safe

text: But even for devices that don’t, you can and should use a password manager to generate and store strong passwords for use on all devices in its vault.
label: safe

text: Preferably, find a password manager that requires two-factor authentication.  2. Protect Your Home Routers and Wi-Fi:
label: safe

text: In a home of computers, phones, tablets and IoT devices, nearly always the common point is the home router and Wi-Fi.
label: safe

text: For most, it’s something they set up once and forget about.
label: safe

text: But if you want to keep your home devices more secure, you need to make sure the underlying router and Wi-Fi are more secure.
label: safe

text: Take time to ensure you have a good, complex, unguessable password.
label: safe

text: This is where a password manager can help.
label: safe

text: You may consider configuring it to not broadcast the SSID as well: that can make adding devices a little harder, but that means it’s even harder for people to try and join your home network.  3. Set up More Secure Accounts on Your PCs and Macs: PCs and Macs (both desktop and laptop) are still around and as important as ever in the home.
label: safe

text: Take time to set up an account for everyone with their own username and password.
label: safe

text: Also, all modern operating systems allow you to make accounts “regular user” accounts rather than admin accounts.
label: safe

text: Set everyone up as a “regular user” and set up a separate administrative account to use for maintenance.
label: safe

text: If you have kids, avoid the temptation to let them all use one account or accounts without passwords: this is a chance for them to start to learn the right way to handle passwords by giving them their own and teaching them to never share that password.
label: safe

text: You can generate the password for them and retain it as the “administrator” if you want for monitoring.
label: safe

text: This also is an important lesson for kids to understand that privacy on computers isn’t absolute: the admin can always look at what they’re doing.
label: safe

text: 4. Prevent Lost Tablets and Smartphones from Turning into Something Worse: Portable devices means an increased risk of loss or theft.
label: safe

text: These days, our portable devices often have greater access to more sensitive information than our PCs and Macs do – in the form of mobile banking apps, wallet apps and stored credit cards.
label: safe

text: All modern tablets and smartphones have settings you should enable before you take these portable devices out of your home:  a. Passcodes to lock the device.
label: safe

text: b. Encryption of information on the device.
label: safe

text: c. Lost device location.
label: safe

text: d. Deleting or “wiping” data if too many bad passcodes are tried or if you active it remotely.
label: safe

text: 5. Protect your Data on Smartwatches and Personal Fitness Devices: Smartwatches and personal fitness devices are similar to smartphones and tablets and have some of the same features.
label: safe

text: In addition to using those features, you should take time to ensure you know what health information is being used and that the cloud account(s) these devices synchronize with have very strong passwords.
label: safe

text: These devices gather some of your most personal information.
label: safe

text: In some cases, the most serious risk isn’t around the device but the data being stored in the cloud.
label: safe

text: 6. Be Smart with Your Smart Home: Smart home is an umbrella term for a diverse set of devices that have one thing in common: they all feature some kind of internet connectivity.
label: safe

text: Each and every device will have its own security and privacy settings and it pays to take time to understand those BEFORE you put these to work in your home.
label: safe

text: Across the board, though, making sure your home router and Wi-Fi have good security and that you’re using good, strong unique passwords when paring devices with apps (where possible) are easy things you can do for all these devices.
label: safe

text: 7. Don’t Forget About Home Entertainment Apps, TVs and DVRs:
label: safe

text: When we think about home entertainment, there’s really two things you need to think about with security.
label: safe

text: First is the security of the devices themselves.
label: safe

text: In nearly all cases, good security around home routers and Wi-Fi will be the best thing you can do for the devices.
label: safe

text: But home entertainment isn’t just the physical devices.
label: safe

text: It’s the apps you use to view content.
label: safe

text: All apps like those from Netflix, Amazon, Hulu and others have their own passwords to connect to their service, and attackers crack and sell compromised accounts to these services.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Because of this, make sure you’re using good, strong unique passwords for the apps you use on these devices.
label: safe

text: This will also protect these apps on your tablets, smartphones, PCs and Macs.
label: safe

text: While You’re at it, Protect Your Gaming Consoles:
label: safe

text: Similar to home entertainment devices, gaming consoles have both the security of the actual device and then the security of the cloud-based accounts to deal with.
label: safe

text: Just like with home entertainment devices, it’s the cloud-based account that attackers are more interested in.
label: safe

text: Here again, taking time to set up good strong passwords is key.
label: safe

text: Also, many gaming platforms now include a second means of authentication (typically a text sent to your phone): you can and should enable that, if at all possible.
label: safe

text: 9. Configure User Profiles for Voice Assistants:
label: safe

text: Voice assistants are some of the newest devices out there, which means they’re the least known and understood.
label: safe

text: The biggest risk that’s been popularly discussed is voice command hijacking by outside sources.
label: safe

text: While a cool news story, it’s not been documented to be a broad risk, especially as devices get better at specific voice recognition.
label: safe

text: For these devices, take time to configure individual user profiles as much as possible.
label: safe

text: And many of these devices feature mute buttons that can functionally turn them off when you don’t need them.
label: safe

text: If you haven’t been using it, consider using that feature.
label: safe

text: 10. Use Smart Speakers Smartly:
label: safe

text: Smart speakers can be thought of as a subset of home assistants in that they are voice-activated devices in your home.
label: safe

text: And many smart speakers have digital home assistants built into them, making the distinction even less clear.
label: safe

text: This means that what you would do for security for your digital home assistant would apply to smart speakers as well.
label: safe

text: However, one thing to consider is if all you really want or need is a smart music device, it may make sense to keep your purchases focused on devices that do only that.
label: safe

text: This can improve your security by reducing the risk posed by features that you don’t want or need.
label: safe

text: 11. Drive Safely and Securely with Smart Cars:
label: safe

text: While “car hacking” is something that you see in the news, the reality is that practical smart car security is more common than headlines may lead you to believe.
label: safe

text: A key differentiating feature with smart cars is they often have “smart” lock and ignition systems that are tied to fobs and/or your devices (like a smartphone).
label: safe

text: Good smart car security in this case means building on the good security around devices and good physical security.
label: safe

text: Ensure that any connected smart devices have good security, especially to protect against loss or theft.
label: safe

text: Make sure you only give fobs to people that you trust.
label: safe

text: And ensure that any cloud-connected accounts have good passwords and use a second authentication method, if possible.
label: safe

text: 12. Patch, Patch and Patch Some More:
label: safe

text: We close this list with patching because it is the most important thing you can do.
label: safe

text: Few people like getting into the guts of devices to manage updates and the apps on them but the reality right now is that this is not only critical for security and privacy, it’s also sometimes a process that can only be done manually.
label: safe

text: For every kind of device or system, you should think about and understand how you can do updates for:  a.
label: safe

text: The “firmware”: this is the software that is on the physical device itself, like the actual router, the actual car or the actual DVR.
label: safe

text: b. The operating system on the device: Some devices don’t have an operating system separate from the firmware, but many do.
label: safe

text: PCs and Macs have firmware and an operating system (Windows, macOS and Linux).
label: SOFTWARE

text: c. The apps and applications on the computer or device: Like we noted about home entertainment and gaming consoles, sometimes it’s the apps rather than the device itself that is important.
label: safe

text: Many apps these days have auto-update capabilities.
label: safe

text: But some don’t, so it’s important to make sure you know how apps get their updates.
label: safe

text: If you take some time to understand these basic ideas and take these basic steps, you can ensure that you’ve got a good start on using new devices more safely and with better privacy during the holiday season.  Of course, this isn’t an exhaustive list.
label: safe

text: And it’s always good to know about other features and capabilities, for example child safety controls.
label: safe

text: But the start of a journey of a thousand miles begins with one step, and the start of a journey of a thousand days of using these new devices safely can start with these simple steps.
label: safe

text: We have recently been investigating an antivirus app in the Google Play store that was displaying fake virus detection results to scare users into purchasing a premium service.
label: SOFTWARE

text: According to the Google Play store statistics, users have downloaded “AntiVirus for Android™” more than one million times and the app was listed in Top 100 free apps in Tools category.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Our Wildfire analysis cloud captured the initial app and identified it as Scareware.
label: SOFTWARE

text: On January 20, we reported this issue to Google and two days later, they removed the app from Google Play.
label: identity

text: “AntiVirus for Android™” was developed by a company named “CTG Network Ltd.
label: malware

text: ”(Figure 1)
label: safe

text: According the (now removed) Google Play listing, the app was downloaded and installed between 1 million and 5 millions times.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Before the removal it had also received 5,162 recommendations and 16,531 reviews that resulted in an average score of 4.0.
label: safe

text: According to AppBrain, the app was also listed in top 30 of Top Grossing Apps in Tools category in United States, Japan, France and South Korea.
label: location

text: Figure 1 AntiVirus for Android™ in the Google Play Store
label: malware

text: When a user opens the app, it will always report that it has located two or three threats on the device (Figure 2), including the following:  Figure 2
label: safe

text: The App Indicates Two Threats were Found  If the user clicks the “Repair” button, the apps will indicate that one of the threats was eliminated and advise the user to upgrade to its full version to remove the remaining threat(s).
label: safe

text: If the user clicks the “Update to Full Protection” button they will be prompted to subscribe to a service that costs $4.99 (US) per month through In-App Purchase of Google Play (Figure 3).  Figure 3
label: safe

text: The app requests that the user pay 4.99$ per month for full protection.
label: safe

text: Through analyzing the app’s code we discovered a multiple indications that this program was not a legitimate Antivirus program, but actually Scareware.
label: safe

text: First, the initial “threats detection results” are hard-coded in the app (Figure 4), which means the app wasn't actually detecting them on the phone.
label: safe

text: The developer even directly named these “infected packages” as “fake.virus” in the source code.
label: FILEPATH

text: Figure 4 Hard-coded fake threat detection results
label: safe

text: Since the detection result is fake, the subsequent cleaning is not real either – the elimination operation is just marking a flag of "initial_virus_cleared" to “1” in the app’s internal database.
label: safe

text: The code in Figure 5 shows that the “We have eliminated 1 of %d Threat(s)” message shown in Figure 3 is also hard coded.
label: safe

text: Figure 5 Code that generated the fake threat cleared page.
label: safe

text: One interesting difference between this program and other Fake AV apps is “AntiVirus for Android™” will actually provide real antivirus services to paid users.
label: malware

text: The app integrates a mobile antivirus engine provided by Bitdefender and if users upgrade to the premium version, it will scan apps and the device’s SD card with that engine.
label: safe

text: This is the main reason we classify the program as Scareware rather than just Fake AV.
label: safe

text: It is not clear whether the integrated BitDefender AV engine is actually licensed to the app’s developer.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The engine retrieves code updated and new signatures updating from hxxp:// api.androidsantivirus .com /antivirus/android-arm, which is hosted on the app’s official website.
label: URL

text: Figure 6 The App Integrates the BitDefender AV Engine for Premium Users
label: SOFTWARE

text: In March of 2014, a Fake AV app named “Virus Shield” was listed for sale at $3.99 and quickly rose to the top position of Google Play’s New Paid Apps list.
label: malware

text: Virus Shield was downloaded over 30,000 times, fare fewer than this latest piece of Scareware, although we do not know how many users actually paid for the $4.99 monthly service before Google removed the app from the store.
label: identity

text: The fact that AntiVirus for Android™ contains an actual AV engine makes it more difficult for other programs to identify it as Scareware, as this makes the program appear legitimate.
label: malware

text: While Google has already removed this application from the Play store, we’ll keep monitoring the latest Android apps to make sure WildFire is providing the best protection for our customers.
label: identity
