label: safe

text: up front
label: safe

text: Overview
label: safe

text: In the past 48 hours, there has been a flurry of activity as hardware and software vendors move to address two sets of vulnerabilities that have been dubbed “Meltdown” and “Spectre”.
label: vulnerability

text: This blog is meant to give an overview of the situation, the vulnerabilities, assist Palo Alto Networks customers and others with their risk assessment, and provide recommendations for actions they can take to prevent successful attacks against these vulnerabilities.
label: identity

text: Situation
label: safe

text: On January 3, 2018, researchers, including those with Google Project Zero, released information on three new vulnerabilities:
label: TIME

text: They grouped these vulnerabilities under the names “Spectre” (CVE-2017-5753 and CVE-2017-5715) and “Meltdown” (CVE-2017-5754).
label: vulnerability

text: Comprehensive details on both of these are available at https://meltdownattack.com.
label: URL

text: Security updates to address these vulnerabilities began to be released prior to disclosure on January 3, 2018.
label: TIME

text: Security updates are continuing to be released and are expected to be released over time due to the uniquely broad nature of these vulnerabilities.
label: safe

text: At the time of this writing, there are no known active attacks against any of these vulnerabilities.
label: safe

text: Vulnerabilities  These vulnerabilities present a unique situation because they ultimately are hardware-based vulnerabilities.
label: safe

text: All three stem from issues in modern processors and are known to affect Intel and ARM chips.
label: safe

text: The vulnerability status of AMD chips is unclear at the time of this writing.
label: safe

text: Because these affect processors, this means that the operating systems and applications that run on top of these processors are vulnerable.
label: safe

text: Because these vulnerabilities affect the processors at the physical layer, the only way for the vulnerabilities to be fully addressed is for the processors to be replaced or to have a firmware update.
label: safe

text: Until then, the makers of operating systems can (and have) released patches that make the physical-layer vulnerabilities inaccessible.
label: safe

text: For all intents and purposes, it “patches” the vulnerabilities.
label: safe

text: Full technical details on the vulnerabilities are available at the sites referenced above.
label: safe

text: But the key point to understand about these vulnerabilities is that they are information disclosure vulnerabilities that can enable processes and applications to access information they otherwise shouldn’t be able to: user-mode applications can access privileged information in the kernel and throughout the operating system.
label: safe

text: For regular end-user systems and devices, malware and malicious scripts can use these vulnerabilities to access information like usernames, passwords and account information.
label: safe

text: For shared-hosting environments like public cloud providers, this means that one hosted customer could potentially access the information of any other customer hosted on the same hardware.
label: safe

text: Based on analysis of the vulnerabilities, an industry consensus is emerging that generic protections against attacks aimed at these vulnerabilities will be difficult, if not impossible to develop.
label: safe

text: This means that prevention against attacks will have to focus on specific malware, attacks, and hosting sites as they emerge.
label: safe

text: Risk Assessment
label: safe

text: Because these are information disclosure vulnerabilities, they don’t pose the same, immediate danger like WannaCry/WanaCrypt0r or Petya/NotPetya.
label: malware

text: This has more in common with the Heartbleed event of 2014.
label: vulnerability

text: In terms of the severity of the vulnerabilities themselves: they are important, but not critical.
label: safe

text: They are information disclosure, not code execution, vulnerabilities.
label: safe

text: The greatest area of risk is in shared-hosting scenarios.
label: safe

text: Fortunately, most cloud providers have already deployed security updates and those that haven’t are expected to do so shortly.
label: safe

text: For end-users and those managing networks, the greatest risk these vulnerabilities pose is exploitation by malware seeking to gather information like usernames and passwords from systems.  What makes these vulnerabilities most notable from a risk assessment point of view is breadth of exposure.
label: safe

text: Since these potentially affect nearly every device with a modern processor, that means that full mitigation and remediation may not be possible.
label: safe

text: Older systems (like Windows XP) and devices (like older Android smartphones and IoT devices) will likely never receive fixes for these vulnerabilities.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Calls to Action
label: safe

text: The actions to take in response to this event are clear and simple:  As always, we will continue to watch this event closely and provide any updates that we can.
label: safe

text: For information on how Palo Alto Networks products are affected by these issues, customers can see our posting on the Live Community at: https://live.paloaltonetworks.com/t5/Customer-Advisories/Information-about-Meltdown-and-Spectre-findings/ta-p/193878/jump-to/first-unread-message.
label: identity

text: If you have any questions, please visit the Threat & Vulnerability Discussions on our Live Community.
label: safe

text: In recent research, Palo Alto Networks found attackers were targeting home routers to take control and use them for attacks against other websites that can bring them down.
label: identity

text: Here we explain this type of attack and what you should do.
label: safe

text: These attacks could affect you in two ways:  What causes this kind of attack?
label: safe

text: Weak passwords and out-of-date software can both enable attackers to take complete control of your home router.
label: attack-pattern

text: How can I prevent it?
label: safe

text: Attackers target home routers like this by targeting default passwords and out-of-date software on the routers.
label: attack-pattern

text: An easy thing you can do is restart your router once a week (typically by unplugging it).
label: safe

text: You can also stay safe by changing the password on your router and updating the software.
label: safe

text: If you’re not sure how to do this, contact your Internet Service Provider (ISP) that gave you the router for help.
label: safe

text: How does it work?
label: safe

text: When devices (in this case, the routers) are under someone else’s control like this, the collection is referred to as a “botnet”, a network (-net) of remotely controlled systems or devices (bot-).
label: safe

text: When attackers have complete control of your home router, they can install attack software that they control, turning the device into a “bot”.
label: safe

text: Attacks can make all the controlled routers in a botnet do anything they want, including sending huge amounts of data to try and bring websites down.
label: safe

text: These kinds of attacks are called “Distributed Denial of Service” or “DDoS” attacks.
label: attack-pattern

text: Attackers use them to take down websites for several reasons:  About Threat Briefs are meant to help busy people understand real-world threats and how they can prevent them in their lives.
label: safe

text: They’re put together by Palo Alto Networks Unit 42 threat research team and are meant for you to read and share with your family, friends, and coworkers so you can all be safer and get on with the business of your digital life.
label: identity

text: Email us at u42comms@paloaltonetworks.com.
label: EMAIL

text: There’s a very good reason why AWS remains a leader in cloud computing.
label: safe

text: While many providers describe themselves as “customer obsessed,” few come close to our long-time partner in the lengths it goes to earn and retain the trust of its customers.
label: safe

text: AWS starts with the customer and works backwards.
label: identity

text: That means the vast majority of its feature enhancements and new services are directly driven from their input.
label: safe

text: The latest is Amazon GuardDuty Malware Protection.
label: SOFTWARE

text: This threat detection tool, which will work closely with Trend Micro cloud solutions, will provide another valuable layer of defense in our fight against a shared adversary.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Shining a light on an expanding attack surface Spurred by a drive for greater cost efficiency and business agility, global organizations are migrating to the cloud in droves.
label: safe

text: Gartner predicts the worldwide market for public cloud services will reach almost $495bn this year, and grow by over 21% in 2023.
label: identity

text: In this environment, security remains a persistent concern for cloud builders, because if not properly managed, investments can increase the digital attack surface.
label: safe

text: According to recent Trend Micro research, many global organizations are already struggling to securely manage their cloud assets.
label: identity

text: We found that 73% of IT and business leaders are concerned with the size of their attack surface, and 43% claim it is “spiralling out of control.”
label: safe

text: Cloud is the area where most respondents say they have least insight.
label: safe

text: They want their cloud providers to do more—for example by building enhanced detection into their systems, to complement third-party tools.
label: safe

text: That’s part of the reason why AWS built Amazon GuardDuty Malware Protection was built.
label: SOFTWARE

text: This new feature is triggered by detection of known malicious signatures across the cloud network.
label: safe

text: Based on this detection, the service scans the associated Amazon EBS storage environment for malware and reports any findings to AWS Security Hub.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Open APIs from here link to products like Trend Micro Cloud One to enhance existing detection and response efforts.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Better together Trend Micro and AWS have been working closely together for over a decade now, and this latest announcement represents another exciting stage in the journey.
label: identity

text: Customers will welcome AWS native threat detection as a complement to their Trend Micro Cloud One capabilities, delivering a comprehensive range of features to secure the hybrid cloud.
label: identity

text: Once they add the AWS tool to our virtual patching, vulnerability scanning, lateral movement detection, posture management and other capabilities, joint customers will have a powerful set of integrated offerings to deliver simple, all-in-one cloud security and compliance.
label: SOFTWARE

text: In addition, this move from AWS validates our XDR strategy, which is focused on using as many data sources as possible to enhance detection and response.
label: identity

text: The bottom line is that security takes a village.
label: safe

text: Customers, cloud providers and security vendors have a shared responsibility to work together as the threat landscape continues to evolve.
label: safe

text: That’s what we’ll continue to do, expanding and deepening our strategic partnerships with AWS and other providers in a collective effort to make the digital world safer.
label: identity

text: Tags  Cloud | Latest News | Malware | APT & Targeted Attacks |
label: safe

text: Compliance & Risks | Articles, News, Reports
label: safe

text: We discovered a new malware that targets online gambling companies in China via a watering hole attack, in which visitors are tricked into downloading a malware loader disguised as a legitimate installer for well-known apps such as Adobe Flash Player or Microsoft Silverlight.
label: attack-pattern

text: Closer examination of the loader shows that it loads either a Cobalt Strike shellcode or a previously undocumented backdoor written in Python, a new type of malware that we found to be named BIOPASS RAT (remote access trojan).
label: tools

text: BIOPASS RAT possesses basic features found in other malware, such as file system assessment, remote desktop access, file exfiltration, and shell command execution.
label: malware

text: It also has the ability to compromise the private information of its victims by stealing web browser and instant messaging client data.
label: safe

text: What makes BIOPASS RAT particularly interesting is that it can sniff its victim’s screen by abusing the framework of Open Broadcaster Software (OBS) Studio, a popular live streaming and video recording app, to establish live streaming to a cloud service via Real-Time Messaging Protocol (RTMP).
label: malware

text: In addition, the attack misuses the object storage service (OSS) of Alibaba Cloud (Aliyun) to host the BIOPASS RAT Python scripts as well as to store the exfiltrated data from victims.
label: malware

text: We consider BIOPASS RAT as still being actively developed.
label: malware

text: For example, some markers that we discovered during our analysis refer to different versions of RAT code, such as “V2” or “BPSV3”.
label: safe

text: Many of the loaders that we found were used to load Cobalt Strike shellcode by default instead of the BIOPASS RAT malware.
label: tools

text: Furthermore, BIOPASS RAT also creates scheduled tasks to load the Cobalt Strike shellcode during the initialization, indicating that the malicious actor behind the attack still heavily relies on Cobalt Strike.
label: malware

text: We also found several clues that show how the malware might be connected with the Winnti Group(also known as APT41).
label: threat-actor

text: In this blog entry, we will dive deeper into BIOPASS RAT with a detailed technical analysis of the infection chain, the different components of the malware, and any possible associations with Winnti.
label: threat-actor

text: Infection chain
label: safe

text: The initial delivery mechanism of BIOPASS RAT uses of a watering hole, a compromised website in which the malicious actors inject their custom JavaScript code to deliver malware.
label: attack-pattern

text: In most of the cases that we observed, the attackers usually place their injection script in their target’s online support chat page.
label: safe

text: Figure 1. The login panel of BIOPASS RAT       Figure 2. Code showing the watering hole attack injection     The injected script will try to scan the affected host by sending HTTP requests to a list of ports.
label: malware

text: If it receives any response with an expected string from these ports, the script will stop.
label: safe

text: This step is likely designed to avoid attacking an already infected victim.
label: safe

text: We found that the BIOPASS RAT has the ability to open an HTTP service running on localhost on a port chosen from a hard-coded list.
label: malware

text: This functionality allows the script to identify whether the victim has already been infected by their malware.
label: safe

text: It conducts this identification by testing whether the port is open or not and then by checking the response.      Figure 3.
label: safe

text: The script used to check for existing BIOPASS RAT infections     If the script confirms that the visitor has not yet been infected, it will then replace the original page content with the attackers’ own content.
label: malware

text: The new page will show an error message with an accompanying instruction telling website visitors to download either a Flash installer or a Silverlight installer, both of which are malicious loaders.
label: SOFTWARE

text: It is important to note that both Adobe Flash and Microsoft Silverlight have already been deprecated by their respective vendors.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Figure 4.
label: safe

text: The fake Adobe Flash Player download page of the watering hole attack      Figure 5.
label: attack-pattern

text: The fake Silverlight download page of the watering hole attack      Figure 6.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Anti-VM checks in sample c47fabc47806961f908bed37d6b1bbbfd183d564a2d01b7cae87bd95c20ff8a5      Figure 7.
label: SHA2

text: Check for zh-CN-preferred UI language in sample 89c0b2036ce8d1d91f6d8b8171219aafcd6237c811770fa16edf922cedfecc54
label: SHA2

text: The legitimate known application is downloaded and executed.
label: safe

text: Authenticode-signed files are either downloaded from the official websites (as seen in sample c47fabc47806961f908bed37d6b1bbbfd183d564a2d01b7cae87bd95c20ff8a5) or are hosted on Alibaba Cloud OSS on the attackers’ account.
label: Infrastucture

text: Visual C++ runtime, a legitimate and signed vc_redist.x??.exe, and Python runtime are then downloaded.
label: FILEPATH

text: These files are also hosted on Alibaba Cloud OSS on an attacker-controlled account.
label: Infrastucture

text: The Python runtime is usually a ZIP file with all required executables, as well as the DLL and Python libraries necessary for running Python scripts on machines where Python is not installed.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Scheduled tasks that are activated on a new login are created.
label: safe

text: These tasks can run a BPS backdoor or a Cobalt Strike loader.
label: tools

text: Figure 8.
label: safe

text: Code excerpt from the scheduled task     We also noticed the path string “ServiceHub”, which is a path to the extracted Python runtime.
label: attack-pattern

text: After the hex decoding of the arguments, we get a Python one-liner that downloads additional Python scripts from the cloud.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Figure 9.
label: safe

text: Python code for downloading additional components from Alibaba Cloud OSS      Figure 10.
label: Infrastucture

text: The BIOPASS RAT infection flow
label: malware

text: Examining the BIOPASS RAT modules We observed a few scheduled tasks being created, with the number dependent on the analyzed sample.
label: malware

text: In the following section, we provide an analysis for each important backdoor module.
label: safe

text: The cdaemon module  One of the modules used is called “cdaemon”.
label: safe

text: At the time of our research into this threat, only the “print(1)” command is able to be executed.
label: safe

text: An old sample of the module (30ccfbf24b7c8cc15f85541d5ec18feb0e19e75e1e4d2bca9941e6585dad7bc7) is likely a watchdog to check the status of another module that is known as “c1222”.  The malicious actors can change this behavior by replacing the content of the cdaemon.txt service in the cloud so that when combined with the regular execution of the scheduled task, the cdaemon task can behave like a backdoor.
label: malware

text: Figure 11.
label: safe

text: The content of the cdaemon.txt backdoor     The c1222 module
label: malware

text: The second scheduled task is called “c1222.txt,” which is a Python code run by a previously downloaded Python runtime.
label: SOFTWARE

text: This code runs an HTTP server that listens on predefined ports.
label: safe

text: If accessed by an HTTP client, it returns a marker value.
label: safe

text: The list of predefined ports to bind an HTTP service to, which is reversed     After accessing the infected machine with an HTTP server bound to a predefined port
label: safe

text: , the module returns the marker value.
label: safe

text: Figure 13.
label: safe

text: The HTTP service with marker BPSV3     We also observed other markers — such as, “cs_online”, “online”, and “dm_online”.
label: safe

text: The purpose of the HTTP service is to act as a marker for an infected machine to avoid repeated infection, as aforementioned in the infection chain section.
label: safe

text: The most important task of the c1222 script is to download, decode, and execute the Cobalt Strike shellcode.
label: malware

text: Based on the platform, it downloads a file with an encoded shellcode (sc3.txt, x64.txt), and then decodes it (the shellcode is base85 and hex-encoded).      Figure 14. Decoding the Cobalt Strike shellcode     The big module (BIOPASS RAT)
label: FILEPATH

text: The third scheduled task —is called “big.txt”— is responsible for implementing the BIOPASS RAT malware.
label: FILEPATH

text: This is a Python-based backdoor that is distributed in plain text or compiled with Nuitka or PyArmor and PyInstaller.
label: SOFTWARE

text: When the malware starts, it checks whether the file with the hard-coded name “%PUBLIC%/20200318” exists.
label: FILEPATH

text: This file is a marker to determine if the scheduled task of the backdoor has been installed.
label: safe

text: If the file (that is, the marker) is not found, the backdoor creates a new one and writes the current timestamp onto it.
label: safe

text: The malware will then delete the scheduled tasks added by the loader and add two new scheduled tasks that are listed in Table 1.
label: safe

text: Task Name  Behavior   ServiceHub  Executes Python with a parameter that is the Python script to download and execute Cobalt Strike loader script “c1222” module  ShellExperienceHost  Executes Python with a parameter that is the Python script to download and execute BIOPASS RAT script “big” module   Table 1.
label: malware

text: The scheduled tasks created by BIOPASS RAT   The BIOPASS RAT malware loads a Python script, “online.txt” that will open an HTTP server that listens on one of the following port numbers: 43990, 43992, 53990, 33990, 33890, 48990, 12880, 22880, 32880, 42880, 52880, or 62880.
label: FILEPATH

text: The HTTP server does nothing but returns string “BPSV3” to request.
label: safe

text: A second HTTP server will also be created to listen on one of the aforementioned port numbers.
label: safe

text: The second HTTP server behaves the same as the first but returns a string, “dm_online”, instead.
label: safe

text: These are the markers of infection as previously mentioned.
label: safe

text: After the servers are established and running, the backdoor creates an execution root directory in the folder “%PUBLIC%/BPS/V3/”.
label: FILEPATH

text: Figure 15.
label: safe

text: The script of a simple HTTP server to return string “dm_online”     If the malware finds that the system username is “vbccsb”
label: safe

text: , it will stop.
label: safe

text: It must be noted that “vbccsb” is the default username on ThreatBook Cloud Sandbox, a popular alternative to VirusTotal in China.
label: location

text: If the backdoor finds that the file “debug” present inside the root directory, it will wait for 130 seconds and then continue with execution.       Figure 16.
label: safe

text: The script used to check the username and debug mode
label: safe

text: Next, the backdoor will try to read the file “bps.key” inside the root directory.
label: FILEPATH

text: This file contains the victim ID assigned by the command-and-control (C&C) server.
label: safe

text: If the file hasn’t been created, it will set the victim ID to a null value until the C&C server assigns it.
label: safe

text: At the end of initialization, it collects the information of the victim’s system and initializes values in the global config variable that contains important configuration information.
label: safe

text: This includes the backdoor version (we observed V2 and V3), access keys, endpoint address, the bucket name for Alibaba Cloud OSS, and a URL for downloading the utility sc.exe that is used for taking screenshots.
label: FILEPATH

text: Figure 17.
label: safe

text: The BPS backdoor global configuration variable     The backdoor communicates with the C&C server using the Socket.io protocol.
label: malware

text: The C&C communication is encrypted with AES ECB algorithm using a hard-coded password, ZLIB compression, and base85 encoding.
label: safe

text: Figures 18 and 19 show how the malware sends the “join” event to initialize C&C communication and attach the victim’s encrypted data.
label: safe

text: Figure 18.
label: safe

text: Encoded “join” event sent to the C&C server      Figure 19.
label: safe

text: Decoded “join” event sent to the C&C server.
label: safe

text: It’s important to note that attributes like IP address, computer and username, architecture, installed antivirus, and geolocation are included.
label: safe

text: The BIOPASS RAT malware registers three custom Socket.io event handlers:
label: malware

text: 1.      The “notice” handler is used for checking the connection with the C&C server.
label: safe

text: The backdoor regularly sends a “notice” event to the server and records the timestamp if it also receives a “notice” event as the response.
label: safe

text: If the malware doesn’t receive any “notice” event within a hard-coded threshold period, it will restart.
label: safe

text: 2.      The “set key” handler is used for accepting the victim ID, a random string with six characters, assigned by the C&C server.
label: safe

text: It will be attached in each of commands sent from the server and will also be used as the folder name on a cloud storage service to save the stolen data.
label: safe

text: The victim ID will be stored in the “bps.key” file.
label: FILEPATH

text: 3.      The “accept task” handler is the main handler used to process the command sent from the C&C server and to return the execution result.
label: safe

text: We share more details of each command in the next section.
label: safe

text: After the malware joins the C&C server, the server will assign a victim ID with “set key” event and send multiple “accept task” events with the commands “ScreenShot”, “SnsInfo”, “PackingTelegram”, “GetBrowsersCookies”, “GetBrowsersLogins”, “GetBrowsersHistories”, and “GetBrowsersBookmarks” to instruct the malware to collect private data from the victim.
label: safe

text: A closer look at the BIOPASS RAT commands
label: malware

text: The BIOPASS RAT malware implements multiple commands, most of which are self-explanatory.
label: malware

text: A summary of commands is listed in Table 2, while additional details of some commands are explained in the following section.
label: safe

text: Command  Behavior  Compress_Files  Compresses specified files or directories to a ZIP archive  Decompress_File  Extracts files from a specified ZIP archive  AutoRun  Creates a scheduled task for persistence  CloseEverything  Kills the Everything process with the command “TASKKILL /F /IM Everything.exe”  OpenEverything  Downloads and runs Everything from voidtools  CloseFFmpegLive  Kills the FFmpeg process with the command “TASKKILL /F /IM ffmpeg.exe”  OpenFFmpegLive  Downloads and runs FFmpeg (for screen video capture)  DeleteFile  Deletes files or directories at specified locations  CreateDir  Creates a directory at a specified location  ShowFiles  Gets the disk partition or lists a specified directory with detailed information, including file name, file path, size, create time, and time of modification  Download_File  Downloads a URL and saves the file to a specified location  Upload_File  Uploads the victim’s files to cloud storage  uUninstall  Kills the BIOPASS RAT process and deletes installed files.  CloseObsLive  Kills the OBS process with command “TASKKILL /F /IM obs64.exe”  Open_Obs_Live  Downloads OBS Studio and starts live streaming  ProcessList  Lists processes on the victim’s environment and their process identifier (PID)  KillProcess  Kills the process specified by PID with the TASKKILL command  ScreenShot  Takes a screenshot and uploads it to cloud storage  Shell  Executes commands or scripts (subcommands with prefixes subprocess, python, noreturn, getversion, restart)  SnsInfo  Lists QQ, WeChat, and Aliwangwang directories  InstallTcpdump  Downloads and installs the tcpdump tool  PackingTelegram  Compresses and uploads Telegram's “tdata” directory to cloud storage  CloseProxy  Kills frpc process with command “TASKKILL /F /IM frpc.exe”  OpenProxy  Downloads and installs the frp proxy client in the “%PUBLIC%” folder  OpenVnc  Downloads and installs jsmpeg-vnc tool in the “%PUBLIC%/vnc/” folder  CloseVnc  Kills the VNC process with the command “TASKKILL /F /IM vdwm.exe”  GetBrowsersCookies  Decrypts the cookie file of the browser and uploads it to cloud storage  GetBrowsersLogins  Decrypts the login file of the browser and uploads it to cloud storage  GetBrowsersHistories  Uploads the history file of the browser to cloud storage  GetBrowsersBookmarks  Uploads the bookmark file of the browser to cloud storage   Table 2.
label: FILEPATH

text: BIOPASS RAT commands   OpenEverything  The malware downloads “Everything” files if the “Everything” binary is not found in the “%TEMP%” folder.
label: FILEPATH

text: It then changes the port number of the HTTP server inside the configuration file and starts the Everything process, which will open an HTTP server to allow the threat actor to access the file system of the victim.
label: safe

text: OpenFFmpegLive  The malware downloads FFmpeg files if they are not found on the victim’s machine.
label: malware

text: Next, it starts the FFmpeg process to monitor the victim’s desktop via RTMP live streaming to the cloud.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The malicious actor can then connect to the relevant RTMP address to watch the streaming.
label: safe

text: Open_Obs_Live
label: safe

text: The malware downloads OBS Studio files if the OBS folder and config file are not found in the root directory.
label: malware

text: It writes the basic config and RTMP config of OBS and then starts the OBS process to monitor the victim’s desktop using RTMP live streaming to the cloud.
label: safe

text: The malicious actor can connect to the relevant RTMP address to watch the streaming.
label: safe

text: Figure 20.
label: safe

text: The script used to download OBS Studio, prepare the configuration, and start the process     ScreenShot
label: SOFTWARE

text: The malware downloads the screenshot-cmd tool if it is not found in the root directory.
label: safe

text: It takes a screenshot of the victim’s screen with the tool and saves it as a PNG file with a random number as the file name.
label: safe

text: The malware will then upload the screenshot files to cloud storage.
label: safe

text: Shell
label: safe

text: The malware uses a number of methods to execute the shell command or script.
label: safe

text: The “Shell” command instructs the malware to execute a command using the Python function “win32api.ShellExecute” and to return the result to a C&C server, applying a 60-second timeout for command execution.
label: SOFTWARE

text: If the command has one of the following prefixes, it will perform a specific behavior:
label: safe

text: 1.      “subprocess”: executes a system command using the Python function “subprocess.Popen”.
label: SOFTWARE

text: 2.      “python”: executes a Python script delivered with the command.
label: SOFTWARE

text: 3.      “noreturn”: executes a system command using the Python function “win32api.ShellExecute” without waiting for the result.
label: SOFTWARE

text: 4.      “getversion”: returns the string “20200202”.
label: safe

text: 5.      “restart”: kills the process itself and restarts it via scheduled malicious tasks. SnsInfo
label: safe

text: The command will list the installation directory of several popular instant messaging applications including WeChat, QQ, and Aliwangwang and return this information to the C&C server.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Figures 21 and 22 show the result of running “SnsInfo” command to enumerate messengers.
label: safe

text: Figure 21.
label: safe

text: Encoded SUBMIT RESULT command sent to C&C server      Figure 22. Decoded SUBMIT RESULT command sent to C&C server     None of the Chinese messenger applications has been installed on our testing machine, which explains the result seen in the images.
label: safe

text: GetBrowsersCookies  This command is designed to steal cookie information from browsers.
label: safe

text: It will read the “Local State” file to grab the AES secret key of Google Chrome-based browsers.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Depending on the different argument “type” delivered with the command, it performs different behaviors.
label: safe

text: If the value of the “type” argument is “Chrome”, it will use the AES secret key or DPAPI (for Chrome versions before 80) to decrypt the cookie file.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The decrypted result will be sent to the C&C server.
label: safe

text: Figure 23.
label: safe

text: The script to decrypt Chrome’s file with AES or DPAPI decryption     If the value of the “type” argument is “File”
label: SOFTWARE

text: , it will directly upload the cookie file to cloud storage.
label: safe

text: The command that we received showed that the targeted browsers include Google Chrome, Microsoft Edge Beta, 360 Chrome, QQ Browser, 2345 Explorer, Sogou Explorer, and 360 Safe Browser.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Figure 24.
label: safe

text: Code showing the command to target Sogou Explorer     GetBrowsersLogins
label: SOFTWARE

text: This command has a nearly identical function to “GetBrowsersCookies”, although it targets a browser’s “Login Data” files instead.
label: safe

text: Additional Findings on BIOPASS RAT
label: malware

text: Although these are not implemented inside the BIOPASS RAT malware, we have observed two additional plug-ins that are written in Python (“getwechatdb” and “xss_spoof”) and were deployed by the threat actor to a victim who had been infected with Cobalt Strike.
label: malware

text: The script “getwechatdb” is used for exfiltrating the chat history from the WeChat Windows client.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The script will detect the version of the installed WeChat client and grab the decryption key and the user ID.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The predefined list of offsets is used to locate where the decryption key and the user ID are embedded.
label: safe

text: The list supports 36 different versions of memory offsets for the message client.
label: safe

text: The script will then upload database files inside the WeChat folder including “MicroMsg.db” to cloud storage.
label: SOFTWARE

text: These database files are used for saving the chat history.
label: safe

text: Finally, the script will print out the client ID and the decryption key that allows the malicious actors to decrypt the stolen database files of the chat history.
label: safe

text: Figure 25.
label: safe

text: A predefined list of memory offset intended to grab information from different versions of WeChat      Figure 26.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The script used to exfiltrate WeChat chat database files     The other plug-in, “xss_spoof”, is an archive that contains multiple Python scripts.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The scripts are designed for web server infection via a cross-site scripting (XSS) attack.
label: attack-pattern

text: This plug-in can inject malicious scripts into the response of the victim’s web server by leveraging the WinDivert package, which is used to sniff and manipulate the network traffic on Windows.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The scripts intercept HTTP GET requests that are sent to port 80.
label: safe

text: An “ignore” list is used to filter the file extensions of URLs to avoid manipulating resources that are not JavaScript or HTML.
label: safe

text: The script then modifies the original JavaScript or HTML content and delivers it to website visitors.
label: safe

text: Figure 27.
label: safe

text: The JavaScript payload used to replace the original script of compromised websites     The delivered script is almost the same as the malicious script previously discussed in the section on the watering hole attack.
label: attack-pattern

text: The script performs checks by scanning localhost to determine if the machine is infected by BIOPASS RAT while showing the fake updated webpages.
label: malware

text: It is likely that the malicious actors compromised the web servers first and then ran “xss_spoof” for propagation.
label: safe

text: Figure 28.
label: safe

text: The main script used to manipulate traffic with WinDivert     Potential links with the Winnti group
label: threat-actor

text: We have found several connections between BIOPASS RAT and the Winnti Group:
label: malware

text: 1.      We discovered that many BIOPASS RAT loader binaries were signed with two valid certificates.
label: malware

text: It is well known that the Winnti Group has previously used stolen certificates from game studios to sign its malware.
label: attack-pattern

text: Certificate Thumbprint  Valid From  Valid To  EFB70718BC00393A01694F255A28E30E9D2142A4  12:00 a.m.,  Jan. 2, 2019  11:59 p.m., Mar. 2, 2021  8CE020AA874902C532B9911A4DCA8EFFA627DC80  12:00 a.m., Sept. 6, 2018  11:59 p.m., Oct. 5, 2021   Table 3.
label: TIME

text: Information from the stolen certificates   2.      While checking the stolen certificates, we found a server-side variant of the Derusbi malware sample (e5fdb754c1a7c36c288c46765c9258bb2c7f38fa2a99188a623182f877da3783) that was signed with the same stolen certificate.
label: SHA2

text: Derusbi is known to be used by multiple advanced persistent threat (APT) groups.
label: malware

text: The server-side variant has also been noted to be used as a malware loader by the Winnti Group.
label: threat-actor

text: 3.      We found an interesting Cobalt Strike loader (a7e9e2bec3ad283a9a0b130034e822c8b6dfd26dda855f883a3a4ff785514f97) that embeds a URL that leads to the BIOPASS RAT loader.
label: SHA2

text: However, the URL is unused and was likely left inside the loader as a mistake.
label: safe

text: The Cobalt Strike loader, which has a PDB string “C:\Users\test\Desktop\fishmaster\x64\Release\fishmaster.pdb”, connects to the C&C server “download[.]google-images[.]ml”.
label: tools

text: The domains and the PDB string have been mentioned in a recent report and have been attributed to the Winnti Group.
label: threat-actor

text: While these connections allow us to link the malware to the Winnti Group, the different targets between BIOPASS RAT and the current operations by Winnti’s that we are tracking makes associating the two more difficult.
label: threat-actor

text: BIOPASS RAT highlights the importance of downloading from trusted sources BIOPASS RAT is a sophisticated type of malware that is implemented as Python scripts.
label: malware

text: It possesses many features, such as the ability to use scheduled tasks as a method of maintaining persistence in the infected system.
label: safe

text: The malware abuses publicly available tools and cloud services for its malicious behavior.
label: safe

text: Given that the malware loader was delivered as an executable disguised as a legitimate update installer on a compromised website, we advise users to be careful  with regard to the applications that they download.
label: safe

text: As much as possible, it is recommended to download apps only from trusted sources and official websites to avoid being compromised by attacks such as the one discussed here.
label: safe

text: Organizations can also help protect their end users by implementing security solutions that provide  a multilayered defense system that helps with detecting, scanning, and blocking malicious URLs.
label: safe

text: Note that we’ve submitted an abuse report to Alibaba, but we have yet to receive feedback at the time of publication.
label: identity

text: This post is also available in:      日本語 (Japanese)  On May 4, 2022, F5 released a security advisory for a remote code execution vulnerability in the iControlREST component of its BIG-IP product tracked in CVE-2022-1388.
label: vulnerability

text: Threat actors can exploit this vulnerability to bypass authentication and run arbitrary code on unpatched systems.
label: attack-pattern

text: This is a critical vulnerability that needs immediate attention, as it was given a 9.8 CVSS score.
label: safe

text: Since the release of this advisory, mass scanning activity has started to occur, seeking unpatched systems, and in-the-wild exploitation has begun.  Palo Alto Networks released a Threat Prevention signature for the F5 BIG-IP Authentication Bypass Vulnerability (92570) and within just 10 hours, the signature triggered 2,552 times due to vulnerability scanning and active exploitation attempts.
label: identity

text: Unit 42 recommends customers upgrade to the latest release of F5 BIG-IP products.
label: identity

text: Palo Alto Networks Next Generation Firewall Threat Prevention customers are protected with Signature 92570.
label: identity

text: Vulnerable Systems Mitigation Actions Observed in the Wild Conclusion Additional Resources Indicators of Compromise  The F5 product vulnerable to CVE-2022-1388 is BIG-IP with the following versions:  The vulnerability exists within the iControl REST framework used by BIG-IP.
label: vulnerability

text: We recommend that customers update their F5 BIG-IP deployments to one of the following versions that have patches to mitigate CVE-2022-1388:
label: tools

text: Until you can install the patched versions of BIG-IP, see the Mitigation section on the F5 security advisory for information on how to mitigate this vulnerability via a workaround to limit the vulnerable component to trusted networks.  In response to the F5 security advisory, Palo Alto Networks released the Threat Prevention signature F5 BIG-IP Authentication Bypass Vulnerability (92570) on May 9.
label: TIME

text: We observed this signature triggered 2,552 times between 4:47 and 14:00 UTC on May 10.
label: TIME

text: We were able to analyze 2,151 packets that triggered the signature and observed both vulnerability scanning activity and active exploitation attempts.
label: safe

text: Table 1 shows the commands that would be executed in the event of successful exploitation.
label: safe

text: These were found by analysis of the packet captures that triggered the F5 BIG-IP Authentication Bypass Vulnerability signature.
label: vulnerability

text: Table 1. Commands observed in CVE-2022-1388 exploitation attempts.
label: vulnerability

text: Palo Alto Networks customers receive protections against the exploitation of this vulnerability in the following ways:  Palo Alto Networks will update this Threat Brief with new information and recommendations as they become available.
label: identity

text: Blackgear (also known as Topgear and Comnie) is a cyberespionage campaign dating back to 2008, at least based on the Protux backdoor used by its operators.
label: campaign

text: In 2016, for instance, we found their campaigns attacking Japanese organizations with various malware tools, notably the Elirks backdoor.
label: TIME

text: Blackgear’s operators are well-organized, developing their own tools, which we observed to have been recently fine-tuned, based on their latest attacks.
label: threat-actor

text: A notable characteristic of Blackgear is the degree to which its attacks are taken to evade detection, abusing blogging, microblogging, and social media services to hide its command-and-control (C&C) configuration.
label: attack-pattern

text: Compared to when C&C information is embedded within the malware, where it’s preset and can thus be easily blocked, this tactic lets Blackgear’s operators to quickly change C&C servers as needed.
label: threat-actor

text: It can, in turn, prolong the campaign’s foothold in the system and enable attackers to carry out further lateral movement.
label: attack-pattern

text: Analyzing the Marade downloader (detected by Trend Micro as TSPY_MARADE.ZTBC) and the version of Protux (BKDR_PROTUX.ZTBC) employed by Blackgear’s latest campaigns, we found their encrypted configurations on blog and social media posts (see Figure 1).
label: malware

text: This can be an indication that these malware tools were developed by the same group.
label: safe

text: Figure 1. Marade’s encrypted configuration on a Facebook post Figure 2. Infection chain of Blackgear’s attack Attack chain
label: threat-actor

text: To paint a bigger picture of Blackgear’s attacks, we correlated the tools and tactics they used against their targets.
label: threat-actor

text: Here’s a summary of Blackgear’s latest campaign:  Use a decoy document or fake installer file, sent via spam email to lure a potential victim into clicking it.
label: campaign

text: The decoy document will extract the Marade downloader.
label: malware

text: It drops itself in the machine’s Temp folder and increases its file size to over 50MB in order to bypass traditional sandbox solutions.
label: safe

text: Marade will check if the infected host can connect to the internet and if it is installed with anti-virus (AV) software.
label: malware

text: If the affected system can connect online and doesn’t have AV software, Marade will connect to a Blackgear-controlled public blog or social media post to retrieve an encrypted C&C configuration.
label: Infrastucture

text: Otherwise, Marade will use the C&C information embedded in its code.
label: malware

text: The encrypted strings will pose as a magnet link to keep its malicious traffic from being detected by AV software.
label: safe

text: Marade will then decrypt the encrypted strings and retrieve the C&C server information.
label: malware

text: The C&C server will send Protux to the victim’s host and execute it.
label: malware

text: Protux, a known backdoor, is executed by abusing the rundll32 dynamic-link library (DLL).
label: malware

text: It tests the host’s network, retrieves the C&C server from another blog, and uses the RSA algorithm to generate the session key and send information to the C&C server.  Blackgear’s malware tools are delivered to targets using RAR self-extracting executable (SFX) files or office Visual Basic Script (VBScript) to create a decoy document.
label: attack-pattern

text: Below is a screenshot of the SFX files and document used by the latest campaigns: Figure 3.
label: safe

text: Contents of malicious SFX file used by Blackgear, posing as a Flash Player installer  Figure 4. Malicious document used by Blackgear (top) and how VBScript is used to execute Marade (bottom)
label: threat-actor

text: Encrypted configurations of Protux (top) and Marade (bottom) in the same blog post Correlating Marade and Protux
label: malware

text: The encrypted configurations of Marade and Protux can both be found on a single blog post.
label: malware

text: As shown in Figure 5, the strings highlighted in red function as a search tag to identify the location of the configuration information; those highlighted in orange pertain to the encrypted configuration that Protux will retrieve.
label: malware

text: In Blackgear’s previous campaigns, Protux’s configuration format had to be changed to another version.
label: threat-actor

text: For instance, Protux’s older iteration will look for the “++a++” tag, as shown in Figure 5.
label: malware

text: The format used by Protux’s latest version is now similar to Marade’s, as shown in Figure 6.
label: malware

text: Protux’s encrypted configuration on a public blog (note the six magnet URLs; the third is Protux’s latest configuration format)
label: malware

text: Reverse analysis of Protux’s latest version also allowed us to determine how to decrypt the C&C information, which is done in the Python code shown below.
label: malware

text: This can also be used by researchers, system administrators, and information security professionals when decrypting Protux’s latest version.
label: malware

text: /usr
label: safe

text: bin
label: safe

text: env python2
label: safe

label: safe

text: tail = str.find("&xl=")     if -1 ==tail: tail = str.find("&xl=")     if -1 == head or -1 == tail:       print("can't find delimiter") sys.exit()
label: safe

text: b64_data = str[len("magnet:?xt=urn:bhih:"): tail] b64_decode = base64.b64decode(b64_data) key = ord(b64_decode[2]) data = b64_decode[4:] output_file = open("C2_info", "wb")     for single_byte in data: output_file.write(chr(ord(single_byte) ^ key)) output_file.close()
label: safe

text: if __name__ == '__main__': decrypt (
label: safe

text: A new remote controller tool
label: safe

text: We were also able to source a sample of Protux’s remote controller tool.
label: malware

text: This provides a user interface (UI) that allows attackers to send instructions to and monitor any compromised endpoint host.
label: safe

text: This tool can also remotely control Marade in the affected system.
label: malware

text: Figure 7.
label: safe

text: The controller retrieving the Marade-related information (top) and collecting Protux-related information (bottom)
label: malware

text: Based on the controller’s behavior, we can posit that both Marade and Protux were authored by the same threat actors.
label: malware

text: Each serves a specific role once in the system.
label: safe

text: Marade acts as the first stage of attack, sending the compromised system’s information to the C&C server and then awaiting commands from the controller.
label: malware

text: This allows threat actors to monitor and check whether the affected system is of interest to them.
label: safe

text: If so, the attack moves to the second stage by deploying Protux.
label: malware

text: The tool can also control the communication between the backdoor and attacker in real time.
label: safe

text: The following is a list of Protux’s notable components and their functions:  FileManage - Lists all of the system’s drives and folders.
label: malware

text: ProcManage - Lists all of the processes, modules, threads, and ports in the compromised host.
label: safe

text: ServiceManage - Lists all of the services in the compromised host.
label: safe

text: RegManage - Lists all of the registries in the compromised host.
label: safe

text: ScreenManage - Takes a screenshot.
label: safe

text: ShellManage - Creates a shell.
label: safe

text: Protux:
label: malware

text: An old dog learning new tricks Protux is an old backdoor, with its first version developed in 2005.
label: malware

text: It uses DLL injection to execute its routines.
label: safe

text: Based on this behavior, we can map out a pattern, from the downloader to the decoy documents used.
label: safe

text: The trigger format is: %system32/rundll32.exe <PROTUX file name> <export name>.
label: FILEPATH

text: We saw two notable changes throughout Protux’s history: its export name and how it functions:
label: malware

text: Export name Year How C&C information is retreieved TStartUp 2005 – 2012
label: TIME

text: Directly connect to the C&C server and use DNS server to retrieve the C&C IP address.
label: safe

text: CRestart 2009 – 2014 Use web DNS query to retrieve the C&C IP address, e.g., ip138[.]com.
label: TIME

text: CReset 2013 – 2018
label: malware

text: Find the encrypted configuration through keywords on blog services.
label: safe

text: Our research into and correlation of Protux led us to several samples that have version numbers embedded in them.
label: malware

text: The highlighted portions in Figure 8 show the backdoor’s version number and timestamp with the “with encrypt” strings.
label: safe

text: We also found that these versions encrypt the communication to its C&C servers.
label: safe

text: Protux’s latest version, 3.7, uses the open-source compiler OpenCSP to generate a session key with the RSA algorithm.
label: malware

text: Figure 8.
label: safe

text: Different versions of Protux used by Blackgear Figure 9.
label: malware

text: Protux with the OpenCSP encryption function Building a proactive incident response strategy Blackgear has been targeting various industries since its emergence a decade ago.
label: threat-actor

text: Its apparent staying power stems from the furtive ways with which its attacks can evade traditional security solutions.
label: safe

text: For instance, Blackgear employs two stages of infection for each of its attacks.
label: threat-actor

text: The potential victim may not be able to notice the intrusions as the first stage involves only profiling and reconnaissance.
label: safe

text: And once infection with a backdoor occurs, typical red flags may not be raised as it abuses microblogging and social media services to retrieve information needed for C&C communication.
label: safe

text: Indeed, Blackgear’s attacks exemplify the need for organizations to develop and implement security strategies that can proactively respond to threats.
label: threat-actor

text: A robust threat hunting strategy, for instance, helps validate indicators of attack to ascertain if the intrusions, threats, or suspicious system activities are one-off attacks or part of a larger campaign.
label: safe

text: This further visibility equips organizations with actionable threat intelligence, context, and insights that can be used to delve deeper into an attack — which security gaps are exploited, if the attack has multiple payloads, or if the malware has already spread within the network.
label: safe

text: Organizations can also consider managed detection and response, which provides in-depth threat analysis and correlation — from networks to servers and endpoints — to obtain a complete picture of and further understand a targeted attack.
label: safe

text: Managed detection and response also helps make better sense of system- and network-level activities that an organization may not have the time or resources to do.
label: safe

text: A list of indicators of compromise (IoCs) related to Blackgear is in this appendix.
label: threat-actor

text: Trend Micro solutions
label: identity

text: The Trend Micro™ Deep Discovery™ solution provides detection, in-depth analysis, and proactive response to today’s stealthy malware and targeted attacks in real time.
label: identity

text: It provides a comprehensive defense tailored to protect organizations against targeted attacks and advanced threats through specialized engines, custom sandboxing, and seamless correlation across the entire attack life cycle, allowing it to detect threats delivered by Blackgear even without any engine or pattern update.
label: threat-actor

text: Blackgear’s campaigns also use email as an entry point, which is why it’s important to secure the email gateway.
label: threat-actor

text: The Trend Micro™ Hosted Email Security no-maintenance cloud solution delivers continuously updated protection to stop spam, malware, spear phishing, and advanced targeted attacks before they reach the network.
label: attack-pattern

text: The Trend Micro™ Deep Discovery™ Email Inspector and InterScan™ Web Security solutions prevent malware from ever reaching end users.
label: tools

text: At the endpoint level, the Trend Micro™ Smart Protection Suites deliver several capabilities that minimize the impact of attacks.
label: identity

text: Tags  Articles, News, Reports | APT & Targeted Attacks | Research
label: safe

text: In November 2019, we published a blog analyzing an exploit kit we named Capesand that exploited Adobe Flash and Microsoft Internet Explorer flaws.
label: TIME

text: During our analysis of the indicators of compromise (IoCs) in the deployed samples that were infecting the victim’s machines, we noticed some interesting characteristics: notably that these samples were making use of obfuscation tools that made them virtually undetectable.
label: safe

text: After some data collection we found more than 300 samples that correlate to the mentioned indicators that were recently very active  our first detections occurred in August, with the campaign itself still ongoing (having occasional spikes in between).
label: TIME

text: We saw a rising usage of tools that provide fully-undetectable obfuscation capabilities – signifying that the authors behind the samples designed their malware variants to be as stealthy as possible.
label: safe

text: We decided to name the potential campaign associated with these IoCs as “KurdishCoder”, based on the property name of an assembly module found in one of the samples.
label: campaign

text: We took a look at one of the samples captured from Capesand that was used to deploy the njRat malware – notably its main executable NotepadEx.
label: malware

text: We found that were multiple layers of obfuscation using a combination of two tools: the .NET protectors ConfuserEx and Cassandra (CyaX).
label: tools

text: Both of these tools are used in combination to provide an array of fully undetectable capabilities to the deployed njRat malware variant.
label: malware

text: Examining the Capesand samples The simplified diagram taken from the previous blog shows the combination of ConfuserEx and Cassandra via the second layer of obfuscation protection, which involves the DLL CyaX_Sharp Assembly (both CyaX_Sharp and CyaX are part of the Cassandra protector).
label: malware

text: The infection chain for Capesand that also shows the obfuscation mechanisms For this particular sample, CyaX_Sharp is obfuscated with a customized version of ConfuserEx.
label: tools

text: The following image shows an assembly module property that was generated for this sample.
label: safe

text: The generated assembly module property
label: safe

text: The module’s property name is “KurdishCoderProducts”, with a value shown to be “ConfuserEx v1.0.0-custom”.
label: safe

text: To understand where this value is coming from, let’s take a look at the open-source ConfuserEx tool to see how the values are created.
label: tools

text: From there, we can establish a hypothesis as to their source.
label: safe

text: A closer look at ConfuserEx’s functions
label: tools

text: While ConfuserEx is able to apply multiple transformations to the target binary, we are interested in two particular functions that we can use for correlation:  Source code building.
label: tools

text: ConfuserEx is an open-source tool with multiple versions hosted on Github.
label: tools

text: By examining one of the community-supported versions, we can see there is a tool to build ConfuserEx from the command line.
label: tools

text: This build command line has a function to update the final binary versions based on the last Git-tagged version.
label: safe

text: However, if ConfuserEx is built outside Git, the version update tool will just generate the value “version-custom” as shown below.
label: tools

text: Code taken from a ConfuserEx version created outside GIT
label: tools

text: Since the string “ConfuserEx v1.0.0-custom” is present in the module property: [module: KurdishCoderProducts("ConfuserEx v1.0.0-custom")]”, we can surmise that the version of ConfuserEx that was used for CyaX_Sharp was indeed built outside of Git.
label: tools

text: 2. Watermarking
label: safe

text: When ConfuserEx performs its obfuscation routine, one of the operations creates a watermark – a unique identifier within the software--that is present in the final binary.
label: tools

text: The watermarking technique is implemented through the module attributes of the assembly.
label: safe

text: The following source code screenshot shows how this is implemented.
label: safe

text: Figure 4. Code showing how the watermarking is performed via the module attributes of the assembly
label: safe

text: From the previous code section, we can see the default attribute added by ConfuserEx is “ConfusedBy”.
label: tools

text: If we test it using a sample binary, the following is generated:  Figure 5. Testing a sample binary using ConfuserEx There are two important aspects to this attribute: first, it is hardcoded as a string constant and second, its value is presented in clear text in the final binary as the following image shows.
label: tools

text: Figure 6.
label: safe

text: The default attribute shown in clear text in the final binary We now have solid evidence that CyaX_Sharp was obfuscated using a modified version of ConfuserEx.
label: tools

text: Next, let’s look for the attribute indicator, starting with the CyaX assembly used in the NotepadEx attack.
label: campaign

text: Cassandra Protector: CyaX
label: tools

text: After inspection we noticed that this version of CyaX was similarly notable due to two characteristics.
label: tools

text: First, the debug symbols paths were leaked -- suggesting a possible custom build which can be correlated with another modification applied to CyaX.  Figure 7.
label: tools

text: The leaked debug symbols paths
label: safe

text: The second indicator has to do with one of the methods of CyaX which was modified -- specifically the one injecting the binary in memory.
label: tools

text: The following image shows the modified function name.
label: safe

text: Figure 8.
label: safe

text: The modified method which was renamed to Kirkuk, which is also a name of a city in Iraq What other payloads are using KurdishCoder?
label: safe

text: Analysis of some of the captured samples reveals the different payloads being used (as shown in the table below).
label: safe

text: Note that this does not cover all the samples – it is possible that other payloads are being deployed as well.
label: safe

text: Sample Payload KurdishCoderMainSample KurdishCoder_CyaX_Sharp CyaX_method_rename CustomIncreaseX phoenix_keylogger Yes Yes Kirkuk NotePadEx Njrat No Yes Kirkuk QuickTranslation Agent Tesla Yes Yes Kurd SandiwchGenerator Agent Tesla Yes Yes Kirkuk SimpleGame Remcos Yes Yes Kirkuk AnimalGames Hawkeye Rebord Keylogger Yes Yes Kurd   Table 1.
label: malware

text: The different samples organized name, payload delivered and the fully-undetectable stages where the attribute “KurdishCoderProduction” is present
label: safe

text: Cassandra Crypter
label: tools

text: We think one of the possible sources of the customized ConfuserEx is the online service Cassandra Crypter, which offers two kinds of subscription plans: The Premium Plan and the Private Stub.
label: tools

text: The Premium Plan requires payment and works automatically, while the Private Stub requires the user to contact the support from the service for further personalization.
label: safe

text: Figure 9.
label: safe

text: Cassandra Crypter’s subscription plans
label: tools

text: The combination of ConfuserEx and CyaX (Cassandra protector) seems to be unique and customized based on the indicators mentioned earlier.
label: tools

text: While we don’t have definitive evidence that the use of these tools are part of a single campaign, we think the analyzed samples are related to a specific campaign.
label: safe

text: Note that the KurdishCoder indicator was spotted also by the Italian Computer Emergency Response Team - Pubblica Amministrazione (CERT-PA), which they reported as a single incident.
label: identity

text: As with Capesand, we will be monitoring the use of the tools mentioned in this blog entry for any future developments and updates.
label: malware
