text: This bulletin includes coordinated influence operation campaigns terminated on our platforms in Q2 2022.
label: TIME

text: It was last updated on July 29, 2022.
label: TIME

text: The following testimony was delivered to the U.S. House Intelligence Committee by Shane Huntley, Senior Director of Google’s Threat Analysis Group (TAG) on July 27, 2022.  Chairman Schiff, Ranking Member Turner, and esteemed Members of the Committee: Thank you for the opportunity to appear before the Committee to discuss Google’s efforts to protect users from commercial spyware.
label: identity

text: Google has been tracking the activities of commercial spyware vendors for years, and we have been taking critical steps to protect our users.
label: identity

text: Our Threat Analysis Group, or TAG, is dedicated to protecting users from threats posed by state-sponsored malware attacks and other advanced persistent threats.
label: identity

text: TAG actively monitors threat actors and the evolution of their tactics and techniques.
label: identity

text: For example, TAG has been closely tracking and disrupting campaigns targeting individuals and organizations in Ukraine, and frequently publishes reports on Russian threat actors.
label: identity

text: TAG tracks and proactively counters serious state-sponsored and financially motivated information cyber criminal activities, such as hacking and the use of spyware.
label: identity

text: We are joined in this effort by many other security teams at Google, including Project Zero, our team of security researchers at Google who study zero-day vulnerabilities in the hardware and software systems that are depended upon by users around the world.
label: identity

text: Google has a long track record combating commercial surveillance tools targeting our users.
label: identity

text: In 2017, Android – which is owned by Google – was the first mobile platform to warn users about NSO Group’s Pegasus spyware.
label: TIME

text: At the time, our Android team released research about a newly discovered family of spyware related to Pegasus that was used in a targeted attack on a small number of Android devices.
label: malware

text: We remediated the compromises for these users and implemented controls to protect all Android users.
label: SOFTWARE

text: NSO Group continues to pose risks across the Internet ecosystem.
label: threat-actor

text: In 2019, we confronted the risks posed by NSO Group again, relying upon NSO Groups’s marketing information suggesting that they had a 0-day exploit for Android.
label: TIME

text: Google was able to identify the vulnerability in use and fix the exploit quickly.
label: identity

text: In December 2021, we released research about novel techniques used by NSO Group to compromise iMessage users.
label: TIME

text: iPhone users could be compromised by receiving a malicious iMessage text, without ever needing to click a malicious link.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Short of not using a device, there is no way to prevent exploitation by a zero-click exploit; it's a weapon against which there is no defense.
label: safe

text: Based on our research and findings, we assessed this to be one of the most technically sophisticated exploits we had ever seen, further demonstrating that the capabilities NSO provides rival those previously thought to be accessible to only a handful of nation states.
label: threat-actor

text: Although this Committee must be concerned with the exploits of NSO Group, it is not the only entity posing risks to our users.
label: threat-actor

text: For example, TAG discovered campaigns targeting Armenian users which utilized zero-day vulnerabilities in Chrome and Internet Explorer.
label: threat-actor

text: Reporting by CitizenLab linked this activity to Candiru, an Israeli spyware vendor.
label: identity

text: Other reporting from Microsoft has linked this spyware to the compromise of dozens of victims, including political dissidents, human rights activists, journalists, and academics.
label: identity

text: Most recently, we reported in May on five zero-day vulnerabilities affecting Chrome and Android which were used to compromise Android users.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We assess with high confidence that commercial surveillance company Cytrox packaged these vulnerabilities, and sold the hacking software to at least eight governments.
label: identity

text: Our reporting is consistent with earlier analysis produced by CitizenLab and Meta.
label: identity

text: TAG also recently released information on a segment of attackers we call “hack-for-hire” that focuses on compromising accounts and exfiltrating data as a service.
label: attack-pattern

text: In contrast to commercial surveillance vendors, who we generally observe selling a capability for the end user to operate, hack-for-hire firms conduct attacks themselves.
label: attack-pattern

text: In June, we provided examples of the hack-for-hire ecosystem from India, Russia, and the United Arab Emirates.
label: location

text: The growth of commercial spyware vendors and hack-for-hire groups has necessitated growth in TAG to counter these threats.
label: identity

text: Where once we only needed substreams to focus on threat actors such as China, Russia, and North Korea, TAG now has a dedicated analysis subteam dedicated to commercial vendors and operators.
label: location

text: Seven of the nine zero-day vulnerabilities our Threat Analysis Group discovered in 2021 were originally developed by commercial providers and sold to and used by state-sponsored actors.
label: identity

text: TAG is actively tracking more than 30 vendors with varying levels of sophistication and public exposure selling exploits or surveillance capabilities to state-sponsored actors.
label: identity

text: Last year, TAG identified an ongoing campaign targeting security researchers working on vulnerability research and development at different companies and organizations.
label: identity

text: While vulnerability research is an important contributor to online safety when that research is used to improve the security of products, vendors stockpiling zero-day vulnerabilities in secret can pose a severe risk to the Internet when the vendor itself gets compromised.
label: safe

text: This is why when Google discovers these activities, we not only take steps to protect users, but also disclose that information publicly to raise awareness and help the entire ecosystem, in line with our historical commitment to openness and democratic values.
label: identity

text: Across all Google products, we incorporate industry-leading security features and protections to keep our users safe.
label: identity

text: On Search, Google’s Safe Browsing is an industry-leading service to identify unsafe websites across the web and notify users and website owners of potential harm.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Google Safe Browsing helps protect over four billion devices every day by showing warnings to users when they attempt to navigate to unsafe sites or download harmful files.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Safe Browsing also notifies webmasters when their websites are compromised by malicious actors and helps them diagnose and resolve the problem so that their visitors stay safer.
label: SOFTWARE

text: On Gmail, we recommend certain Gmail security precautions to prevent spoofing, phishing, and spam.
label: attack-pattern

text: By default, Gmail displays warnings and moves untrustworthy emails to the user’s spam folder.
label: SOFTWARE

text: For Android, through its entire development lifecycle, we subject the products to a rigorous security program.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The Android security process begins early in the development lifecycle, and each major feature of the platform is reviewed by engineering and security resources.
label: SOFTWARE

text: During the development stage, Android-created and open source components are subject to vigorous security reviews
label: SOFTWARE

text: For users, Android provides safety and control over how apps and third parties can access the data from their devices.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We have also built additional tools to prevent successful attacks on devices that run Android once those devices are in users’ hands.
label: safe

text: For example, Google Play Protect, our built-in malware protection for Android, continuously scans devices for potentially harmful applications.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Google manages a vulnerability rewards program (VRP), rewarding researchers millions of dollars for their contributions in securing our devices and platforms.
label: identity

text: This is all part of a larger strategy to keep Google products and users, as well as the Internet at large more secure.
label: identity

text: Project Zero is also a critical component of this strategy, pushing transparency and more timely patching of vulnerabilities.
label: identity

text: Google developed Project Shield, a free protection against distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks, to protect news media and human rights organization websites.
label: identity

text: APP has a strong track record protecting users – since the program’s inception, there are no documented cases of an account compromise via phishing.
label: attack-pattern

text: We appreciate the Committee’s focus on this issue, and recommend the U.S. Intelligence Community prioritize identifying and analyzing threats from foreign commercial spyware providers as being on par with other major advanced threat actors.
label: identity

text: The U.S. should also consider ways to foster greater transparency in the marketplace, including setting heightened transparency requirements for the domestic surveillance industry.
label: identity

text: The U.S. could also set an example to other governments by reviewing and disclosing its own historical use of these tools.
label: identity

text: We welcome recent steps taken by the government in applying sanctions to the NSO Group and Candiru, and we believe other governments should consider expanding these restrictions.
label: threat-actor

text: Additionally, the U.S. government should consider a full ban on Federal procurement of commercial spyware technologies and contemplate imposing further sanctions to limit spyware vendors’ ability to operate in the U.S. and receive U.S. investment.
label: identity

text: Finally, we urge the United States to lead a diplomatic effort to work with the governments of the countries who harbor problematic vendors, as well as those who employ these tools, to build support for measures that limit harms caused by this industry.
label: identity

text: Google is investing heavily as a company and as an industry to counter serious threats to our users.
label: identity

text: Google is committed to leading the industry in detecting and disrupting these threats.
label: identity

text: Google’s Threat Analysis Group (TAG) continues to closely monitor the cybersecurity environment in Eastern Europe with regard to the war in Ukraine.
label: location

text: Many Russian government cyber assets have remained focused on Ukraine and related issues since the invasion began, while Russian APT activity outside of Ukraine largely remains the same.
label: location

text: TAG continues to disrupt campaigns from multiple sets of Russian government-backed attackers, some of which are detailed in our previous updates.
label: identity

text: Similarly, Russian observed disinformation efforts are also focused on the war in Ukraine and TAG has disrupted coordinated influence operations from several actors including the Internet Research Agency and a Russian consulting firm as detailed in the TAG Bulletin.
label: threat-actor

text: Here is a deeper look at some campaign activity TAG has observed since our last update: Turla, a group publicly attributed to Russia’s Federal Security Service (FSB), recently hosted Android apps on a domain spoofing the Ukrainian Azov Regiment.
label: identity

text: This is the first known instance of Turla distributing Android-related malware.
label: threat-actor

text: The apps were not distributed through the Google Play Store, but hosted on a domain controlled by the actor and disseminated via links on third party messaging services.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We believe there was no major impact on Android users and that the number of installs was miniscule.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The app is distributed under the guise of performing Denial of Service (DoS) attacks against a set of Russian websites.
label: attack-pattern

text: However, the 'DoS' consists only of a single GET request to the target website, not enough to be effective.
label: attack-pattern

text: The list of target websites for the app can be seen in the CyberChef recipe here.
label: tools

text: During our investigation into the Turla CyberAzov apps, we identified another Android app first seen in the wild in March 2022 that also claimed to conduct DoS attacks against Russian websites.
label: SOFTWARE

text: In this case, the Android app name was stopwar.apk (com.ddos.stopwar) and was distributed from the website stopwar.pro.
label: malware

text: This app is quite different from the Turla apps described above and written by a different developer.
label: threat-actor

text: It also downloads a list of targets from an external site, but unlike the Turla apps, it continually sends requests to the target websites until it is stopped by the user.
label: threat-actor

text: Based on our analysis, we believe that the StopWar app was developed by pro-Ukrainian developers and was the inspiration for what Turla actors based their fake CyberAzov DoS app off of.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Indicators: The Follina vulnerability (CVE-2022-30190), first disclosed in late May, received significant usage from both APT and cybercrime groups throughout June after it was patched by Microsoft.
label: identity

text: Follina is a remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability in the Microsoft Windows Support Diagnostic Tool (MSDT).
label: SOFTWARE

text: Consistent with CERT-UA reporting, TAG observed multiple Russian GRU actors - APT28 and Sandworm - conduct campaigns exploiting the Follina vulnerability.
label: identity

text: The Sandworm campaign used compromised government accounts to send links to Microsoft Office documents hosted on compromised domains, primarily targeting media organizations in Ukraine.
label: campaign

text: TAG has also observed an increasing number of financially motivated actors targeting Ukraine.
label: identity

text: One recent campaign from a group tracked by CERT-UA as UAC-0098 delivered malicious documents with the Follina exploit in password-protected archives, impersonating the State Tax Service of Ukraine.
label: identity

text: We assess this actor is a former initial ransomware access broker who previously worked with the Conti ransomware group distributing the IcedID banking trojan based on overlaps in infrastructure, tools used in previous campaigns, and a unique cryptor.
label: malware

text: Ghostwriter/UNC1151, a threat actor attributed to Belarus, has remained active targeting accounts of webmail and social media networks of Polish users.
label: threat-actor

text: They continue to use the 'Browser in the Browser' phishing technique that TAG first observed and described in March.
label: attack-pattern

text: An example of this technique, used to target Facebook users, can be seen in the screenshot below.
label: SOFTWARE

text: COLDRIVER, a Russian-based threat actor sometimes referred to as Callisto, continues to send credential phishing emails to targets including government and defense officials, politicians, NGOs and think tanks, and journalists.
label: location

text: In addition to including phishing links directly in the email, the attackers also link to PDFs and/or DOCs, hosted on Google Drive and Microsoft One Drive, that contain a link to an attacker-controlled phishing domain.
label: attack-pattern

text: These phishing domains have been blocked through Google Safe Browsing – a service that identifies unsafe websites across the web and notifies users and website owners of potential harm.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Recently observed COLDRIVER indicators: In another campaign tracked by CERT-UA as UAC-0056 we observed compromised email addresses of a Regional Prosecutor’s office of Ukraine leveraged to send malicious Microsoft Excel documents with VBA macros delivering Cobalt Strike.
label: identity

text: In just two days, the volume observed and categorized as spam by Gmail exceeded 4,500 emails.
label: SOFTWARE

text: As part of TAG's mission to counter serious threats to Google and our users, we've published analysis on a range of persistent threats including government-backed attackers, commercial surveillance vendors, and serious criminal operators.
label: identity

text: Today, we're sharing intelligence on a segment of attackers we call hack-for-hire, whose niche focuses on compromising accounts and exfiltrating data as a service.
label: attack-pattern

text: In contrast to commercial surveillance vendors, who we generally observe selling a capability for the end user to operate, hack-for-hire firms conduct attacks themselves.
label: attack-pattern

text: Both, however, enable attacks by those who would otherwise lack the capabilities to do so.
label: safe

text: We have seen hack-for-hire groups target human rights and political activists, journalists, and other high-risk users around the world, putting their privacy, safety and security at risk.
label: attack-pattern

text: They also conduct corporate espionage, handily obscuring their clients’ role.
label: safe

text: To help users and defenders, we will provide examples of the hack-for-hire ecosystem from India, Russia, and the United Arab Emirates and context around their capabilities and persistence mechanisms.
label: attack-pattern

text: The hack-for-hire landscape is fluid, both in how the attackers organize themselves and in the wide range of targets they pursue in a single campaign at the behest of disparate clients.
label: safe

text: Some hack-for-hire attackers openly advertise their products and services to anyone willing to pay, while others operate more discreetly selling to a limited audience.
label: attack-pattern

text: For example, TAG has observed Indian hack-for-hire firms work with third party private investigative services — intermediaries that reach out for services when a client requires them — and provide data exfiltrated from a successful operation.
label: location

text: This is detailed in depth in today’s Reuters investigation into the Indian hack-for-hire ecosystem.
label: location

text: We have also observed Indian hack-for-hire firms work with freelance actors not directly employed by the firms themselves.
label: location

text: The breadth of targets in hack-for-hire campaigns stands in contrast to many government-backed operations, which often have a clearer delineation of mission and targets.
label: attack-pattern

text: A recent campaign from an Indian hack-for-hire operator was observed targeting an IT company in Cyprus, an education institution in Nigeria, a fintech company in the Balkans and a shopping company in Israel.
label: location

text: Since 2012, TAG has been tracking an interwoven set of Indian hack-for-hire actors, with many having previously worked for Indian offensive security providers Appin and Belltrox.
label: TIME

text: One cluster of this activity frequently targets government, healthcare, and telecom sectors in Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, and Bahrain with credential phishing campaigns.
label: location

text: These credential phishing campaigns have ranged from targeting specific government organizations to AWS accounts to Gmail accounts.
label: campaign

text: TAG has linked former employees of both Appin and Belltrox to Rebsec, a new firm that openly advertises corporate espionage as an offering on its company website.
label: identity

text: While investigating a 2017 credential phishing campaign that targeted a prominent Russian anti-corruption journalist, we discovered the Russian attacker targeting other journalists, politicians across Europe, and various NGOs and non-profit organizations.
label: TIME

text: This hack-for-hire actor has been publicly referred to as 'Void Balaur'.
label: attack-pattern

text: These campaigns were similar regardless of target, consisting of a credential phishing email with a link to an attacker-controlled phishing page.
label: attack-pattern

text: The lures ranged from fake Gmail and other webmail provider notifications to messages spoofing Russian government organizations.
label: location

text: After the target account was compromised, the attacker generally maintained persistence by granting an OAuth token to a legitimate email application like Thunderbird or generating an App Password to access the account via IMAP.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Both OAuth tokens and App Passwords are revoked when a user changes their password.
label: safe

text: During our early investigation, TAG discovered the attacker’s public website (no longer available) advertising account hacking capabilities for email and social media services.
label: identity

text: The site claimed to have received positive reviews on Russian underground forums such as Dublikat and Probiv.cc.
label: DOMAIN

text: Over the past five years, TAG has observed the group targeting accounts at major webmail providers like Gmail, Hotmail, and Yahoo! and regional webmail providers like abv.bg, mail.ru, inbox.lv, and UKR.net.
label: identity

text: United Arab Emirates TAG is also tracking a hack-for-hire group now based in the United Arab Emirates that is mostly active in the Middle East and North Africa.
label: location

text: They have primarily targeted government, education, and political organizations including Middle East focused NGOs in Europe and the Palestinian political party Fatah.
label: location

text: Amnesty International has also reported on their campaigns.
label: safe

text: The group commonly uses Google or OWA password reset lures to steal credentials from targets, often using the MailJet or SendGrid API to send phishing emails.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Unlike many hack-for-hire actors that use open source phishing frameworks like Evilginx or GoPhish, this group uses a custom phishing kit that utilizes Selenium, a self described 'suite of tools for automating web browsers.'
label: tools

text: Previously described by Amnesty, this phishing kit has remained under active development over the past five years.
label: identity

text: After compromising an account, the actor maintains persistence by granting themselves an OAuth token to a legitimate email app like Thunderbird, or by linking the victim Gmail account to an attacker-owned account on a third-party mail provider.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The attacker would then use a custom tool to download the mailbox contents via IMAP.
label: safe

text: This group also has links to the original developers of H-Worm, also known as njRAT.
label: malware

text: In 2014, Microsoft filed a civil suit against the developer, Mohammed Benabdellah, for the development and dissemination of H-Worm.
label: TIME

text: Benabdellah, who also goes by the moniker Houdini, has been actively involved in the day-to-day development and operational deployment of the credential phishing capabilities used by this group since its inception.
label: attack-pattern

text: As part of our efforts to combat serious threat actors, we use results of our research to improve the safety and security of our products.
label: safe

text: Upon discovery, all identified websites and domains were added to Safe Browsing to protect users from further harm.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We encourage any high risk user to enable Advanced Protection and Google Account Level Enhanced Safe Browsing and ensure that all devices are updated.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Additionally, our CyberCrime Investigation Group is sharing relevant details and indicators with law enforcement.
label: identity

text: TAG is committed to sharing our findings as a way of raising awareness with the security community, and with companies and individuals that might have been targeted.
label: identity

text: We hope that improved understanding of the tactics and techniques will enhance threat hunting capability and lead to stronger user protections across the industry.
label: safe

text: With contributions from Winnona DeSombre UAE hack-for-hire Group Domains: Indian hack-for-hire Group Domains: Russian hack-for-hire Group Domains:
label: location

text: Google’s Threat Analysis Group tracks actors involved in disinformation campaigns, government backed hacking, and financially motivated abuse.
label: identity

text: Since late 2019, our team has disrupted financially motivated phishing campaigns targeting YouTubers with Cookie Theft malware.
label: TIME

text: The actors behind this campaign, which we attribute to a group of hackers recruited in a Russian-speaking forum, lure their target with fake collaboration opportunities (typically a demo for anti-virus software, VPN, music players, photo editing or online games), hijack their channel, then either sell it to the highest bidder or use it to broadcast cryptocurrency scams.
label: safe

text: In collaboration with YouTube, Gmail, Trust & Safety, CyberCrime Investigation Group and Safe Browsing teams, our protections have decreased the volume of related phishing emails on Gmail by 99.6% since May 2021.
label: identity

text: We blocked 1.6M messages to targets, displayed ~62K Safe Browsing phishing page warnings, blocked 2.4K files, and successfully restored ~4K accounts.
label: safe

text: With increased detection efforts, we’ve observed attackers shifting away from Gmail to other email providers (mostly email.cz, seznam.cz, post.cz and aol.com).
label: identity

text: Moreover, to protect our users, we have referred the below activity to the FBI for further investigation.
label: identity

text: In this blog, we share examples of the specific tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs) used to lure victims, as well as some guidance on how users can further protect themselves.
label: safe

text: Cookie Theft, also known as “pass-the-cookie attack,” is a session hijacking technique that enables access to user accounts with session cookies stored in the browser.
label: attack-pattern

text: While the technique has been around for decades, its resurgence as a top security risk could be due to a wider adoption of multi-factor authentication (MFA) making it difficult to conduct abuse, and shifting attacker focus to social engineering tactics.
label: attack-pattern

text: Many YouTube creators provide an email address on their channel for business opportunities.
label: safe

text: In this case, the attackers sent forged business emails impersonating an existing company requesting a video advertisement collaboration.
label: safe

text: The phishing typically started with a customized email introducing the company and its products.
label: attack-pattern

text: Once the target agreed to the deal, a malware landing page disguised as a software download URL was sent via email or a PDF on Google Drive, and in a few cases, Google documents containing the phishing links.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Around 15,000 actor accounts were identified, most of which were created for this campaign specifically.
label: safe

text: The attackers registered various domains associated with forged companies and built multiple websites for malware delivery.
label: safe

text: To date, we’ve identified at least 1,011 domains created solely for this purpose.
label: safe

text: Some of the websites impersonated legitimate software sites, such as Luminar, Cisco VPN, games on Steam, and some were generated using online templates.
label: SOFTWARE

text: During the pandemic, we also uncovered attackers posing as news providers with a “Covid19 news software.”
label: safe

text: In one case, we observed a fake social media page copying content from an existing software company.
label: safe

text: The following screenshot is an example of a fake page where the original URL is replaced with one leading to a cookie theft malware download.
label: safe

text: Because Google actively detects and disrupts phishing links sent via Gmail, the actors were observed driving targets to messaging apps like WhatsApp, Telegram or Discord.
label: attack-pattern

text: Once the target runs the fake software, a cookie stealing malware executes, taking browser cookies from the victim’s machine and uploading them to the actor's command & control servers.
label: safe

text: Although this type of malware can be configured to be persistent on the victim's machine, these actors are running all malware in non-persistent mode as a smash-and-grab technique.
label: safe

text: This is because if the malicious file is not detected when executed, there are less artifacts on an infected host and therefore security products fail to notify the user of a past compromise.
label: safe

text: We have observed that actors use various types of malware based on personal preference, most of which are easily available on Github.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Some commodity malware used included RedLine, Vidar, Predator The Thief, Nexus stealer, Azorult, Raccoon, Grand Stealer, Vikro Stealer, Masad (Google’s naming), and Kantal (Google’s naming) which shares code similarity with Vidar.
label: malware

text: Open source malware like Sorano and AdamantiumThief were also observed.
label: malware

text: Related hashes are listed in the Technical Details section, at the end of this report.
label: safe

text: Most of the observed malware was capable of stealing both user passwords and cookies.
label: safe

text: Some of the samples employed several anti-sandboxing techniques including enlarged files, encrypted archive and download IP cloaking.
label: safe

text: A few were observed displaying a fake error message requiring user click-through to continue execution.
label: safe

text: A large number of hijacked channels were rebranded for cryptocurrency scam live-streaming.
label: safe

text: The channel name, profile picture and content were all replaced with cryptocurrency branding to impersonate large tech or cryptocurrency exchange firms.
label: safe

text: The attacker live-streamed videos promising cryptocurrency giveaways in exchange for an initial contribution.
label: safe

text: On account-trading markets, hijacked channels ranged from $3 USD to $4,000 USD depending on the number of subscribers.
label: safe

text: These campaigns were carried out by a number of hack-for-hire actors recruited on Russian-speaking forums via the following job description, offering two types of work: This recruitment model explains the highly customized social engineering, as well as the varied malware types given each actor's choice of preferred malware.
label: safe

text: We are continuously improving our detection methods and investing in new tools and features that automatically identify and stop threats like this one.
label: safe

text: Some of these improvements include: It is also important that users remain aware of these types of threats and take appropriate action to further protect themselves.
label: safe

text: Our recommendations: Additional resources: Avoid & Report Phishing Emails.
label: safe

text: Related Malware hashes: Top Phishing Domains:
label: safe

text: Google’s Threat Analysis Group tracks actors involved in disinformation campaigns, government backed hacking, and financially motivated abuse.
label: identity

text: We have a long-standing policy to send you a warning if we detect that your account is a target of government-backed phishing or malware attempts.
label: attack-pattern

text: So far in 2021, we’ve sent over 50,000 warnings, a nearly 33% increase from this time in 2020.
label: TIME

text: This spike is largely due to blocking an unusually large campaign from a Russian actor known as APT28 or Fancy Bear.
label: threat-actor

text: We intentionally send these warnings in batches to all users who may be at risk, rather than at the moment we detect the threat itself, so that attackers cannot track our defense strategies.
label: safe

text: On any given day, TAG is tracking more than 270 targeted or government-backed attacker groups from more than 50 countries.
label: identity

text: This means that there is typically more than one threat actor behind the warnings.
label: safe

text: In this blog, we explore some of the most notable campaigns we’ve disrupted this year from a different government-backed attacker: APT35, an Iranian group, which regularly conducts phishing campaigns targeting high risk users.
label: threat-actor

text: This is the one of the groups we disrupted during the 2020 US election cycle for its targeting of campaign staffers.
label: TIME

text: For years, this group has hijacked accounts, deployed malware, and used novel techniques to conduct espionage aligned with the interests of the Iranian government.
label: identity

text: In early 2021, APT35 compromised a website affiliated with a UK university to host a phishing kit.
label: threat-actor

text: Attackers sent email messages with links to this website to harvest credentials for platforms such as Gmail, Hotmail, and Yahoo.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Users were instructed to activate an invitation to a (fake) webinar by logging in.
label: safe

text: The phishing kit will also ask for second-factor authentication codes sent to devices.
label: safe

text: APT35 has relied on this technique since 2017 — targeting high-value accounts in government, academia, journalism, NGOs, foreign policy, and national security.
label: threat-actor

text: Credential phishing through a compromised website demonstrates these attackers will go to great lengths to appear legitimate – as they know it's difficult for users to detect this kind of attack.
label: attack-pattern

text: In May 2020, we discovered that APT35 attempted to upload spyware to the Google Play Store.
label: TIME

text: The app was disguised as VPN software that, if installed, could steal sensitive information such as call logs, text messages, contacts, and location data from devices.
label: safe

text: Google detected the app quickly and removed it from the Play Store before any users had a chance to install it.
label: identity

text: Although Play Store users were protected, we are highlighting the app here as TAG has seen APT35 attempt to distribute this spyware on other platforms as recently as July 2021.
label: identity

text: One of the most notable characteristics of APT35 is their impersonation of conference officials to conduct phishing attacks.
label: threat-actor

text: Attackers used the Munich Security and the Think-20 (T20) Italy conferences as lures in non-malicious first contact email messages to get users to respond.
label: safe

text: When they did, attackers sent them phishing links in follow-on correspondence.
label: attack-pattern

text: Targets typically had to navigate through at least one redirect before landing on a phishing domain.
label: safe

text: Link shorteners and click trackers are heavily used for this purpose, and are oftentimes embedded within PDF files.
label: safe

text: We’ve disrupted attacks using Google Drive, App Scripts, and Sites pages in these campaigns as APT35 tries to get around our defenses.
label: threat-actor

text: Services from Dropbox and Microsoft are also abused.
label: identity

text: One of APT35’s novel techniques involves using Telegram for operator notifications.
label: threat-actor

text: The attackers embed javascript into phishing pages that notify them when the page has been loaded.
label: safe

text: To send the notification, they use the Telegram API sendMessage function, which lets anyone use a Telegram bot to send a message to a public channel.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The attackers use this function to relay device-based data to the channel, so they can see details such as the IP, useragent, and locales of visitors to their phishing sites in real-time.
label: safe

text: We reported the bot to Telegram and they have taken action to remove it.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We warn users when we suspect a government-backed threat like APT35 is targeting them.
label: threat-actor

text: Thousands of these warnings are sent every month, even in cases where the corresponding attack is blocked.
label: safe

text: If you receive a warning it does not mean your account has been compromised, it means you have been identified as a target.
label: safe

text: Workspace administrators are also notified regarding targeted accounts in their domain.
label: safe

text: Users are encouraged to take these warnings seriously and consider enrolling in the Advanced Protection Program or enabling two-factor authentication if they haven't already.
label: safe

text: We also block malicious domains using Google Safe Browsing – a service that Google's security team built to identify unsafe websites across the web and notify users and website owners of potential harm.
label: identity

text: When a user of a Safe Browsing-enabled browser or app attempts to access unsafe content on the web, they’ll see a warning page explaining that the content they’re trying to access may be harmful.
label: SOFTWARE

text: When a site identified by Safe Browsing as harmful appears in Google Search results, we show a warning next to it in the results.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Threat Analysis Group will continue to identify bad actors and share relevant information with others in the industry, with the goal of bringing awareness to these issues, protecting you and fighting bad actors to prevent future attacks.
label: identity

text: Indicators from APT28 phishing campaign: service-reset-password-moderate-digital.rf[.]gd reset-service-identity-mail.42web[.]io digital-email-software.great-site[.]net  Indicators from APT35 campaigns:  Abused Google Properties: https://sites.google[.]com/view/ty85yt8tg8-download-rtih4ithr/ https://sites.google[.]com/view/user-id-568245/ https://sites.google[.]com/view/hhbejfdwdhwuhscbsb-xscvhdvbc/  Abused Dropbox Properties: https://www.dropbox[.]com/s/68y4vpfu8pc3imf/Iraq&Jewish.pdf  Phishing Domains: nco2[.]live summit-files[.]com filetransfer[.]club continuetogo[.]me accessverification[.]online customers-verification-identifier[.]site service-activity-session[.]online identifier-service-review[.]site recovery-activity-identification[.]site review-session-confirmation[.]site recovery-service-activity[.]site verify-service-activity[.]site service-manager-notifications[.]info
label: URL

text: Android App: https://www.virustotal.com/gui/file/5d3ff202f20af915863eee45916412a271bae1ea3a0e20988309c16723ce4da5/detection  Android App C2: communication-shield[.]site cdsa[.]xyz
label: DOMAIN

text: To protect our users, Google’s Threat Analysis Group (TAG) routinely hunts for 0-day vulnerabilities exploited in-the-wild.
label: identity

text: In 2021, we reported nine 0-days affecting Chrome, Android, Apple and Microsoft, leading to patches to protect users from these attacks.
label: SOFTWARE

text: This blog is a follow up to our July 2021 post on four 0-day vulnerabilities we discovered in 2021, and details campaigns targeting Android users with five distinct 0-day vulnerabilities: We assess with high confidence that these exploits were packaged by a single commercial surveillance company, Cytrox, and sold to different government-backed actors who used them in at least the three campaigns discussed below.
label: threat-actor

text: Consistent with findings from CitizenLab, we assess likely government-backed actors purchasing these exploits are operating (at least) in Egypt, Armenia, Greece, Madagascar, Côte d’Ivoire, Serbia, Spain and Indonesia.
label: location

text: The 0-day exploits were used alongside n-day exploits as the developers took advantage of the time difference between when some critical bugs were patched but not flagged as security issues and when these patches were fully deployed across the Android ecosystem.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Our findings underscore the extent to which commercial surveillance vendors have proliferated capabilities historically only used by governments with the technical expertise to develop and operationalize exploits.
label: safe

text: Seven of the nine 0-days TAG discovered in 2021 fall into this category: developed by commercial providers and sold to and used by government-backed actors.
label: identity

text: TAG is actively tracking more than 30 vendors with varying levels of sophistication and public exposure selling exploits or surveillance capabilities to government-backed actors.
label: TIME

text: All three campaigns delivered one-time links mimicking URL shortener services to the targeted Android users via email.
label: safe

text: The campaigns were limited — in each case, we assess the number of targets was in the tens of users.
label: safe

text: Once clicked, the link redirected the target to an attacker-owned domain that delivered the exploits before redirecting the browser to a legitimate website.
label: safe

text: If the link was not active, the user was redirected directly to a legitimate website.
label: safe

text: We've seen this technique used against journalists and other unidentified targets, and alerted those users when possible.
label: safe

text: We assess that these campaigns delivered ALIEN, a simple Android malware in charge of loading PREDATOR, an Android implant described by CitizenLab in December 2021.
label: TIME

text: ALIEN lives inside multiple privileged processes and receives commands from PREDATOR over IPC.
label: malware

text: These commands include recording audio, adding CA certificates, and hiding apps.
label: safe

text: The first campaign, detected in August 2021, used Chrome on a Samsung Galaxy S21 and the web server immediately replied with a HTTP redirect (302) pointing to the following intent URL.
label: TIME

text: This URL abused a logic flaw and forced Chrome to load another URL in the Samsung Browser without user interaction or warnings.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We did not capture the subsequent stages, but assess the attackers did not have exploits for the current version of Chrome (91.0.4472) at that time, but instead used n-day exploits targeting Samsung Browser, which was running an older and vulnerable version of Chromium.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We assess with high confidence this vulnerability was sold by an exploit broker and probably abused by more than one surveillance vendor.
label: safe

text: More technical details about this vulnerability are available in this RCA by Maddie Stone.
label: identity

text: Related IOCs
label: safe

text: In September 2021, TAG detected a campaign where the exploit chain was delivered to a fully up-to-date Samsung Galaxy S10 running the latest version of Chrome.
label: TIME

text: We recovered the exploit used to escape the Chrome Sandbox, but not the initial RCE exploit.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The sandbox escape was loaded directly as an ELF binary embedding libchrome.so and a custom libmojo_bridge.so was used to ease the communication with the Mojo IPCs.
label: safe

text: This means the renderer exploit did not enable MojoJS bindings like we often see in public exploits.
label: safe

text: Analysis of the exploit identified two different vulnerabilities in Chrome: After escaping the sandbox, the exploit downloaded another exploit in /data/data/com.android.chrome/p.so to elevate privileges and install the implant.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We haven’t retrieved a copy of the exploit.
label: safe

text: In October 2021, we detected a full chain exploit from an up-to-date Samsung phone running the latest version of Chrome.
label: TIME

text: The chain included two 0-day exploits: Of note, CVE-2021-1048 was fixed in the Linux kernel in September 2020, over a year before this campaign.
label: vulnerability

text: The commit was not flagged as a security issue and therefore the patch was not backported in most Android kernels.
label: safe

text: At the time of the exploit, all Samsung kernels were vulnerable; LTS kernels running on Pixel phones were recent enough and included the fix for this bug.
label: safe

text: Unfortunately, this is not the first time we have seen this happen with exploits in the wild; the 2019 Bad Binder vulnerability is another example.
label: TIME

text: In both cases, the fix was not flagged as a security issue and thus not backported to all (or any) Android kernels.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Attackers are actively looking for and profiting from such slowly-fixed vulnerabilities.
label: safe

text: We’d be remiss if we did not acknowledge the quick response and patching of these vulnerabilities by Google’s Chrome and Android teams.
label: identity

text: We would also like to thank Project Zero for their technical assistance in helping analyze these bugs.
label: safe

text: TAG continues to track more than 30 vendors with varying levels of sophistication and public exposure selling exploits or surveillance capabilities to government-backed actors.
label: identity

text: We remain committed to updating the community as we uncover these campaigns.
label: safe

text: Tackling the harmful practices of the commercial surveillance industry will require a robust, comprehensive approach that includes cooperation among threat intelligence teams, network defenders, academic researchers and technology platforms.
label: safe

text: We look forward to continuing our work in this space and advancing the safety and security of our users around the world.
label: safe

text: NOTE: On May 20th, we updated our attribution to more precisely describe our findings.
label: TIME

text: Google’s Threat Analysis Group (TAG) has been closely monitoring the cybersecurity activity in Eastern Europe with regard to the war in Ukraine.
label: identity

text: Since our last update, TAG has observed a continuously growing number of threat actors using the war as a lure in phishing and malware campaigns.
label: identity

text: Similar to other reports, we have also observed threat actors increasingly target critical infrastructure entities including oil and gas, telecommunications and manufacturing.
label: safe

text: Financially motivated and criminal actors are also using current events as a means for targeting users.
label: safe

text: As always, we continue to publish details surrounding the actions we take against coordinated influence operations in our quarterly TAG bulletin.
label: identity

text: We promptly identify and remove any such content but have not observed any significant shifts from the normal levels of activity that occur in the region.
label: safe

text: Here is a deeper look at the campaign activity TAG has observed and the actions the team has taken to protect our users over the past few weeks: APT28 or Fancy Bear, a threat actor attributed to Russia GRU, was observed targeting users in Ukraine with a new variant of malware.
label: location

text: The malware, distributed via email attachments inside of password protected zip files (ua_report.zip), is a .Net executable that when executed steals cookies and saved passwords from Chrome, Edge and Firefox browsers.
label: FILEPATH

text: The data is then exfiltrated via email to a compromised email account.
label: safe

text: Malware samples:
label: safe

text: TAG would like to thank the Yahoo! Paranoids Advanced Cyber Threats Team for their collaboration in this investigation.
label: identity

text: Turla, a group TAG attributes to Russia FSB, continues to run campaigns against the Baltics, targeting defense and cybersecurity organizations in the region.
label: identity

text: Similar to recently observed activity, these campaigns were sent via email and contained a unique link per target that led to a DOCX file hosted on attacker controlled infrastructure.
label: safe

text: When opened, the DOCX file would attempt to download a unique PNG file from the same attacker controlled domain.
label: safe

text: Recently observed Turla domains: COLDRIVER, a Russian-based threat actor sometimes referred to as Callisto, continues to use Gmail accounts to send credential phishing emails to a variety of Google and non-Google accounts.
label: threat-actor

text: The targets include government and defense officials, politicians, NGOs and think tanks, and journalists.
label: safe

text: The group's tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs) for these campaigns have shifted slightly from including phishing links directly in the email, to also linking to PDFs and/or DOCs hosted on Google Drive and Microsoft One Drive.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Within these files is a link to an attacker controlled phishing domain.
label: safe

text: These phishing domains have been blocked through Google Safe Browsing – a service that identifies unsafe websites across the web and notifies users and website owners of potential harm.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Recently observed COLDRIVER credential phishing domains: Ghostwriter, a Belarusian threat actor, has remained active during the course of the war and recently resumed targeting of Gmail accounts via credential phishing.
label: threat-actor

text: If the user clicked continue, they would be redirected to an attacker controlled site that collected the users credentials.
label: safe

text: There were no accounts compromised from this campaign and Google will alert all targeted users of these attempts through our monthly government-backed attacker warnings.
label: identity

text: Both pages from this campaign are shown below.
label: safe

text: In mid-April, TAG detected a Ghostwriter credential phishing campaign targeting Facebook users.
label: TIME

text: The targets, primarily located in Lithuania, were sent links to attacker controlled domains from a domain spoofing the Facebook security team.
label: identity

text: Recently observed Ghostwriter credential phishing domains and emails: Curious Gorge, a group TAG attributes to China's PLA SSF, has remained active against government, military, logistics and manufacturing organizations in Ukraine, Russia and Central Asia.
label: location

text: In Russia, long running campaigns against multiple government organizations have continued, including the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
label: identity

text: Over the past week, TAG identified additional compromises impacting multiple Russian defense contractors and manufacturers and a Russian logistics company.
label: identity

text: Upon discovery, all identified websites and domains were added to Safe Browsing to protect users from further exploitation.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We also send all targeted Gmail and Workspace users government-backed attacker alerts notifying them of the activity.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We encourage any potential targets to enable Google Account Level Enhanced Safe Browsing and ensure that all devices are updated.
label: safe

text: The team continues to work around the clock, focusing on the safety and security of our users and the platforms that help them access and share important information.
label: safe

text: We’ll continue to take action, identify bad actors and share relevant information with others across industry and governments, with the goal of bringing awareness to these issues, protecting users and preventing future attacks.
label: safe

text: In early March, Google’s Threat Analysis Group (TAG) published an update on the cyber activity it was tracking with regard to the war in Ukraine.
label: identity

text: Since our last update, TAG has observed a continuously growing number of threat actors using the war as a lure in phishing and malware campaigns.
label: identity

text: TAG has also continued to observe multiple ransomware brokers continuing to operate in a business as usual sense.
label: identity

text: As always, we continue to publish details surrounding the actions we take against coordinated influence operations in our quarterly TAG bulletin.
label: identity

text: We promptly identify and remove any such content, but have not observed any significant shifts from the normal levels of activity that occur in the region.
label: safe

text: Here is a deeper look at the campaign activity TAG has observed over the past two weeks: Curious Gorge, a group TAG attributes to China's PLA SSF, has conducted campaigns against government and military organizations in Ukraine, Russia, Kazakhstan, and Mongolia.
label: location

text: While this activity largely does not impact Google products, we remain engaged and are providing notifications to victim organizations.
label: identity

text: Recently observed IPs used in Curious Gorge campaigns: COLDRIVER, a Russian-based threat actor sometimes referred to as Calisto, has launched credential phishing campaigns, targeting several US based NGOs and think tanks, the military of a Balkans country, and a Ukraine based defense contractor.
label: threat-actor

text: However, for the first time, TAG has observed COLDRIVER campaigns targeting the military of multiple Eastern European countries, as well as a NATO Centre of Excellence.
label: identity

text: These campaigns were sent using newly created Gmail accounts to non-Google accounts, so the success rate of these campaigns is unknown.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We have not observed any Gmail accounts successfully compromised during these campaigns.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Recently observed COLDRIVER credential phishing domains: Ghostwriter, a Belarusian threat actor, recently introduced a new capability into their credential phishing campaigns.
label: location

text: In mid-March, a security researcher released a blog post detailing a 'Browser in the Browser' phishing technique.
label: TIME

text: While TAG has previously observed this technique being used by multiple government-backed actors, the media picked up on this blog post, publishing several stories highlighting this phishing capability.
label: identity

text: Ghostwriter actors have quickly adopted this new technique, combining it with a previously observed technique, hosting credential phishing landing pages on compromised sites.
label: attack-pattern

text: The new technique, displayed below, draws a login page that appears to be on the passport.i.ua domain, overtop of the page hosted on the compromised site.
label: DOMAIN

text: Once a user provides credentials in the dialog, they are posted to an attacker controlled domain.
label: safe

label: threat-actor

text: On February 10, Threat Analysis Group discovered two distinct North Korean government-backed attacker groups exploiting a remote code execution vulnerability in Chrome, CVE-2022-0609.
label: TIME

text: These groups' activity has been publicly tracked as Operation Dream Job and Operation AppleJeus.
label: campaign

text: However, other organizations and countries may have been targeted.
label: safe

text: One of the campaigns has direct infrastructure overlap with a campaign targeting security researchers which we reported on last year.
label: safe

text: The exploit was patched on February 14, 2022.
label: TIME

text: The earliest evidence we have of this exploit kit being actively deployed is January 4, 2022.
label: TIME

text: We suspect that these groups work for the same entity with a shared supply chain, hence the use of the same exploit kit, but each operate with a different mission set and deploy different techniques.
label: safe

text: It is possible that other North Korean government-backed attackers have access to the same exploit kit.
label: threat-actor

text: In this blog, we will walk through the observed tactics, techniques and procedures, share relevant IOCs and analyze the exploit kit used by the attackers.
label: safe

text: In line with our current disclosure policy, we are providing these details 30 days after the patch release.
label: safe

text: The campaign, consistent with Operation Dream Job, targeted over 250 individuals working for 10 different news media, domain registrars, web hosting providers and software vendors.
label: campaign

text: The targets received emails claiming to come from recruiters at Disney, Google and Oracle with fake potential job opportunities.
label: identity

text: The emails contained links spoofing legitimate job hunting websites like Indeed and ZipRecruiter.
label: identity

text: Victims who clicked on the links would be served a hidden iframe that would trigger the exploit kit.
label: safe

text: Attacker-Owned Fake Job Domains: Exploitation URLs:
label: safe

text: Another North Korean group, whose activity has been publicly tracked as Operation AppleJeus, targeted over 85 users in cryptocurrency and fintech industries leveraging the same exploit kit.
label: location

text: This included compromising at least two legitimate fintech company websites and hosting hidden iframes to serve the exploit kit to visitors.
label: safe

text: In other cases, we observed fake websites — already set up to distribute trojanized cryptocurrency applications — hosting iframes and pointing their visitors to the exploit kit.
label: safe

text: Attacker-Owned Websites: Compromised Websites (Feb 7 - Feb 9): Exploitation URLs:
label: safe

text: The attackers made use of an exploit kit that contained multiple stages and components in order to exploit targeted users.
label: safe

text: The attackers placed links to the exploit kit within hidden iframes, which they embedded on both websites they owned as well as some websites they compromised.
label: safe

text: The kit initially serves some heavily obfuscated javascript used to fingerprint the target system.
label: safe

text: This script collected all available client information such as the user-agent, resolution, etc. and then sent it back to the exploitation server.
label: safe

text: If a set of unknown requirements were met, the client would be served a Chrome RCE exploit and some additional javascript.
label: SOFTWARE

text: If the RCE was successful, the javascript would request the next stage referenced within the script as “SBX”, a common acronym for Sandbox Escape.
label: attack-pattern

text: We unfortunately were unable to recover any of the stages that followed the initial RCE.
label: attack-pattern

text: Careful to protect their exploits, the attackers deployed multiple safeguards to make it difficult for security teams to recover any of the stages.
label: safe

text: These safeguards included: Although we recovered a Chrome RCE, we also found evidence where the attackers specifically checked for visitors using Safari on MacOS or Firefox (on any OS), and directed them to specific links on known exploitation servers.
label: attack-pattern

text: We did not recover any responses from those URLs.
label: safe

text: Example Exploit Kit:
label: safe

text: The attackers made multiple attempts to use the exploit days after the vulnerability was patched on February 14, which stresses the importance of applying security updates as they become available.
label: TIME

text: Upon discovery, all identified websites and domains were added to Safe Browsing to protect users from further exploitation.
label: safe

text: We also sent all targeted Gmail and Workspace users government-backed attacker alerts notifying them of the activity.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We encourage any potential targets to enable Enhanced Safe Browsing for Chrome and ensure that all devices are updated.
label: safe

text: TAG is committed to sharing our findings as a way of raising awareness with the security community, and with companies and individuals that might have been targeted or suffered from these activities.
label: identity

text: We hope that improved understanding of the tactics and techniques will enhance threat hunting capability and lead to stronger user protections across industry.
label: safe

text: &nbsp; [Lightly edited transcript of the video above] Hi there, Mark Nunnikhoven from Trend Micro Research, I want to talk to you about the concept of lateral movement.
label: attack-pattern

text: And the reason why I want to tackle this today is because I've had some conversations in the last few days that have really kind of hit that idea bulb that people don't truly understand how cybercriminals get away with their crimes in the organization.
label: safe

text: Specifically how they launch their attacks
label: safe

text: Now don't get me wrong, this isn't to blame on defenders.
label: safe

text: This isn't to blame of the general public.
label: safe

text: I'm going to go with Hollywood's to blame a little bit here, because we're watching movies in Hollywood inevitably…you know the hackers in their dark hat and with no lighting, underground, Lord knows where they find these places to hack from and they are attacking directly through.
label: safe

text: You see a bunch of text go across the screen and they penetrate through the first firewall, through the second firewall in into the data.
label: safe

text: That's not how it works at all.
label: safe

text: That's ridiculous.
label: safe

text: It's absurd.
label: safe

text: [00:59] It makes for interesting cinema, just like the red code/green code in CSI Cyber, but it's not a reflection of reality and that's a real challenge.
label: safe

text: Because a lot of people don't have the experience of working with cybersecurity, working in cybersecurity, so their only perception is what they see either through media—you know TV, movies, books—or if they happen to run into somebody at in the industry.
label: safe

text: So there is an overwhelming amount of sort of information or misinformation.
label: safe

text: Not even misinformation, just storytelling that tries to make it far more dramatic than it is.
label: safe

text: The reality is that cybercriminals are out for profit.
label: safe

text: We know this time and time again—yes a bunch of nation-state stuff does happen but the vast majority of you are unaffected by it same with there's a massive amount of script-kiddie just sort of scanning random people with random tools that are just seeing what they can get away with that and if you have solid, automated defenses that doesn't really impact you.
label: safe

text: What does impact you is the vast majority of organized cybercriminals who are out to make a profit.
label: safe

text: Trend Micro had a great series and continues to have a great series on the Underground, the Digital Underground that shows just how deep these profit motivations go.
label: identity

text: This is very much a dark industry.
label: safe

text: And with that in mind we come back to the concept of lateral movement.
label: attack-pattern

text: [02:22] If an attacker breaches into your systems, whether they come in like a fourth of all attacks do via email whether they come in directly through a server compromise, which is about half of all breaches according to the Verizon data breach investigation report or one of the other methods that is commonly used…then they start to move around within your network.
label: safe

text: That's lateral movement.
label: attack-pattern

text: We talk about north/south traffic with the network, which is basically inside the network to outside of the network, so out to the the internet and back.
label: safe

text: East/west is within the network itself.
label: safe

text: Most defenses, traditional defenses worry about that north/south traffic.
label: safe

text: Not enough worry about the east/west and it's breaking down finally.
label: safe

text: We are getting rid of this hard perimeter.
label: safe

text: "It's mine, I defend everything inside" …and realizing that this is actually how cybercriminals work.
label: safe

text: Once they're inside they move around.
label: safe

text: So we need to defend in-depth and have really great monitoring and protection tools within our networks because of this challenge of lateral movement.
label: safe

text: [03:23] Let me give you a little easier to digest analogy.
label: safe

text: Most of us in a home have a grocery list and maybe once a week—maybe twice–we head to the grocery store and we try to get everything we want off the list and then we come back.
label: safe

text: That just makes sense.
label: safe

text: That's how we do it.
label: safe

text: Right?
label: safe

text: You would never think of going, "Okay.
label: safe

text: Number one of the list is ketchup.
label: safe

text: I'm going to drive to the store to get ketchup.
label: safe

text: I'm going to buy it and I'm going to come back home.
label: safe

text: I'm going to look at item number two.
label: safe

text: I need a loaf of bread.
label: safe

text: I'm going to drive back to the store.
label: safe

text: I'm going to buy a loaf of bread and I'm going to come back and we can go to item 3, and I'm going to go and I'm going to come back.
label: safe

text: I'm going to..."
label: safe

text: That's just ridiculous, right?
label: safe

text: That's absolutely absurd and cybercrimals agree.
label: safe

text: Once they've driven to the store.
label: safe

text: They're going to buy everything that they need and everything that they see as an opportunity, right?
label: safe

text: They are really susceptible to those end caps and impulse buys... and then they're going to leave.
label: safe

text: This is how they attack our organizations.
label: safe

text: We know that, because of the average time to detect a breach is around 197 days right now and that stat has fluctuated maybe plus or minus 15 days for the last decade.
label: safe

text: We also know that it takes almost three…it takes two and a half to three months actually contain a breach once you discover it and the reason for all of this is lateral movement.
label: safe

text: Once you're in as a cybercriminal, once you've made headway, once you gained a beachhead or a foothold within that network you're going to do everything you can to expand it because it's going to make you the most amount of money.
label: safe

text: [04:55] What do you think?
label: safe

text: Let us know in the comments below, hit us up on social @TrendMicro or you can reach me directly @marknca.
label: identity

text: How are you handling lateral movement?
label: attack-pattern

text: How are you trying to reduce it?
label: safe

text: How are you looking for visibility across all of your systems?
label: safe

text: Let's continue this conversation because when we talk we all get better and more secure online.
label: safe

text: By Federico Maggi, Rainer Vosseler (Trend Micro Research), Mars Cheng, Patrick Kuo, Chizuru Toyama, Ta-Lun Yen (TXOne Networks), Erik Boasson (ADLINK), and Victor Mayoral Vilches (Alias Robotics)
label: identity

text: Despite being unknown even to industry practitioners, the Data Distribution Service (DDS) protocol has been in use for more than a decade.
label: safe

text: This middleware software technology is responsible for running billions of public and private devices and mechanisms currently in use.
label: safe

text: DDS is integral in embedded systems that require real-time machine-to-machine communication, facilitating a reliable communication layer between sensors, controllers, and actuators.
label: safe

text: This technology is situated at the beginning of the supply chain as a layer that connects, controls, and monitors applications, sensors, and actuators, aimed at maintaining interoperability and fault tolerance.
label: safe

text: It is used in various critical sectors such as healthcare, transportation, industrial internet of things (IIoT), robotics, aeronautics, and the military, among others.
label: safe

text: Given these factors, this makes the middleware technology an attractive target for attackers.
label: safe

text: We analyzed this software and found multiple security vulnerabilities.
label: safe

text: This blog lists 13 identified security gaps that were assigned new CVE IDs found in the six most common DDS implementations, mostly concerning deployment.
label: safe

text: We also show a preview of the security gaps we found in the standard’s specification and a summary of our testing procedure.
label: safe

text: For details on the known vulnerabilities, attack scenarios, and research methodology, read our full paper “A Security Analysis of the Data Distribution Service (DDS) Protocol.”
label: safe

text: All the vulnerabilities found have been disclosed and patched or mitigated by their respective vendors.
label: safe

text: New vulnerabilities
label: safe

text: We studied six widely used DDS implementations, chosen based on executions’ number of users and customers in the critical sectors globally.
label: safe

text: We also looked at each implementation’s real-time publish-subscribe (RTPS) packet, as DDS is dependent on its own lower layer standard protocol.
label: safe

text: Notably, we also studied the Robot Operating System 2 (ROS 2) because it uses DDS as its default standard operating system (OS) middleware for all robotics and automation use cases.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Given the service’s position as a security and operations building block, all vulnerabilities that affect DDS also affect the rest of the software stack, such as RTPS and all ROS 2 instances.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Product Name
label: safe

label: safe

label: safe

text: A summary of our findings across the main DDS implementations and standard specification.
label: safe

text: When the security gaps on the network attack surface are exploited, it allows an attacker to perform spoofing, reconnaissance, automated data collection, and denial of service (DoS), affecting the control of an exposed system.
label: safe

text: Meanwhile, the vulnerabilities we found on the configuration attack surface can be abused to affect the DDS developer or system integrator, potentially compromising the integrity of the software supply chain.
label: safe

text: Vulnerabilities in the standard specification
label: safe

text: The built-in RTPS discovery protocol is used in peer-to-peer networks to discover the locator of each participant (such as IP address and UDP/TCP port or offset in shared memory).
label: safe

text: The “chatty” nature of this discovery protocol and the fact that it expects a reply from each contacted participant, paired with easy-to-spoof transport protocols such as the User Datagram Protocol (UDP), make RTPS vulnerable to network reflection and amplification.
label: attack-pattern

text: Confidentiality and authenticity for this data is not protected even with DDS Security, making it possible for an attacker to spoof the information.      CVE ID
label: safe

text: Scope
label: safe

text: Partially Mitigated*
label: safe

text: BAF Percentage of Attack Duration (Total experiment duration = 139s)  CVE-2021-38425 Fast-DDS, ROS 2 master branch 9.875 100.0 CVE-2021-38429 OpenDDS, ROS 2 >= 3.18.1 18.68 24.17 CVE-2021-38487
label: vulnerability

text: The network reflection and amplification vulnerability with bandwidth amplification factor (BAF) is calculated as the ratio between outbound and reflected traffic.
label: vulnerability

text: Note: Implementations with less than 100% attack duration likely have a timeout mechanism.
label: safe

text: (*) A full mitigation will require relevant changes in the RTPS specification.
label: safe

text: The longest running node was based on Connext DDS (at 139 seconds), which we kept as a reference.
label: safe

text: Table 3 shows that the BAF is greater than one, implying there are asymmetric network flows although the values are at the order of magnitude lower than modern amplification attacks (note that Memcached can reach 10,000 to 51,000 BAF).
label: safe

text: However, the network bandwidth in embedded systems is also lower than, for example, what internet nodes can provide.
label: safe

text: An attacker can abuse this built-in discovery feature for remote discovery and fingerprinting.
label: safe

text: We sent RPTS discovery probes to the entire IPv4 space (except for the no-scan subnets) and received answers from 643 hosts (excluding obvious honeypots).
label: safe

text: Notably, hosts never stopped sending traffic to us, even if we only sent them a single 288-byte packet.
label: safe

text: This new network-reflection vulnerability that we found is not the only instance of a specification-level vulnerability.
label: safe

text: Security researchers from different organizations have been documenting and creating attack scenarios abusing these vulnerabilities as early as 2015.
label: TIME

text: Conclusion
label: safe

text: Proper supply chain management processes allow contextualization, tracking, and monitoring of new vulnerabilities within different downstream software using a specific library such as DDS.
label: safe

text: In the case of this middleware technology, DDS is just one of the many critical libraries used in embedded applications that’s easy to lose track of.
label: safe

text: Our paper, “A Security Analysis of the Data Distribution Service (DDS) Protocol,” includes short- and long-term mitigation best practices and recommendations, as well as a consideration for adopting a shift-left approach.
label: safe

text: We also acknowledge the cooperation and engaging response that some vendors like ADLINK have adopted when we approached them with our findings.
label: identity

text: As we encourage more DDS researchers, users, and implementors to keep on studying and promoting security awareness for the DDS ecosystem, we hope the level of engagement we received can serve as a model for the software industry.
label: safe

text: Download our full paper here.
label: safe
