text: Research
label: safe

text: Updated on April 26, 2017, 01:39 PM (UTC-7) to add the accurate IP address.
label: TIME

text: In particular, we managed to gather details on an individual using the handle Hack520, who we believe is connected to Winnti.
label: safe

text: Who is the Winnti group?
label: safe

text: Based on the use of domain names they registered, the group started out in the business of fake/rogue anti-virus products in 2007.
label: malware

text: The group, which was primarily motivated by profit, is noted for utilizing self-developed technically-proficient tools for their attacks.
label: safe

text: They once attacked a game server to illicitly farm in-game currency (“gaming gold”, which also has real-world value) and stole source codes of online game projects.
label: location

text: The group has since earned infamy for being involved in malicious activities associated with targeted attacks, such as deploying spear-phishing campaigns and building a backdoor.
label: location

text: These samples led us to the discovery of additional C&C servers that provided us with more information than we initially expected.
label: safe

text: A closer look at Hack520
label: safe

text: Our initial investigation on the domains registered by Hack520 revealed that similar domains (listed below) were registered by another profile.
label: safe

text: hack520[.]co[.]kr shaiya[.]kr zhu[.]kr shenqi[.]kr zhuxian[.]kr  Several of these domains are linked to variants of malware that were used by the Winnti threat actor.
label: location

text: Figure 1: Twitter account of Hack520
label: safe

text: A rough translation of this message is as follows: “Fxxk, when I am released, the server is offline, I can’t find the machine, the domain is expired, it is so bad.
label: safe

text: After further research, we were able to link Hack520 to different network administration activities, notably with a Virtual Private Server (VPS) hosting service.
label: safe

text: While one of his signatures uses his own blog domain, there is also a second signature which uses 93[.]gd, a domain that was found to have been actively selling VPS services in the past.
label: safe

text: The email address admin@93[.]gd is linked to IP addresses owned by a certain user with the nickname “PIG GOD”—another reference to Hack520’s passion for pigs.
label: safe

text: The IP range for “PIG GOD” is 43[.]255[.]188.0/22, which appears to be hosted in Hong Kong as seen in the information we found:  inetnum: 43[.]255[.]188[.]0 - 43[.]255[.]191[.]255 netname: PIG-HK description: PIG GOD country: HK admin-c: PG406-AP tech-c: PG406-AP person: pig god country: HK phone: +852-39437000 e-mail: admin@66[.]to nic-hdl: PG406-AP mnt-by: MAINT-RAIBOW-HK changed: admin@66[.]to 20160917 source: APNIC  The domain 66[.]to leads to another website that shows Hack520’s pet pig.
label: location

text: Figure 3: Hack520’s pet pig
label: safe

text: We also found a live service selling VPS hosting at secure[.]66[.]to.
label: safe

text: Figure 4: Screenshot of secure[.]66[.]to
label: safe

text: Threat actors are always looking to expand the strategies they use, thus security practices and solutions that work for less organized cybercriminals might not work for determined groups who are willing to spend time, resources and manpower to accomplish their goals.
label: location

text: Overview of Iran-Linked Campaigns:
label: safe

text: The target radius for these groups have spanned across the globe, across all major industries.
label: location

text: https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049/  OilRig is a threat group Unit 42 named and discovered in May 2016.
label: malware

text: This threat group is extremely persistent and relies heavily on spear-phishing as their initial attack vector, but has also been associated with other more sophisticated attacks such credential harvesting campaigns and DNS hijacking.
label: location

text: In their spear-phishing attacks, OilRig preferred macro-enabled Microsoft Office (Word and Excel) documents to install their custom payloads that came in the form of portable executables (PE), PowerShell and VBScripts.
label: location

text: Once gaining access to an end point, actors would use credential dumping tools, such as Mimikatz to gather credentials to legitimate accounts to then move laterally to other systems on the network.
label: location

text: https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/behind-the-scenes-with-oilrig/
label: safe

text: https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/dns-tunneling-in-the-wild-overview-of-oilrigs-dns-tunneling/  https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-analyzing-oilrigs-ops-tempo-testing-weaponization-delivery/  https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-oilrig-uses-updated-bondupdater-target-middle-eastern-government/  https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-oilrig-targets-middle-eastern-government-adds-evasion-techniques-oopsie/  https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-oilrig-targets-technology-service-provider-government-agency-quadagent/  https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-oopsie-oilrig-uses-threedollars-deliver-new-trojan/  https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-oilrig-uses-rgdoor-iis-backdoor-targets-middle-east/  https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-oilrig-performs-tests-twoface-webshell/  https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-oilrig-deploys-alma-communicator-dns-tunneling-trojan/  https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-oilrig-group-steps-attacks-new-delivery-documents-new-injector-trojan/  https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-striking-oil-closer-look-adversary-infrastructure/  https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-oilrig-uses-ismdoor-variant-possibly-linked-greenbug-threat-group/  https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-oilrig-actors-provide-glimpse-development-testing-efforts/  https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/the-oilrig-campaign-attacks-on-saudi-arabian-organizations-deliver-helminth-backdoor/  https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059/  The Magic Hound campaign targeted energy, government, and technology organizations with spear-phishing emails as a delivery mechanism. These emails delivered macro-enabled Microsoft Office documents and PE files within attachments. The documents and executables attached to emails would install a variety of tools from portable PE files, .NET Framework PE files, Meterpreter, IRC bots, an open sourced Meterpreter module called Magic Unicorn, and an open sourced Python RAT called Pupy.  The custom tools used in the Magic Hound campaign provided connections to other threat groups, such as the IRC Bot which was very similar to the Parastoo tool associated with the NEWSCASTER threat group.
label: URL

text: Also, a Magic Hound C2 server was also used as a C2 server for a tool called MPKBot that had been associated with the Rocket Kitten threat group.
label: location

text: https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-magic-hound-campaign-attacks-saudi-targets/
label: safe

text: https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064/
label: safe

text: They use spear-phishing attacks with a domain masquerading technique to make the links in their emails appear legitimate.
label: location

text: A recent report uncovered this threat group’s attack infrastructure, which leveraged commercial VPN providers in addition to compromised systems to use as proxies to further mask their origins.
label: threat-actor

text: https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2017/09/apt33-insights-into-iranian-cyber-espionage.html  https://blog.trendmicro.com/trendlabs-security-intelligence/more-than-a-dozen-obfuscated-apt33-botnets-used-for-extreme-narrow-targeting/
label: URL

text: https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0079/
label: URL

text: The DarkHydrus threat group has targeted government entities and educational institutions with spear-phishing attacks and credential harvesting campaigns.
label: threat-actor

text: DarkHydrus is a more sophisticated group when compared to others operating in the region, as their toolset and TTPs show a higher skill level.
label: threat-actor

text: DarkHydrus has used custom tools in addition to publicly available red-teaming tools such as Phishery.
label: safe

text: They have also been observed using Google Drive for their C2 channel.
label: safe

text: https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-new-threat-actor-group-darkhydrus-targets-middle-east-government/  https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-darkhydrus-uses-phishery-harvest-credentials-middle-east/  https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/darkhydrus-delivers-new-trojan-that-can-use-google-drive-for-c2-communications/

text: MuddyWater is a group that emerged in 2017 and was initially thought to be part of the financially motivated criminal group commonly referred to as FIN7 due to the use of an open source tool that was used by both sets of activity.
label: threat-actor

text: This group generally used spear-phishing with macro-enabled Office documents to deliver their payloads, which were either embedded directly in the macro, or hosted on a first stage C2 server.
label: location

text: A significant portion of MuddyWater’s toolset consisted of open sourced red-teaming tools such as Invoke-Obfuscation, Lazagne, Mimikatz, etc.  https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-muddying-the-water-targeted-attacks-in-the-middle-east/  https://securelist.com/muddywater/88059/  https://www.clearskysec.com/muddywater2/  https://blog.trendmicro.com/trendlabs-security-intelligence/muddywater-resurfaces-uses-multi-stage-backdoor-powerstats-v3-and-new-post-exploitation-tools/
label: safe

text: Assuming the highlighted groups are indeed Iranian in origin, their activity has been well documented and the various groups often times use very similar tactics and techniques to execute their attacks, such as the heavy use of spear-phishing and credential harvesting.
label: location

text: Link to IOCs on GitHub
label: safe

text: This post is also available in:      日本語 (Japanese)  Palo Alto Networks Unit 42 threat intelligence team has just released new research that has uncovered a previously unknown second wave of Shamoon 2 attacks: Second Wave of Shamoon 2 Attacks Identified  Based on our analysis, these attacks were timed to occur on November 29, 2016, twelve days after the initial Shamoon 2 attacks that we wrote about previously.
label: location

text: Like the initial Shamoon 2 attacks, this second wave of Shamoon 2 attacks utilize the Disttrack wiper malware.
label: tools

text: But this second wave of Shamoon 2 attacks show evidence of potential new tactic.
label: safe

text: VDI solutions can provide protection against a destructive malware like Disttrack through the ability to load snapshots of wiped systems to recover from a wiper attack.
label: location

text: They used access to the VSA software to deploy ransomware associated with the REvil/Sodinokibi ransomware-as-a-service group, according to reports.
label: malware

text: The company has not released further information on the vulnerability.
label: safe

text: Kaseya recommends that any organization using VSA shut the system down immediately.
label: safe

text: CISA has also issued a bulletin asking organizations using the software to follow Kaseya guidance.
label: safe

text: The full extent of the attack is currently unknown.
label: safe

text: If an MSP’s VSA system was compromised, that could allow an attacker to deploy malware into multiple networks managed by that MSP.
label: safe

text: We have not been able to independently determine how these attacks were conducted.
label: safe

text: Multiple sources have stated that the following three files were used to install and execute the ransomware attack on Windows systems:  agent.exe  | d55f983c994caa160ec63a59f6b4250fe67fb3e8c43a388aec60a4a6978e9f1e mpsvc.dll | e2a24ab94f865caeacdf2c3ad015f31f23008ac6db8312c2cbfb32e4a5466ea2 mpsvc.dll  | 8dd620d9aeb35960bb766458c8890ede987c33d239cf730f93fe49d90ae759dd  Palo Alto Networks WildFire, Threat Prevention and Cortex XDR detect and prevent REvil ransomware infections.
label: location

text: On any given day, Google's Threat Analysis Group (TAG) is tracking more than 270 targeted or government-backed attacker groups from more than 50 countries.
label: safe

text: Our team of analysts and security experts is focused on identifying and stopping issues like phishing campaigns, zero-day vulnerabilities and hacking against Google, our products and our users.
label: location

text: Today, we’re sharing recent findings on government-backed phishing, threats and disinformation, as well as a new bulletin to share information about actions we take against accounts that we attribute to coordinated influence campaigns.
label: attack-pattern

text: Last month, we sent 1,755 warnings to users whose accounts were targets of government-backed attackers.
label: safe

text: Generally, 2020 has been dominated by COVID-19.
label: safe

text: And as others have reported, we’re seeing a resurgence in COVID-related hacking and phishing attempts from numerous commercial and government-backed attackers.
label: location

text: To help protect users against these kinds of tracks, our Advanced Protection Program (APP) utilizes hardware security keys and provides the strongest protections available against phishing and account hijackings.
label: location

text: APP was designed specifically for high-risk accounts.
label: safe

text: Our products are designed with robust built-in security features, like Gmail protections against phishing and Safe Browsing in Chrome, but we still dedicate significant resources to developing new tools and technology to help identify, track and stop this kind of activity.
label: location

text: We will also continue to share more detailed analysis of vulnerabilities we find, phishing and malware campaigns that we see, and other interesting or noteworthy trends across this space.
label: location

text: This bulletin includes coordinated influence operation campaigns terminated on our platforms in Q1 of 2020.
label: safe

text: It was last updated on May 27, 2020.
label: safe

text: We terminated 3 YouTube channels as part of our ongoing investigation into coordinated influence operations linked to Iran.
label: safe

text: We received leads from Graphika that supported us in this investigation.
label: safe

text: Google’s Threat Analysis Group (TAG) is a specialized team of security experts that works to identify, report, and stop government-backed phishing and hacking against Google and the people who use our products.
label: location

text: One notable campaign attempted to target personal accounts of U.S. government employees with phishing lures using American fast food franchises and COVID-19 messaging.
label: location

text: Once people clicked on the emails, they were presented with phishing pages designed to trick them into providing their Google account credentials.
label: attack-pattern

text: The vast majority of these messages were sent to spam without any user ever seeing them, and we were able to preemptively block the domains using Safe Browsing.
label: tools

text: We’ve also seen attackers try to trick people into downloading malware by impersonating health organizations: Generally, we’re not seeing an overall rise in phishing attacks by government-backed groups; this is just a change in tactics.
label: location

text: While it’s not unusual to see some fluctuations in these numbers, it could be that attackers, just like many other organizations, are experiencing productivity lags and issues due to global lockdowns and quarantine efforts.
label: identity

text: Our teams continue to track these and stop them before they reach people—and we’ll continue to share new and interesting findings.
label: location

text: From late 2019 to February of this year, researchers published several reports on Gamaredon, tracking the group’s activities.
label: safe

text: In March, we came across an email with a malware attachment that used the Gamaredon group’s tactics.
label: safe

text: A brief history of Gamaredon   In 2015, researchers from LookingGlass published the first report on Gamaredon.
label: safe

text: The report also described Gamaredon’s political beginnings, particularly its ties to the Ukrainian revolution in 2014.
label: safe

text: They moved on to Ukrainian government institutions after the revolution.
label: safe

text: In 2018, CERT-UA published an advisory against the malware Pterodo, which the group allegedly used.
label: safe

text: The group remained active, with several Gamaredon-related activities reported in February 2020.
label: safe

text: In March, they were among the threat groups that were identified taking advantage of the coronavirus pandemic to trick targets.
label: safe

text: Opening document starts a template injection technique for loading the document template from the internet.
label: safe

text: The downloaded document template contains the malicious macro codes, which executes a VBScript (VBS).
label: safe

text: The attacks we found all arrived through targeted emails (MITRE ATT&CK framework ID T1193).
label: safe

text: The email that used the coronavirus-related subject came with an attached document file.
label: safe

text: Opening this file (MITRE ATT&CK framework ID T1204) executes the template injection method (MITRE ATT&CK framework ID T1221).
label: safe

text: Figure 2. Code for downloading the document template with the malicious macro
label: safe

text: As mentioned, the template contains malicious macro (MITRE ATT&CK framework ID T1064), which exports VBS (MITRE ATT&CK framework ID T1064) to execute itself.
label: safe

text: This particular behavior is a slight departure from previously reported attacks by Gamaredon, which did not use this technique.
label: safe

text: Registry: HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce\MediaPlayer wscript.exe //b ％USERPROFILE%\Documents\MediaPlayer\PlayList.vbs
label: REGISTRYKEY

text: Connect with “hxxp:// kristom[.]hopto[.]org /{computer name}_{hexadecimal volume serious number}/help_05_03[.]php” (MITRE ATT&CK framework IDs T1043, T1071, T1082)
label: safe

text: If the downloaded file size in the first step exceeds 10,485 bytes, then the file is saved as “%APPDATA%\\Microsoft\Windows\Cookies.txt” (MITRE ATT&CK framework ID T1105)
label: safe

text: Use XOR for the file saved from the second step, where ASCII code converted from its own hexadecimal volume serial number is used as the key.
label: safe

text: The decrypted result is saved as “%APPDATA%\\Microsoft\Windows\Cookies.exe” (T1001)
label: safe

text: If the file size of “%APPDATA%\\Microsoft\Windows\Cookies.exe” exceeds 4,485 bytes, it is executed.
label: safe

text: Interestingly, after decoding the VBS, we saw what appeared to be a programming mistake by the attacker.
label: safe

text: If, however, these lines do not pass through this IF statement, an error would occur.
label: safe

text: Network destination for template injection: 176[.]119[.]147[.]225 Network destination for VBS: 176[.]57[.]215[.]115  These IP addresses are from Russian hosting companies.
label: IPV4

text: hxxp://{FQDN}/{computer name}_{hexadecimal volume serial number}/help_{day}_{month}[.]php  Conclusion Gameradon is not the first group to take advantage of the Covid-19 topic.
label: safe

text: Be especially wary of unsolicited emails, that come from unknown senders.
label: safe

text: Avoid activating macro for any attached Microsoft Office files, especially for emails that request macro activation using an image of the body of the opened file or those that don’t show anything.
label: safe

text: Trend Micro™ Hosted Email Securityis a no-maintenance cloud solution that delivers continuously updated protection to stop spam, malware, spear phishing, ransomware, and advanced targeted attacks before they reach the network.
label: location

text: And as others have reported, we’re seeing a resurgence in COVID-related hacking and phishing attempts from numerous commercial and government-backed attackers.
label: location

text: To help protect users against these kinds of tracks, our Advanced Protection Program (APP) utilizes hardware security keys and provides the strongest protections available against phishing and account hijackings.
label: location

text: Our products are designed with robust built-in security features, like Gmail protections against phishing and Safe Browsing in Chrome, but we still dedicate significant resources to developing new tools and technology to help identify, track and stop this kind of activity.
label: location

text: We will also continue to share more detailed analysis of vulnerabilities we find, phishing and malware campaigns that we see, and other interesting or noteworthy trends across this space.
label: location

text: Google’s Threat Analysis Group (TAG) is a specialized team of security experts that works to identify, report, and stop government-backed phishing and hacking against Google and the people who use our products.
label: location

text: One notable campaign attempted to target personal accounts of U.S. government employees with phishing lures using American fast food franchises and COVID-19 messaging.
label: location

text: Once people clicked on the emails, they were presented with phishing pages designed to trick them into providing their Google account credentials.
label: attack-pattern

text: The vast majority of these messages were sent to spam without any user ever seeing them, and we were able to preemptively block the domains using Safe Browsing.
label: tools

text: We’ve also seen attackers try to trick people into downloading malware by impersonating health organizations: Generally, we’re not seeing an overall rise in phishing attacks by government-backed groups; this is just a change in tactics.
label: location

text: While it’s not unusual to see some fluctuations in these numbers, it could be that attackers, just like many other organizations, are experiencing productivity lags and issues due to global lockdowns and quarantine efforts.
label: identity

text: Following our November update, today we’re sharing the latest insights to fight phishing, and for security teams, providing more details about our work identifying attacks against zero-day vulnerabilities.
label: attack-pattern

text: We have a long-standing policy to send you a warning if we detect that your account is a target of government-backed phishing or malware attempts.
label: location

text: In 2019, we sent almost 40,000 warnings, a nearly 25 percent drop from 2018.
label: safe

text: We’ve detected a few emerging trends in recent months.
label: safe

text: Upon reviewing phishing attempts since the beginning of this year, we’ve seen a rising number of attackers, including those from Iran and North Korea, impersonating news outlets or journalists.
label: attack-pattern

text: For example, attackers impersonate a journalist to seed false stories with other reporters to spread disinformation.
label: safe

text: The chart below details the Russian threat actor group SANDWORM’s targeting efforts (by sector) over the last three years.
label: safe

text: In 2019, one in five accounts that received a warning was targeted multiple times by attackers.
label: safe

text: APP provides the strongest protections available against phishing and account hijacking and is specifically designed for the highest-risk accounts.
label: attack-pattern

text: Last year, TAG discovered that a single threat actor was capitalizing on five zero-day vulnerabilities.
label: safe

text: The exploits were delivered via compromised legitimate websites (e.g. watering hole attacks), links to malicious websites, and email attachments in limited spear phishing campaigns.
label: location

text: The majority of targets we observed were from North Korea or individuals who worked on North Korea-related issues.
label: safe

text: The vulnerabilities underlying these exploits included: Internet Explorer - CVE-2018-8653 Internet Explorer - CVE-2019-0676 Chrome - CVE-2019-5786 Windows Kernel - CVE-2019-0808 Internet Explorer - CVE-2019-1367 Internet Explorer - CVE-2019-1429
label: safe

text: Exploiting CVE-2019-0676 enabled attackers to reveal presence or non-presence of files on the victim’s computer; this information was later used to decide whether or not a second stage exploit should be delivered.
label: safe

text: The attack vector for CVE-2019-1367 was rather atypical as the exploit was delivered from an Office document abusing the online video embedding feature to load an external URL conducting the exploitation.
label: tools

text: This APT group (also referred to as Operation C-Major, PROJECTM, Mythic Leopard, and Transparent Tribe) has been known to use social engineering and phishing lures as an entry point, after which, it deploys the Crimson RAT malware to steal information from its victims.
label: threat-actor

text: In late 2021, we saw the group leverage CapraRAT, an Android RAT with clear similarities in design to the group’s favored Windows malware, Crimson RAT.
label: malware

text: Looking into one of Earth Karkaddan’s recent campaigns Typically, Earth Karkaddan’s arrival methods include the use of spear-phishing emails and a USB worm that would then drop and execute a remote access trojan (RAT).      Figure 1. Earth Karkaddan’s attack chain

label: malware

label: location

label: location

text: This malware is also commonly distributed in spear-phishing campaigns using social engineering tactics to lure victims into downloading another malicious document.
label: location

label: location

text: Crimson RAT and ObliqueRat spear-phishing email attachments that feature the same download domain     CapraRAT, One of Earth Karkaddan’s custom Android RAT
label: malware

text: Aside from using spear-phishing emails and a USB worm as arrival vectors, Earth Karkaddan also uses Android RATs that could be deployed by means of malicious phishing links.
label: location

text: This is not particularly novel for the APT group — in 2018, it used StealthAgent (detected by Trend Micro as AndroidOS_SMongo.HRX), an Android spyware that can intercept phone calls and messages, track victims’ locations, and steal photos.
label: location

text: In 2020, Earth Karkaddan used an updated version of the AhMyth Android RAT to target Indian military and government personnel via a disguised porn app and a fraudulent national Covid-19 tracking app.
label: malware

text: We observed this group using another Android RAT — TrendMicro has named this “CapraRat”— which is possibly a modified version of an open-source RAT called AndroRAT.
label: malware

text: While analyzing this android RAT, we saw several similar capabilities to the CrimsonRat malware that the group usually uses to infect Windows systems.
label: malware

text: We have been observing CapraRAT samples since 2017,  and one of the first samples we analyzed (SHA-256: d9979a41027fe790399edebe5ef8765f61e1eb1a4ee1d11690b4c2a0aa38ae42, detected by Trend Micro as as AndroidOS_Androrat.HRXD)

label: location

text: Update as of April 27, 2021, 7 A.M. E.T.:
label: TIME

text: This blog details how Iron Tiger threat actors have updated their toolkit with an updated SysUpdate malware variant that now uses five files in its infection routine instead of the usual three.
label: safe

text: A Look at the Iron Tiger Threat Group
label: threat-actor

text: In 2020 and 2021, Talent-Jump found new samples for malware families that are attributed to the Iron Tiger threat actor, which is also referred to as LuckyMouse, EmissaryPanda, and APT27.
label: location

text: While investigating Operation DRBControl in 2019, we found several connections to multiple threat actors:  Iron Tiger, which uses the HyperBro trojan and some infrastructure links Winnti, which uses the same infrastructure and code-sharing links detailed in our paper Bronze President, a threat actor that targets non-governmental organizations (NGOs).
label: threat-actor

text: However, after the publication of our report, we learned that the Type 2 malware family described in our report was the same as the “RCSession” malware family that Dell Secureworks described in a blog that they published in December 2019.
label: location

text: After finding multiple tools belonging to the Iron Tiger threat actor (which we now track as Earth Smilodon), it is likely that the new malware families that we found during the Operation DRBControl investigation came from the same threat actor.
label: threat-actor

text: New Version of SysUpdate Malware      Figure 1.
label: malware

text: The old and new SysUpdate infection chains      In December 2020, we found a sample that we identified as one belonging to the SysUpdate malware family, also named Soldier, FOCUSFJORD, and HyperSSL.
label: location

text: SysUpdate was first described by the NCC Group in 2018.
label: malware

text: An additional executable that serves as a launcher is loaded in memory, which then loads the final SysUpdate payload.
label: malware

text: Based on our investigation, instead of the usual three files, the threat actor used five:  dlpumgr32.exe, a legitimate signed file that belongs to the DESlock+ product DLPPREM32.DLL, a malicious DLL sideloaded by dlpumgr32.exe that loads and decodes DLPPREM32.bin DLPPREM32.bin, a shellcode that decompresses and loads a launcher in memory data.res, an encrypted file decoded by the launcher and contains two SysUpdate versions: one for a 32-bit architecture and another for a 64-bit architecture config.res, an encrypted file decoded by the launcher and contains the SysUpdate configuration, such as the command-and-control (C&C) address
label: location

text: In detail, this process involves multiple steps.
label: safe

text: 4  Directory to copy all files  %PROGRAMDATA%\Test\  8  Name of the legitimate executable  dlpumgr32.exe  12  Name of the sideloaded DLL  DLPPREM32.DLL
label: safe

text: 16  Name of the shellcode  DLPPREM32.bin  20  Name of the encrypted payload  data.res  24  MD5 of the encrypted payload  e43e40416520dab5b4c44ac8af907078  28  Name of the encrypted configuration  config.res  32  Name of the registry key value  servTest  36  Name of the service DisplayName  Servdisplay   Table 1.
label: MD5

text: The launcher’s behavior changes depending on the number of arguments passed to the executable.
label: safe

text: Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) will be used to run dlpumgr32.exe with arguments “-up -run -x” and it will exit the current process.
label: attack-pattern

text: One argument.
label: safe

text: Three arguments.
label: safe

text: It encodes it using another key and writes it to the registry key “Software\Classes\scConfig” (HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE or HKEY_CURRENT_USER hive, depending on the privileges of the process).
label: location

text: After decrypting the configuration, the config.res file is deleted.
label: safe

text: The launcher decrypts the data.res file with a different hardcoded DES key.
label: safe

text: The result is a file with the following structure:     Size of the 32-bit shellcode  32-bit shellcode  Size of the 64-bit shellcode  64-bit shellcode   Table 2.
label: location

text: Structure of decrypted data.res file  Lastly, the launcher starts a suspended process with the command line “C:\Windows\system32\svchost.exe -k LocalServices,”and injects the appropriate shellcode into it (either 32- or 64-bit).
label: location

label: safe

label: malware

text: On two occasions (in March and October 2020), we found a kernel rootkit that had been deployed.
label: location

text: After analysis, it appears that this rootkit’s behavior is very similar to that of the NDISProxy driver and remote access trojan (RAT).
label: attack-pattern

text: The rootkit has multiple stages before getting to the actual payload:
label: attack-pattern

text: This is done in conjunction with the Process Monitor driver (procxp152.sys), both of which are dropped upon loading the rootkit, even if they are not originally installed in the machine.
label: location

label: safe

label: safe

label: safe

text: HyperBro Malware Family
label: malware

text: The Iron Tiger APT group has used the HyperBro malware family since at least 2017.
label: malware

text: It is the evolved version of HttpBrowser, which the group has been using since at least 2015.
label: malware

text: All the requests were sent to the C&C server on port 443, with “/ajax” as the uniform resource identifier (URI).
label: safe

text: While investigating Operation DRBControl, we found an updated version of this malware family that implements some new classes.
label: threat-actor

text: We provided a detailed analysis of this new HyperBro version in our research.
label: malware

text: However, we continue seeing samples that feature the “older” behaviors, which suggests that different groups — or possibly subgroups of Iron Tiger — are using this malware family.
label: threat-actor

text: FRP Tool
label: malware

text: We found the FRP tool being used on a Linux host, which is similar to Avast’s findings in a report that they published on the Iron Tiger threat actor.
label: tools

text: The FRP tool that we analyzed was a modified version, which was possibly copied off of Github.
label: malware

text: We found three new samples of the Type 1 malware family that abuses Dropbox as a secondary C&C channel, which we described in our Operation DRBControl whitepaper.
label: location

text: This shows that the development is still active.
label: safe

text: We believe that this was a direct reaction to our research, suggesting that the threat actor read our investigation.
label: safe

text: This shows that the threat actors intended to confuse forensics investigators with incorrect timestamps, which is why it’s critical to analyze timestamps with caution during investigations.
label: safe

text: Infection Vector
label: tools

text: We could not confirm the primary infection vector.
label: tools

text: However, traces of the exploitation of the Microsoft Exchange vulnerability CVE-2020-0688 were found.
label: safe

text: Multiple infection vectors have been attributed to this threat actor in the past:  Watering holes
label: safe

text: Weaponized documents exploiting the Dynamic Data Exchange (DDE) method Weaponized documents exploiting the CVE-2018-0798 vulnerability in Equation Editor Exploitation of the CVE-2019-0604 vulnerability in Sharepoint Supply chain attack that compromises a chat software installer, Able Desktop Exploitation of recent vulnerabilities (CVE-2021-26855, CVE-2021-26857, CVE-2021-26858, and CVE-2021-27065) in Microsoft Exchange Server
label: attack-pattern

text: During our investigation, we found some old samples that fit in these categories but have not been reported.
label: safe

text: Targets
label: safe

text: The closer look into Iron Tiger was prompted because of an incident response investigation involving a Philippine-based gambling company that the group targeted.

text: Fast Reverse Proxy (FRP) Linux tool found  Conclusion
label: malware

text: We detailed how Iron Tiger threat actors have updated their tools, adding new features, and slightly changing their tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs), notably by using a rootkit to hide its backdoors.
label: location

text: We expect to see more cases involving four or five files instead of the usual “trident” in the future.
label: threat-actor

text: As we’ve observed with cybercriminal groups that aim to maximize profits for every campaign, silence doesn’t necessarily mean inactivity.
label: location

text: It appears hacking group Outlaw, which has been silent for the past few months, was simply developing their toolkit for illicit income sources.
label: safe

text: While they have been quiet since our June analysis, we observed an increase in the group’s activities in December, with updates on the kits’ capabilities reminiscent of their previous attacks.
label: safe

text: Routine
label: safe

text: The honeynet graphs, which show activity peaks associated with specific actions, also suggest that the scans were timed.
label: safe

text: The attackers could hide their activities if they noted the business hours of the intended targets and performed the actions coinciding with said times.
label: TIME

text: Anomalous properties of a command detected from traffic
label: safe

text: They attempted to evade traffic inspection by encoding the code for the scanner with base-64.
label: safe

text: Decoding the scanner revealed the following codes:  #!/bin/bash cd /tmp rm -rf .ssh rm -rf .mountfs rm -rf .X13-unix rm -rf .X17-unix rm -rf .X19-unix mkdir .X19-unix cd .X19-unix mv /var/tmp/dota3.tar.gz dota3.tar.gz tar xf dota3.tar.gz sleep 3s && cd /tmp/.X19-unix/.rsync/c nohup /tmp/.X19-unix/.rsync/c/tsm -t 150 -S 6 -s 6 -p 22 -P 0 -f 0 -k 1 -l 1 -i 0 /tmp/up.txt 192.168 >> /dev/null 2>1& sleep 8m && nohup /tmp/.X19-unix/.rsync/c/tsm -t 150 -S 6 -s 6 -p 22 -P 0 -f 0 -k 1 -l 1 -i 0
label: safe

text: /tmp
label: safe

text: > /dev/null 2>1& sleep 20m && cd ..; /tmp/.X19-unix/.rsync/initall 2>1& exit 0
label: safe

text: The kit we found is in tgz format, though we have observed some samples disguised as png or jpg.
label: safe

text: The tsm binary then runs in the background, forwarding a series of error messages to /dev/null to keep the code running, ensuring the continuous execution of the code referenced with a set of parameters /tmp/up.txt.
label: safe

text: The script then waits 20 minutes before it runs the wrapper script initall: 2e2c9d08c7c955f6ce5e27e70b0ec78a888c276d71a72daa0ef9e3e40f019a1a  initall  Figure 2.

text: However, they are particularly known for dangerous credential phishing campaigns.
label: location

text: In 2016, the group set up aggressive credential phishing attacks against the Democratic National Convention (DNC), German political party Christian Democratic Union (CDU), the parliament and government of Turkey, the parliament of Montenegro, the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA), Al Jazeera, and many other organizations.
label: attack-pattern

text: High profile users of free webmail were targeted by campaigns between 2015 and 2016.
label: safe

text: How is OAuth abused?
label: safe

text: Because of these policies, experienced actor groups like Pawn Storm can take advantage of OAuth for their credential phishing schemes.
label: location

text: Figure 1. The sequence of Pawn Storm's OAuth abuse A dissection of Pawn Storm OAuth attacks
label: threat-actor

text: In these attacks a user would get a message like this:
label: safe

text: Figure 2. A phony email from Pawn Storm
label: threat-actor

text: At this point, the user is faced with a legitimate Google site—since all OAuth approvals are done on the site of the service provider—but the application itself is part of a phishing scheme.
label: location

text: After abusing the screening process for OAuth approvals, Pawn Storm’s rogue application operates like every other app accepted by the service provider.
label: malware

text: Apart from targeting Gmail users, Pawn Storm has also abused OAuth in credential phishing attacks against high profile Yahoo users.
label: attack-pattern

text: After enabling the macros and the payload executes, two files – an obfuscated  Visual Basic script (Detected by Trend Micro as VBS_VALYRIA.DOCT), and an obfuscated PowerShell script (Detected by Trend Mico as TROJ_VALYRIA.PS) — are created in the ProgramData directory placed in randomly-named directories.
label: location

text: The purpose of the .VBS script is to execute the PowerShell script.
label: attack-pattern

text: The path to the VBS script is added to the task scheduler as a form of persistence.
label: safe

text: The PowerShell script, which employs several layers of obfuscation, is divided into three parts.
label: attack-pattern

text: The configuration portion of the PowerShell script
label: attack-pattern

text: The second part contains functions related to the encryption, which is a standard RSA encryption with very small keys.
label: location

text: The third part contains the backdoor function.
label: safe

text: The backdoor first finds out the machine IP address by querying the internet service api[.]ipify[.]org, which returns the IP address of the currently infected machine.
label: safe

text: A simple RSA algorithm with very small keys encrypts the message seen above.
label: identity

text: Let’s take the first character as an example.
label: safe

text: Character “{” = 0x7B =123.
label: safe

text: Variable ${prIVATE} = 959, 713 from section 1 of the PowerShell script has two values; the first number is the key and the second number is the modulus.
label: location

text: By computing (123 ^ 959) mod 713 = 340 we get the encrypted value of the first character (see number 340 in the figure below).
label: safe

text: The message above can be decrypted to: {"STATUS": "OK", "TOKEN": "d02153ffaf8137b1fa3bb852a27a12f8"}
label: location

text: Figure 11.
label: safe

text: The XML message with the screenshot
label: safe

text: Figure 12.
label: safe

text: For the PowerShell script, the first part contains a variable named dragon_middle, which is an array containing a few hundred URLs ending with connection.php that serve as proxies between victim and C&C.
label: attack-pattern

text: If communication with C&C fails, and if the PowerShell script is run from a command line, a few error messages written in simplified Mandarin Chinese are displayed, with a curious phrase that translates to "waiting for dragon":  无法访问本地计算机寄存器 (Unable to access local computer register) 任务计划程序访问被拒绝 (Mission Scheduler access is denied) 无法连接到网址，请等待龙 (Cannot connect to URL, please wait for dragon) 无法连接到网址，请等待龙 (Cannot connect to website, please wait for dragon)  These messages may not reveal anything about the real attackers as the malware writers sometimes like to embed false flags into their programs to confuse researchers.
label: location

text: Countermeasures and Trend Micro Solutions Users unfamiliar with the various kinds of social engineering techniques might find it difficult to distinguish a legitimate message from a malicious one – thus the need for education on identifying and mitigating phishing attacks – especially if it involves organizations in sensitive industries such as government and manufacturing.
label: location

text: Trend Micro™ Email Security is a no-maintenance cloud solution that delivers continuously updated protection to stop spam, malware, spear phishing, ransomware, and advanced targeted attacks before they reach the network.  Trend Micro™ Deep Discovery™ Inspector and InterScan™ Web Security prevent malware from ever reaching end users.
label: location

text: It features high-fidelity machine learning to secure the gateway and endpoint data and applications, and protects physical, virtual, and cloud workloads. text: In the group's latest campaign, they started using HTML attachments to deliver malicious .XLS files that lead to downloader and backdoor FlawedAmmyy, mostly to target users in South Korea.
label: location

text: Figure 1. TA505’s latest infection chain
label: safe

text: We also touch on the latest TA505 developments, including an email stealer, their use of legitimate software and MSI Installer, and more.
label: malware

text: As previously mentioned, TA505, first named by Proofpoint, is known for targeting financial enterprises.
label: safe

text: Since last December, TA505 has been very active and has been using legitimate or compromised RATs (remote access trojans) such as FlawedAmmyy, FlawedGrace, and Remote Manipulator System (RMS).
label: location

text: Figure 2. Korean language (left), simplified Chinese language (right) Microsoft Office instructions on how to enable macro  Figure 3.
label: tools

text: This said macro executes a command to download the first stage payload using msiexec.exe, a Microsoft Installer tool that can download and run a Windows Installer file.
label: identity

text: The first stage payload is an MSI Installer that was created using an EXE to MSI converter.
label: safe

text: Figure 4. MSI Installer payload that used EXE to MSI converter
label: safe

text: The actual malicious payload is in the MSI Installer package.
label: safe

text: The payload can vary in each campaign, but it typically uses the FlawedAmmyy downloader, ServHelper, or RMS RAT launcher.
label: location

text: Payload as FlawedAmmyy downloader
label: malware

text: The MSI Installer itself contains a FlawedAmmyy downloader, which is always signed.
label: malware

text: Figure 5. FlawedAmmyy downloader  Figure 6.
label: malware

text: Digitally signed FlawedAmmyy downloader
label: malware

text: It then runs the “net group /domain” command and checks if “workgroup” is contained in the output result.
label: malware

text: After performing the check, it downloads the RC4-encrypted FlawedAmmyy RAT, decrypts it, and executes it as the final payload.
label: location

text: We recently observed an instance where the FlawedAmmyy downloader was not digitally signed (FlawedAmmyy RAT payload is still signed, however).
label: malware

text: If the MSI Installer package contains ServHelper as a payload, it will come with an NSIS (Nullsoft Scriptable Install System) installer.
label: location

text: Figure 7.
label: safe

text: NSIS Installer NSIS is a legitimate tool that manages the installation for Windows, but some hacking groups also abuse it.
label: malware

text: TA505, for instance, abuses NSIS to install ServHelper.
label: malware

text: This NSIS installer has two files: (nsExec.dll and repotaj.dll) and [NSIS].nsi.
label: malware

text: The latter is a configuration file that handles files to install.
label: safe

text: NSIS Installer sections
label: malware

text: In this case, repotaj.dll, which is ServHelper, will be extracted to %TEMP% and execute with the “feast” parameter as its export function.
label: location

text: Once ServHelper is executed, it runs a PowerShell script to get information from the infected machine.
label: attack-pattern

text: Payload as RMS RAT TA505 also uses RMS, a legitimate RAT, in their campaigns.
label: safe

text: Today, Palo Alto Networks researcher Claud Xiao is delivering a presentation titled “Insecure Internal Storage in Android” at the Hacks in Taiwan Conference (HITCON).  Claud is discussing techniques for accessing private data in Android’s internal storage system using the Android Debug Bridge (ADB) backup/restore functionality.
label: safe

text: While there is still debate about how to store passwords in internal storage, if Android internal storage isn’t accessible to anything but the application that owns it, it remains secure.
label: safe

text: If an attacker has control over a PC, which the Android device is attached to (for charging or for other purposes), they don’t need to get physical access to the phone.
label: safe

text: Or through a rogue “charging station” which users plug their device into without thought.  2.
label: malware

text: Next, the device must support ADB backup, which was not introduced until Android 4.0 (Ice Cream Sandwich).
label: safe

text: As of July 7, this includes 85.8% of active Android devices.
label: safe

text: For these devices, ADB debugging must be enabled for backup to work.
label: safe

text: Some device vendors have even left it enabled by default when shipping their phones.
label: safe

text: If the device is running Android 4.2.2 or above (approximately 54.3% of active devices) it uses ADB authentication.
label: safe

text: Finally, when an ADB backup is initiated, a window pops up on the device screen to ask the user to press “Back up my data.”
label: safe

text: Of the 12,351 applications on the Google Play store with > 500,000 installations, only 556 explicitly disable this backup system.
label: safe

text: Another 156 implement a BackupAgent that restricts which data is subject to the backup.
label: safe

text: The other 94.2% of applications place no restrictions on the backup of their internal storage data.
label: safe

text: This includes (as discussed earlier) the default Android Mail and Browser applications, but also other e-mail, SSH and FTP applications, many of which store login and password details without any additional encryption.
label: location

text: Google could reverse this situation by making setting the android:allowBackup property to false by default, requiring developers to opt-in to the backup system, rather than opt-out.
label: safe

label: safe

label: location

text: This post is also available in:      日本語 (Japanese)  As part of Palo Alto Networks Unit 42’s ongoing monitoring of the Shamoon 2 situation, we have updated information since our last posting Threat Brief: Second Wave of Shamoon 2 Attacks Reveal Possible New Tactic.
label: location

text: Since that Threat Brief, our Unit 42 researchers have become aware of another wave of Shamoon 2 attacks.
label: tools

text: This third wave was set to wipe systems using the Disttrack malware on January 23, 2017.
label: safe

text: In order to understand how this works, let’s first take a look at how Android installs apps.
label: safe

text: Android supports the ability to install apps from the Google Play store as well as from the local file system.
label: safe

text: Google Play downloads Android packages (APKs) to a protected space of the file system.
label: safe

text: Both methods use a system application called PackageInstaller to complete the installation.
label: safe

text: Let’s take a closer look at what happens.
label: safe

text: Verified with Android OS source code posted in AOSP, it shows that the PackageInstaller on affected versions does not verify the APK file at the “Time of Use”.
label: attack-pattern

text: This method has several stages:
label: safe

text: Method B: Self modifying the APK  This exploit can take advantage of the same vulnerability to mask what permissions the app really requires.  This vulnerability affects Android device users as well as Android app developers.  For Android device users, the users may end up with installing apps that are not the ones they agree to install.  Android app developers are also affected, because app-store apps and mobile ads libraries that do not rely on Google Play store would be likely to save the promoted apps in unprotected storage, e.g. /sdcard.
label: location

text: According to source code posted on the AOSP website, Android 4.3_r0.9 introduced a hash check of the Android manifest that is verified between “Time to Check” and “Time to Use”.
label: attack-pattern

text: For instance, we have successfully tested this exploit on Samsung Galaxy S4 Android phones running Android 4.3 (Build version JSS15J.I337UCUEMK2, Built on Nov. 16, 2013), and Amazon Fire OS version 13.3.2.5.
label: location

text: We encourage all Android device vendors to verify the existence of this vulnerability on their devices including those with Android 4.3.
label: safe

text: Palo Alto Networks has published a vulnerability scanner app in the Google Play store.
label: safe

text: From Google:  “Android Open Source Project includes patches for this issue for Android 4.3 and later.
label: attack-pattern

text: Since late 2019, our team has disrupted financially motivated phishing campaigns targeting YouTubers with Cookie Theft malware.
label: attack-pattern

text: The actors behind this campaign, which we attribute to a group of hackers recruited in a Russian-speaking forum, lure their target with fake collaboration opportunities (typically a demo for anti-virus software, VPN, music players, photo editing or online games), hijack their channel, then either sell it to the highest bidder or use it to broadcast cryptocurrency scams.
label: location

text: In collaboration with YouTube, Gmail, Trust & Safety, CyberCrime Investigation Group and Safe Browsing teams, our protections have decreased the volume of related phishing emails on Gmail by 99.6% since May 2021.
label: location

text: We blocked 1.6M messages to targets, displayed ~62K Safe Browsing phishing page warnings, blocked 2.4K files, and successfully restored ~4K accounts.
label: location

text: Moreover, to protect our users, we have referred the below activity to the FBI for further investigation.
label: safe

text: Cookie Theft, also known as “pass-the-cookie attack,” is a session hijacking technique that enables access to user accounts with session cookies stored in the browser.
label: attack-pattern

text: The phishing typically started with a customized email introducing the company and its products.
label: attack-pattern

text: Once the target agreed to the deal, a malware landing page disguised as a software download URL was sent via email or a PDF on Google Drive, and in a few cases, Google documents containing the phishing links.
label: location

text: Because Google actively detects and disrupts phishing links sent via Gmail, the actors were observed driving targets to messaging apps like WhatsApp, Telegram or Discord.
label: location

text: Some commodity malware used included RedLine, Vidar, Predator The Thief, Nexus stealer, Azorult, Raccoon, Grand Stealer, Vikro Stealer, Masad (Google’s naming), and Kantal (Google’s naming) which shares code similarity with Vidar.
label: malware

text: Open source malware like Sorano and AdamantiumThief were also observed.
label: attack-pattern

text: In this blog, we explore some of the most notable campaigns we’ve disrupted this year from a different government-backed attacker: APT35, an Iranian group, which regularly conducts phishing campaigns targeting high risk users.
label: location

text: In early 2021, APT35 compromised a website affiliated with a UK university to host a phishing kit.

text: Credential phishing through a compromised website demonstrates these attackers will go to great lengths to appear legitimate – as they know it's difficult for users to detect this kind of attack.

text: Data of WeChat, Outlook, Twitter, Yahoo Mail, Facebook, Gmail, and Chrome  The app encrypts all stolen data using RSA and AES encryption algorithms.

text: When encrypting, it creates a block of data we named headData.

text: In December 2021, TAG discovered a novel Charming Kitten tool, named HYPERSCRAPE, used to steal user data from Gmail, Yahoo!, and Microsoft Outlook accounts.
label: threat-actor

text: The attacker runs HYPERSCRAPE on their own machine to download victims’ inboxes using previously acquired credentials.
label: safe

text: We have seen it deployed against fewer than two dozen accounts located in Iran.
label: safe

text: HYPERSCRAPE demonstrates Charming Kitten’s commitment to developing and maintaining purpose-built capabilities.
label: threat-actor

text: Like much of their tooling, HYPERSCRAPE is not notable for its technical sophistication, but rather its effectiveness in accomplishing Charming Kitten’s objectives.
label: location

text: HYPERSCRAPE requires the victim’s account credentials to run using a valid, authenticated user session the attacker has hijacked, or credentials the attacker has already acquired.
label: safe

text: We use our research to continuously improve the safety and security of our products and share this intelligence with our industry peers.
label: tools

text: And we don’t just plug security holes – we work to eliminate entire classes of threats for consumers and businesses whose work depends on the Internet.
label: location

text: NSO Group continues to pose risks across the Internet ecosystem.
label: safe

text: In 2019, we confronted the risks posed by NSO Group again, relying upon NSO Groups’s marketing information suggesting that they had a 0-day exploit for Android.
label: safe

text: In December 2021, we released research about novel techniques used by NSO Group to compromise iMessage users.
label: safe

text: While vulnerability research is an important contributor to online safety when that research is used to improve the security of products, vendors stockpiling zero-day vulnerabilities in secret can pose a severe risk to the Internet when the vendor itself gets compromised.
label: tools

text: This has happened to multiple spyware vendors over the past ten years, raising the specter that their stockpiles can be released publicly without warning.
label: malware

text: The proliferation of commercial hacking tools is a threat to national security, making the Internet less safe and undermining the trust on which a vibrant, inclusive digital society depends.
label: location

text: Safe Browsing also notifies webmasters when their websites are compromised by malicious actors and helps them diagnose and resolve the problem so that their visitors stay safer.
label: threat-actor

text: On Gmail, we recommend certain Gmail security precautions to prevent spoofing, phishing, and spam.
label: location

text: We use email authentication to protect against email spoofing, which is when email content is changed to make the message appear from someone or somewhere other than the actual source.
label: location

text: And we offer other advanced phishing and malware protection to administrators to better protect their users.
label: location

text: During the development stage, Android-created and open source components are subject to vigorous security reviews
label: location

text: For users, Android provides safety and control over how apps and third parties can access the data from their devices.
label: tools

text: APP has a strong track record protecting users – since the program’s inception, there are no documented cases of an account compromise via phishing.
label: location

text: Any one government’s ability to meaningfully impact this market is limited; only through a concerted international effort can this serious risk to online safety be mitigated.
label: location

text: With so much diversity in the attack surface, it’s important to leverage security best practices to manage your cyber risk.
label: location

text: Get advice here: https://success.trendmicro.com
label: safe

text: Pay close attention to unrecognized network traffic (both inbound and outbound) and watch for sophisticated new phishing attacks.
label: location

text: Where possible, reduce your attack surface.

text: Since late 2019, our team has disrupted financially motivated phishing campaigns targeting YouTubers with Cookie Theft malware.
label: attack-pattern

text: The actors behind this campaign, which we attribute to a group of hackers recruited in a Russian-speaking forum, lure their target with fake collaboration opportunities (typically a demo for anti-virus software, VPN, music players, photo editing or online games), hijack their channel, then either sell it to the highest bidder or use it to broadcast cryptocurrency scams.
label: location

text: In collaboration with YouTube, Gmail, Trust & Safety, CyberCrime Investigation Group and Safe Browsing teams, our protections have decreased the volume of related phishing emails on Gmail by 99.6% since May 2021.
label: location

text: We blocked 1.6M messages to targets, displayed ~62K Safe Browsing phishing page warnings, blocked 2.4K files, and successfully restored ~4K accounts.
label: location

text: Cookie Theft, also known as “pass-the-cookie attack,” is a session hijacking technique that enables access to user accounts with session cookies stored in the browser.
label: attack-pattern

text: The phishing typically started with a customized email introducing the company and its products.
label: attack-pattern

text: Once the target agreed to the deal, a malware landing page disguised as a software download URL was sent via email or a PDF on Google Drive, and in a few cases, Google documents containing the phishing links.
label: location

text: Because Google actively detects and disrupts phishing links sent via Gmail, the actors were observed driving targets to messaging apps like WhatsApp, Telegram or Discord.
label: location

text: Some commodity malware used included RedLine, Vidar, Predator The Thief, Nexus stealer, Azorult, Raccoon, Grand Stealer, Vikro Stealer, Masad (Google’s naming), and Kantal (Google’s naming) which shares code similarity with Vidar.
label: malware

text: Open source malware like Sorano and AdamantiumThief were also observed.
label: attack-pattern

text: Our recommendations: Additional resources: Avoid & Report Phishing Emails.
label: attack-pattern

label: attack-pattern

text: We have a long-standing policy to send you a warning if we detect that your account is a target of government-backed phishing or malware attempts.
label: location

text: In this blog, we explore some of the most notable campaigns we’ve disrupted this year from a different government-backed attacker: APT35, an Iranian group, which regularly conducts phishing campaigns targeting high risk users.
label: location

text: In early 2021, APT35 compromised a website affiliated with a UK university to host a phishing kit.
label: threat-actor

text: The phishing kit will also ask for second-factor authentication codes sent to devices.
label: attack-pattern

text: APT35 has relied on this technique since 2017 — targeting high-value accounts in government, academia, journalism, NGOs, foreign policy, and national security.
label: threat-actor

text: Credential phishing through a compromised website demonstrates these attackers will go to great lengths to appear legitimate – as they know it's difficult for users to detect this kind of attack.
label: attack-pattern

text: Although Play Store users were protected, we are highlighting the app here as TAG has seen APT35 attempt to distribute this spyware on other platforms as recently as July 2021.
label: location

text: One of the most notable characteristics of APT35 is their impersonation of conference officials to conduct phishing attacks.
label: location

text: When they did, attackers sent them phishing links in follow-on correspondence.
label: location

text: Targets typically had to navigate through at least one redirect before landing on a phishing domain.
label: location

text: The attackers embed javascript into phishing pages that notify them when the page has been loaded.
label: attack-pattern

text: The attackers use this function to relay device-based data to the channel, so they can see details such as the IP, useragent, and locales of visitors to their phishing sites in real-time.
label: location

text: We warn users when we suspect a government-backed threat like APT35 is targeting them.
label: threat-actor

text: In June, we announced that we saw phishing attempts against the personal email accounts of staffers on the Biden and Trump campaigns by Chinese and Iranian APTs (Advanced Persistent Threats) respectively.
label: attack-pattern

text: We haven’t seen any evidence of such attempts being successful.
label: safe

text: The Iranian attacker group (APT35) and the Chinese attacker group (APT31) targeted campaign staffers’ personal emails with credential phishing emails and emails containing tracking links.
label: location

text: As part of our wider tracking of APT31 activity, we've also seen them deploy targeted malware campaigns.
label: location

text: Every malicious piece of this attack was hosted on legitimate services, making it harder for defenders to rely on network signals for detection.
label: safe

text: In one example, attackers impersonated McAfee.
label: safe

text: The targets would be prompted to install a legitimate version of McAfee anti-virus software from GitHub, while malware was simultaneously silently installed to the system.
label: safe

text: This targeting is consistent with what others have subsequently reported.
label: safe

text: Shortly after the U.S. Treasury sanctioned Ukrainian Parliament member Andrii Derkach for attempting to influence the U.S. electoral process, we removed 14 Google accounts that were linked to him.
label: safe

text: As the course of the COVID-19 pandemic evolves, we’ve seen threat actors evolve their tactics as well.
label: safe

text: In previous posts, we discussed targeting of health organizations as well as attacker efforts to impersonate the World Health Organization.
label: safe

text: In the threat actor toolkit, different types of attacks are used for different purposes: Phishing campaigns can be used like a scalpel—targeting specific groups or individuals with personalized lures that are more likely to trick them into taking action (like clicking on a malware link), while DDoS attacks are more like a hatchet—disrupting or blocking a site or a service entirely.
label: location

text: While it’s less common to see DDoS attacks rather than phishing or hacking campaigns coming from government-backed threat groups, we’ve seen bigger players increase their capabilities in launching large-scale attacks in recent years.
label: attack-pattern

text: For example in 2017, our Security Reliability Engineering team measured a record-breaking UDP amplification attack sourced out of several Chinese ISPs (ASNs 4134, 4837, 58453, and 9394), which remains the largest bandwidth attack of which we are aware.
label: attack-pattern

text: Through the Apex One with Endpoint Sensor (iES), we discovered one such incident wherein an attacker utilized sophisticated techniques in an attempt to exfiltrate sensitive information from a company.
label: safe

text: Technical analysis Detection
label: safe

text: We noticed the execution of schtasks.exe with the command line parameter “schtasks /create /tn <name> c:\programdata\<software name>\<file name>.bat /sc /once /st <time> /ru <user account>”.
label: malware

text: The scheduled task was not created for persistence.
label: attack-pattern

text: The batch file that was to be executed had a suspicious name that stood out.
label: safe

text: This prompted us to dig deeper.
label: safe

text: Evasion
label: safe

text: The image file of the process residing in the Windows directory that triggered the schtasks command was marked as normal.
label: malware

text: PlugX and  malicious BLOBs
label: malware

text: Reversing the file revealed that it was the PlugX loader, a remote access tool (RAT) that has been historically used in attacks targeting government-related industries and organizations.
label: malware

text: The relationship between the normal file used, the PlugX, and the malicious BLOB      Despite being around for quite some time, PlugX is still effective at evading detection.
label: location

text: Detection support for the BLOB is probably low.
label: safe

text: Aside from this, changing the encryption mechanism or packer would result in a totally different BLOB.
label: safe

text: It should be noted that we have also observed an increase use of BLOB files since 2020.
label: safe

text: A closer look at PlugX svchost injection
label: tools

text: This variant of PlugX (detected by Trend Micro as Backdoor.Win32.PLUGX.DYSGUT), including the code in the BLOB, launches an svchost.exe process and injects to it.
label: malware

text: Usually, svchost is launched by services.exe, so the action done by PlugX could be used as a trigger for investigation.
label: location

text: Svchost injection is not new — in fact, Trickbot and other malware variants use this technique.
label: tools

text: The difference between Trickbot and PlugX is that Trickbot is much easier to detect.
label: location

text: Trickbot’s binary, which is not whitelisted, does the injection; in PlugX’s case, a normal process that is possibly whitelisted, does the injection.
label: malware

text: Our investigation shows that the attacker used other tools during the attack.
label: safe

text: The tools used varied from network scanners to account harvesters.
label: safe

text: Figure 2.
label: safe

text: To avoid this, the attacker chose a different approach.
label: safe

text: For every tool that needs to be run, it creates three things:   The auxiliary tool file <filename>.bat file Cmd.exe with a schtasks.exe command to create a scheduled task to run the batch file above  Instead of directly launching the auxiliary tool, it makes use of a scheduled task that runs the batch file that, in turn, executes the tool.
label: location

text: The attacker’s usage of a tool can be divided into two separate events: the dropping of the tool by the svchost.exe process that runs the malicious code and the execution of the tool via the scheduled task.
label: location

text: If the creation of the tool, batch file, and scheduled task is disregarded, it would seem that there is no connection between PlugX and the execution of the auxiliary tool.
label: location

text: However, a deeper investigation proved otherwise.
label: safe

text: Launching the auxiliary tool via the scheduled task     Scheduled tasks are usually associated with persistence or privilege escalation, which is not the case in this incident.
label: location

text: Having the scheduled task run only once removes the notion of persistence.
label: attack-pattern

text: Meanwhile, having the same user account launch the PlugX process and the auxiliary tool shows that the scheduled task is not for privilege escalation.
label: location

text: However, the attacker was able to delete it before we were able to get our hands on the tools used for investigation purposes.
label: safe

text: An analysis of these tools could be used to better understand what is happening or what has happened in the environment.
label: safe

text: Whenever a tool is used, the attacker deletes it from the disk as soon as it has done its purpose – which usually does not last for more than 15 minutes.
label: location

text: Based on our investigation of this specific attack, we provide helpful tips for enterprises and organizations to spot PlugX and lateral movement in their environments.
label: location

text: Threat hunters can use this to possibly identify other machines that have PlugX installed: Using attributes that could identify the normal file, such as the hash and the digital signer, a sweeping task could be carried out to identify instances of the normal file.
label: location

text: Chances are, the normal file that loads the rest of PlugX uses a file name that is different from what it normally uses or is in a location where it is not usually found.
label: location

text: For example, Microsoft’s outlook.exe is usually found in the Program Files directory.
label: safe

text: Finding such entries that stand out could help identify how wide the infection is.
label: safe

text: How to spot lateral movement
label: safe

text: In this particular attack, we observed that to perform lateral movement, the attacker mapped Windows admin shares and used remotely created scheduled tasks to launch malware.
label: attack-pattern

text: Both events never or rarely happened in the victim’s environment.
label: safe

text: The importance of looking into anomalous events
label: safe

text: When identifying PlugX and lateral movement techniques utilized in attacks, it’s important to be able to determine anomalous events.
label: malware

text: Keeping an eye on anomalous events could help detect incidents earlier.
label: malware

text: Trend Micro Solutions Trend Micro’s comprehensive XDR solution applies the most effective expert analytics to the deep data sets collected from Trend Micro solutions across the enterprise — including email, endpoints, servers, cloud workloads, and networks — making faster connections to identify and stop attacks.
label: location

text: One console with one source of prioritized, optimized alerts supported with guided investigation simplifies the steps needed to fully understand the attack path and impact on the organization.
label: attack-pattern

text: HyperBro is a malware family used by Iron Tiger (also known as Emissary Panda, APT27, Bronze Union, and Luckymouse), an advanced persistent threat (APT) group that has been performing cyberespionage for almost a decade, and there have been no reports of this group associated with a tool for Mac operating systems (OS).
label: malware

text: Further investigation showed that MiMi chat installers have been compromised to download and install HyperBro samples for the Windows platform and rshell samples for the Mac OS platform.
label: location

text: Infection vector MiMi (mimi = 秘密  = secret in Chinese) is an instant messaging application designed especially for Chinese users, with implementations for major desktop and mobile operating systems: Windows, macOS, Android, and iOS.
label: tools

text: We already came across an abuse of this application during the Earth Berberoka investigation.
label: safe

text: Also, we could not find anything malicious in the latest Windows installer.
label: safe

text: In this case, we can see that it took an hour and a half for the attackers to modify the legitimate installer and add malicious code to it.
label: location

text: For older versions, it took the attackers one day to inject its modifications.
label: safe

text: Once deobfuscated, we saw that the inserted code downloads rshell from the IP address 139[.]180[.]216[.]65 and executes it once run on the macOS platform.
label: IPV4

text: After looking at previous versions of this installer, we found that the first compromised version was 2.3.0, built on May 26, 2022, while the previous version (2.2.10, published on May 6, 2022) was clean.
label: safe

text: Figure 4. Malicious Javascript code inserted into 2.2.0.exe targeting Windows OS      Figure 5.
label: safe

text: HyperBro
label: malware

text: The HyperBro malware family has been around since 2017 and has been extensively analyzed.
label: malware

text: It was updated in mid-2019, which we described in detail in our Operation DRBControl paper.
label: safe

text: The said company was formerly known as Kingsoft Internet Software Holdings Limited, wherein during our previous investigation on the group, we already found one HyperBro DLL signed by a certificate belonging to Kingsoft.
label: safe

text: We found 13 different targets while following our sensors‘ data.
label: safe

text: Interestingly, we found a sample from the Reptile rootkit framework in that same company, as well as network requests to a subdomain that belongs to Earth Berberoka’s infrastructure.
label: location

text: Threat actor modified version 2.2.0 of Windows MiMi chat installer to download and execute HyperBro backdoor May 2021:
label: location

text: First, the dlpprem32.dll file linked to HyperBro shares certain characteristics (specifically imphash, RICH header) with previous samples already attributed to the group.
label: malware

text: Also, the file names involved in the decoding and loading of HyperBro are similar to those we witnessed during our investigation last year.
label: location

text: Second, one of the Linux rshell samples used the IP address 45[.]142[.]214[.]193 as its C&C.
label: IPV4

text: In 2020, that IP address had a particular reverse DNS: nbaya0u2[.]example[.]com.
label: safe

text: During our Operation DRBControl investigation, we found a HyperBro sample that had 138[.]124[.]180[.]108 as its C&C. This second IP address had nbaya0u1[.]example[.]com as its reverse DNS.
label: malware

text: However, as the rshell sample was found in 2021, we initially did not find this correlation strong enough to attribute the rshellmalware family to Iron Tiger.
label: location

text: We also found some links to Earth Berberoka.
label: safe

text: From one of the victims where we found an rshell sample, we also found a binary belonging to the Reptile rootkit framework, a rootkit identified as part of the arsenal of Earth Berberoka.
label: location

text: We also noticed network communications from this victim to a subdomain of Earth Berberoka, suggesting it could have been previously compromised by this threat actor.
label: safe

text: One of the rshell samples had center[.]veryssl[.]org as the C&C.
label: safe

text: Both findings suggest that those victims could be compromised by both threat actors, or that Earth Berberoka is actually a subgroup of Iron Tiger.
label: threat-actor

text: As a reminder, while investigating Earth Berberoka, we found multiple links to Iron Tiger that we detailed in our research.
label: threat-actor

text: Indicators of Compromise (IOCs)
label: safe

text: The malware known as RATANKBA is just one of the weapons in Lazarus’ arsenal.
label: identity

text: We analyzed a new RATANKBA variant (BKDR_RATANKBA.ZAEL-A), discovered in June 2017, that uses a PowerShell script instead of its more traditional PE executable form—a version that other researchers also recently identified.
label: safe

text: We identified a number of servers Lazarus used as a backend system for temporarily holding stolen data.
label: safe

text: They could have also been performing exercises in preparation for an attack against similar targets.
label: safe

text: Lazarus’ backend logs also record victim IP addresses.
label: safe

text: Infection Flow  Figure 1.
label: safe

text: RATANKBA Infection Flow RATANKBA is delivered to its victims using a variety of lure documents, including Microsoft Office documents, malicious CHM files, and different script downloaders.
label: malware

text: These documents contain topics discussing either software development or digital currencies.
label: safe

text: An example of a lure used in a RATANKBA attack can be seen below:  Figure 2. Malicious CHM file used as RATANKBA lure
label: location

text: This RATANKBA backdoor is what is used to communicate with RATANKBA’s Command-and-Control (C&C) server.
label: malware

text: Killkill: Stops the backdoor’s activities interval: Changes the interval in which the backdoor retrieves jobs; the default interval is set at 120 seconds cmd: Executes shell commands exe:Reflectively injects a DLL downloaded from a specific URL
label: malware

text: In addition to the backdoor’s modus operandi, the attackers will use a Microsoft WMI command-line tool to list the compromised system’s running processes, which are sent to the C&C server:  “C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe” /c “wmic process get processid,commandline,sessionid | findstr SysWOW” “C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe” /c “wmic process get processid,commandline,sessionid | findstr x86”    Technical Analysis
label: location

text: During our analysis, we collected a copy of the RATANKBA malware’s Lazarus Remote Controller tool.

label: location

label: safe

text: Kill: Posts a job to kill the backdoor inject Posts a job for DLL injection Interval Changes the sleep interval Cmd

text: RATANKBA host manipulation console RATANKBA’s controllers use the “Nimo Software HTTP Retriever 1.0” user-agent string for its communication.
