text: A typical Lurk infection uses browser exploits to deliver non-persistent payloads to potential victims, probing their targets before deploying additional malware.
label: safe

text: Nine more suspected members of the group were arrested by Russia's Ministry of Internal Affairs on February 8.
label: safe

text: How did Lurk evolve from a clique of threat actors to a full-fledged cybercriminal group?
label: safe

text: What other techniques were they known for—that other cybercriminals emulated?
label: safe

text: Lurk’s web-based attacks were the first signs of their campaigns.
label: safe

text: The group already implemented certain mechanisms to prevent AV detection.
label: safe

text: Requests during a time period or from a source IP address that didn’t match their preferred distribution area, for instance, would yield a redirect to a third-party site such as Google.
label: location

text: Lurk compromised systems by exploiting web browser vulnerabilities via drive-by download attacks.
label: malware

text: Malvertising and poisoning of content-serving application components, such as memcached cache poisoning, were also part of their traffic redirection methods.
label: location

text: Stealth was already a fixture in their operations.
label: safe

text: During this time we developed URL-based signatures and used them to detect Lurk-related network traffic.
label: location

text: The signature pattern ^[A-Z0-9]{4}$ was particularly effective in detecting URL patterns employed by Lurk from 2011 to 2013.
label: threat-actor

text: Mid-2012 to mid-2014: Honing the Craft Lurk was most prolific during this period, with its series of URL redirection campaigns in Russia becoming more extensive.
label: malware

text: Lurk also targeted programmatic advertising infrastructures to increase the scale of their operations.
label: threat-actor

text: When 2014 rolled in, Lurk started exhibiting some patterns similar with the Angler exploit kit.
label: threat-actor

text: Figure 1. Exploit loading sequence in ria[.]ru (February 2012) Figure 2. [bg].ru (February 2012) found redirecting victims to Lurk’s exploit kit Figure 3. Redirects to the Lurk landing page from adfox[.]ru banner network Figure 4. Malicious iframe content served by tks[.]ru (August 2013)
label: threat-actor

text: Lurk’s transition from simple web-browser-exploiting crooks to organized cybercriminals also stood out.
label: malware

text: Serving criteria were often modified, malicious payloads were often updated.
label: safe

text: While Lurk only exploited a certain set of browser vulnerabilities, the exploit code also often changed.
label: threat-actor

text: The initial bodiless payload was designed to be triggered by the exploit kit shellcode, which performed routine checks in the infected machine.
label: safe

text: Acquiring additional modules of the group’s malware, for instance, was nearly impractical if the exploit URLs were loaded in a sandboxed environment.
label: safe

text: Malicious content were also often distributed during lunchtime (Moscow’s timezone), and in very short intervals.
label: location

text: Lurk’s infrastructure also exhibited new capabilities.
label: safe

text: The mechanisms of redirections were different for each intermediate victim.
label: safe

text: vesti[.]ru utro[.]ua
label: safe

text: womanhit[.]ru   Figure 5.

text: Lurk’s intermediate targets by year 2014 to 2016:
label: malware

text: Going Global 2014 was a significant year in Lurk’s history.
label: safe

text: Why not go global to turn in more profit?
label: safe

text: By the second half of the year, Lurk’s geographical distribution drastically changed.
label: safe

text: Lurk then launched a new URL pattern that served payloads round-the-clock, eschewing pre-filtering of IP address locations in favor of targeting global IP addresses.
label: safe

text: It was delivered only if the victim’s source IP address (and time) met Lurk’s parameters—otherwise users received a 404 error response.
label: location

text: 2016: Lurk’s Downfall Lurk’s active compromise of financial institutions led to a series of enquiries that culminated in the arrest of over 50 individuals involved in its operations across Russia.
label: safe

text: The ripple effect led other cybercriminal groups to lie low for the rest of the year.
label: safe

text: By then, Angler’s activities already ceased.
label: safe

text: Coincidence?
label: safe

text: Unfortunately, Lurk is just one of the many cybercriminal groups looking to profit from organizations and end users.
label: identity

text: Best Practices Lurk’s story demonstrates the aptitude of cybercriminals for honing in on specific victims and profiting from them.
label: location

text: This should be especially enforced for HTTP and HTTPS protocols that cybercriminals frequently leverage for their attacks.
label: location

text: The location of injected payment checkout libraries on affected online stores were:  hxxps://[online store domain]/innerweb/v4.0/include/js/checkout_payment[.]js hxxps://[online store domain]/innerweb/v3.1/include/js/checkout_payment[.]js  The injected script forged the Google Analytics script format, but loaded a different script from the attackers’ server.

text: We recently discovered a new advanced persistent threat (APT) group that we have dubbed Earth Berberoka (aka GamblingPuppet).
label: location

text: Based on our analysis, this group targets gambling websites.
label: safe

text: Our investigation has also uncovered that Earth Berberoka targets the Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms, and uses malware families that have been historically attributed to Chinese-speaking individuals.
label: threat-actor

text: This malware lineup includes tried-and-tested malware families that have been upgraded, such as PlugX and Gh0st RAT, and a brand-new multistage malware family that we have dubbed PuppetLoader.
label: location

text: We discuss the full technical details of Earth Berberoka’s malware families aimed at Linux and macOS as well as Windows, infection vectors, targets, and possible connections with other APT groups in our research paper “Operation Earth Berberoka: An Analysis of a Multivector and Multiplatform APT Campaign Targeting Online Gambling Sites.” Technical analysis
label: threat-actor

text: PuppetLoader
label: malware

text: We discovered a new malware family that we have dubbed PuppetLoader.
label: malware

text: In this stage, a blob of payload data is decrypted using a hard-coded key (2726c6aea9970bb95211304705b5f595) and what appears to be an RC4 (Rivest Cipher 4) algorithm.
label: location

text: However, the cipher’s “swap” operation in the pseudorandom generation part of the cipher code was improperly implemented.
label: safe

text: It seems that this hard-coded key and flawed RC4 implementation were also used in a malware family named TigerPlug, probably because it spreads the PlugX malware.
label: location

text: Hijacking loaded module
label: safe

text: After the payload is decrypted, it is loaded in the machine’s memory and is executed using a stealthy method: PuppetLoader starts by loading a legitimate DLL from the Windows\System32 directory.
label: location

text: This is done by hooking NTDLL APIs such as NtQueryAttributesFile, NtOpenFile, NtCreateSection, NtMapViewOfSection, NtQuerySection and ZwClose.
label: attack-pattern

text: For its command-line parameters, PuppetLoader uses the same flawed RC4 implementation using the password “whk0q9ogev6ofg8d”.
label: malware

text: These hijacking steps result in the following:
label: safe

text: Figure 2. asycfilt.dll shown among loaded module names      lz32.dll is opened based on process monitoring tools.       Figure 3. lz32.dll shown among opened files      Only PuppetLoader’s dropper payload is loaded and none of the previously mentioned libraries is actually loaded.
label: location

label: safe

text: Table 1.
label: safe

label: safe

label: safe

text: oRAT
label: malware

text: Another malware family that we obtained both Windows and macOS samples of during our investigation was oRAT.
label: location

text: The oRAT droppers that we found in our analysis were a MiMi chat application built using the Electron JS framework and a DMG (disk image) file.
label: malware

text: We discuss the full details of both in our research paper.
label: safe

text: The decrypted oRAT configuration     The configuration is decrypted using the AES-GCM (AES with Galois/Counter Mode) algorithm.
label: malware

text: The control server is implemented by registering routes.
label: safe

text: Requesting a URL therefore results in executing the corresponding code on an infected system.
label: safe

text: We obtained oRAT samples that register these routes:   GET /agent/info GET /agent/ping POST /agent/upload GET /agent/download GET /agent/screenshot GET /agent/zip GET /agent/unzip GET /agent/kill-self GET /agent/portscan GET /agent/proxy GET /agent/ssh GET /agent/net  PuppetDownloaders (C++ downloaders)
label: malware

text: During our investigation, we also saw malicious websites that distribute fake Adobe Flash Player updates that were actually delivering C++ downloaders.
label: safe

text: The infection starts with an executable written in C++ that connects through a Winsock API to a domain or IP address in a specific port.
label: safe

text: If the SMTemp.dat file exists, the Loader.dll file executes it.
label: safe

text: During our investigation, we noted that the server hosting the second stage of the PuppetDownloaders malware payload was offline.
label: safe

text: Figure 7.  XOR decryption routine
label: safe

text: We dubbed these downloaders PuppetDownloaders since they are connected to the PuppetLoader malware family, as evidenced by our observations:  This malware and PuppetLoader both use the same string decryption routine that uses the same key.
label: location

text: This malware and PuppetLoader both use the same XOR key (2726c6aea9970bb95211304705b5f595) that is used to decrypt the embedded Loader.dll file.
label: location

text: This malware and PuppetLoader’s decrypted Loader.dlls share similar strings such as “[-] UnExist pwszModuleFunName:”.
label: location

text: This suggests that a common framework was used to compile both DLLs.
label: safe

text: MFC socket downloaders
label: safe

text: We also saw WinRAR self-extracting (SFX) files dropping downloaders written using the Microsoft Foundation Class Library (MFC) framework.
label: malware

text: However, it is possible that multiple groups might be covertly sharing the source code for this malware.
label: attack-pattern

text: This malware family sends a DWORD, a 32-bit unsigned integer, in the HELLO packet.
label: safe

text: Gh0st RAT
label: malware

text: We also saw at least three different variants of Gh0st RAT, another malware family that has been in the wild for more than 10 years, being used in Earth Berberoka’s campaign.
label: malware

text: This malware family’s source code is public, which is why it has many variants.
label: attack-pattern

text: One of the variants we analyzed had an interesting destructive feature: It replaces the master boot record (MBR) to display an explicit message (“I am virus ! F*ck you :-)”).
label: safe

text: A 2017 Industrial Control Systems Cyber Emergency Response Team (ICS-CERT) report also discussed how Gh0st RAT variants wiped the MBR and replaced it with messages that varied across different samples.
label: location

text: Other Known Malware Families
label: safe

text: We also found other legitimate tools being abused by Earth Berberoka and a malware family being used by the group in its campaign:  Quasar RAT – a Windows-based open-source RAT that has been used by APT groups for network exploitation
label: threat-actor

text: AsyncRAT – an open-source RAT that can be used to remotely monitor and control devices via an encrypted connection Trochilus – a stealthy RAT that can evade sandbox analysis and can be used in cyberespionage campaigns  Security recommendations
label: malware

text: In December 2021, TAG discovered a novel Charming Kitten tool, named HYPERSCRAPE, used to steal user data from Gmail, Yahoo!, and Microsoft Outlook accounts.
label: threat-actor

text: HYPERSCRAPE demonstrates Charming Kitten’s commitment to developing and maintaining purpose-built capabilities.
label: threat-actor

text: Like much of their tooling, HYPERSCRAPE is not notable for its technical sophistication, but rather its effectiveness in accomplishing Charming Kitten’s objectives.

text: MuddyWater is a well-known threat actor group that has been active since 2017.
label: safe

text: They target groups across Middle East and Central Asia, primarily using spear phishing emails with malicious attachments.
label: location

text: The group has been quite visible since the initial 2017 Malwarebytes report on their elaborate espionage attack against the Saudi Arabian government.
label: safe

text: However, we recently observed a few interesting delivery documents similar to the known MuddyWater TTPs.
label: safe

text: Our analysis revealed that they drop a new backdoor, which is written in PowerShell as MuddyWater’s known POWERSTATS backdoor.
label: attack-pattern

text: But, unlike previous incidents using POWERSTATS, the command and control (C&C) communication and data exfiltration in this case is done by using the API of a cloud file hosting provider.
label: malware

text: The screenshots below show the malicious attachments, which are disguised to look real, similar to any typical phishing document.
label: location

text: If the targeted victims enable macros, then the malicious process continues.
label: safe

text: Fake Office document tries to get user to enable malicious macros.
label: safe

text: The blurred document contains logos of different Turkish government entities  Figure 2.
label: safe

text: A similar fake Office document has blurred logos for a Turkish government institution related to taxes The macros contain strings encoded in base52, which is rarely used by threat actors other than MuddyWater.
label: threat-actor

text: The group is known to use it to encode their PowerShell backdoor.
label: attack-pattern

text: After enabling macros, a .dll file (with a PowerShell code embedded) and a .reg file are dropped into %temp% directory.
label: attack-pattern

text: The macro then runs the following command: "C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe" /k %windir%\System32\reg.exe IMPORT %temp%\B.reg
label: safe

text: Running this registry file adds the following command to the Run registry key: rundll32 %Temp%\png.dll,RunPow  Figure 3.
label: attack-pattern

text: Run registry key We assume that RunPow stands for “run PowerShell,” and triggers the PowerShell code embedded inside the .dll file.
label: attack-pattern

text: The PowerShell code has several layers of obfuscation.
label: attack-pattern

text: Encrypted PowerShell code
label: attack-pattern

text: The other layers are simple obfuscated PowerShell scripts.
label: location

text: But the last layer is the main backdoor body.
label: safe

text: This backdoor has some features similar to a previously discovered version of the Muddywater backdoor.
label: safe

text: Figure 5. String of system information collected from the victim’s system
label: safe

text: The previous MuddyWater version collected similar information but used a different separator:  Figure 6.
label: safe

text: When we analyzed further, we saw that the communication methods use files named <md5(hard disk serial number)> with various extensions depending on the purpose of the file.
label: safe

text: The figure below is the decoded .res file from Figure 9.
label: safe

text: Figure 10.
label: safe

text: Decoded .res file
label: safe

text: The backdoor supports the following commands:  $upload - upload a file to file hosting service $dispos - remove persistence $halt - exit $download - download file from a hosting service No prefix - execute command via Invoke Expression (IEX), a PowerShell command that runs commands or expressions on the local computer  Based on our analysis, we can confirm that the targets were Turkish government organizations related to the finance and energy sectors.
label: attack-pattern

text: This is yet another similarity with previous MuddyWater campaigns, which were known to have targeted multiple Turkish government entities.
label: safe

text: The main delivery method of this type of backdoor is spear phishing emails or spam that uses social engineering to manipulate targets into enabling malicious documents.
label: location

text: It is important that employers and employees across all organizations and enterprises be able to identify phishing attacks and distinguish legitimate emails from malicious ones.
label: location

text: In general, users should always practice caution when it comes to email.
label: safe

text: Apart from knowledge and awareness of phishing and social engineering, it is also important to be prepared with effective and layered security solutions.
label: location

text: Trend Micro™ Email Security is a no-maintenance cloud solution that delivers continuously updated protection to stop spam, malware, spear phishing, ransomware, and advanced targeted attacks before they reach the network.
label: location

text: While we have been following cyberespionage group TICK (a.k.a. “BRONZE BUTLER” or “REDBALDKNIGHT”) since 2008, we noticed an unusual increase in malware development and deployments towards November 2018.
label: threat-actor

text: Given their targets, we have named this campaign “Operation ENDTRADE,” and identified some of the findings in our research “Operation ENDTRADE: TICK’s Multi-Stage Backdoors for Attacking Industries and Stealing Classified Data”.
label: location

text: Operation ENDTRADE’s timeline
label: safe

text: Based on the language that was hardcoded in the samples we found, TICK appeared to be targeting Japanese organizations with subsidiaries in China to serve as footholds for intrusion: TICK hard-coded two code pages 932 and 936, referring to Japanese and Simplified Chinese characters respectively.

text: Modified Mimikatz Conclusion TICK is an organized and persistent cyber espionage group specialized in targeting high-value individuals and organizations, with the skills and resources needed to coordinate sophisticated attacks.

text: Trend Micro's Zero-Day Initiative (ZDI) provided technical analysis of recently patched vulnerabilities in the SolarWinds Orion Platform.
label: safe

text: These vulnerabilities, when combined, could allow an unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary code as Administrator on an affected system.
label: safe

text: Various sources have recently disclosed a sophisticated attack that hit organizations via the supply chain.
label: identity

text: This was carried out via a compromised version of a network monitoring application called SolarWinds Orion.
label: safe

text: This backdoor provided the attacker with complete access to the targeted organization’s network.
label: safe

text: What is Sunburst?
label: safe

text: Sunburst is a sophisticated backdoor that provides an attacker nearly complete control over an affected system.
label: safe

text: It has several peculiarities in its behavior, however.
label: safe

text: This specific set of circumstances makes analysis by researchers more difficult, but it also limits the scope of its victims to some degree.
label: safe

text: The commands that can be executed include:  Registry operations (read, write, and delete registry keys/entries) File operations (read, write, and delete files) Run/stop processes Reboot the system    What is Supernova?
label: location

text: Supernova, one of the malicious components associated with the attack, is a .NET web shell backdoor that presents itself as a legitimate SolarWinds web service handler.
label: tools

text: It is a second-stage payload in the attack.
label: safe

text: It can also execute web shell commands via a specific HTTP request format.
label: location

text: Who is affected?
label: safe

text: It is believed that Sunburst was delivered via a trojanized version of the Orion network monitoring application.
label: safe

text: This was done as part of the build process; the source code repository was not affected.
label: attack-pattern

text: According to the SolarWinds SEC filing, this trojanized version was downloaded by under 18,000 customers from March to June of 2020.
label: safe

text: In the second half of 2017 Pawn Storm, an extremely active espionage actor group, didn’t shy away from continuing their brazen attacks.
label: safe

text: We saw attacks against political organizations again in the second half of 2017.
label: safe

text: In summer and fall of 2017, we observed Pawn Storm targeting several organizations with credential phishing and spear phishing attacks.
label: attack-pattern

text: Pawn Storm’s modus operandi is quite consistent over the years, with some of their technical tricks being used repeatedly.
label: safe

text: The method, which we first discussed in 2014, involves changing a browser tab to point to a phishing site after distracting the target.
label: location

text: The screenshots below show two typical credential phishing emails that targeted specific organizations in October and November 2017.
label: attack-pattern

text: The other says there is a new file on the company’s OneDrive system.
label: safe

text: Figure 1. A sample of a credential phishing email Pawn Storm sent in October and November 2017  Figure 2.
label: location

text: Second type of credential phishing email that was sent by Pawn Storm in November 2017.
label: location

text: The logo of the target organization has been removed from the screenshot and the color was changed as not to reveal the source.
label: location

text: We successfully prevented both attacks from causing any harm.
label: safe

text: In one case we were able to warn the target within two hours after a dedicated credential phishing site was set up.
label: location

text: In an earlier attack, we were able to warn the organization 24 hours before the actual phishing emails were sent.
label: TIME

text: Olympic Wintersports Federations
label: safe

text: Political targets
label: safe

text: In the week of the 2017 presidential elections in Iran, Pawn Storm set up a phishing site targeting chmail.ir webmail users.
label: attack-pattern

text: We were able to collect evidence that credential phishing emails were sent to chmail.ir users on May 18, 2017, just one day before the presidential elections in Iran.
label: attack-pattern

text: Beginning in June 2017, phishing sites were set up mimicking the ADFS (Active Directory Federation Services) of the U.S. Senate.
label: attack-pattern

text: By looking at the digital fingerprints of these phishing sites and comparing them with a large data set that spans almost five years, we can uniquely relate them to a couple of Pawn Storm incidents in 2016 and 2017.
label: attack-pattern

text: The real ADFS server of the U.S. Senate is not reachable on the open internet, however phishing of users’ credentials on an ADFS server that is behind a firewall still makes sense.
label: location

text: In case an actor already has a foothold in an organization after compromising one user account, credential phishing could help him get closer to high profile users of interest.
label: location

text: The future of politically motivated campaigns Rogue political influence campaigns are not likely to go away in the near future.
label: malware

text: This makes them vulnerable to hacking and spear phishing.
label: location

text: As we have mentioned in our overview paper on Pawn Storm, other actors may also start their own campaigns that aim to influence politics and issues of interest domestically and abroad.
label: threat-actor

text: In 2016, we published a report on C Major, an espionage group that primarily targets the Indian military.
label: safe

text: With the Olympics and several significant global elections taking place in 2018, we can be sure Pawn Storm’s activities will continue.
label: location

text: Indicators of Compromise (IoCs):  adfs[.]senate[.]group adfs-senate[.]email adfs-senate[.]services adfs.senate[.]qov[.]info chmail.ir[.]udelivered[.]tk webmail-ibsf[.]org fil-luge[.]com biathlovvorld[.]com mail-ibu[.]eu fisski[.]ca iihf[.]eu         Tags  Malware | APT & Targeted Attacks | Endpoints | Research | Phishing | Network
label: location

text: Since late 2019, our team has disrupted financially motivated phishing campaigns targeting YouTubers with Cookie Theft malware.
label: attack-pattern

text: The actors behind this campaign, which we attribute to a group of hackers recruited in a Russian-speaking forum, lure their target with fake collaboration opportunities (typically a demo for anti-virus software, VPN, music players, photo editing or online games), hijack their channel, then either sell it to the highest bidder or use it to broadcast cryptocurrency scams.
label: location

text: In collaboration with YouTube, Gmail, Trust & Safety, CyberCrime Investigation Group and Safe Browsing teams, our protections have decreased the volume of related phishing emails on Gmail by 99.6% since May 2021.
label: location

text: We blocked 1.6M messages to targets, displayed ~62K Safe Browsing phishing page warnings, blocked 2.4K files, and successfully restored ~4K accounts.
label: location

text: Cookie Theft, also known as “pass-the-cookie attack,” is a session hijacking technique that enables access to user accounts with session cookies stored in the browser.
label: attack-pattern

text: The phishing typically started with a customized email introducing the company and its products.
label: attack-pattern

text: Once the target agreed to the deal, a malware landing page disguised as a software download URL was sent via email or a PDF on Google Drive, and in a few cases, Google documents containing the phishing links.
label: location

text: The following screenshot is an example of a fake page where the original URL is replaced with one leading to a cookie theft malware download.
label: tools

text: Because Google actively detects and disrupts phishing links sent via Gmail, the actors were observed driving targets to messaging apps like WhatsApp, Telegram or Discord.
label: location

text: Some commodity malware used included RedLine, Vidar, Predator The Thief, Nexus stealer, Azorult, Raccoon, Grand Stealer, Vikro Stealer, Masad (Google’s naming), and Kantal (Google’s naming) which shares code similarity with Vidar.
label: malware

text: Open source malware like Sorano and AdamantiumThief were also observed.
label: attack-pattern

text: We are continuously improving our detection methods and investing in new tools and features that automatically identify and stop threats like this one.
label: location

text: Our recommendations: Additional resources: Avoid & Report Phishing Emails.
label: attack-pattern

text: Related Malware hashes: Top Phishing Domains:
label: attack-pattern

text: Likewise, brute force attacks on internet-facing services like email, Microsoft Autodiscover, SMB, LDAP, and SQL are so common that they may seem like background noise that can be ignored.
label: attack-pattern

text: The RATs were also sent to a wider net of targets including various industries around the world.
label: malware

text: The group also performed widespread brute force attacks to steal credentials such as those of corporate email accounts, as evidenced by network probes we attribute to Pawn Storm and the loose way the actor abused compromised email accounts in malware and in sending spear-phishing emails.
label: attack-pattern

text: Recently, Norwegian authorities announced that Pawn Storm hacked the Norwegian parliament through brute force attacks.
label: attack-pattern

text: As shown in incremental improvements, subsequent versions of the malware hint towards a learning curve of the malware author that is more typical for an inexperienced actor than for an advanced actor.
label: safe

text: This mistake was corrected swiftly, but it shows the relative inexperience of this particular Pawn Storm operator.
label: safe

text: However, we have solid attribution for these samples based on our long-term monitoring of Pawn Storm’s activities.
label: location

text: Recap of recent Pawn Storm activities Compromising accounts of users from the Middle East Trend Micro has been closely and consistently monitoring the activities of Pawn Storm, and in March 2020, we released our latest research on the group.
label: location

text: In the aforementioned research paper, we shared that Pawn Storm heavily abuses compromised accounts — mainly in the Middle East — to send spear-phishing emails.
label: location

text: The abuse of compromised email accounts in the Middle East continued in 2020.
label: safe

text: The group then logged in to a compromised email account of a chicken farm in Oman, and then sent out credential phishing spam messages to high-profile targets around the world.
label: location

text: Since August 2020, they didn’t use these email addresses to only send spear-phishing emails, but also as a way to communicate with compromised systems in IMAP RATs.
label: location

text: Brute force attacks
label: attack-pattern

text: We think that Pawn Storm compromises lots of email accounts through brute force attacks on internet-facing services like email, LDAP, Microsoft Autodiscover, SMB, and SQL.
label: threat-actor

text: For example, in May 2020, Pawn Storm scanned IP addresses worldwide, including IP addresses from the defense industry in Europe, on TCP port 445 and 1433, likely in an attempt to find vulnerable SMB and SQL servers or brute force credentials.
label: location

text: In 2020, Pawn Storm often tries to obfuscate these brute force attempts by routing their attack traffic over Tor and VPN servers.
label: attack-pattern

text: Yet this is not always enough to hide these activities.
label: safe

text: In a Microsoft article about brute-forcing Office365 credentials over Tor, Microsoft attributed the activities to Strontium, which is another name for Pawn Storm.
label: malware

text: We wrote about related attacks in early 2020.
label: safe

text: These brute force attacks started in 2019, and then we could firmly attribute them to Pawn Storm because we could cross-relate the extensive probing of Microsoft Autodiscover servers around the world with high-confidence indicators of the group’s more traditional attack methods (spear phishing and credential phishing).
label: attack-pattern

text: To illustrate the simplicity of the malware in Pawn Storm’s recent spear-phishing attacks, we describe one example below:
label: location

text: Technical analysis of Google Drive RAT       Figure 1. Spear phishing email from Pawn Storm – collected in August 2020.

text: The MuddyWater campaign was first sighted in 2017 when it targeted the Saudi government using an attack involving PowerShell scripts deployed via Microsoft Office Word macro.
label: location

text: In March 2018, we provided a detailed analysis of another campaign that bore the hallmarks of MuddyWater.
label: location

text: Like the previous campaigns, these samples again involve a Microsoft Word document embedded with a malicious macro that is capable of executing PowerShell (PS) scripts leading to a backdoor payload.
label: attack-pattern

text: One notable difference in the analyzed samples is that they do not directly download the Visual Basic Script(VBS) and PowerShell component files, and instead encode all the scripts on the document itself.
label: location

text: Executing the malicious routine via Document_Open()
label: safe

text: The code inside the BLUE box constructs the main Powershell commands and scripts.
label: location

text: Figure 4.
label: safe

text: Analysis of the code revealed a PowerShell script capable of decoding the contents of the malicious document, which results in the execution of yet another encoded PowerShell script.
label: attack-pattern

text: The second encoded PowerShell script, which is executed after the first script is decoded This will then result in more readable PowerShell scripts capable of dropping various components in the %Application Data%\Microsoft\CLR\* directory.
label: attack-pattern

text: The main PowerShell file invoker.ps1 uses these components to run the final payload, PRB-Backdoor, previously analyzed by other security researchers in May 2018.
label: attack-pattern

text: Figure 7: The components dropped in the %Application Data%\Microsoft\CLR\* directory PRB-Backdoor is a backdoor that takes its name from the function used in the final PowerShell script payload, as seen in the figure below.  Figure 8.

text: We look forward to continuing our work in this space and advancing the safety and security of our users around the world.

text: Our team of analysts and security experts is focused on identifying and stopping issues like phishing campaigns, zero-day vulnerabilities and hacking against Google, our products and our users.
label: location

text: Today, we’re sharing recent findings on government-backed phishing, threats and disinformation, as well as a new bulletin to share information about actions we take against accounts that we attribute to coordinated influence campaigns.
label: attack-pattern

text: And as others have reported, we’re seeing a resurgence in COVID-related hacking and phishing attempts from numerous commercial and government-backed attackers.
label: location

text: To help protect users against these kinds of tracks, our Advanced Protection Program (APP) utilizes hardware security keys and provides the strongest protections available against phishing and account hijackings.
label: location

text: Our products are designed with robust built-in security features, like Gmail protections against phishing and Safe Browsing in Chrome, but we still dedicate significant resources to developing new tools and technology to help identify, track and stop this kind of activity.
label: location

text: We will also continue to share more detailed analysis of vulnerabilities we find, phishing and malware campaigns that we see, and other interesting or noteworthy trends across this space.
label: location

text: Google’s Threat Analysis Group (TAG) is a specialized team of security experts that works to identify, report, and stop government-backed phishing and hacking against Google and the people who use our products.
label: location

text: One notable campaign attempted to target personal accounts of U.S. government employees with phishing lures using American fast food franchises and COVID-19 messaging.
label: location

text: Once people clicked on the emails, they were presented with phishing pages designed to trick them into providing their Google account credentials.
label: attack-pattern

text: The vast majority of these messages were sent to spam without any user ever seeing them, and we were able to preemptively block the domains using Safe Browsing.
label: tools

text: We’ve also seen attackers try to trick people into downloading malware by impersonating health organizations: Generally, we’re not seeing an overall rise in phishing attacks by government-backed groups; this is just a change in tactics.
label: location

text: While it’s not unusual to see some fluctuations in these numbers, it could be that attackers, just like many other organizations, are experiencing productivity lags and issues due to global lockdowns and quarantine efforts.
label: identity

text: Following our November update, today we’re sharing the latest insights to fight phishing, and for security teams, providing more details about our work identifying attacks against zero-day vulnerabilities.

text: Last week at CyberwarCon, we presented analysis about previously undisclosed campaigns from a Russia-nexus threat group called “Sandworm” (also known as “Iridium”).
label: safe

text: Although much of Sandworm’s activity targeting Ukraine and their attacks against the 2018 Winter Olympics have been covered publicly, some campaigns have not been reported.

text: In December 2017, TAG discovered a series of campaigns from Sandworm attempting to deploy Android malware.
label: safe

text: They then uploaded these modified apps to the Play Store using their own attacker-controlled developer accounts.
label: safe

text: This application had approximately 1,000 total installs.
label: safe

text: In November 2018, we saw evidence that Sandworm shifted from using attacker-controlled accounts to try and upload malicious apps to compromising legitimate developers.

text: As organizations reeled from the Log4Shell vulnerability (CVE-2021-44228), cyberattacks aiming at open-source web servers, like Apache HTTP Server, were rapidly rising.
label: attack-pattern

text: To protect enterprises against malicious activities, we need more than just timely patches.
label: identity

text: Vulnerabilities of Apache HTTP Server have increased since 2017 Open-source web servers, especially Apache HTTP Server, have been heavily exploited in the past five years.
label: attack-pattern

text: Compared to Nginx, another widely used open-source web server, Apache had the greatest increase in vulnerabilities over the past five years – particularly high-risk ones.
label: attack-pattern

text: According to the Apache HTTP Server webpage, from 2012 to 2016 there were a total of 31 vulnerabilities found in the Apache HTTP Server.
label: safe

text: However, from 2017 to 2021 the total vulnerabilities number surged to 57.
label: safe

text: 2021 alone accounted for 14 of those vulnerabilities, breaking a 17-year record high.
label: safe

text: Before that, there were no vulnerabilities rated at this level.
label: safe

text: Source: Apache HTTP Server Project
label: attack-pattern

text: The most common types of attack include denial of service (DoS), path traversal, server-side request forgery (SSRF), and remote code execution (RCE).
label: location

text: Additional analysis and insights by Higashi Yuka and Chizuru Toyama REDBALDKNIGHT, also known as BRONZE BUTLER and Tick, is a cyberespionage group known to target Japanese organizations such as government agencies (including defense) as well as those in biotechnology, electronics manufacturing, and industrial chemistry.
label: location

text: Their campaigns employ the Daserf backdoor (detected by Trend Micro as BKDR_DASERF, otherwise known as Muirim and Nioupale) that has four main capabilities: execute shell commands, download and upload data, take screenshots, and log keystrokes.
label: location

text: Like many cyberespionage campaigns, REDBALDKNIGHT’s attacks are intermittent but drawn-out.
label: location

text: The specificity of their targets stems from the social engineering tactics used.
label: safe

text: One of the decoy documents, for instance, was about the “plan of disaster prevention in heisei 20” (Heisei is the current/modern era in Japan).  Figure 1: File properties of one of the decoy documents that REDBALDKNIGHT sends to Japanese targets  Figures 2: Sample of decoy documents used by REDBALDKNIGHT, employing socially engineered titles in their spear phishing emails such as “disaster prevention”
label: location

text: Attack ChainREDBALDKNIGHT’s attacks typically use spear phishing emails as an entry point.
label: attack-pattern

text: Their attachments exploit a vulnerability in Ichitaro, as shown above.
label: safe

text: Based on the hardcoded version number they divulged (Version:1.15.11.26TB Mini), we were able to source other versions of the backdoor (listed in the appendix).
label: attack-pattern

text: Version v1.40 Mini uses the MPRESS packer, which provides some degree of protection against AV detection and reverse engineering.
label: location

text: How REDBALDKNIGHT Employs
label: threat-actor

text: SteganographyDaserf’s infection chain accordingly evolved, as shown below.
label: safe

text: It has several methods for infecting its targets of interest: spear phishing emails, watering hole attacks, and exploiting a remote code execution vulnerability (CVE-2016-7836, patched last March 2017) in SKYSEA Client View, an IT asset management software widely used in Japan.
label: attack-pattern

text: REDBALDKNIGHT’s use of steganography isn’t limited to Daserf.
label: safe

text: Based on their pdb strings, they’re both components of another REDBALDKNIGHT-related threat, XXMM (TROJ_KVNDM), a downloader Trojan that can also act as a first-stage backdoor with its capability to open a shell.
label: threat-actor

text: While xxmm2_builder allows REDBALDKNIGHT to customize the settings of XXMM, xxmm2_ steganography is used to hide malicious code within an image file.
label: threat-actor

text: REDBALDKNIGHT’s tool can create, embed, and hide executables or configuration files within the image file with its tag and encrypted strings via steganography.
label: threat-actor

text: Additionally, we also found that the steganography algorithm (alternative base64 + RC4) between XXMM and Daserf were the same.
label: location

text: Our team of analysts and security experts is focused on identifying and stopping issues like phishing campaigns, zero-day vulnerabilities and hacking against Google, our products and our users.
label: location

text: Today, we’re sharing recent findings on government-backed phishing, threats and disinformation, as well as a new bulletin to share information about actions we take against accounts that we attribute to coordinated influence campaigns.
label: attack-pattern

text: And as others have reported, we’re seeing a resurgence in COVID-related hacking and phishing attempts from numerous commercial and government-backed attackers.
label: location

text: To help protect users against these kinds of tracks, our Advanced Protection Program (APP) utilizes hardware security keys and provides the strongest protections available against phishing and account hijackings.
label: location

text: Our products are designed with robust built-in security features, like Gmail protections against phishing and Safe Browsing in Chrome, but we still dedicate significant resources to developing new tools and technology to help identify, track and stop this kind of activity.
label: location

text: We will also continue to share more detailed analysis of vulnerabilities we find, phishing and malware campaigns that we see, and other interesting or noteworthy trends across this space.
label: location

text: We have also taken extraordinary measures beyond our actions against coordinated influence operations to protect users and stop the spread of misinformation and disinformation about the war in Ukraine online.
label: location

text: Their blog contains write-ups and analysis of vulnerabilities that have been publicly disclosed, including “guest” posts from unwitting legitimate security researchers, likely in an attempt to build additional credibility with other security researchers.
label: threat-actor

text: In the video, they purported to show a successful working exploit that spawns a cmd.exe shell, but a careful review of the video shows the exploit is fake.
label: malware

text: Within the Visual Studio Project would be source code for exploiting the vulnerability, as well as an additional DLL that would be executed through Visual Studio Build Events.
label: attack-pattern

text: Host IOCs Registry Keys HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\KernelConfig HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\DriverConfig HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\SSL Update File Paths C:\Windows\System32\Nwsapagent.sys C:\Windows\System32\helpsvc.sys C:\ProgramData\USOShared\uso.bin C:\ProgramData\VMware\vmnat-update.bin C:\ProgramData\VirtualBox\update.bin
label: location

text: In June, we announced that we saw phishing attempts against the personal email accounts of staffers on the Biden and Trump campaigns by Chinese and Iranian APTs (Advanced Persistent Threats) respectively.
label: attack-pattern

text: The Iranian attacker group (APT35) and the Chinese attacker group (APT31) targeted campaign staffers’ personal emails with credential phishing emails and emails containing tracking links.
label: location

text: As part of our wider tracking of APT31 activity, we've also seen them deploy targeted malware campaigns.
label: location

text: In the threat actor toolkit, different types of attacks are used for different purposes: Phishing campaigns can be used like a scalpel—targeting specific groups or individuals with personalized lures that are more likely to trick them into taking action (like clicking on a malware link), while DDoS attacks are more like a hatchet—disrupting or blocking a site or a service entirely.
label: location

text: While it’s less common to see DDoS attacks rather than phishing or hacking campaigns coming from government-backed threat groups, we’ve seen bigger players increase their capabilities in launching large-scale attacks in recent years.
label: attack-pattern

text: For example in 2017, our Security Reliability Engineering team measured a record-breaking UDP amplification attack sourced out of several Chinese ISPs (ASNs 4134, 4837, 58453, and 9394), which remains the largest bandwidth attack of which we are aware.
label: attack-pattern

text: Vision One integrates with Palo Alto Networks Cortex™ XSOAR to drive automated response to incidents uncovered by Vision One.
label: safe

text: Having the incident details available in the Cortex™ XSOAR platform enables analysts to execute a series of manual or automated actions through the Trend Micro Vision One™ platform in response to a potential threat.
label: safe

text: Collect files Collects the specified file from an endpoint during an investigation Submit a file for sandbox analysis Submits a file to the Trend Micro Vision One sandbox for automated analysis Retrieve sandbox analysis report Retrieves the analysis report, IOCs, or artifacts available after automated analysis Quarantine email message
label: safe

text: Delete email message Permanently deletes the specified email message from the user’s mailbox
label: safe

text: Gather information on an endpoint Gathers information from the endpoint such as the current logged on user, operating system details, IP address, hostname, mac address
label: safe

text: Terminate process Terminates the specified process if currently running on an endpoint Isolate endpoint Blocks all network activity on an endpoint while the system is being investigated
label: safe

text: Restore endpoint connection Restores the network connectivity on an endpoint after investigation and/or remediation has occurred
label: safe

text: Scenario: If credential dumping was detected on a host, the security operations team wanted to automate the collection of artifacts to be used during a subsequent investigation.
label: attack-pattern

text: Trend Micro Vision One™ is very effective at identifying the various techniques threat actors use to discover credentials.
label: safe

text: However, since threat actors tend to cover their tracks quickly, by the time the security analyst is reviewing the incident, there is a chance that critical information may have been permanently deleted and is no longer readily accessible.          Instead of depending on a security analyst to review a credential dumping event and manually collecting artifacts for their investigation, Trend Micro wanted to automate the collection of this evidence as quickly as possible when a detection occurs.
label: location

text: The first step in our playbook is to check if the event is related to credential dumping.
label: location

text: After we have gathered the information, the next step is to collect the file from the endpoint using the command “trendmicro-visionone-collect-forensic-file”.
label: safe

text: We need to request that a download link be generated for the collected files with the “trendmicro-visionone-download-information-for-collected-forensic-file”.
label: safe

text: Once we have the download link, we can then use the Cortex™ XSOAR built-in command “http” to retrieve the file and save it to the War Room for this incident so that it can be downloaded and analyzed.          This is just one example use case that we have seen implemented to automate security operations by leveraging the integration between Trend Micro Vision One™ and Palo Alto Networks Cortex™ XSOAR.
label: location

text: We use our research to continuously improve the safety and security of our products and share this intelligence with our industry peers.
label: tools

text: And we don’t just plug security holes – we work to eliminate entire classes of threats for consumers and businesses whose work depends on the Internet.
label: location

text: While vulnerability research is an important contributor to online safety when that research is used to improve the security of products, vendors stockpiling zero-day vulnerabilities in secret can pose a severe risk to the Internet when the vendor itself gets compromised.
label: tools

text: This has happened to multiple spyware vendors over the past ten years, raising the specter that their stockpiles can be released publicly without warning.
label: malware

text: The proliferation of commercial hacking tools is a threat to national security, making the Internet less safe and undermining the trust on which a vibrant, inclusive digital society depends.
label: location

text: Safe Browsing also notifies webmasters when their websites are compromised by malicious actors and helps them diagnose and resolve the problem so that their visitors stay safer.
label: threat-actor

text: On Gmail, we recommend certain Gmail security precautions to prevent spoofing, phishing, and spam.
label: location

text: We use email authentication to protect against email spoofing, which is when email content is changed to make the message appear from someone or somewhere other than the actual source.
label: location

text: And we offer other advanced phishing and malware protection to administrators to better protect their users.
label: location

text: During the development stage, Android-created and open source components are subject to vigorous security reviews
label: location

text: For users, Android provides safety and control over how apps and third parties can access the data from their devices.
label: tools

text: APP has a strong track record protecting users – since the program’s inception, there are no documented cases of an account compromise via phishing.
label: location

text: Any one government’s ability to meaningfully impact this market is limited; only through a concerted international effort can this serious risk to online safety be mitigated.
label: location

text: This is the first known instance of Turla distributing Android-related malware.
label: safe

text: The app is distributed under the guise of performing Denial of Service (DoS) attacks against a set of Russian websites.
label: safe

text: During our investigation into the Turla CyberAzov apps, we identified another Android app first seen in the wild in March 2022 that also claimed to conduct DoS attacks against Russian websites.
label: safe

text: Follina is a remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability in the Microsoft Windows Support Diagnostic Tool (MSDT).
label: location

text: Consistent with CERT-UA reporting, TAG observed multiple Russian GRU actors - APT28 and Sandworm - conduct campaigns exploiting the Follina vulnerability.
label: location

text: The Sandworm campaign used compromised government accounts to send links to Microsoft Office documents hosted on compromised domains, primarily targeting media organizations in Ukraine.
label: threat-actor

text: TAG has also observed an increasing number of financially motivated actors targeting Ukraine.
label: safe

text: We assess this actor is a former initial ransomware access broker who previously worked with the Conti ransomware group distributing the IcedID banking trojan based on overlaps in infrastructure, tools used in previous campaigns, and a unique cryptor.
label: threat-actor

text: They continue to use the 'Browser in the Browser' phishing technique that TAG first observed and described in March.
label: attack-pattern

text: COLDRIVER, a Russian-based threat actor sometimes referred to as Callisto, continues to send credential phishing emails to targets including government and defense officials, politicians, NGOs and think tanks, and journalists.
label: threat-actor

text: In addition to including phishing links directly in the email, the attackers also link to PDFs and/or DOCs, hosted on Google Drive and Microsoft One Drive, that contain a link to an attacker-controlled phishing domain.
label: attack-pattern

text: These phishing domains have been blocked through Google Safe Browsing – a service that identifies unsafe websites across the web and notifies users and website owners of potential harm.
label: attack-pattern

text: Recently observed COLDRIVER indicators: In another campaign tracked by CERT-UA as UAC-0056 we observed compromised email addresses of a Regional Prosecutor’s office of Ukraine leveraged to send malicious Microsoft Excel documents with VBA macros delivering Cobalt Strike.
label: threat-actor

text: Email contents vary from COVID-19 vaccine policy to the humanitarian crisis in Ukraine.
label: malware

text: We have seen hack-for-hire groups target human rights and political activists, journalists, and other high-risk users around the world, putting their privacy, safety and security at risk.
label: location

text: India
label: safe

text: One cluster of this activity frequently targets government, healthcare, and telecom sectors in Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, and Bahrain with credential phishing campaigns.
label: location

text: These credential phishing campaigns have ranged from targeting specific government organizations to AWS accounts to Gmail accounts.
label: attack-pattern

text: Russia
label: safe

text: While investigating a 2017 credential phishing campaign that targeted a prominent Russian anti-corruption journalist, we discovered the Russian attacker targeting other journalists, politicians across Europe, and various NGOs and non-profit organizations.
label: attack-pattern

text: This hack-for-hire actor has been publicly referred to as 'Void Balaur'.
label: location

text: These campaigns were similar regardless of target, consisting of a credential phishing email with a link to an attacker-controlled phishing page.
label: location

text: The group commonly uses Google or OWA password reset lures to steal credentials from targets, often using the MailJet or SendGrid API to send phishing emails.
label: attack-pattern

text: Unlike many hack-for-hire actors that use open source phishing frameworks like Evilginx or GoPhish, this group uses a custom phishing kit that utilizes Selenium, a self described 'suite of tools for automating web browsers.'
label: location

text: Previously described by Amnesty, this phishing kit has remained under active development over the past five years.
label: attack-pattern

text: After compromising an account, the actor maintains persistence by granting themselves an OAuth token to a legitimate email app like Thunderbird, or by linking the victim Gmail account to an attacker-owned account on a third-party mail provider.
label: safe

text: This group also has links to the original developers of H-Worm, also known as njRAT.
label: malware

text: Benabdellah, who also goes by the moniker Houdini, has been actively involved in the day-to-day development and operational deployment of the credential phishing capabilities used by this group since its inception.
label: location

text: As part of our efforts to combat serious threat actors, we use results of our research to improve the safety and security of our products.
label: tools

text: We hope that improved understanding of the tactics and techniques will enhance threat hunting capability and lead to stronger user protections across the industry.
label: location

text: Looking at the code of the page, we can see that only the WhatsApp download links are pointing to attacker controlled content for Android and iOS users.
label: malware

text: The resulting application is signed with a certificate from a company named 3-1 Mobile SRL (Developer ID: 58UP7GFWAA).
label: safe

text: The certificate satisfies all of the iOS code signing requirements on any iOS devices because the company was enrolled in the Apple Developer Enterprise Program.
label: attack-pattern

text: The app is broken up into multiple parts.
label: safe

text: It contains a generic privilege escalation exploit wrapper which is used by six different exploits.
label: attack-pattern

text: It also contains a minimalist agent capable of exfiltrating interesting files from the device, such as the Whatsapp database.
label: safe

text: In collaboration with TAG, Project Zero has published the technical analysis of CVE-2021-30983.
label: safe

text: Installing the downloaded APK requires the victim to enable installation of applications from unknown sources.
label: safe

text: Although the applications were never available in Google Play, we have notified the Android users of infected devices and implemented changes in Google Play Protect to protect all users.  Android Implant This analysis is based on fe95855691cada4493641bc4f01eb00c670c002166d6591fe38073dd0ea1d001 that was uploaded to VirusTotal on May 27.
label: location

text: The Android app disguises itself as a legitimate Samsung application via its icon: When the user launches the application, a webview is opened that displays a legitimate website related to the icon.
label: safe

text: The configuration is encoded with a 105-byte XOR key.
label: safe

text: This trend should be concerning to all Internet users.
label: safe

text: While vulnerability research is an important contributor to online safety when that research is used to improve the security of products, vendors stockpiling zero-day vulnerabilities in secret poses a severe risk to the Internet especially if the vendor gets compromised.
label: tools

text: This has happened to multiple spyware vendors over the past ten years, raising the specter that their stockpiles can be released publicly without warning.
label: malware

text: We look forward to continuing our work in this space and advancing the safety and security of our users around the world.
label: location

text: AWS has responded to this customer request by offering partner CloudFormation Resource Types directly from the AWS Management Console.
label: safe

text: CloudFormation now handles the details of automating that implementation, reducing the knowledge needed about the underlying mechanisms to automate that resource deployment.
label: safe

text: Tags  Cloud | Malware | Cyber Crime | Exploits & Vulnerabilities | Phishing | Deep Web | Cyber Threats | APT & Targeted Attacks | Compliance & Risks | Articles, News, Reports | Security Strategies
label: location

text: While tracking the activities of the SideWinder group, which has become infamous for targeting the South Asia region and its surrounding countries, we identified a server used to deliver a malicious LNK file and host multiple credential phishing pages.
label: location

text: We learned that these pages were copied from their victims’ webmail login pages and subsequently modified for phishing.
label: location

text: We believe further activities are propagated via spear-phishing attacks.
label: location

text: After the gathered credentials are sent, some of the phishing pages will redirect victims to different documents or news pages.
label: location

text: Furthermore, it seems that these lures are distributed via phishing links.
label: location

text: We also found multiple Android APK files on their phishing server.
label: attack-pattern

text: One of the normal applications, called “OpinionPoll,” is a survey app for gathering opinions regarding the Nepal-India political map dispute, which seems to be another political lure similar to the one they used in the spear-phishing portion.
label: location

text: SideWinder has been very active in 2020.
label: safe

text: Analysis of the malicious document
label: safe

text: The use of malicious documents is one of SideWinder’s most common infection vectors.
label: location

text: An example of a downloaded ZIP file containing an LNK file that is used to download a malicious HTA file
label: safe

text: All of these cases end up with either the downloading or dropping of files and then the execution of JavaScript code, which is a dropper used to install the main backdoor + stealer.
label: location

text: The downloaded RTF files exploit the CVE-2017-11882 vulnerability
label: safe

text: It drops a file named 1.a (a JavaScript code), which drops the backdoor + stealer into a folder in ProgramData and directly executes it or creates a scheduled task to execute the dropped files at a later time.
label: malware

text: Figure 2.
label: safe

text: A scheduled task with a command to execute the dropped backdoor + stealer
label: attack-pattern

label: location

text: Figure 3.
label: safe

label: location

text: Figure 5. Algorithm for decrypting both main backdoor + stealer and configuration
label: malware

text: The decrypted payload is the main backdoor .NET executable binary.
label: safe

text: In Resources, the Default resource contains the encrypted configuration.
label: safe

text: After decryption (using the same principle as with the main backdoor + stealer), the configuration reveals which file formats the attackers are targeting.
label: location

text: The decrypted configuration     The main functions of the backdoor + stealer are:  1) Downloading the .NET executable and running it 2) Collecting system information and uploading it to the command-and-control (C&C) server 3) Uploading selected files to the C&C server
label: malware

text: We found several interesting dynamic DNS domains resolving to a server that was used to deliver SideWinder’s malicious documents.
label: safe

text: For example, “mail-nepalgovnp[.]duckdns[.]org” was created to pretend to be the original Nepal government’s domain “mail[.]nepal[.]gov[.]np”.
label: safe

text: Digging deeper, we found that it hosted several phishing pages.
label: attack-pattern

text: These pages were copied from the webmail servers of various targets and then modified for spear-phishing attacks designed to steal login credentials.
label: location

text: Although it’s not clear to us how these phishing pages are delivered to the victims, finding the original webmail servers that they copied to make these phishing pages allows us to identify who they were targeting.
label: location

text: Analysis of the phishing pages revealed that most of them would redirect to the original webmail servers, which they copied after the victims sent out their login credentials.
label: attack-pattern

text: Since late 2019, our team has disrupted financially motivated phishing campaigns targeting YouTubers with Cookie Theft malware.
label: attack-pattern

text: The actors behind this campaign, which we attribute to a group of hackers recruited in a Russian-speaking forum, lure their target with fake collaboration opportunities (typically a demo for anti-virus software, VPN, music players, photo editing or online games), hijack their channel, then either sell it to the highest bidder or use it to broadcast cryptocurrency scams.
label: location

text: In collaboration with YouTube, Gmail, Trust & Safety, CyberCrime Investigation Group and Safe Browsing teams, our protections have decreased the volume of related phishing emails on Gmail by 99.6% since May 2021.
label: location

text: We blocked 1.6M messages to targets, displayed ~62K Safe Browsing phishing page warnings, blocked 2.4K files, and successfully restored ~4K accounts.
label: location

text: Cookie Theft, also known as “pass-the-cookie attack,” is a session hijacking technique that enables access to user accounts with session cookies stored in the browser.
label: attack-pattern

text: The phishing typically started with a customized email introducing the company and its products.
label: attack-pattern

text: Once the target agreed to the deal, a malware landing page disguised as a software download URL was sent via email or a PDF on Google Drive, and in a few cases, Google documents containing the phishing links.
label: location

text: Because Google actively detects and disrupts phishing links sent via Gmail, the actors were observed driving targets to messaging apps like WhatsApp, Telegram or Discord.
label: location

text: Some commodity malware used included RedLine, Vidar, Predator The Thief, Nexus stealer, Azorult, Raccoon, Grand Stealer, Vikro Stealer, Masad (Google’s naming), and Kantal (Google’s naming) which shares code similarity with Vidar.
label: malware

text: Open source malware like Sorano and AdamantiumThief were also observed.
label: attack-pattern

text: Our recommendations: Additional resources: Avoid & Report Phishing Emails.
label: attack-pattern

text: Related Malware hashes: Top Phishing Domains:
label: attack-pattern

text: We have a long-standing policy to send you a warning if we detect that your account is a target of government-backed phishing or malware attempts.
label: location

text: In this blog, we explore some of the most notable campaigns we’ve disrupted this year from a different government-backed attacker: APT35, an Iranian group, which regularly conducts phishing campaigns targeting high risk users.
label: location

text: In early 2021, APT35 compromised a website affiliated with a UK university to host a phishing kit.
label: threat-actor

text: The phishing kit will also ask for second-factor authentication codes sent to devices.
label: attack-pattern

text: APT35 has relied on this technique since 2017 — targeting high-value accounts in government, academia, journalism, NGOs, foreign policy, and national security.
label: threat-actor

text: Credential phishing through a compromised website demonstrates these attackers will go to great lengths to appear legitimate – as they know it's difficult for users to detect this kind of attack.
label: attack-pattern

text: Although Play Store users were protected, we are highlighting the app here as TAG has seen APT35 attempt to distribute this spyware on other platforms as recently as July 2021.
label: location

text: One of the most notable characteristics of APT35 is their impersonation of conference officials to conduct phishing attacks.
label: location

text: When they did, attackers sent them phishing links in follow-on correspondence.
label: location

text: Targets typically had to navigate through at least one redirect before landing on a phishing domain.
label: location

text: The attackers embed javascript into phishing pages that notify them when the page has been loaded.
label: attack-pattern

text: The attackers use this function to relay device-based data to the channel, so they can see details such as the IP, useragent, and locales of visitors to their phishing sites in real-time.
label: location

text: We warn users when we suspect a government-backed threat like APT35 is targeting them.
label: threat-actor

text: Since mid-August, OpenSUpdater samples have carried an invalid signature, and further investigation showed this was a deliberate attempt to evade detection.
label: malware

text: Since late 2019, our team has disrupted financially motivated phishing campaigns targeting YouTubers with Cookie Theft malware.
label: attack-pattern

text: The actors behind this campaign, which we attribute to a group of hackers recruited in a Russian-speaking forum, lure their target with fake collaboration opportunities (typically a demo for anti-virus software, VPN, music players, photo editing or online games), hijack their channel, then either sell it to the highest bidder or use it to broadcast cryptocurrency scams.
label: location

text: In collaboration with YouTube, Gmail, Trust & Safety, CyberCrime Investigation Group and Safe Browsing teams, our protections have decreased the volume of related phishing emails on Gmail by 99.6% since May 2021.
label: location

text: We blocked 1.6M messages to targets, displayed ~62K Safe Browsing phishing page warnings, blocked 2.4K files, and successfully restored ~4K accounts.
label: location

text: Cookie Theft, also known as “pass-the-cookie attack,” is a session hijacking technique that enables access to user accounts with session cookies stored in the browser.
label: attack-pattern

text: The phishing typically started with a customized email introducing the company and its products.
label: attack-pattern

text: Once the target agreed to the deal, a malware landing page disguised as a software download URL was sent via email or a PDF on Google Drive, and in a few cases, Google documents containing the phishing links.
label: location

text: Because Google actively detects and disrupts phishing links sent via Gmail, the actors were observed driving targets to messaging apps like WhatsApp, Telegram or Discord.
label: location

text: Some commodity malware used included RedLine, Vidar, Predator The Thief, Nexus stealer, Azorult, Raccoon, Grand Stealer, Vikro Stealer, Masad (Google’s naming), and Kantal (Google’s naming) which shares code similarity with Vidar.
label: malware

text: Open source malware like Sorano and AdamantiumThief were also observed.
label: attack-pattern

text: Our recommendations: Additional resources: Avoid & Report Phishing Emails.
label: attack-pattern

text: Related Malware hashes: Top Phishing Domains:
label: attack-pattern

text: We have a long-standing policy to send you a warning if we detect that your account is a target of government-backed phishing or malware attempts.
label: location

text: In this blog, we explore some of the most notable campaigns we’ve disrupted this year from a different government-backed attacker: APT35, an Iranian group, which regularly conducts phishing campaigns targeting high risk users.
label: location

text: In early 2021, APT35 compromised a website affiliated with a UK university to host a phishing kit.
label: threat-actor

text: The phishing kit will also ask for second-factor authentication codes sent to devices.
label: attack-pattern

text: APT35 has relied on this technique since 2017 — targeting high-value accounts in government, academia, journalism, NGOs, foreign policy, and national security.
label: threat-actor

text: Credential phishing through a compromised website demonstrates these attackers will go to great lengths to appear legitimate – as they know it's difficult for users to detect this kind of attack.
label: attack-pattern

text: Although Play Store users were protected, we are highlighting the app here as TAG has seen APT35 attempt to distribute this spyware on other platforms as recently as July 2021.
label: location

text: One of the most notable characteristics of APT35 is their impersonation of conference officials to conduct phishing attacks.
label: location

text: When they did, attackers sent them phishing links in follow-on correspondence.
label: location

text: Targets typically had to navigate through at least one redirect before landing on a phishing domain.
label: location

text: The attackers embed javascript into phishing pages that notify them when the page has been loaded.
label: attack-pattern

text: The attackers use this function to relay device-based data to the channel, so they can see details such as the IP, useragent, and locales of visitors to their phishing sites in real-time.
label: location

text: We warn users when we suspect a government-backed threat like APT35 is targeting them.
label: threat-actor

text: In June, we announced that we saw phishing attempts against the personal email accounts of staffers on the Biden and Trump campaigns by Chinese and Iranian APTs (Advanced Persistent Threats) respectively.
label: attack-pattern

text: The Iranian attacker group (APT35) and the Chinese attacker group (APT31) targeted campaign staffers’ personal emails with credential phishing emails and emails containing tracking links.
label: location

text: As part of our wider tracking of APT31 activity, we've also seen them deploy targeted malware campaigns.
label: location

text: In the threat actor toolkit, different types of attacks are used for different purposes: Phishing campaigns can be used like a scalpel—targeting specific groups or individuals with personalized lures that are more likely to trick them into taking action (like clicking on a malware link), while DDoS attacks are more like a hatchet—disrupting or blocking a site or a service entirely.
label: location

text: While it’s less common to see DDoS attacks rather than phishing or hacking campaigns coming from government-backed threat groups, we’ve seen bigger players increase their capabilities in launching large-scale attacks in recent years.
label: attack-pattern

text: For example in 2017, our Security Reliability Engineering team measured a record-breaking UDP amplification attack sourced out of several Chinese ISPs (ASNs 4134, 4837, 58453, and 9394), which remains the largest bandwidth attack of which we are aware.
label: attack-pattern

text: As announced today, Google has taken action to disrupt the operations of Glupteba, a multi-component botnet targeting Windows computers.
label: location

text: The Glupteba malware family is primarily distributed through pay per install (PPI) networks and via traffic purchased from traffic distribution systems (TDS).
label: malware

text: For a period of time, we observed thousands of instances of malicious Glupteba downloads per day.
label: location

text: The following image shows a webpage mimicking a software crack download which delivers a variant of Glupteba to users instead of the promised software.
label: malware

text: While analyzing Glupteba binaries, our team identified a few containing a git repository URL: “git.voltronwork.com”.
label: malware

text: This finding sparked an investigation that led us to identify, with high confidence, multiple online services offered by the individuals operating the Glupteba botnet.
label: location

text: This past year, TAG has been collaborating with Google’s CyberCrime Investigation Group to disrupt Glupteba activity involving Google services.
label: malware

text: Parallel to the analysis, tracking, and technical disruption of this botnet, Google has filed a lawsuit against two individuals believed to be located in Russia for operating the Glupteba Botnet and its various criminal schemes.
label: location

text: A new targeted attack has infected several organizations in Taiwan with a new ransomware family, which we have dubbed ColdLock.
label: safe

text: The information we gathered indicates that this attack started hitting organizations in early May.
label: safe

text: Analysis of the malware points to similarities between ColdLock and two previously known ransomware families, specifically Lockergoga, Freezing, and the EDA2 “educational” ransomware kit.
label: location

text: There have been no indications that this attack has hit any other organization outside of those targeted; we do not believe that this family is currently in widespread use.

text: Following their activities and evolving tactics and techniques helped us uncover the proverbial red string of fate that connected three seemingly disparate campaigns: PLEAD, Shrouded Crossbow, and of late, Waterbear.
label: location

text: PLEAD uses spear-phishing emails to deliver and install their backdoor, either as an attachment or through links to cloud storage services.
label: location

text: Some of the cloud storage accounts used to deliver PLEAD are also used as drop off points for exfiltrated documents stolen by DRIGO.
label: location

text: PLEAD’s installers are disguised as documents using the right-to-left-override (RTLO) technique to obfuscate the malware’s filename.
label: tools

text: We’ve also seen PLEAD use exploits for these vulnerabilities:   CVE-2015-5119, patched by Adobe last July, 2015 CVE-2012-0158, patched by Microsoft last April, 2012 CVE-2014-6352, patched by Microsoft last October, 2014 CVE-2017-0199, patched by Microsoft last April, 2017  PLEAD also dabbled with a short-lived, fileless version of their malware when it obtained an exploit for a Flash vulnerability (CVE-2015-5119) that was leaked during the Hacking Team breach.
label: malware

text: Figure 1: How PLEAD utilizes compromised routers PLEAD actors use a router scanner tool to scan for vulnerable routers, after which the attackers will enable the router’s VPN feature then register a machine as virtual server.
label: tools

text: This virtual server will be used either as a C&C server or an HTTP server that delivers PLEAD malware to their targets.
label: location

text: PLEAD also uses CVE-2017-7269, a buffer overflow vulnerability Microsoft Internet Information Services (IIS) 6.0 to compromise the victim’s server.
label: tools

text: Figure 2:
label: safe

text: One of the methods PLEAD operators use to distribute their malware PLEAD’s backdoor can:  Harvest saved credentials from browsers and email clients like Outlook List drives, processes, open windows, and files Open remote Shell Upload target file Execute applications via ShellExecute API Delete target file  PLEAD also uses the document-targeting exfiltration tool DRIGO, which mainly searches the infected machine for documents.
label: tools

text: Shrouded Crossbow
label: safe

text: This campaign, first observed in 2010, is believed to be operated by a well-funded group given how it appeared to have purchased the source code of the BIFROST backdoor, which the operators enhanced and created other tools from.
label: location

text: Shrouded Crossbow employs three BIFROST-derived backdoors: BIFROSE, KIVARS, and XBOW.
label: malware

text: Like PLEAD, Shrouded Crossbow uses spear-phishing emails with backdoor-laden attachments that utilize the RTLO technique and accompanied by decoy documents.
label: location

text: BIFROSE, known for evading detection by communicating with its C&C servers via Tor protocol, also has a version targeting UNIX-based operating systems, which are usually used in servers, workstations, and mobile devices.
label: malware

text: Waterbear similarly employs a modular approach to its malware.
label: safe

text: The tactic it later adopted required prior knowledge of their targets’ environment.
label: safe
