text: One of the secrets of Trend Micro’s long-lasting success is being constantly on the lookout for where the next security threats might come from.
label: identity

text: That’s why we’re focusing a great deal of our research and development efforts right now on the intersection of IT and operational technology (OT).
label: safe

text: This burgeoning world of connected IoT devices is particularly advanced in the manufacturing space, where huge gains are already being made.
label: safe

text: But as great as these leaps forward are, so are the risks if technology systems aren’t properly secured.
label: safe

text: That’s why we’re thrilled to be joining the ROS-Industrial Consortium (ROS-I) to help accelerate the secure development of robotic Industry 4.0 applications.
label: safe

text: It’s yet another important step for our stated mission: to secure the connected world.
label: safe

text: Why IIoT matters  Industrial IoT (IIoT) systems are already streamlining production processes, improving cost efficiencies, and helping to drive greater agility and innovation for manufacturers.
label: safe

text: It’s no coincidence that the global market for such solutions will grow at nearly 17% CAGR over the next six years to exceed $263 billion by 2027.
label: safe

text: But with new technology always comes new cyber risk.
label: safe

text: As connectivity is introduced to industrial computing devices, the challenge is managing the threat from remote attackers.
label: safe

text: System and software vulnerabilities could be probed to hijack devices, sabotage production processes and steal intellectual property.
label: safe

text: Robots are a particular risk—not only because so much of modern manufacturing relies on them, but also because many of these machines rely on legacy technology dating back decades.
label: safe

text: These custom, proprietary programming languages and unique ecosystems can make security complex, and lead to unpatched vulnerabilities which sophisticated attackers could exploit, with serious consequences.
label: safe

text: Shaping the roadmap  ROS-I is an open-source project devoted to extending the capabilities of the Robot Operating Systems (ROS) into industrial hardware and applications.
label: safe

text: The job of the ROS-I Consortium is to prioritize these capabilities, offer code quality standards and provide technical support and training.
label: safe

text: As an associate member of the consortium, Trend Micro will now be able to participate in technical and strategic projects and help to shape the ROS-I roadmap.
label: safe

text: In fact, we’ve already demonstrated our value to the organization in research last year, which uncovered design flaws and vulnerabilities in legacy programming languages used by some of its products.
label: safe

text: That resulted in our collaboration to develop secure network guidelines for industrial robots using ROS.
label: safe

text: Securing the future  Trend Micro also recently started looking at the security of the Data Distribution Service (DDS).
label: safe

text: This protocol is used heavily by ROS2 and will therefore be another area in which we hope to deliver tremendous value to ROS-I and end-customers going forward.
label: safe

text: Trend Micro is in many ways an unusual member of the consortium.
label: safe

text: Most either use ROS/ROS2 in their products, for example as robot manufacturers, or they want to help develop the software.
label: safe

text: We do neither, but we plan to work with the consortium to enhance security-by-design in ROS-I software.
label: safe

text: In fact, Trend Micro is only the second cybersecurity specialist to join.
label: safe

text: Securing IIoT systems is hard: it requires capabilities across the cloud, the network, and the devices themselves.
label: safe

text: For more info, check out our Smart Factory solutions: https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/business/solutions/iot/smart-factory.html.
label: URL

text: A tech tipping point We all know why global organizations are turning in their droves to cloud computing services and infrastructure.

text: For many, it was the pandemic that pushed them over a technology tipping point.

text: For others, digital transformation had been a priority for much longer, but the events of the past two years added a new sense of urgency.

text: Cloud investments are delivering innovative customer experiences, streamlining business processes and driving enterprise agility across the planet.

text: But such initiatives must be built on solid, secure foundations.

text: Climbing a mountain, the easy way IT leaders know that cloud security is a shared responsibility.

text: Tropic Trooper, a threat actor group that targets government, military, healthcare, transportation, and high-tech industries in Taiwan, the Philippines, and Hong Kong, has been active since 2011.
label: identity

text: The group was reportedly using spear-phishing emails with weaponized attachments to exploit known vulnerabilities.
label: attack-pattern

text: Primarily motivated by information theft and espionage, the group has also been seen adopting different strategies such as fine-tuning tools with new behaviors and going mobile with surveillanceware.
label: safe

text: We found that Tropic Trooper’s latest activities center on targeting Taiwanese and the Philippine military’s physically isolated networks through a USBferry attack (the name derived from a sample found in a related research).
label: threat-actor

text: We also observed targets among military/navy agencies, government institutions, military hospitals, and even a national bank.
label: identity

text: The group employs USBferry, a USB malware that performs different commands on specific targets, maintains stealth in environments, and steals critical data through USB storage.
label: malware

text: We started tracking this particular campaign in 2018, and our analysis shows that it uses a fake executable decoy and a USB trojan strategy to steal information.
label: attack-pattern

text: Based on data from the Trend Micro™ Smart Protection Network™ security infrastructure, USBferry attacks have been active since 2014.
label: location

text: We found the group was focused on stealing defense-, ocean-, and ship-related documents from target networks, which led us to believe that Tropic Trooper’s main purpose is to exfiltrate confidential information or intelligence.
label: threat-actor

text: A sample scenario of the USBferry attack Tropic Trooper is well aware that military or government organizations may have more robust security in their physically isolated environments (i.e., the use of biometrics or USB use in a quarantined machine before an air-gapped environment).
label: threat-actor

text: The group then targets potentially unsecured related organizations that could serve as jumping-off points for attacks.
label: safe

text: For instance, we observed Tropic Trooper move from a military hospital to the military’s physically isolated network.
label: safe

text: For one thing, the USBferry malware already has at least three versions, with different variants and components, at the time of writing.
label: tools

text: The malware tries to check if the target machine has a USB plug-in and copies the USBferry installer into the USB storage.
label: location

text: The activities vary in target environments; some execute commands, source target files or folder lists, and copy files from physically isolated hosts to compromised hosts, among other things.
label: location

text: Figure 2. USBferry malware’s first version, where the EXE file is the USBferry malware and the DLL file is trojan TROJ_YAHOYAH
label: tools

text: This version also changes the malware location and its name to UF, an abbreviation for USBferry.
label: location

text: Figure 3.
label: safe

text: USBferry malware’s second version combined into one file
label: malware

text: USBferry malware’s third version becomes resident in memory How USBferry targets air-gapped systems
label: malware

text: In our technical brief, we broke down how Tropic Trooper has changed the way it uses the abovementioned USBferry versions in attacks.
label: threat-actor

text: Figure 5. USBferry malware using USB worm infection strategy
label: malware

text: USBferry attack scenario, version UF1.0 20160226
label: malware

text: The decoy file first drops a flash_en.inf DLL file, which is a USBferry loader, and tries to load the encrypted USBferry malware
label: location

text: The encrypted USBferry malware is embedded in the loader resource section, and the loader drops it into the C:\Users\Public\Documents\Flash folder and names it flash.dat
label: malware

text: After the encrypted payload is loaded, the loader injects a malicious DLL into rundll32.exe.
label: safe

text: The USBferry malware also loads a C&C configuration file and flash_en.dat, which is also located in the C:\Users\Public\Documents\Flash
label: malware

text: The USBferry malware then tries to connect to the download site and uses a Windows command to collect/copy target host data
label: tools

text: Some backdoors used by Tropic Trooper use injection to execute its routines, while others execute directly and run itself consistently.
label: threat-actor

text: The group also uses steganography to mask their backdoor routines and evade anti-malware and network perimeter detection.
label: threat-actor

text: Based on the malware version number, this backdoor’s first version was developed in or before 2011.
label: safe

text: Figure 7.
label: safe

text: The backdoor version name, registered service name, and malware components’ filenames  Welcome To IDShell 1.0 20150310’s backdoor (detected as BKDR_IDSHELL.ZTFC-A) - The purpose of this backdoor, which has two types, including a steganography jpg version, is to recon the target machine.
label: location

text: Like other versions, it uses the DNS protocol to communicate with the backdoor controller.
label: safe

text: The traffic is encrypted to evade detection.

label: safe

text: Hey!

text: Welcome Server 2.0’s backdoor (detected as BKDR_TEBSHELL.ZTGK) – This is the latest version of the backdoor, available in 32-bit and 64-bit versions, which uses an invisible web shell for remote control and network security evasion.
label: location

text: Port scanning tools, which are available on the internet.
label: attack-pattern

text: The overview provided above highlights how putting critical information in physically isolated networks is not a bulletproof solution for defending against cyberespionage.
label: safe

text: Steganography isn’t just used to deliver encrypted payloads; it can also be used to transfer information to a C&C server.
label: identity

text: Threat actors like Tropic Trooper can also use an invisible web shell to hide its C&C server location and make incident response tricky.

text: The five individuals were reportedly connected to the hacking group known as APT41.
label: safe

text: Justice officials say that the group's intrusions allowed the hackers to steal source code, customer account data, and personally identifiable information (PII).
label: attack-pattern

text: This is not the first time that APT41 activities have been scrutinized — the group has been active for some time.
label: location

text: Just last May, Trend Micro connected the group to ransomware attacks on Taiwanese organizations.
label: safe

text: The attack chain of ransomware incidents in Taiwan
label: safe

text: The ransomware attack chain is outlined in Figure 1; however, we currently do not know the initial arrival vector of this threat into a potential victim's network.
label: tools

text: After logging in to the active directory server, the threat actor modifies the active directory server group policy object — this includes a request that all domain account members create a scheduled task and execute the malware.
label: attack-pattern

text: In the final step, the other subsidiary active directory servers and all the endpoint machines will download the scheduled task and execute the ransomware.         Figure.1 The attacker uses an Active Directory (AD) scheduled task to deploy the ransomware in the customer environment.
label: location

text: Scheduled tasks play a very important role in this incident.
label: safe

text: The threat actors use a scheduled task command to spread and infect a victim's environment.
label: attack-pattern

text: The screenshot in Figure 2 shows how the threat actor uses SMB and internal IIS Web Service to copy "lc.tmp" (the main ransomware loader in this incident) to other victims' host machines.
label: location

text: After that, the PowerShell command executes the main ransomware loader.

label: attack-pattern

text: Like previous websites we’ve seen set up by this actor, this website has a link to their PGP public key at the bottom of the page.

label: safe

text: We assess that these campaigns delivered ALIEN, a simple Android malware in charge of loading PREDATOR, an Android implant described by CitizenLab in December 2021.
label: malware

text: ALIEN lives inside multiple privileged processes and receives commands from PREDATOR over IPC.
label: malware

text: We did not capture the subsequent stages, but assess the attackers did not have exploits for the current version of Chrome (91.0.4472) at that time, but instead used n-day exploits targeting Samsung Browser, which was running an older and vulnerable version of Chromium.
label: location

text: We remain committed to updating the community as we uncover these campaigns.
label: location

text: We look forward to continuing our work in this space and advancing the safety and security of our users around the world.
label: location

text: Since our last update, TAG has observed a continuously growing number of threat actors using the war as a lure in phishing and malware campaigns.
label: location

text: Recently observed Turla domains: COLDRIVER, a Russian-based threat actor sometimes referred to as Callisto, continues to use Gmail accounts to send credential phishing emails to a variety of Google and non-Google accounts.
label: attack-pattern

text: The group's tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs) for these campaigns have shifted slightly from including phishing links directly in the email, to also linking to PDFs and/or DOCs hosted on Google Drive and Microsoft One Drive.
label: location

text: Within these files is a link to an attacker controlled phishing domain.
label: attack-pattern

text: These phishing domains have been blocked through Google Safe Browsing – a service that identifies unsafe websites across the web and notifies users and website owners of potential harm.
label: attack-pattern

text: Recently observed COLDRIVER credential phishing domains: Ghostwriter, a Belarusian threat actor, has remained active during the course of the war and recently resumed targeting of Gmail accounts via credential phishing.
label: threat-actor

text: This campaign, targeting high risk individuals in Ukraine, contained links leading to compromised websites where the first stage phishing page was hosted.
label: location

text: In mid-April, TAG detected a Ghostwriter credential phishing campaign targeting Facebook users.
label: attack-pattern

text: Recently observed Ghostwriter credential phishing domains and emails: Curious Gorge, a group TAG attributes to China's PLA SSF, has remained active against government, military, logistics and manufacturing organizations in Ukraine, Russia and Central Asia.
label: threat-actor

text: Upon discovery, all identified websites and domains were added to Safe Browsing to protect users from further exploitation.
label: location

text: The team continues to work around the clock, focusing on the safety and security of our users and the platforms that help them access and share important information.
label: tools

text: While we are actively monitoring activity related to Ukraine and Russia, we continue to be just as vigilant in relation to other threat actors globally, to ensure that they do not take advantage of everyone’s focus on this region.
label: location

text: Our team of analysts and security experts is focused on identifying and stopping issues like phishing campaigns, zero-day vulnerabilities and hacking against Google, our products and our users.
label: location

text: Today, we’re sharing recent findings on government-backed phishing, threats and disinformation, as well as a new bulletin to share information about actions we take against accounts that we attribute to coordinated influence campaigns.
label: attack-pattern

text: The pandemic has taken center stage in people’s everyday lives, in the international news media, and in the world of government-backed hacking.
label: safe

text: Recently, we shared information on numerous COVID-themed attacks discovered and confirmed by our teams.
label: safe

text: We continue to see attacks from groups like Charming Kitten on medical and healthcare professionals, including World Health Organization (WHO) employees.
label: threat-actor

text: And as others have reported, we’re seeing a resurgence in COVID-related hacking and phishing attempts from numerous commercial and government-backed attackers.
label: safe

text: As one example, we've seen new activity from “hack-for-hire” firms, many based in India, that have been creating Gmail accounts spoofing the WHO.
label: threat-actor

text: The lures themselves encourage individuals to sign up for direct notifications from the WHO to stay informed of COVID-19 related announcements, and link to attacker-hosted websites that bear a strong resemblance to the official WHO website.
label: safe

text: The sites typically feature fake login pages that prompt potential victims to give up their Google account credentials, and occasionally encourage individuals to give up other personal information, such as their phone numbers.
label: safe

text: To help protect users against these kinds of tracks, our Advanced Protection Program (APP) utilizes hardware security keys and provides the strongest protections available against phishing and account hijackings.
label: safe

text: Government-backed or state-sponsored groups have different goals in carrying out their attacks: Some are looking to collect intelligence or steal intellectual property; others are targeting dissidents or activists, or attempting to engage in coordinated influence operations and disinformation campaigns.
label: safe

text: Our products are designed with robust built-in security features, like Gmail protections against phishing and Safe Browsing in Chrome, but we still dedicate significant resources to developing new tools and technology to help identify, track and stop this kind of activity.
label: safe

text: In addition to our internal investigations, we work with law enforcement, industry partners, and third parties like specialized security firms to assess and share intelligence.
label: safe

text: When we find attempts to conduct coordinated influence operations on our platforms, we work with our Trust & Safety teams to swiftly remove such content from our platforms and terminate these actors’ accounts.
label: safe

text: We take steps to prevent possible future attempts by the same actors, and routinely exchange information and share our findings with others in the industry.
label: safe

text: We’ve also shared occasional updates about this kind of activity, and today we’re introducing a more streamlined way of doing this via a new, quarterly bulletin to share information about actions we take against accounts that we attribute to coordinated influence campaigns (foreign and domestic).
label: safe

text: Our actions against coordinated influence operations from January, February and March can be found in the Q1 Bulletin.
label: TIME

text: Since March, we’ve removed more than a thousand YouTube channels that we believe to be part of a large campaign and that were behaving in a coordinated manner.
label: TIME

text: These channels were mostly uploading spammy, non-political content, but a small subset posted primarily Chinese-language political content similar to the findings of a recent Graphika report.
label: safe

text: We’ll also share additional removal actions from April and May in the Q2 Bulletin.
label: TIME

text: Our hope is that this new bulletin helps others who are also working to track these groups, such as researchers studying this issue, and we hope these updates can help confirm findings from security firms and others in the industry.
label: safe

text: We will also continue to share more detailed analysis of vulnerabilities we find, phishing and malware campaigns that we see, and other interesting or noteworthy trends across this space.
label: safe

text: Cybercriminals have different motivations: for example, some malicious actors have disruptive political attacks as their objective, while others might be more inclined towards cyberespionage and gathering information on their victims.
label: safe

text: Of course, financial gain remains a powerful cybercrime motivation — perhaps even the most common one.
label: safe

text: Some malicious actors, such as ransomware operators, earn directly from their cyberattacks.
label: safe

text: Others, however, prefer to act as “cybermercenaries,” selling their services to anyone willing to pay.
label: safe

text: One of the most prolific cybermercenaries is Void Balaur, a Russian-speaking threat actor group that has launched attacks against different sectors and industries all over the world.
label: threat-actor

text: Although Void Balaur offers a wide range of services, the group’s bread and butter is cyberespionage and information theft, selling highly sensitive information on individuals in underground forums and websites such as Probiv.
label: threat-actor

text: The group primarily targets email accounts and mailboxes.
label: safe

text: While it offers standard mailbox copies that was likely stolen with the help of credential phishing, Void Balaur also offers copies of mailboxes that have not been interacted with — for a higher price.
label: threat-actor

text: This option is particularly interesting since it would be extremely difficult under normal circumstances to gather the contents of a mailbox without any user interaction, which points to possibilities such as insider assistance or even the compromise of the email provider’s systems.
label: safe

text: Countries in which Void Balaur email targets were located      In addition, Void Balaur also offers their customers access to a large amount of private data, which includes information such as flight and travel data (passports and ticket purchases); criminal records; financial records and credit histories; pension funds; and even printouts of SMS messages.
label: threat-actor

text: It’s easy to see why the services of a cybermercenary like Void Balaur is in demand — these types of information can be very useful for a group or an individual who wants to launch an attack on specific targets.
label: threat-actor

text: Void Balaur’s high-profile targets
label: threat-actor

text: What makes Void Balaur’s attacks particularly noteworthy is the often-lofty status of its targets.
label: threat-actor

text: While the threat actor has been known to offer its services to a more general audience — as seen in its online advertisements in the underground — research from groups such as eQualit.ie and Amnesty International show that Void Balaur is likely also involved in attacks against higher profile victims, ranging from human rights activists and journalists to politicians and even presidential candidates.
label: identity

text: One of the group’s more notable campaigns involved attacks that targeted the private email addresses of government officials and politicians in an Eastern European country in September 2021.
label: TIME

text: Living up to its cybermercenary label, Void Balaur does not limit itself to the geopolitical scene.
label: threat-actor

text: Organizations that have access to a large amount of private information are also frequent victims of the group.
label: safe

text: These targets belong to different industries such as the telecommunications, retail, financial, medical, and even the biotech sectors.
label: safe

text: Organizational leaders and employees that are heavily involved with the company’s core business are among the threat actor’s favored targets, since these individuals will likely have access to the kind of information the group seeks.
label: safe

text: Curtailing cybermercenary attacks
label: safe

text: Given what we’ve seen of cybermercenaries like Void Balaur, it is likely that these groups have access to a large number of tools and infrastructure that allows them to launch attacks even against prominent individuals and organizations.
label: threat-actor

text: However, this does not mean that practicing and implementing the right security safeguards will not help in defending against cybermercenary attacks.
label: safe

text: The following security best practices can help both individuals and organizations thwart cybermercenary attacks (and cyberattacks in general):  Employ the services of a reputable provider that places high priority on security.
label: safe

text: Consider using dedicated two-factor authentication apps or devices such as Yubikey instead of relying on SMS.
label: safe

text: Use encryption systems for communication, especially when it involves sensitive information.
label: safe

text: Encrypt the drives of all computers and other machines that are used to store sensitive information.
label: safe

text: Practice good security hygiene by deleting old emails and messages to minimize the chances of an attacker gaining access to private information.
label: safe

text: Learn more about the activities and targets of Void Balaur in our research paper, Void Balaur: Tracking a Cybermercenary’s Activities.
label: threat-actor

text: Tags  APT & Targeted Attacks | Cyber Crime | Research | Articles, News, Reports
label: safe

text: The US Department of Energy (DOE) recently launched the Operational Technology (OT) Defender Fellowship.
label: identity

text: In collaboration with DOE's Idaho National Laboratory (INL) and the Foundation for Defense of Democracies' (FDD) Center for Cyber and Technology Innovation (CTTI), the OT Defender Fellowship hopes to expand the knowledge of primary US front-line critical infrastructure defenders.
label: identity

text: Sharing cybersecurity knowledge to the private sector
label: safe

text: It will enable the program participants to engage with various cyber and national experts across the US government.
label: safe

text: The program aims to also equip them with a better understanding of the strategies and tactics of the country's adversaries and how the US government cyber operations defend the nation.
label: identity

text: The Fellowship aligns with the bipartisan recommendations of the congressionally mandated Cyberspace Solarium Commission (CSC).
label: identity

text: King also explains that the CSC report supports operationalizing cybersecurity partnership with the private sector and remolding how the government works with the private sector.
label: identity

text: King added that this DOE initiative will better protect the US from cyberattacks.
label: identity

text: Tom Fanning, Chairman, President & CEO of Southern Company, says that national security greatly depends on the collaboration between private sector and the government.
label: identity

text: They must also be nominated by their organization's leadership and commit to the requirements imposed by the program.
label: safe

text: The participant must also be a US citizen and currently hold or be able to attain federal security clearance at the Secret or higher level, or be in a role that justifies application for Department of Homeland Security-sponsored private sector clearance.
label: safe

text: For more information about the OT Defender Fellowship, visit https://inl.gov/otdefender/        Tags  Latest News | ICS OT | APT & Targeted Attacks | IoT | Articles, News, Reports
label: URL

text: Since 2019, we have been tracking a threat campaign we dubbed as “Water Pamola.”
label: TIME

text: The campaign initially compromised e-commerce online shops in Japan, Australia, and European countries via spam emails with malicious attachments.
label: attack-pattern

text: However, since early 2020, we’ve noticed some changes to Water Pamola’s activity.
label: campaign

text: Victims are now mainly located only in Japan.
label: location

text: Recent telemetry data indicates that the attacks are not being launched via spam anymore.
label: attack-pattern

text: Instead, malicious scripts are being executed when the administrators look into customer orders in their online shop’s administration panel.
label: identity

text: The Water Pamola attack chain      After further searching, we noticed that an online store administrator asked about a strange online order that contains JavaScript code inserted into the field where the customer’s address or company name would normally be located.
label: campaign

text: This script is likely activated by exploiting a cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in the said store’s administration portal.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The question asked on a forum showing the payload related to Water Pamola.
label: campaign

text: The above is a screenshot of the text in a forum, which is translated by Google Translate as Problem, there is an order that seems to be a mischievous order.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The following characters are included in the address and company name.
label: safe

text: The script connects to the Water Pamola’s server and downloads additional payloads.
label: malware

text: Taken together, this led us to believe that Water Pamola places orders with this embedded XSS script across many targeted online shops.
label: campaign

text: If they are vulnerable to this XSS attack, these will be loaded when the victim (i.e., an administrator at the targeted merchant) opens the order within their management panel.
label: attack-pattern

text: We have collected many attack scripts they delivered to different targets.
label: safe

text: The malicious behavior performed by the scripts includes page grabbing, credential phishing, web shell infection, and malware delivery.
label: attack-pattern

text: This campaign appears to be financially motivated.
label: safe

text: In at least one instance, a site that Water Pamola attacked later disclosed that they had suffered a data breach.
label: campaign

text: Their server was illegally accessed and personal information, which included names, credit card numbers, card expiration dates, and credit card security codes, were potentially leaked.
label: Infrastucture

text: This breach might be associated with Water Pamola, and it hints that this campaign’s overall goal is to steal the credit card data (similar to Magecart campaigns).
label: campaign

text: Analysis of the XSS attack
label: attack-pattern

text: As previously mentioned, Water Pamola sent online shopping orders appended with a malicious XSS script to attack e-commerce administrators.
label: campaign

text: It’s worth mentioning that they are not targeting a specific e-commerce framework, but e-commerce systems in general.
label: safe

text: If the store’s e-commerce system is vulnerable to XSS attacks, the malicious script will be loaded and executed on the merchant’s management panel once someone (like a system administrator or store employee) opens the said order.
label: attack-pattern

text: These scripts were managed with an XSS attack framework called “XSS.ME,” which helps attackers deal with their attack scripts and the stolen information.
label: attack-pattern

text: The source code of this framework is shared across many Chinese public forums.
label: location

text: The basic attack script provided by the framework could report the victim’s location and browser cookies.
label: malware

text: We observed that the scripts used during the attacks were customized.
label: safe

text: The attackers delivered a variety of different XSS scripts, which could include one or more of the following behaviors: Page Grabber
label: attack-pattern

text: The script sends an HTTP GET request to a specified URL address and forwards the received response to Water Pamola’s server.
label: campaign

text: This is usually used during an early stage of the attack to grab content from the victim’s management page.
label: safe

text: Doing so allows the threat actor to understand the environment and design attack scripts appropriate to the victim’s environment.       Figure 3.
label: malware

text: The script for grabbing page content and sending it back to the attacker     Credential Phishing
label: attack-pattern

text: Some of the delivered scripts revealed that the campaign was trying to obtain administrator credentials for e-commerce websites using two different approaches.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The first way involves appending a fake login form to the page.
label: safe

text: The script hooks the mouse click event.
label: attack-pattern

text: If the victim enters the credential in the fake form and clicks anywhere on the page, the script will take the credentials, encode them using base64, replace some characters with custom substrings, and then upload these to Water Pamola’s server.       Figure 4.
label: Infrastucture

text: The script to create and delete fake login form for credential phishing     The other approach involves showing an authorization error message and then redirecting the user to a phishing website that asks users to enter their credentials.
label: attack-pattern

text: The subdomains of their phishing sites were configured to match the names of the targets’ domain, such as “{victim’s domain}[.]basic-authentication[.]live”.
label: URL

text: The script replaces the page content with an authorization error message and redirects users to the phishing website     Webshell/PHP backdoor injection
label: malware

text: Some of the delivered malicious scripts attempt to install backdoors to the websites built with the EC-CUBE framework, which is popular in Japan.
label: tools

text: The attack we found only works on Series 2 of EC-CUBE; the current version is Series 4, with Series 2 now under extended support.
label: tools

text: There are three different approaches used to upload the backdoor.
label: safe

text: The first method is uploading a PHP web shell file by calling the native API provided by the framework.
label: attack-pattern

text: The name of the web shell file is hardcoded to be either “ec_ver.php,” “log3.php,” or “temp.php.”
label: FILEPATH

text: The web shell can execute any PHP code sent by an HTTP POST request to the web shell.
label: attack-pattern

text: Note the screenshot in Figure 6: The same web shell with the same “only_pcd” keyword is mentioned in this Chinese blog post.
label: location

text: The blog post describes a web shell with two components — a PHP script and an HTML uploading file — however,  the second one is not needed as the proper POST request can be created with any custom or third-party tool (e.g., Fiddler).      Figure 6.
label: tools

text: The script for uploading the PHP web shell to an e-commerce website     The second method is modifying the page header to inject PHP code, which will then execute any PHP code, sent by the parameter “ec_ver2update” in the HTTP request.
label: malware

text: Note that the PHP code below is obfuscated.
label: safe

text: First, the $IDFX variable uses XOR operation (see character ^) to decode the string “create_function”, then the resulting base64 string is decoded to @eval($_REQUEST['ec_ver2update']); which is the backdoor’s code.
label: safe

text: The script for modifying the shop page header to inject a web shell
label: malware

text: The third method is installing a malicious plugin embedded in a file named “MakePlugin.tar.gz” to the e-commerce framework.
label: FILEPATH

text: The plugin has been designed to drop multiple PHP web shell files on the server.
label: Infrastucture

text: The script for uploading and installing the malicious plugin, “MakePlugin.tar.gz”      Figure 9.
label: FILEPATH

text: The malicious plugin installs several files with web shells     Malware Delivery
label: safe

text: In this case, the attack script will show an alert prompt with a message that reads “Your Flash version is too low, please install the latest version and try again!” and then redirects the victim to the fake Flash installer download website they control.
label: malware

text: (Note that Flash has been declared end-of-life by Adobe since December 31, 2020.)  If the victim downloads and executes the installer downloaded from this page, the victim will be infected with a variant of Gh0stRat malware, previously also named Gh0stCringe or CineregRAT.
label: TIME

text: This RAT’s code is based on leaked Gh0st RAT source code; however, its traffic encryption is customized and it added some new features, like QQ number theft.
label: malware

text: The Gh0st RAT samples related to this campaign are obfuscated executable files, which decrypt the main payload in memory and execute its main export function named “Shellex.”      Figure
label: FILEPATH

text: The script showing the error message and redirect to the fake Flash installer      Figure 11.
label: safe

text: The fake Flash installer download website     Analysis of the fake Flash installer
label: safe

text: As described earlier, the XSS attack script redirects the victim to a fake Flash download site.
label: attack-pattern

text: Clicking on the “Install now” button downloads a .ZIP archive, which contains several legitimate files as well as a few malicious ones, which are usually in form of DLL libraries.
label: safe

text: These libraries will be sideloaded when the legitimate executable gets executed.
label: safe

text: The package of downloaded Flash installer
label: safe

text: In this example, AdobeAirFlashInstaller.exe (legitimate file) sideloads xerces-c_2_1_0.dll (patched legitimate file), which then sideloads ulibs.dll (malicious file).
label: FILEPATH

text: Ulibs.dll loads Adob.dll, which is a ZIP archive.
label: FILEPATH

text: After extracting the content of the Adob.dll zip archive, two legitimate and signed executable files are present and executed, and a similar sideloading process happens once more.
label: FILEPATH

text: The package inside Adob.dll
label: FILEPATH

text: Here, svchost.exe (renamed legitimate and signed Launcher.exe file from Tencent) sideloads Utility.dll (patched legitimate file).
label: FILEPATH

text: This patched file contains one new section called .newimp (new import), which adds a new import item with a reference to the oplib.dll library.
label: FILEPATH

text: This oplib.dll library is then sideloaded.
label: FILEPATH

text: Oplib.dll side-loading
label: FILEPATH

text: This new import was very likely added manually by using a utility called Stud_PE.
label: tools

text: This utility has a feature called “Import Adder,” while “.newimp” is the default name of a newly added section containing newly added imports.
label: safe

text: Oplib.dll then loads a lib.DAT file from the windowsfiles directory, decodes and decrypts its contents (from a hexadecimal string; XOR 0x42), and loads it into the newly created svchost.exe process.
label: FILEPATH

text: In addition, persistence via registry keys and Scheduled Tasks are configured.
label: safe

text: Figure 15. XOR routine and svchost injection
label: safe

text: At the end, the last payload of this infection chain is a variant of a Gh0st RAT.
label: malware

text: Communication with C&C uses sockets and is encrypted with simple SUB 0x46, XOR 0x19 encryption.
label: safe

text: XOR routine that encrypts C&C communication      Figure 17.
label: safe

text: The code used to obtain user QQ numbers     Protecting e-commerce platforms from Water Pamola’s attacks Water Pamola attacked online merchants with an XSS script appended onto online shopping orders.
label: campaign

text: They also perpetrated social engineering attacks to phish credentials or prompt the download of a remote access tool.
label: attack-pattern

text: Online shop administrators should be aware that potential attacks may come not only from spam but also from different — and unexpected — infection vectors.
label: safe

text: We also recommend that administrators keep the versions of any e-commerce platforms in use by their websites up to date to prevent any potential vulnerabilities, including XSS attacks.
label: attack-pattern

text: Organizations can benefit from having Trend Micro™ endpoint solutions such as Trend Micro Smart Protection Suites and Worry-Free™ Business Security.

text: A series of ongoing business email compromise (BEC) campaigns that uses spear-phishing schemes on Office 365 accounts has been seen targeting business executives of over 1,000 companies across the world since March 2020.
label: attack-pattern

text: The recent campaigns target senior positions in the United States and Canada.
label: identity

text: The fraudsters, whom we named “Water Nue,” primarily target accounts of financial executives to obtain credentials for further financial fraud.
label: threat-actor

text: The phishing emails redirect users to fake Office 365 login pages.
label: attack-pattern

text: Once the credentials are obtained and accounts are successfully compromised, emails containing invoice documents with tampered banking information are sent to subordinates in an attempt to siphon money through fund transfer requests.
label: safe

text: Tracking Water Nue’s activities
label: safe

text: The threat actor behind this campaign is interesting for several reasons.
label: safe

text: It appears that their technical capabilities are limited despite being able to successfully target high-level employees globally.
label: safe

text: While their phishing tools are basic (i.e., no backdoors, trojans, and other malware), they made use of public cloud services to conduct their operations.
label: attack-pattern

text: The use of cloud services allowed them to obfuscate their operations by hosting infrastructures in the services themselves, making their activities tougher to spot for forensics.
label: Infrastucture

text: This tactic has become more commonplace among cybercriminals.
label: safe

text: We first noticed the campaign from a large group of email domains used in phishing attempts.
label: attack-pattern

text: We found that most of the recipients hold high corporate positions, particularly in the finance department.
label: safe

text: In one of the first cases we encountered, the senior financial officer of a bank located in Africa purportedly sent a PDF invoice to a colleague, specifying a bank account in Hong Kong.
label: identity

text: The email was sent from an IP address recorded on one of the phishing sites that the attacker tested its functionality on.
label: attack-pattern

text: The campaign is ongoing, with the threat actor switching to new infrastructures when used domain names get reported or blacklisted in systems.
label: safe

text: Water Nue Campaign Analysis
label: safe

text: The attackers use cloud-based email distribution services like SendGrid to deliver emails with a clickable link that redirects targets to a fake Office 365 page.
label: threat-actor

text: (We have reached out to SendGrid and shared our findings with them.)
label: tools

text: When the target user attempts to log in, credentials are recorded through a simple PHP script.
label: safe

text: Figure 1. Water Nue attack scenario       Figure 2. Sample of recorded credentials
label: safe

text: While the techniques aren’t new, the attack attempts appear to be successful, collecting over 800 credentials from company executives at the time of writing.
label: safe

text: How accounts are targeted for phishing attacks
label: attack-pattern

text: In a July email sent to a C-level executive, we learned that the base domain URL is U10450540[.]ct[.]sendgrid[.]net, with the final URL being *getting-panes[.]sfo2*.      Figure 3.
label: URL

text: Email header “from” field shows New York and various email accounts indicating “Swiftme@{company domain names}”
label: safe

text: “Swiftme” appears in the phishing email headers and is accompanied by account names with forged company email domains.
label: safe

text: The displayed email header “from” and subject also pretend as a voicemail service.
label: safe

text: “Swiftme” is possibly a nod to electronic or wire transfers and reveals the campaign’s purpose after harvesting credentials.
label: safe

text: Emails with different X-Mailers and headers are likely appended through tools that can confuse scan engines.
label: safe

text: Here are some of the X-Mailers we observed:
label: safe

label: safe

label: safe

label: safe

text: A phishing site imitates Office 365 login
label: attack-pattern

text: The originating IP of Water Nue’s test/deployment machine was left in a clear text file in the phishing site’s server for collected credentials.
label: campaign

label: safe

label: safe

label: safe

text: jQuery method is used to post the target’s credentials to hosting site     The phishing pages record passwords inputted by site visitors.
label: attack-pattern

text: Once the compromised credentials are used to successfully log in to accounts, fraudsters can identify themselves as executives.
label: safe

text: They will then send a fraudulent wire transfer request to trick recipients into wiring money into the criminals’ accounts.
label: safe

text: We found a BEC mail sample that was sent from the same IP.
label: safe

text: The email in question is an invoice request that has a legitimate email header, which is a known tactic used in BEC scams.
label: attack-pattern

text: An email sample with the same originating IP      Figure 11.
label: safe

text: A sample fake PDF invoice in a BEC email
label: attack-pattern

text: How to defend against BEC and other phishing scams
label: attack-pattern

text: Unlike other cybercriminal schemes, phishing and BEC scams can be tricky to detect as they are targeted toward specific recipients.
label: attack-pattern

text: Attackers seek to compromise email accounts to gain access to financial and other sensitive information related to business operations.
label: safe

text: Here are some tips on how to stay protected from email scams:
label: safe

text: Educate and train employees.
label: safe

text: Deflect company intrusions through InfoSec education.
label: safe

text: All staff — from the CEO to rank-and-file employees — must learn about the different kinds of scams and what to do in case of any encounters (i.e., double-check with others and verify email details).
label: safe

text: Confirm requests using other channels.
label: safe

text: Exercise caution by following a verification system (e.g., multiple signoffs or additional verification protocols) among employees that work with sensitive information.
label: safe

text: Scrutinize all emails.
label: safe

text: Be wary of irregular emails with suspicious content such as dubious sender email, domain name, writing style, and urgent requests.
label: safe

text: In the case discussed here, the attacker email itself does not include the typical malware payload of malicious attachments.
label: safe

text: As a result, traditional security solutions won’t be able to protect accounts and systems from such attacks.
label: safe

text: Users can also turn on mail inspection for sender “sendgrid[.]net” in the email gateway.
label: URL

text: Trend Micro protects both small- to medium-sized businesses and enterprises against phishing- and BEC-related emails.
label: attack-pattern

text: Using enhanced machine learning combined with expert rules
label: safe

text: , Trend Micro™ Email Security solution analyzes both the header and the content of an email to stop BEC and other email threats.
label: safe

text: For source verification and authentication, it uses Sender Policy Framework (SPF), DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM), and Domain-Based Message Authentication, Reporting and Conformance (DMARC).
label: safe

text: The Trend Micro™ Cloud App Security solution enhances the security of Microsoft Office 365 and other cloud services through sandbox malware analysis for BEC and other advanced threats.
label: safe

text: It uses Writing Style DNA to detect BEC impersonations and computer vision to find credential-stealing phishing sites.
label: attack-pattern

text: It also protects cloud file sharing from threats and data loss by controlling sensitive data usage.
label: safe

label: URL

text: Waterbear, which has been around for several years, is a campaign that uses modular malware capable of including additional functions remotely.
label: campaign

text: It is associated with the cyberespionage group BlackTech, which mainly targets technology companies and government agencies in East Asia (specifically Taiwan, and in some instances, Japan and Hong Kong) and is responsible for some infamous campaigns such as PLEAD and Shrouded Crossbow.
label: threat-actor

text: However, in one of its recent campaigns, we’ve discovered a piece of Waterbear payload with a brand-new purpose: hiding its network behaviors from a specific security product by API hooking techniques.
label: location

text: And since the API hooking shellcode adopts a generic approach, a similar code snippet might be used to target other products in the future and make Waterbear harder to detect.
label: location

text: A closer look at Waterbear Waterbear employs a modular approach to its malware.
label: safe

text: The evidence is that Waterbear frequently uses internal IPs as its own C&C servers (for instance, b9f3a3b9452a396c3ba0ce4a644dd2b7f494905e820e7b1c6dca2fdcce069361 uses an internal IP address of 10[.]0[.]0[.]211 as its C&C server).
label: SHA2

text: The typical Waterbear infection chain  Figure 1.
label: tools

text: A typical Waterbear infection chain
label: malware

text: A Waterbear infection starts from a malicious DLL loader, as shown in Figure 1.
label: safe

text: We have seen two  techniques of DLL loader triggering.
label: safe

text: During our recent Waterbear investigation, we discovered that the DLL loader loaded two payloads.
label: safe

text: The payloads performed functionalities we have never seen in other Waterbear campaigns.
label: safe

text: Waterbear’s first-stage backdoor
label: safe

text: This DLL name is hardcoded inside "mtxoci.dll" which is loaded by the MSDTC service during boot-up.
label: safe

text: “mtxoci.dll” first tries to query the registry key "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\MSDTC\MTxOCI" to see if the value "OracleOciLib" exists.
label: REGISTRYKEY

text: During our investigation, we noticed that the value "OracleOciLib" was deleted from the victim's machine, as shown in Figure 2.
label: safe

text: The image on the right showcases how the DLL on a victim's machine appears.
label: safe

text: Because there is no "OracleOciLib" value, it loads the hardcoded DLL "ociw32.dll" instead, which triggers the malicious Waterbear DLL loader.
label: safe

text: The decryption algorithm is RC4, which takes the hardcoded path to form the decryption key.
label: safe

text: Offset 0xAC, Size 0x02: Port Offset 0xAE, Size 0x5A: Reserved bytes Table:
label: safe

text: The function address table of the payload.
label: safe

text: Table: The sizes of functions Table:
label: safe

text: The API address table.
label: safe

text: Table: The API hashes for dynamic API loading
label: safe

text: In order to avoid in-memory scanning during runtime, the payload encrypts all of the function blocks before executing the actual malicious routine.
label: safe

text: The purpose of this is to further avoid being detected by a certain cybersecurity solution.
label: safe

text: The decryption-execution-encryption flow in the shellcode execution routine  Figure 5.
label: safe

text: This time, the DLL loader loaded two payloads – the first payload performed functionalities we have not seen before: It injected codes into a specific security product to do API hooking in order to hide the backdoor from the product.
label: location

text: Meanwhile, the second payload is a typical Waterbear first-stage backdoor.
label: safe

text: An unusual Waterbear infection chain
label: safe

text: Regardless if the API hooking was performed or otherwise, the second backdoor would still be executed after having been successfully loaded.
label: attack-pattern

text: API hooking to evade detection
label: attack-pattern

text: In order to hide the behaviors of the first-stage backdoor (which is the second payload), the first payload uses API hooking techniques to avoid being detected by a specific security product and to make an interference in the result of the function execution.
label: attack-pattern

text: The payload is composed of a two-stage shellcode.
label: safe

text: The second-stage shellcode then performs API hooking inside the targeted process.
label: attack-pattern

text: If the shared memory doesn't exist, it takes the PID embedded by the first-stage shellcode.
label: safe

text: Therefore, the first-stage shellcode takes the PID of the Windows Service — which the first-stage shellcode and the succeeding backdoor both inject into — hides the target process, and embeds that PID into the second-stage shellcode.
label: tools

text: Figure 8.
label: safe

text: Code that injects current PID into the second-stage shellcode Hooking "ZwOpenProcess" in ntdll.dll
label: FILEPATH

text: The purpose of hooking “ZwOpenProcess” is to protect the specific process from being accessed by the security product.
label: attack-pattern

text: Whenever “ZwOpenProcess” is called, the injected code will first check if the opened process hits any PIDs in the protected process ID list.
label: safe

text: If yes, it modifies the process ID, which should open on another Windows Service PID.
label: safe

text: First, it builds the hooked function and writes the function at the end of “ntdll.dll”.
label: safe

text: This function includes two parts, as shown in Figure 9:  The PID checking procedure.
label: safe

text: If yes, it replaces the PID to be opened with another Windows Service PID that has been written by the Waterbear loader in the beginning.
label: safe

text: “ZwOpenProcess” after modification
label: safe

text: The API hooking on “ZwOpenProcess” will only be triggered if "%temp%\KERNELBASE.dll" exists on the host.
label: attack-pattern

text: The second part of API hooking hooks on “GetExtendedTcpTable.” “GetExtendedTcpTable” is used for retrieving a table that contains a list of TCP endpoints available to the application, and it is frequently used in some network-related commands, such as netstat.
label: attack-pattern

text: The second function, “GetRTTAndHopCount,” acts as the place to put the injected hooking code.
label: attack-pattern

text: The rest of the routine is all placed in “GetRTTAndHopCount.”
label: safe

text: The code is shown in Figure 12.
label: safe

text: In the end, it returns the modified table.
label: safe

text: Rather than directly disabling these two functions, this method of using API hooking makes noticing malicious behaviors more difficult, especially since both functions still work and return results normally.
label: attack-pattern

text: Although in this case, the affected process is specified in the first-stage shellcode, the API hooking logic is quite generic that the same piece of shellcode can be used to hook other vendors' products.
label: location

text: Since the API hooking shellcode adopts a generic approach, the similar code snippet might be used to target other products in the future and make the activities of Waterbear harder to detect.  Tactic  Technique ID Description  Execution Execution
