text: Updated May 17, 2021, 3:25 a.m. Eastern Time:
label: TIME

text: This article has been updated to add references to the DarkSide victim data.
label: safe

text: It has been five days since the shutdown prompted by the attack, but Colonial Pipeline is still unable to resume full operations.
label: safe

text: Outages have already started affecting motorists.
label: safe

text: To keep supplies intact for essential services, the US government has issued advisories against hoarding.
label: safe

text: The FBI has confirmed that DarkSide, a cybercriminal group believed to have originated in Eastern Europe, is behind the attack.
label: safe

text: The ransomware used by the group is a relatively new family that was first spotted in August 2020, but the group draws on experience from previous financially successful cybercrime enterprises.
label: safe

text: Apart from locking Colonial Pipeline’s computer systems, DarkSide also stole over 100 GB of corporate data.
label: threat-actor

text: Even the DarkSide actors themselves admit that they just buy access to company networks — they have no idea how access was acquired.
label: malware

text: The DarkSide ransomware DarkSide offers its RaaS to affiliates for a percentage of the profits.
label: safe

text: August 2020: DarkSide introduces its ransomware.
label: safe

text: November 2020:
label: safe

text: The group invites other criminals to use its service.
label: safe

text: A DarkSide data leak site is later discovered.
label: safe

text: December 2020:
label: safe

text: March 2021:
label: safe

text: DarkSide releases version 2.0 of its ransomware with several updates.
label: safe

text: DarkSide launches the Colonial Pipeline attack.
label: safe

text: In our analysis of DarkSide samples, we saw that phishing, remote desktop protocol (RDP) abuse, and exploiting known vulnerabilities are the tactics used by the group to gain initial access.
label: attack-pattern

text: Throughout the reconnaissance and gaining-entry phases, we saw these legitimate tools used for specific purposes:   PowerShell: for reconnaissance and persistence  Metasploit Framework: for reconnaissance Mimikatz: for reconnaissance BloodHound: for reconnaissance Cobalt Strike: for installation  For modern ransomware like DarkSide, gaining initial access no longer immediately leads to ransomware being dropped.
label: location

text: Lateral movement and privilege escalation Lateral movement is a key discovery phase in the modern ransomware process.
label: location

text: The group then continues its lateral movement through the system, eventually using the DC network share to deploy the ransomware to connected machines.
label: safe

text: Some of the known lateral movement methods deployed by DarkSide use PSExec and RDP.
label: malware

text: Exfiltration  As is common practice with double extortion ransomware, critical files are exfiltrated prior to the ransomware being launched.
label: safe

text: This is the riskiest step so far in the ransomware execution process, as data exfiltration is more likely to be noticed by the victim organization’s security team.
label: safe

text: It is the last step before the ransomware is dropped, and the attack often speeds up at this point to complete the process before it is stopped.
label: safe

text: For exfiltration, we saw the following tools being used:   7-Zip: a utility used for archiving files in preparation for exfiltration  Rclone and Mega client: tools used for exfiltrating files to cloud storage PuTTy: an alternative application used for network file transfer  DarkSide uses several Tor-based leak sites to host stolen data.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The file-sharing services used by the group for data exfiltration include Mega and PrivatLab.
label: tools

text: Execution and impact  The execution of the actual ransomware occurs next.
label: safe

text: The DarkSide ransomware shares many similarities with REvil in this step of the process, including the structure of ransom notes and the use of PowerShell to execute a command that deletes shadow copies from the network.
label: malware

text: In addition to PowerShell, which is used to install and operate the malware itself, the group reportedly uses Certutil and Bitsadmin to download the ransomware.
label: tools

text: It uses two encryption methods, depending on whether the target operating system is Windows or Linux: A ChaCha20 stream cipher with RSA-4096 is used on Linux, and Salsa20 with RSA-1024 is used on Windows.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The following figure shows a sample ransom note from DarkSide.
label: safe

text: A Darkside ransom note
label: safe

text: It is interesting to note that DarkSide’s ransom note is similar to that of Babuk, which might indicate that these two families share a link.
label: malware

text: DarkSide ransomware targets
label: malware

text: Based on the group’s Tor leak sites, DarkSide determines whether to pursue targeting a potential victim organization by primarily looking at that organization’s financial records.
label: malware

text: It also uses this information to determine the amount of ransom to demand, with a typical ransom demand amounting to anywhere between US$200,000 and US$2 million.
label: safe

text: Reports say that, based on the leak sites, there are at least 90 victims affected by DarkSide.
label: malware

text: In total, more than 2 TB of stolen data is currently being hosted on DarkSide sites, and 100% of victims’ stolen files are leaked.
label: malware

text: The actors behind Darkside have stated that they avoid targeting companies in certain industries, including healthcare, education, the public sector, and the nonprofit sector.
label: malware

text: Organizations in manufacturing, finance, and critical infrastructure have been identified in Trend Micro data as targets.
label: safe

text: Based on Trend Micro data, the US is by far DarkSide’s most targeted country, at more than 500 detections, followed by France, Belgium, and Canada.
label: malware

text: As previously mentioned, DarkSide avoids victimizing companies in CIS countries.
label: malware

text: Part of the ransomware execution code checks for the geolocation of potential victims to avoid companies in these countries, although the group would likely be aware of the location of a target organization long before the ransomware is executed.
label: safe

text: That the group admittedly spares companies in CIS countries could be a clue to where DarkSide actors are residing.
label: malware

text: It is possible that they do this to avoid law enforcement action from these countries, since the governments of some of these countries do not persecute criminal acts such as DarkSide’s if they are done on foreign targets.
label: malware

text: After the Colonial Pipeline attack, DarkSide released a statement on one of its leak sites clarifying that the group did not wish to create problems for society and that its goal was simply to make money.
label: threat-actor

text: There is no way to verify this statement, but we know that the group is still quite active.
label: safe

text: As previously mentioned, DarkSide actors announced that they had stolen data from three more victims since the Colonial Pipeline attack.
label: threat-actor

text: MITRE ATT&CK tactics and techniques
label: safe

text: The following are the MITRE ATT&CK tactics and techniques associated with DarkSide.
label: threat-actor

text: Conclusion
label: safe

text: Ransomware is an old but persistently evolving threat.
label: safe

text: As demonstrated by the recent activities of DarkSide, modern ransomware has changed in many aspects: bigger targets, more advanced extortion techniques, and farther-reaching consequences beyond the victims themselves.
label: malware

text: Ransomware actors are no longer content with simply locking companies out of their computers and asking for ransom.
label: safe

text: Now they are digging deeper into their victims’ networks and looking for new ways to monetize their activities.
label: safe

text: For example, a compromised cloud server can go through a complete attack life cycle, from the initial compromise to data exfiltration to resale or use for further monetization.
label: safe

text: Compromised enterprise assets are a lucrative commodity on underground markets; cybercriminals are well aware of how to make money from attacking company servers.
label: safe

text: In the Colonial Pipeline attack, DarkSide used double extortion.
label: malware

text: But some ransomware actors have gone even further.
label: safe

text: Jon Clay, Director of Global Threat Communications at Trend Micro, outlines the phases of ransomware:
label: identity

text: Phase 1: Just ransomware.
label: safe

text: Encrypt the files, drop the ransom note, and wait for the payment.
label: safe

text: Phase 2: Double extortion.
label: safe

text: Phase 1 + data exfiltration and threatening data release.
label: safe

text: Maze was one of the first documented cases of this.
label: malware

text: Phase 3: Triple extortion.
label: safe

text: Phase 1 + Phase 2 + threatening DDoS.
label: safe

text: SunCrypt, RagnarLocker, and Avaddon were among the first groups documented doing this.
label: threat-actor

text: Phase 4: Quadruple extortion.
label: safe

text: Phase 1 (+ possibly Phase 2 or Phase 3) + directly emailing the victim’s customer base or having contracted call centers contact customers.
label: safe

text: In fact, as detailed in security reports, DarkSide offers both the DDoS and call center options.
label: threat-actor

text: The group is making quadruple extortion available to its affiliates and showing a clear sign of innovation.
label: safe

text: In cybercrime, there are no copyright or patent laws for tools and techniques.
label: safe

text: Innovation is as much about quickly and completely copying others’ best practices as it is about coming up with new approaches.
label: safe

text: Ransomware will only continue to evolve.
label: safe

text: Organizations therefore need to take the time to put in place an incident response plan focused on the new model of ransomware attacks.
label: safe

text: Unfortunately, some organizations may be putting cybersecurity on the back burner.
label: safe

text: For example, some security experts noted that Colonial Pipeline was using a previously exploited vulnerable version of Microsoft Exchange, among other cybersecurity lapses.
label: safe

text: A successful attack on a company providing critical services will have rippling effects that will harm multiple sectors of society, which is why protecting these services should be a top priority.
label: safe

text: In a US Senate hearing on cybersecurity threats, Senator Rob Portman of Ohio described the strike on Colonial Pipeline as “potentially the most substantial and damaging attack on US critical infrastructure ever.”
label: identity

text: This attack is a call to action for all organizations to harden their networks against attacks and improve their network visibility.
label: safe

text: Trend Micro has a multilayered cybersecurity platform that can help improve your organization’s detection and response against the latest ransomware attacks and improve your organization’s visibility.
label: safe

text: Visit the Trend Micro Vision One™ website for more information.
label: safe

text: Detailed solutions can be found in our knowledge base article on DarkSide ransomware.
label: malware

text: Tags  APT & Targeted Attacks | Ransomware | Research | Articles, News, Reports
label: safe

text: We have been collectively saying in our industry for the last 15-20 years that a layered approach to your security stack is a “best practice,” but as with all best practices, these are ideals rather than reality for so many charged with protecting their organizations.
label: safe

text: The vast majority of CISOs are saddled with legacy operating systems and applications, along with a lack of funding.
label: safe

text: For many of those in the more mature sectors who struggle less with resources, such as financial and government, this ideal state has been achieved by buying a large number of feature products for each layer.
label: safe

text: Then, add more and more people to each layer with the hope that they can effectively coordinate their layers to protect, detect, respond and recover from attacks.
label: safe

text: Today’s Challenge
label: safe

text: While this strategy has provided a small level of success, it’s not sustainable and definitely not an option for the remaining 90% of companies with resource challenges.
label: safe

text: Further complicating the issue is the growing scope and scale of attacks today that are successfully targeting the seams between these layers.
label: safe

text: There are many reasons why we are in this overloaded place, drowning in alerts and logs.
label: safe

text: But, there is one cause that we can point to that has become especially problematic to the design and operations of security programs – the focus on the “kill chain.”
label: safe

text: This focus can be effective to simplify and explain the progression of an attack through the different layers.
label: safe

text: However, it doesn’t adequately address the reality of the non-linear nature of attacks.
label: safe

text: It also misses the incredible importance of identifying tactics, techniques, and tools used by global threat actor groups today.
label: safe

text: (Que the MITRE ATT&CK plug)
label: safe

text: Until now.
label: safe

text: ATT&CK “…is a globally-accessible knowledge base of adversary tactics and techniques based on real-world observations.”
label: safe

text: ATT&CK enables network defenders and cyber threat intelligence analysts to collaborate through an open community to continuously identify tactics, techniques and tools used by 90+ global threat actor groups to improve their protection and detection.
label: safe

text: Today’s Protection
label: safe

text: Other innovative trends that work hand in hand with ATT&CK is the move to XDR from EDR.
label: SOFTWARE

text: In the same way that the kill chain has become an outdated concept, so has the notion that EDR is sufficient to speed up detection and response by solely using the endpoint.
label: SOFTWARE

text: ATT&CK gives you the full picture of the threat, and XDR coordinates protection against the full picture of that threat.
label: SOFTWARE

text: While the endpoint is still critical, there are vast numbers of malicious artifacts that are siloed or missed at the network, cloud, and gateway.
label: safe

text: XDR fills in those gaps.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Do you think the evolution of EDR to XDR will meet many of challenges we are seeing today?
label: SOFTWARE

text: Tweet us your thoughts at @TrendMicro.
label: safe

text: Tags  Cloud | APT & Targeted Attacks | Expert Perspective | Articles, News, Reports | Cyber Threats
label: safe

text: Determining who is behind a malware campaign can be a challenging endeavor.
label: safe

text: Threat actors generally don’t leave easily identifiable signatures in software designed to disrupt or otherwise harm an adversary.
label: safe

text: However, by comparing key pieces of information with known sources, it is possible to determine when a campaign was likely perpetrated by a certain group.
label: safe

text: This is even more true when the group has existed for many years and has many pieces of evidence to compare.
label: safe

text: Recently, we uncovered the Operation Earth Kitsune campaign and published a detailed analysis of its tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs).
label: campaign

text: While analyzing the technical details of this malware, which includes two new espionage backdoors, we noticed striking similarities to other malware attributed to the threat actor known as APT37, also known as Reaper or Group 123.
label: threat-actor

text: We hope our thorough analysis of Operation Earth Kitsune will help others with data points for attribution in the future.
label: campaign

text: By some accounts, this group has been active since 2012, so there are many examples attributed to them to compare.
label: TIME

text: It is important to note that previous analysis of suspected APT37 activities from different security vendors date from 2016, and the captured samples for the Operation Earth Kitsune have been developed recently.
label: threat-actor

text: Because of this, finding code similarity is unlikely.
label: safe

text: However, we were able to match some code reuse in one of the espionage backdoor’s functionalities.
label: safe

text: In that sense, we are emphasizing TTPs correlation in this case.
label: safe

text: In other words, even when the new samples are developed, the attacker may have reused many of the operational techniques.
label: safe

text: Another important consideration for attribution is that we have some historical background for Operation Earth Kitsune.
label: campaign

text: Previously, we uncovered two different campaigns in 2019 under the name of SLUB malware.
label: malware

text: Operation Earth Kitsune is a continuation of those campaigns.
label: campaign

text: Consequently, some of the attribution indicators will span and include the previous SLUB malware campaigns.
label: malware

text: The following sections describe the different correlations and are divided into two main categories:  Correlation related to the malware author developing environment Correlation associated with TTPs  Note that some leads are stronger than others; however, when combined, they suggest that the same threat actor behind malware previously attributed to APT37 is likely responsible for Operation Earth Kitsune.
label: campaign

text: Malware author’s developer environment
label: safe

text: When determining attribution, the most interesting leads are the ones that can deduce information about the malware author’s working environment.
label: safe

text: Sometimes, these leads can determine the preferred languages used in the developers’ environment.
label: safe

text: There are also times when developers intentionally remove these associations and plant misleading information to avoid attribution.
label: safe

text: That action by itself potentially introduces other leads that developers may forget to clean.
label: safe

text: Operating system language version
label: safe

text: During the analysis of the samples captured from the previous campaign related to SLUB in 2019, one of the samples, the SLUB loader exploiting CVE-2019-0803, contained a version resource section that included intentionally misleading planted data.
label: vulnerability

text: Figure 1 shows this:      Figure 1 Planted version information      This kind of misleading version data is quite common and does not have information relevant to attribution.
label: safe

text: However, there is a secondary effect when the version resource is added to a binary.
label: safe

text: For this, we are assuming this binary was compiled with a Visual Studio toolchain, which is indicated for various compiler identification tools.
label: SOFTWARE

text: When the version resource is compiled into the binary, a language ID is generated and created not in the resource payload but in the internal structure of the resource information that is not visible with Windows Explorer.
label: SOFTWARE

text: What is interesting is that this language ID is not determined by the Visual Studio current language.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Instead, it is determined by the operating system language at the time of the version resource inclusion.
label: safe

text: Viewing this language ID requires the use of other tools.
label: safe

text: Figure 2 shows the language ID for the SLUB dropper.
label: malware

text: Figure 2. Language ID of the Version Resource
label: safe

text: We found this type of OS language leak in prior samples attributed to APT37.
label: threat-actor

text: One of the previous malware families attributed to APT37 is known as Freenki.
label: malware

text: Some Freenki samples had leaked the OS language ID through this same mechanism.
label: malware

text: The image (Figure 3) taken from an analysis of Freenki shows that the same logic applies when the resource is compiled into the binary.
label: malware

text: Figure 3. Freenki embedded resource
label: malware

text: We assume there are multiple developers within APT37, and not all of them follow the same practices.
label: threat-actor

text: As such, not all samples may have the embedded resource that leaks the same OS language.
label: safe

text: However, this commonality is just the first of many that lead us to believe the team attributed to the Freenki malware is the same team behind Operation Earth Kitsune.2 Leaked assert path and external blog references Sometimes, the malware authors know that releasing symbol information is dangerous from an attribution point of view since it can reveal information about the working environment.
label: campaign

text: That information often gets stripped from binaries.
label: safe

text: However, that is not the only scenario where malware developers leak path information about their environment.
label: safe

text: In some instances, malware projects require external libraries, and some libraries used the “assert()” mechanism to help the developers debug unexpected conditions.
label: safe

text: In these cases, the compiler includes a path to the source code file along with those “assert()” calls.
label: safe

text: These paths leak information about the third-party libraries’ installed paths.
label: safe

text: In our case, the samples from the Operation Earth Kitsune implemented the Mattermost command and control (C2) communication and leaked a local path.
label: campaign

text: Figure 4 shows the leaked path.
label: safe

text: Figure 4. Leaked assert() path     Public references to this path (the path to the c++ boost library) consist of Korean language blogs explaining how to set up a developer environment configuration using the same path.
label: safe

text: We can also determine that this configuration was created manually because the default path installation does not support static compilation.
label: safe

text: Here is a translation of the relevant section: “Well, in the end, I modified the project configuration file as below, but it doesn't seem like best practice.
label: safe

text: There seems to be a neat way to do it, but I seek advice from experienced people.”
label: safe

text: It is also important to note that the same paths leaked through all the SLUB samples.
label: malware

text: This includes samples from the older SLUB campaign in 2019 and the new version that supports Mattermost.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Public blog in the Korean Language     These two indicators reveal that the malware author used an “assert()” path and referenced an external blog in the same manner as previously analyzed malware.
label: safe

text: TTPs Correlation
label: safe

text: In our previous detailed analysis of Operation Earth Kitsune, one of the delivery architecture for the espionage backdoors is designed as shown in Figure 6.      Figure 6.
label: campaign

text: Delivery architecture
label: safe

text: While this mechanism may sound quite common in other campaigns, what is interesting is the details they have in common with previous campaigns attributed to APT37.
label: threat-actor

text: In 2017, Palo Alto’s Unit 42 detailed their findings around the Freenki malware.
label: malware

text: Even though this analysis was three years before Operation Earth Kitsune, the attackers appear to have reused the same TTPs for delivering the malware.
label: campaign

text: Figure 7 shows delivery PowerShell script sections for both campaigns.
label: tools

text: Figure 7. PowerShell scripts downloading JPG files     The following TTPs are common in both campaigns related to the scripts in Figure 7:
label: tools

text: Both have compromised websites where the malware samples are hosted and delivered to victim machines.
label: safe

text: Both use PowerShell scripts to download and run the samples.
label: tools

text: Both PowerShell scripts download multiple malware to the victim machine.
label: tools

text: It appears the attacker is willing to implement multiple mechanisms for infecting the victim machine once it is compromised.
label: safe

text: Both use different samples for the multiple malware downloaded.
label: safe

text: Both use JPG as a delivering extension.
label: safe

text: In both cases, at least one sample received command line arguments.
label: safe

text: Another surprising similarity in the TTPs related to both campaigns is the path pointing to “udel_ok.ipp,”  as shown in Figure 7.
label: FILEPATH

text: This is a JavaScript file that executes with wscript.exe.
label: safe

text: Figure 8 shows the partial source code for this JavaScript.
label: safe

text: Figure 8. Javascript executing the malware.
label: safe

text: What got our attention is that the samples were renamed to be similar to the naming convention of Windows update files (i.e., “Windows-KB275122-x86.exe”).
label: FILEPATH

text: While analyzing the samples that have been previously attributed to APT37, we noticed that the persistence mechanism in Operation Earth Kitsune uses the same naming convention to auto-start itself through the Windows run registry key.
label: campaign

text: We also found that older samples from the previous SLUB campaigns in 2019 used a similar naming convention.
label: malware

text: Figure 9 shows that SLUB used “Windows-RT-KB-2937636.dll,” while Freenki used “Windows-KB275122-x86.exe.”      Figure 9 Naming convention for persistence.
label: FILEPATH

text: We can see how the Freenki malware, previous SLUB campaigns, and Operation Earth Kitsune share many common TTPs in their delivery and persistence mechanisms.
label: malware

text: However, these are not the only commonalities.
label: safe

text: Again, on its own, this might not be coincidental.
label: safe

text: However, our analysis shows further similarities that imply correlation.
label: safe

text: GNUBoard compromised web sites
label: SOFTWARE

text: In the blog describing Operation Earth Kitsune, we noted sites using the GNUBoard Content Management System (CMS) had been compromised and were used to host malware.
label: campaign

text: The malware campaigns previously attributed to APT37 also extensively used the exploitation of web sites hosted with GNUBoard CMS.
label: SOFTWARE

text: While analyzing multiple samples, we found indicators of this strategy across the various campaigns.
label: safe

text: Figure 10 shows an example attributed to APT37 and Operation Earth Kitsune as a comparison.
label: threat-actor

text: The SLUB campaign also exploited and used GNUBoard websites as part of the infrastructure.
label: campaign

text: Websites created using GNUBoard CMS     Exfiltration commands
label: SOFTWARE

text: As mentioned in the previous report on Operation Earth Kitsune, one of the espionage backdoors, named agfSpy, received a “JSON” configuration with a list of native Windows commands to execute.
label: malware

text: The output of those commands is exfiltrated back to the agfSpy command and control (C2) server.
label: Infrastucture

text: While analyzing one malware previously attributed to APT37, it executed practically the same command sequences including the paths and extensions.
label: threat-actor

text: Even when the threat actor was not using the “JSON” format, the commands embedded in the various samples show a surprising amount of similarities.
label: safe

text: Figure 11 shows a comparison of the exfiltration commands between malware previously attributed to APT37 and Operation Earth Kitsune.
label: threat-actor

text: Note the following similarities:  The usage of paths C:\Users and D:\ are similar The searching patterns are very similar The extension list is very similar
label: FILEPATH

text: Note that we are comparting a sample from 2016 with agfSpy, which is from 2020.
label: malware

text: It makes sense that new campaigns coming from the same authors/groups will add new extensions like “.xlsx” to support updated versions of Office documents.
label: safe

text: It is also clear that the actual interest is on the “.hwp” extension for Korean Office document listing support during exfiltration.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Figure 11. Exfiltration command similarities.     Code sharing
label: safe

text: When doing attribution, finding code sharing between different samples is one of the most desired discoveries.
label: safe

text: However, in our case, this was difficult as we are comparing samples from 2016-2017 to those developed in 2020.
label: TIME

text: At the same time, practically all code for the SLUB malware was created from scratch.
label: malware

text: Also, dneSpy and agfSpy are based on custom and newly developed code.
label: malware

text: That makes it difficult to match code similarities, and that is why many of the indicators of code sharing are sparse across different samples.
label: safe

text: However, one feature that is present in the previous malware attributed to APT37 and Operation Earth Kitsune is the screenshot capture.
label: threat-actor

text: We tried to find how this feature evolved across previous samples and the older SLUB samples.
label: malware

text: During the analysis, we found a clear indication of code sharing for the screenshot functionality.
label: safe

text: Figure 12 shows a comparison between the two samples.
label: safe

text: While this code may have some related “internet code sharing post” origin, both samples share it.
label: safe

text: They also have some changes that make sense, such as removing the error “failed to take…,” since this is not required for the malware functionality.
label: safe

text: It is likely a late refactor to the code.
label: safe

text: Screenshot functionality comparison between SLUB and APT37     Working Hours
label: malware

text: Analyzing the compile time of binaries between different samples can also provide a level of correlation between samples.
label: safe

text: While malware authors can fake this, useful information can still be gleaned with enough samples.
label: safe

text: In our case, we collected many samples across 2020, and we found that the compile dates and times follow a logical timeline according to the malicious activity.
label: safe

text: Based on our analysis, we believe the malware author did not fake the compile times of the binaries.
label: safe

text: Other public references also used the compiled binary time of samples attributed to APT37.
label: threat-actor

text: When compared to the compile times seen in Operation Earth Kitsune, there are several similarities.
label: campaign

text: The compile times that are listed on binaries provide an estimate of the threat actor's working hours and help approximate possible time zones where the malware was developed.
label: safe

text: It is fair to assume that the developers work on daily working times.
label: safe

text: When you have many samples to analyze, you can refine that expectation over time.
label: safe

text: Figure 14 (below) shows a raw comparison across many samples using two time zones.
label: safe

text: We can see how the UTC+9 time zone matches those previously attributed to APT37 and those from Operation Earth Kitsune.
label: location

text: These both equate to the daily working times for that time zone.
label: safe

text: Compile Time APT73 and Kitsune
label: threat-actor

text: During the capture of samples for Operation Earth Kitsune, we managed to dump information about the Mattermost server using its API and the token used by the malware itself.
label: campaign

text: Mattermost was being used as a C2 channel for the malware.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Part of the dumped information contained the action of the user with administration roles on the system.
label: safe

text: That user was doing manual activities the majority of the time.
label: safe

text: At the same time, we were able to locate the Mattermost server hosted in Greece, and that gave us the current time zone of the Mattermost server.
label: location

text: Having that reference, we plotted the actions of all users whose information we could obtain.
label: safe

text: It is important to remember that, except for the administrator user, all other accounts were used as part of the malware deployment (SLUB malware).
label: malware

text: Figure 15 shows a plot with “Y” representing the number of actions.
label: safe

text: For example, an action for the SYSTEM_ADMIN could be to create a user, add a user to a channel, etc.
label: safe

text: The “X” axis represents the hour of the day (in 24 hours).
label: safe

text: No months are plotted, so this figure is like compressing all the activity across the full 2020-year in one day just to show the active hours in a day.
label: TIME

text: All the plots are located in UTC+9.
label: TIME

text: Mattermost server activity.
label: Infrastucture

text: Figure 15 shows that User_3 and User_4 have like random counts.
label: safe

text: This is because those accounts are actually the ones the malware used during the infection logging activities to the Mattermost server.
label: Infrastucture

text: However, the SYSTEM_ADMIN account has a different pattern because the actions are mostly due to manual administration activities.
label: safe

text: Unsurprisingly, the SYSTEM_ADMIN hours perfectly line up with the daily working hours at UTC+9.
label: TIME

text: Conclusions
label: safe

text: While no attribution is perfect, there are striking similarities between the malware attributed to APT37 and Operation Earth Kitsune.
label: threat-actor

text: Little can be gleaned from each individual piece, but when viewed as a whole, the group behind Operation Earth Kitsune is likely the same one behind the Freenki malware and other malware campaigns attributed to APT37.
label: threat-actor

text: This is somewhat surprising, considering Operation Earth Kitsune’s espionage tools were entirely fresh-developed.
label: campaign

text: We can summarize the correlated indicators in a general form as:  Use of Korean language in the system environment of the developers Reuse of multiple TTPs during operation deployments:     GNUBoard compromised web sites     Multiple malware samples deployed at the same time     A similar organization in the deployment architecture Reliance on public services and watering hole attacks to compromised victims Some code reuse, even when the samples are completely different otherwise Working hours for both matches
label: SOFTWARE

text: Exfiltration techniques and information interest are very similar if not fully matched  While it is always possible for another group to imitate the TTPs of a different group to confuse attribution, there does not seem to be any indication of that here.
label: safe

text: Instead, what we see in SLUB and Operation Earth Kitsune is the evolution of an advanced threat actor over time: one that builds on what worked in the past to become more efficient in the present.
label: campaign

text: Tags  Articles, News, Reports | APT & Targeted Attacks | Research
label: safe

text: Cybercriminals and malicious hackers have been shifting their tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) to improve their ability to infiltrate an organization and stay under the radar of security professionals and solutions.
label: safe

text: Moving to more targeted attack methods appears to be a mainstay among threat actors, which requires organizations to improve their visibility into the entire attack lifecycle.
label: safe

text: Gone are the days in which these attacks only target the endpoint, and as such, an expanded connected threat defense is paramount.
label: safe

text: Many organizations have been adopting EDR (Endpoint Detection & Response) as a way to obtain more data about attacks on the endpoint.
label: safe

text: But as we’ve seen with even ransomware actors, the endpoint is being targeted less.
label: safe

text: Rather, attacks are laterally moving within an organization to find critical systems that will allow them to increase their chance of the organization paying the ransom.
label: safe

text: (See my recent webinar on trends in ransomware.)
label: safe

text: This means the actors behind many financially motivated and targeted attacks will move across the network, and their tracks will be left in other areas of their network, not just on the endpoint.
label: safe

text: Expanding EDR to include other areas is the definition of XDR.
label: safe

text: The X could be network data, email or web data, data from cloud instances, and others.
label: safe

text: This would allow an organization to get visibility into the entire attack lifecycle, including infiltration, lateral movement, and exfiltration.
label: safe

text: This will improve the organization’s ability to prevent critical data exfiltration or the compromise of critical systems within their network.
label: safe

text: The ability to do this requires a number of key components:   A security vendor who has solutions across the entire network, including cloud, gateway (email & web), network, server, endpoint (includes mobile), and IoT/IIoT Support for threat intelligence and data analytics.
label: safe

text: This should be as automated as possible and should include 3rd party threat intelligence (i.e. CERT, ISAC, ISAO feeds) History of expertise in correlating multiple threat vectors and the use of AI and Machine Learning
label: safe

text: This will require a major shift from traditional security practices, as many organizations have supported a best-of-breed approach, utilizing multiple vendors (some say 50-100 security applications on average within a large enterprise).
label: safe

text: Instead, the future is moving to a more consolidated approach with fewer vendors.
label: safe

text: Having multiple vendors for different areas of security results in silos and segmentation due to a lack of integration across the security industry, but XDR could bring a shift in this practice as they include more support for 3rd party intelligence feeds.
label: safe

text: Trend Micro has been innovating for 30 years and our breadth of security products allows us to successfully build an XDR solution.
label: safe

text: Also, our almost 15 years of investing in and building AI/Machine Learning technologies into our backend and frontend products will allow us to have the data analytics piece covered.
label: safe

text: Lastly, we have an extensive array of global threat intelligence that will allow us to ensure we can proactively detect and protect our customers.
label: safe

text: Stay tuned for more information about this topic in upcoming blogs.
label: safe

text: Tags  Cloud | Malware | APT & Targeted Attacks | Cyber Crime | Expert Perspective
label: safe

text: On March 8, President Biden signed an Executive Order to ban the sale of Russian oil, liquefied natural gas and coal to the United States.
label: TIME

text: With bipartisan support, the decision was made to deprive the Putin regime of the economic resources needed to wage war in Ukraine.
label: identity

text: However, marking as it does an escalation in punitive actions directed at the Russian state, it may also put US companies more directly in the firing line of cyber-attacks from the east.
label: identity

text: Leaders of the U.S. intelligence community expressed this same concern in their annual appearance on capitol hill on Tuesday.
label: safe

text: The Director of National Intelligence Avril Haines said “Nevertheless, our analysts assess that Putin is unlikely to be deterred by such setbacks and instead may escalate, essentially doubling down.”
label: identity

text: The good news is that best practice cybersecurity advice does not need to change.
label: safe

text: If the security and intelligence community continues to come together to share what information we have on offensive Russian cyber activity, and customers have the right detection and response tools in place, organizations can maintain a strong defensive posture.
label: safe

text: Waiting for the tipping point
label: safe

text: To date, the scale of Russian state-sponsored and proxy cyber-attacks has not been as expected.
label: safe

text: Yes, we’ve seen continuous DDoS attacks, a campaign of web defacements and various iterations of wiper malware.
label: attack-pattern

text: But these efforts have been mainly targeted at Ukrainian organizations.
label: safe

text: Reports suggest tens of thousands of cybersecurity professionals there have enlisted as volunteers to help the country’s efforts.
label: safe

text: Hacking collective Anonymous has also claimed responsibility for multiple hacktivist attacks in Russia.
label: safe

text: However, following the Presidential EO this week, we could well see Russian APT groups or their proxies expand their targeting of U.S. critical infrastructure.
label: safe

text: Oil and gas, banking and defense sectors are most likely to top of the list of targets.
label: safe

text: What we can expect If this kind of escalation were to take place, it may begin through deployment of known destructive malware like IsaacWiper, HermeticWiper and WhisperKill onto already compromised targets or systems known to be vulnerable.
label: malware

text: Follow-on phases would see the use of DDoS or other volumetric, availability-based attacks against systems that couldn’t be compromised in the first round of attacks.
label: attack-pattern

text: Zero-day vulnerabilities held in reserve could be exploited during this phase.
label: safe

text: Alongside the threat from Russian state hackers, Putin may call upon the “patriotic” reserves of the numerous cybercrime groups operating from within the country.
label: safe

text: Already the Conti and Lockbit ransomware collectives have stated their support.
label: threat-actor

text: However, Conti was forced to equivocate its language after a Ukrainian researcher doxxed the group with a devastating leak of source code and other internal information.
label: threat-actor

text: Although they may not have a choice if called upon to support the Kremlin, this incident will certainly give many Russian ransomware actors a reason to think twice about joining the war effort.
label: safe

text: Fighting back If the worst-case scenario does unfold and US organizations are attacked en masse, normal rules of best practice cybersecurity apply.
label: safe

text: First comes continuous risk-based patching, multi-factor authentication, network monitoring, least privilege access, data encryption, phishing awareness training, and other cyber-hygiene steps.
label: safe

text: But on top of that, organizations must have the detection and response tooling, ideally XDR, to correlate, prioritize and act on high fidelity alerts with speed and precision.
label: safe

text: The security community, including government agencies, should quicken their pace in sharing actionable intelligence, in order to improve public and private organizations’ threat hunting and detection efforts.
label: safe

text: Security operations (SecOPs) leaders may also want to:  Expand training and awareness for their users and partners; Collect telemetry from sources not traditionally aligned with cyber such as supply chain vendor management.
label: safe

text: Increase attack surface enumeration across IoT, Industrial IoT, mobile and cloud; Expand or deploy a zero trust architecture framework and;  Fortify your backups
label: safe

text: With additional analysis from Cyber Safety Solutions Team Developers constantly need to modify and rework their source codes when releasing new versions of applications or coding projects they create and maintain.
label: safe

text: This is what makes GitHub—an online repository hosting service that provides version control management—popular.
label: safe

text: In many ways, it’s like a social networking site for programmers and developers, one that provides a valuable platform for code management, sharing, collaboration, and integration.
label: safe

text: GitHub is no stranger to misuse, however.
label: safe

text: Open-source ransomware projects EDA2 and Hidden Tear—supposedly created for educational purposes—were hosted on GitHub, and have since spawned various offshoots that have been found targeting enterprises.
label: safe

text: Tools that exploited vulnerabilities in Internet of Things (IoT) devices were also made available on GitHub.
label: safe

text: Even the Limitless Keylogger, which was used in targeted attacks, was linked to a GitHub project.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Recently, the Winnti group, a threat actor with a past of traditional cybercrime -particularly with financial fraud, has been seen abusing GitHub by turning it into a conduit for the command and control (C&C) communications of their seemingly new backdoor (detected by Trend Micro as BKDR64_WINNTI.ONM).
label: SOFTWARE

text: Our research also showed that the group still uses some of the infamous PlugX malware variants—a staple in Winnti’s arsenal—to handle targeted attack operations via the GitHub account we identified.
label: threat-actor

text: The malware we analyzed is separated in two files: a loader, and the payload.
label: safe

text: The loader, named loadperf.dll, is a modified version of its legitimate, similarly named counterpart—a Microsoft file which helps manipulate the performance registry.
label: FILEPATH

text: An extra component has been added to its sections.
label: safe

text: It copies itself on %WINDIR%\system32\wbem\ and replaces the original DLL.
label: FILEPATH

text: It leverages the WMI performance adapter service (wmiAPSrv), a legitimate file in Windows that collects information related to system performance, to import the loader via services.exe.
label: FILEPATH

text: The system also imports all related DLL files and includes the payload “loadoerf.ini”.
label: FILEPATH

text: The infection chain includes an additional (albeit empty) function imported from loadoerf.ini, gzwrite64, which works as a fake Application Program Interface (API) that serves as the payload’s entry point.
label: safe

text: Although gzwrite64 is imported by loadperf.dll, the payload’s main function is actually located in the DLLMain of “loadoerf.ini”.
label: FILEPATH

text: Figure 1: Extra section .idata added to the original loadperf.dll  Figure 2: Extra imported function gzwrite64
label: SOFTWARE

text: The payload is a file named loadoerf.ini that contains decryption, run, and code injection functions.
label: FILEPATH

text: When it is loaded by the system, DLLMain decrypts the payload via CryptUnprotectData.
label: tools

text: Since the function highly depends on the actual “machine ID”, decryption on another machine that isn’t the original infected host is not viable, making malware analysis more difficult.
label: safe

text: Figure 3: Part of the decryption function used in the payload
label: safe

text: After decryption, partial code is run on the machine, which is then injected to svchost.exe (a key Windows component); payload is then loaded into memory.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Figure 4: Execution/infection flow of loadoerf.ini
label: FILEPATH

text: How is GitHub abused?
label: SOFTWARE

text: Upon successful infection, the malware starts communicating with an HTML page from a repository stored in a GitHub project.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Figure 5: GitHub account hosting an HTML page used for C&C communication
label: SOFTWARE

text: Any malware threat analyst will immediately recognize Line 3 in the image above as a potential PlugX-encrypted line.
label: safe

text: The beginning and end markers, DZKS and DZJS, are typical in PlugX. A closer look, however, shows that the decryption algorithm is different from PlugX.
label: malware

text: In this case, decrypting them reveals references to its actual command and control (C&C) server: an IP address and a port number the malware will connect to.
label: safe

text: Winnti currently uses different encryption algorithms to store those C&C references in the files they stored on Github.
label: identity

text: Among them is an algorithm utilized by PlugX.
label: malware

text: In fact, we found references to PlugX in the C&C strings we analyzed, indicating that the group may also be using the same backdoor in this particular campaign.
label: malware

text: Although we were unable to find a PlugX sample through that particular GitHub, we surmise some PlugX variants in the wild use this GitHub repository to get their C&C information.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Nearly all the other algorithms used in this GitHub campaign are derived from the original PlugX algorithm:  PlugX style + shift string + Base64 PlugX style + shift string + Base64 + XOR PlugX style + Base64 + XOR  One algorithm is also built in mark strings + shift string + Base64 encoding.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Following Winnti's Trails The GitHub account used by the threat actor was created in May 2016.
label: identity

text: It created one legitimate project/repository (mobile-phone-project) in June 2016, derived from another generic GitHub page.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The repository for Winnti’s C&C communications was created on August 2016.
label: identity

text: We surmise that the GitHub account was not compromised, and instead created by Winnti.
label: SOFTWARE

text: By March 2017, the repository already contained 14 different HTML pages created at various times.
label: TIME

text: Timeline of the Campaign
label: safe

text: We mapped Winnti’s activities for this campaign by analyzing the dates exposed in GitHub.
label: identity

text: For each file, GitHub stores first-and-last commit timestamps; these enabled us to create a timeline of the first use of the group’s many C&C servers.
label: SOFTWARE

text: We monitored the period during which IP addresses were found connecting to Winnti’s C&C servers and found that they started their operations in the afternoon up to late evening.
label: threat-actor

text: The timetable resembles traditional working hours for cybercriminals, compared to those with less structure who prefer starting their days late, but also working until very late hours.
label: safe

text: In fact, we only observed one instance of activity during the weekend, where a new HTML file was created.
label: safe

text: The earliest activity we tracked on the GitHub account was from August 17, 2016, with the most recent in March 12, 2017.
label: TIME

text: Here is a timeline of when the C&C server’s IP addresses were first used, based on our monitoring: Figure 6: Timeline of the C&C server’s IP addresses C&C Servers
label: safe

text: The GitHub account used by Winnti shows 12 different IP addresses, with various port numbers used for them.
label: threat-actor

text: All communication to these C&C servers are done on three different port numbers: 53 (DNS), 80 (HTTP), and 443 (HTTPS).
label: safe

text: These are typical techniques PlugX and Winnti malware variants use to communicate between compromised machines and their C&C servers.
label: malware

text: Nearly all the C&C servers are hosted in the U.S., while two are located in Japan.
label: location

text: We have privately disclosed our findings to GitHub prior to this publication and are proactively working with them about this threat.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Abusing popular platforms like GitHub enables threat actors like Winnti to maintain network persistence between compromised computers and their servers, while staying under the radar.
label: threat-actor

text: Although Winnti may still be employing traditional malware, its use of a relatively unique tactic to stay ahead of the threat landscape’s curve reflects the increased sophistication that threat actors are projected to employ.
label: threat-actor

text: Related Hashes (SHA256) detected as BKDR64_WINNTI.ONM: 06b077e31a6f339c4f3b1f61ba9a6a6ba827afe52ed5bed6a6bf56bf18a279ba — cryptbase.dll 1e63a7186886deea6c4e5c2a329eab76a60be3a65bca1ba9ed6e71f9a46b7e9d – loadperf.dll 7c37ebb96c54d5d8ea232951ccf56cb1d029facdd6b730f80ca2ad566f6c5d9b – loadoerf.ini 9d04ef8708cf030b9688bf3e8287c1790023a76374e43bd332178e212420f9fb — wbemcomn.ini b1a0d0508ee932bbf91625330d2136f33344ed70cb25f7e64be0620d32c4b9e2 — cryptbase.ini e5273b72c853f12b77a11e9c08ae6432fabbb32238ac487af2fb959a6cc26089 — wbemcomn.dll        Tags  Malware | APT & Targeted Attacks | Endpoints | Research
label: FILEPATH

text: We discovered a malware family called Maikspy — a multi-platform spyware that can steal users’ private data.
label: malware

text: The spyware targets Windows and Android users, and first posed as an adult game named after a popular U.S.-based adult film actress.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Maikspy, which is an alias that combines the name of the adult film actress and spyware, has been around since 2016.
label: malware

text: Our analysis of the latest Maikspy variants revealed that users contracted the spyware from hxxp://miakhalifagame[.]com/, a website that distributes malicious apps (including the 2016 adult game) and connects to its C&C server to upload data from infected devices and machines.
label: malware

text: Multiple Twitter handles were found promoting the adult game called Virtual Girlfriend and sharing the malicious domain via short links.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Figure 1. Tweets that mention Virtual Girlfriend and the short link of hxxp://miakhalifagame[.]com/ Maikspy on the Android platform  Figure 2.
label: URL

text: Infection chain of Maikspy Android variant
label: malware

text: Based on the analysis of samples that were last seen in the wild in March 2018, the Maikspy variant (detected by Trend Micro as AndroidOS_MaikSpy.HRX) that runs on Android poses as Virtual Girlfriend to lure users into visiting the attackers’ malicious domain.
label: malware

text: When users open the short link version of the domain shared on Twitter, a page that shows gender option buttons will appear followed by a page that will let users choose their “first girlfriend” and lead them to the download page.
label: safe

text: Virtual Girlfriend’s option buttons (first and second screen from the left) and download page (third screen)
label: safe

text: When the downloaded APK file is installed and launched, it will send the infected device’s Unix timestamp to 0046769438867, a phone number containing Sweden’s code.
label: safe

text: This is presumably used for the device’s ID registration:  Figure 4.
label: safe

text: Code snippet of the device’s Unix timestamp being sent to 0046769438867 Subsequently, the Maikspy-carrying app will display "Error: 401. App not compatible.
label: malware

text: Uninstalling
label: safe

text: as an attempt to deceive the user into thinking that the app is already removed from the device.
label: safe

text: However, the spyware just hides itself and runs in the background.
label: safe

text: There, the malicious app first checks the required permissions and then proceeds with its routine:  Steal phone number Steal accounts Steal installed app list Steal contacts Steal SMS  The stolen information will be either written into .txt or .csv formats before being uploaded to the C&C server.
label: safe

text: After fetching and uploading the abovementioned stolen data, the malicious app will check the command (CMD) from the C&C server every 60 seconds.
label: safe

text: The following are the supported commands:  CMD Details startrecording Start recording the sound around the device stoprecording Stop recording uploaddata Upload /sdcard/DCIM,/sdcard/Downloads, /sdcard/Movies, /sdcard/Pictures, /sdcard/Documents files getnumber Get and upload phone number getclipboard Get and upload clipboard contents sms- Send SMS get- Get and upload dedicated files getcontacts Get and upload Contacts getinstalledapps
label: FILEPATH

text: Get and upload installed APP list getmsgdata Get and upload received SMS getmsgdatasent Get and upload sent SMS getaccounts
label: safe

text: Get and upload Accounts tree
label: safe

text: Get and upload dedicated directory file list
label: safe

text: In the first launch of Virtual Girlfriend, the malicious app will use a combination of the Unix timestamp, the device’s Bluetooth adapter name, and the name of user’s Twitter account as device identification name: Timestamp_BTAdapterName_TwitterAccount.
label: malware

text: If the user doesn’t have the Twitter app, it will just be a null string (“”).
label: SOFTWARE

text: If the user has multiple Twitter accounts, the spyware will use the account where the user is logged in.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Code snippet of the process where the Unix timestamp, the device’s Bluetooth adapter name, and the name of user’s Twitter account are combined to produce a device identification name
label: safe

text: Additionally, the spyware will open hxxp://miakhalifagame[.]com/get_access2[.]php when first installed.
label: URL

text: It will display the page below.
label: safe

text: The spyware displays the online dating scam website upon the installation of the malicious Virtual Girlfriend app What will be shown is the registration page of an online dating site, which will lure users into giving out their credit card information.
label: safe

text: When users register, their credit cards will be charged.
label: safe

text: This happens when the data is uploaded with the hidden iframe found in the bottom right part of the page (underlined in red).
label: safe

text: As a result, the attackers behind the scheme will not only obtain the credit card information of the victim, but also steal any money charged to the credit card, so long as the user doesn’t request a chargeback.
label: safe

text: Maikspy on the Windows platform  Figure 7.
label: malware

text: Infection chain of Maikspy Windows variant  Figure 8.
label: malware

text: These buttons greeted users who clicked the Twitter short link of hxxp://miakhalifagame[.]com/
label: SOFTWARE

text: In the case of the Windows variant (WORM_INFOKEY.A) of Maikspy last seen in April 2017, the user will be tricked into downloading a MiaKhalifa.rar file, which contains the files seen in the screenshot below:
label: TIME

text: Content of the MiaKhalifa.rar file README.txt provides instructions teaching the user how to turn off the anti-virus software and how to turn on the network, which the attacker needs to steal and upload data to its C&C server.
label: FILEPATH

text: Content of README.txt register.bat is used to gain administrator privilege.
label: FILEPATH

text: Code snippet of register.bat Uninstall.exe is a copy of the open-source hacking tool Mimikatz (https://github[.]com/gentilkiwi/mimikatz).
label: FILEPATH

text: It has the ability to extract plaintext passwords, hash, PIN code, and Kerberos tickets from memory.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Here, Uninstall.exe is used to get the Windows account and password, and then writes the result to C:\Users\%username%\AppData\local\password.txt.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Setup.exe is the core module used to steal data.
label: FILEPATH

text: Like the Android Maikspy, it first sends a notification to its C&C server to register the device.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Code snippet of notification being sent to the C&C server to register the device
label: Infrastucture

text: After that, it fetches .jpg, .jpeg, .png, .txt, .wav, .html, .doc, .docx and .rtf files from the following directories: C:/Users/%username%/Desktop, C:/Users/%username%/Pictures, C:/Users/%username%/Documents, and C:/Users/%username%/Downloads.
label: FILEPATH

text: File lists of the directories are also stolen.
label: safe

text: Subsequently, it writes them into files before uploading it to the C&C server.
label: Infrastucture

text: Code snippets of the scanning, fetching, and uploading of .jpg, .jpeg, .png, .txt, .wav, .html, .doc, .docx and .rtf files (left).
label: safe

text: It also steal information about the machine’s system i.e. default browser, OS version, Firefox version, Chrome version, IE version and Network configuration (right).
label: SOFTWARE

text: We also stumbled upon a Chrome extension plugin (VirtualGirlfriend.crx) that Windows users can contract upon visiting hxxp://miakhalifagame[.]com.
label: SOFTWARE

text: When the extension plugin (BREX_INFOSTEAL.A) is downloaded, the victims will be instructed how to load it into the browser.
label: safe

text: After that, the malware will collect the username and password inputs from web pages and sends it to hxxps://miakhalifagame[.]com/testinn[.]php.
label: URL

text: Instructions given to the user on how to load the malicious Chrome extension  Figure 15.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Code snippet of the malicious extension plugin Connection between Round Year Fun and Maikspy
label: malware

text: We looked into one of the Twitter accounts (seen in Figure 1) that promoted Virtual Girlfriend.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The name of the Twitter account is Round Year Fun (hxxps://twitter[.]com/RoundYear_Fun), and its homepage is full of tweets that promote games from hxxp://www[.]roundyearfun[.]org.
label: URL

text: Twitter homepage of Round Year Fun hxxp://www[.]roundyearfun[.]org is a portal that promotes games on Twitter.
label: SOFTWARE

text: As seen in the figure below, it also has other games aside from Virtual Girlfriend.
label: malware

text: Upon checking the cached version of the page, we discovered that it was also used to distribute the adult game first used by the attackers behind Maikspy.
label: malware

text: Virtual Girlfriend in the list of games advertised by hxxp://www[.]roundyearfun[.]org  Figure 18.
label: URL

text: The adult game first used by the attackers was also found in the list of games advertised by hxxp://www[.]roundyearfun[.]org Our analysis revealed that hxxp://www[.]roundyearfun[.]org was also used as a C&C address to save victims’ data.
label: Infrastucture

text: The malware also shares the same certification with Virtual Girlfriend.
label: malware

text: One of the samples was sourced from hxxp://roundyearfun[.]org/noavi/MiaKhalifa[.]apk.
label: URL

text: Interestingly, we discovered an image that shows the logo of Round Year Fun, found at hxxp://miakhalifagame[.]com/img/ryf[.]jpg.
label: URL

text: Figure 19. Round Year Fun logo found at Maikspy’s malicious domain
label: malware

text: Based on these findings, it’s possible that the attackers behind Maikspy operate //www[.]roundyearfun[.]org/ and hxxp://miakhalifagame[.]com/.
label: malware

text: Another thing that we discovered about the games offered by Round Year Fun is that if you authorize it to use your Twitter account, the author can use the account to promote games using automation tools.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The author used the other Twitter handle in Figure 1, rifusthegr8, to tweet about Virtual Girlfriend and retweet Round Year Fun’s own Twitter promotion of the game.
label: malware

text: History of Maikspy from 2016 to 2018
label: malware

text: The first variant of Maikspy appeared on the Windows platform in December 2016.
label: malware

text: It disguised itself as the adult game named after an adult film actress.
label: safe

text: It has the ability to update itself from hxxp://fakeomegle[.]com/, and steal .jpg, .jpeg, .png, .txt, .wav, .html, .doc, .docx and .rtf files located in the Desktop, Picture, Documents, and Downloads folders, as well as information about the machine’s Internet Explorer, Chrome, Firefox or default browsers, OS, and network configuration.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The spyware connects to 107[.]180[.]46[.]243.
label: IPV4

text: Meanwhile, the first Android variant of this spyware family appeared in January 2017.
label: SOFTWARE

text: It was also under the guise of the previously mentioned adult game and still connects to the aforementioned C&C server.
label: safe

text: It was capable of recording phone calls and stealing information such as the device’s location, SMS, contacts, WhatsApp database, and record sound around the affected device.
label: SOFTWARE

text: The next variant appeared quickly, and it added the following abilities to its routines: Steal information about the device’s clipboard, phone number, installed app list, and accounts.
label: safe

text: Meanwhile, the ability to steal the WhatsApp database was removed.
label: SOFTWARE

text: It also changed its command format.
label: safe

text: In March 2017, another new variant appeared with the ability to steal photos when users take them using the camera.
label: TIME

text: The code structure and package name also changed, as well as its C&C address: 198[.]12[.]155[.]84.
label: IPV4

text: It was in April 2017 when the last Windows variant of Maikspy appeared with the following changes: The C&C server was changed to 198[.]12[.]155[.]84, password theft is added, as well as the theft of .doc, .docx, and .rtf files.
label: TIME

text: Between June and December 2017, the Android variant had the following alterations: C&C server was changed to 192[.]169[.]217[.]55, the ability to record phone calls was removed, and the C&C server was again changed to 198[.]12[.]149[.]13.
label: SOFTWARE

text: In January 2018, the Android variant’s app label changed to Virtual Girlfriend.
label: TIME

text: Two months later, the C&C server was changed to hxxp://miakhalifagame[.]com.
label: URL

text: The attackers were found using the HTTP protocol to transfer data.
label: safe

text: The ability to steal location and pictures was removed from its routine.
label: safe

text: Relationship between variants and C&C servers used by Maikspy
label: malware

text: The attackers behind Maikspy have changed domains and IP addresses over the years, but all were found hosted in a publicly traded internet domain registrar and web hosting company in the U.S.
label: malware

text: Countermeasures
label: safe

text: Downloading only from legitimate app stores like Google Play can prevent Maikspy from compromising computers and mobile devices.
label: safe

text: It is also important to be aware of what apps are allowed to access, and to understand the risks before accepting any terms or granting certain permissions to apps.
label: safe

text: Trend Micro’s Mobile App Reputation Service (MARS) already covers Android and iOS threats using leading sandbox and machine learning technology.
label: safe

text: End users and enterprises can also benefit from multilayered mobile security solutions such as Trend Micro™ Mobile Security for Android™ which is also available on Google Play.
label: safe

text: For organizations, Trend Micro™ Mobile Security for Enterprise provides device, compliance and application management, data protection, and configuration provisioning, as well as protects devices from attacks that leverage vulnerabilities, preventing unauthorized access to apps, as well as detecting and blocking malware and fraudulent websites.
label: safe

text: The Trend Micro™ Deep Discovery™ threat protection platform enables companies to detect, analyze, and respond to modern threats such as sophisticated malware, targeted attacks, and APTs.
label: safe

text: Trend Micro™ Smart Protection for Endpoints with Maximum XGen™ security infuses high-fidelity machine learning into a blend of threat protection techniques to eliminate security gaps across user activity and any endpoint—the broadest possible protection against advanced attacks. text: Real enterprises are messy places.
label: safe

text: One messy reality is that enterprises don’t manage all their endpoints.
label: safe

text: A smart colleague turned me onto using the % of endpoints and servers managed as a prime security metric.
label: safe

text: On one end of the spectrum are places like universities that maybe manage 10% of the endpoints on their network.
label: safe

text: On the other end are places like some large banking and R&D companies that can manage about 98 or 99%.
label: safe

text: A financial services company that was spending millions of dollars on getting from 96% to achieving 98%, using the very good reasoning that they were “cutting their biggest security problem in half” rather than “2%, meh.” So even the very best enterprises can have unmanaged endpoints that can be more easily exploited than ones with a security agent deployed on them.
label: safe

text: A lot of the advanced security we’ve been delivering on the last few years has been focused on this problem.
label: safe

text: EDR is an example of how stealthy or evasive attackers can be better uncovered than with traditional endpoint protection.
label: safe

text: EDR is great for endpoints they are on.
label: safe

text: Ian Loe of NTUC gives a killer example of uncovering stealthy attacks using EDR and MDR here.
label: safe

text: But most of EDR’s capabilities are for endpoints they are on: ones they manage.
label: safe

text: Sure there’s some herd-immunity with EDR that the greater number of managed endpoints the harder it is for an attacker to move laterally or deeper.
label: safe

text: But more capable, patient, and stealthy attackers are getting better at being evasive, knowing that EDR may be or is deployed.
label: safe

text: Mark Nunnikhoven does a great job in this post talking about lateral movement.
label: identity

text: EDR can only go so far on its own to help spot attacks that are exceptionally low and slow, and/or using unmanaged endpoints.
label: safe

text: Endpoint security needs to step outside the endpoint silo to keep step with advanced attackers.
label: safe

text: An attack using many hops could see movement between managed endpoints, IoT, email, network components, containers and cloud-based servers over the course of many months.
label: safe

text: The delivery and reconnaissance could involve multiple protocols, emails, payloads, files, and credentials.
label: safe

text: Pulling together the tenuous and ephemeral threads of such an intentional attack needs more modern tools, rather than hoping we stumble on a supply of highly advanced threat hunters.
label: safe

text: Pulling together deep security information from across your enterprise is what is needed to face off against such advanced and intentionally evasive attacks.
label: safe

text: XDR is intended to be that security data lake of deeper enterprise infrastructure and security information than we’ve previously gathered in a single addressable pool and designed to be useful for threat hunters and analysts.
label: SOFTWARE

text: In these posts here and here we talk about what XDR is and how it brings in more sources, such as network data.
label: SOFTWARE

text: In the game of measure-countermeasure that is cybersecurity today and tomorrow, XDR is the next evolutionary step in dealing with more evasive threats.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Malicious actors, once in an organization’s network, will need to move beyond their initial infection location to other parts of the network, seeking out areas that hold the data or critical systems they wish to utilize.
label: safe

text: Whether that is the data center, an OT network, or finding critical business systems to support their criminal or destructive intent.
label: safe

text: There are a number of ways lateral movement is performed, but the key is to hide and remove evidence of their presence.
label: safe

text: Initially they will look to scan the internal network using similar scanning tools used by admins to identify what systems are available to them.
label: safe

text: Hacking tools and keyloggers will be used to steal user accounts and passwords to obtain legitimate user credentials within systems.
label: safe

text: More tools will typically be downloaded using the command & control infrastructure to help with their attack.
label: safe

text: After obtaining more powerful user accounts, the attacker can laterally move to other systems and use “normal” tools to perform other activities.
label: safe

text: These activities may be difficult to identify for defenders due to the use of these things like:     PSEXEC to execute a program from remote system Schedule a remote task to execute back door or malicious code RDP or net use to connect to other hosts
label: SOFTWARE

text: Leverage WMI for fileless intrusion Execute Powershell script for fileless intrusion
label: attack-pattern

text: Utilize exploits targeting unpatched systems for known vulnerabilities Execute normal tool like Bitlocker, to encrypt customer data like ransomware did.
label: tools

text: But normal tools will not detect by antivirus system.
label: SOFTWARE

text: This is where adding network intelligence to an XDR and correlating with other intelligence from different areas of the network can be most beneficial.
label: SOFTWARE

text: An XDR that supports advanced detection capabilities can identify correlate data across areas to identify events that would otherwise go unnoticed.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Additionally, in many attacks the malicious actors are removing their tracks once finished with that area, so having the ability to capture and keep intelligence can help with root cause analysis and correlate the different disparate components of an attack.
label: safe

text: This correlation allows an organization to put the pieces of the attack puzzle together to see the full picture.
label: safe

text: Some recent RYUK ransomware attacks are a good example.
label: malware

text: In these attacks, attackers utilized the Eternal Blue exploit and harvested credentials as they moved across the environment, and then used existing system tools to kill security services within machines to hide their presence.
label: vulnerability

text: In both cases the intelligence coming from endpoints, servers, and the network allowed researchers to identify the attack chain and all the components used within the attack.
label: safe

text: Most attacks today, including ransomware, are utilizing lateral movement.
label: safe

text: Including detection of this as part of an overall XDR platform will improve the prevention, detection, and remediation of sophisticated attacks on an organization.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Stay tuned for more upcoming blogs on how XDR will help improve our overall security strategy moving forward.
label: SOFTWARE

text: Tags  Cloud | APT & Targeted Attacks | Cyber Crime | Expert Perspective | Cyber Threats
